reviews.review: The Chora !. A beautiful church from Byzantine with marvelous mosaics. But %30 of the museum is under renovation now. Be aware with that !

It is still under renovation but beautiful Mosaics. First time I visited Kariye Museum. It is a bit out of main touristic area. Mosaics in the museum was beautiful. There are both Mosaic and fresco walls and ceilings. The Naos section of the museum currently closed and under renovation. But even the remaining parts are breathtaking.

Beautiful & interesting mosaics, but museum is partially closed.. We took the tram and metro lines to reach this museum. Unfortunately the building is under renovation and more than half of it is closed. We were aware of this before we started, but decided to see it anyway. The major portion of the mosaics are in the closed section and we were disappointed that we could not see the most attractive part of the museum. We felt that the entrance fee should have been reduced in view of the reduction in the area available to view, however the full price was charged.

Amazing mosaics but under repair. One of the places I was most excited about seeing in Istanbul was Chora Church. I left feeling a massively frustrated as the entire building was under canvas tents and the main rooms of the church were closed to visitors due to repairs. The mosaics that we could see were stunning, true works of art, but we picked the wrong time I guess. What should have been a 1 hour visit ended in less than 10. We purchased museum passes from Hagia Sophia and the staff never mentioned any repair work and limited access to Chora. I will return and hopefully give a more positive review.

Mosaic- laden church. A gem of Byzantine art is currently undergoing restorations. Still it is worth a visit without hustle and bustle of main Sultanahmet area. All the mosaics date back to early 14th century and are truly striking in their beauty. Getting there might be an issue if travelling on your own. Taking ferry, then walking alongside the historical city walls most probably is the easiest option.
The Chora Church. The Chora Church is a Christians history that cannot be missed if you are in Istanbul, great paintings and architecture!

Masterpiece style interiors. Masterpiece style interiors. Fascinating stories attached to each of the creations. Most of this church is currently under wraps being restored. Entry fee applicable. Credit cards accepted.

Fascinating . Masterpiece style interiors. Fascinating stories attached to each of the creations. Most of this church is currently under wraps being restored. Entry fee applicable. Credit cards accepted.

An Amazing Byzantine Church!. If you like the mosaics of Hagia Sophia, you will be mesmerised by what this little church has to offer. The church has the most beautiful and intact mosaics your would ever see. With the museum pass, the entrance is free but please spend a little extra on the audio guide as that makes the tour much more exciting and informative.When we visited a part of the church was closed for restoration but it still left us breathless when we first entered it. The church is a little out of the central city so we had to take the tram and the metro and then walk for about 10 mins to get to it. On our way back we walked Downhill for 15-20 minutes to the ferry stop Ayvansaray (using a GPS app on the cell phone) and took public ferry through the golden horn back to Eminönü. The whole trip was worth it. Highly recommended for history buffs.

A must visit. A bit out of the way but easily accessible by tramMake the effort and you will not be disappointedSome of the best mosaics and frescoes I have ever seen and they're 1500 years old. Amazing

Captivating Mosaics. Although the Chora Church is under restoration and out of the way, our group was glad that we included it in our itinerary. Its a must see. You can see that the presentation of the mosaics are beautifully and painstakingly done to depict the life of the Blessed Virgin Mary and her son Jesus. Would be happy to return when its fully restored to its glory.

Magnıficent mosaics. One of the best museums in Istanbul. Even the outside of the building is on restoration, when you enter the museums you just captivated by the mosaics, parekklesion and fresks. You can have an audio tour also. There is small shop inside for the small soveniers. After the visit, you can have lunch in Asitane Restaurant with a good glass of wine...It will be worth it.

Must see . This is simply one of the best churches is Istanbul. Built outside the city (that's the meaning of "Chora"), for the Cristian people. It's full of mosaics, all very well preserved. They tell stories, and that's why they are all over the place, so that people who couldn't read would know the stories of Jesus and the church. The entrance fee is 20 liras (8 dollars). Amazing place.

quite a lot under restoration . Took ages to find and it was mainly being restored so can't really say to much as I saw very little. it was OK it is quite far out but if your in the area and have a museum pass you may as well visit.
Definitely worth visiting.... It is very recommended to get an audio guide to understand the connection and significance of the various mosaics.
Amazing place. Original was built on 4th century and rebuilt on 12th century. The outside is being renovated but inside is amazing.
bad. while we visited there it was under construction but no one told us . we payed 20 $ but the only thing we visited was a door
Wonderful!. This is a must see sightseeing. The paintings and mosaics are absolutely beautiful. We took a tour with a guide and we truly enjoyed the experience.

One of the secret treasures of Istanbul. Kariye doesn't get as many visitors as some of the other more famous attractions, mainly because it's not walking distance from the rest of them. But it is well worth a visit. The main cupola has been under renovation for the last 18 months but the different naves of the church are still amazing. They do a great job of lighting it and there's a nice giftshop with some good books. A few nice cafes around it to. If you take a taxi, say Kariye (KAH-ree-ye) as they may not know the 'Chora' name.

hidden treasure. this is simply stunning. no matter what your religious beliefs and whether you have them or not you cannot fail to be stunned by the mosaics in this Church - they are beyond amazing. it takes something very special to make my jaw drop but it happened here. Make this one of your MUST sees in Istanbul beyond every expectatoin

Visit here first then take on Hagia Sophia.. This was one of my most enjoyable of Istanbul’s sites I visited. - This church is a perfect example of the greatness of the Byzantine period. The mosaics and frescos of that church are really something a traveller must see. Ticket price was same as Hagia Sophia which expensive considering the Church is tiny in comparison. Covered scaffolding around most of the outside prevented any view of the outer building itself. That said, the scale of fresco restoration work and low number of tourist, made this place one of my Top 5 places in Istanbul.

Historical gem. Absolutely stunning Byzantine mosaics. A most visit when you visit Istanbul. If you are interested in history and visiting slightly off the main tourist route sites. Chora Church is breathtaking. Only a short taxi from anywhere within the metro area. It's close to the medieval walls of the city which is an added bonus.

Mesmerizing mosaics and frescos. We could've spent day after day here; the array of gorgeous iconography is startling and you can feel the deep reverence for the mystery of creation in its preservation. The range of color and sheen leaves every visitor breathing differently...

beautiful mosaics. The mosaics are well preserved and very beautiful. Faces have such real expressions for this kind of work, very impressive. The frescos as well are worth seeing. Easy to get to by public transport and a nice little tea shop across the road to realax in afterwards. Renovation going on which covers the outside and cuts off one of the rooms but I think we saw the best of it.

An amazing memory... A lovely place to visit, we've been here 4 years ago and it was an amazing experience.It's a little out of town, but worth the visit. We will definitely come back when another time.
Beautiful! Well worth the time to get there.. It is a bit out of the way of the other sights in Instanbul but well-worth the effort. Lovely mosaics.

Incredible Byzantine mosaics. I'm a bit of a history/architecture/archaeology geek bit I've never seen such amazingly detailed mosaics. Truly awe inspiring. Be warned though... most of the church is currently closed for restoration so you can only see about 1/3 of it.

Great frescos and mosaics. This church is a perfect example of the greatness of the byzantine period . The mosaics of that church are really something a traveller must see. We were very disappointed when we found out that the main church was closed for restauration and we could see the mosaics only from faded photosoutside the building. Still the ticket we paid was very expensive (the same price as agia sofia-30tl). What made us a very bad empression was that the premier price on the ticket was 15 tl and in second time they putted a sticker on it with the double price. Still the church is very nice to visit.

Don't miss it!. You don't have to be religious to appreciate the mosaics and frescos. Just gorgeous and a must-see for art appreciators and history-lovers! I've been there twice. I'm afraid an earthquake will destroy this at some point...
a hidden treasure. I just discovered by luck. you will see unique frescos and the scene of genesis. its history goes back to 6th century.

Byzantine treasure. Worth the detour. . Often overlooked in Istanbul, but boy what a treasure of Byzantine mosaics and frescos. It challenges anything you can see in Ravenna. We came I. The morning and had the church to ourselves on the way to the airport. One of the best stopovers ever.

It's not the time now. My visit was on 23/8/2016
Place closed the visit doesn't Worth the 30 TL fee entry unless you can enter with other method
Wait. Wait until they finish restoration. Currently the long trip is not worth the 10 minutes you'll spend inside the church.

The 'real' Byzantium. The Kariye Museum is under refurbishment at present and it is a bit out of town. It is still absolutely worth it. The mosaics are so intense and rival only Ravenna for their beuty and sophistication. The advantage of Kariye is that the mosaics are up close and intimate and after the Hagia Sophia, the best place to image how rich and beautiful Byzantium must have been 650 years ago

Kariye museum still under restoration. This is an interesting church with the most exquisite Byzantine mosaics. However, be aware that the nave of this former church has been under restoration for a few years, so you only can see the mosaics in the outer narthexes. In this case the 30 lire charge is expensive when compared to other major sites such as Aya Sofia and Topkapi Palace.

Gorgeous historical mosaics. Spectacular mosaics with detailed depictions of Christian scenes. We were there with our wonderful private guide, Viktor so we had wonderful explanations. Would make sure there is a way to get the information when visit.

Most beautifull Mosaic Panels..... Chora name became a name of a style in mosaic Decoration world. That shows how nice mosaic panels you can see at Chora. Quite small church whic later converted in to a mosque with Ottomans. But lots of well preserved Mosaic panels where you can see life of Virgin Mary and life of Jesus Chris

Extraordinary mosaics! . Chora church was built before 3rd version of Hagia Sofia and has some of the best mosaics in the world!This is more important to visit than Blue Mosque!Make sure you get the audio guide or have a pictorial guide on the meaning behind these beautiful mosaics.The church/museum is undergoing restoration and the main section was closed however the priceless mosaics and frescos of most note are in the adjoining corridors.Taxi will take about 10 to 15 minutes from main areas and cost about 20 TLThere is a cafe out front to dwell on what you have seen.Get the Museum card to save on entrance fee for this and other major museums

disapointed. Church under refurbishement.Price to visit this church just went from 15TL to 30TL.There is no information at all so you have to take audio guide or guide (add minimum 30TL).Inside is very small but looks very interesting.Very nice mosaique and paintings

Marvelaous mosaics. Although it is not in the main route of touristic peninsula of Istanbul, Kariye Museum is one of the most beautiful places. It's Bysantium mosaics are very peculiar and impressive. Even you don't have special interest on mosaics, when you see them you'll be fascinated.

Visions of Byzantium. I felt overwhelmed by the beauty, the richness, the incredible mosaics are simply heart breathing… in my humble opinion should be a UNESCO Heritage site.
The greatness of the Byzantine art at its best. DO yourself a favour and visit it

Just finding this Museum was an adventure. Stayed in the Galata area, so took a ferry across the Golden Horn, then walked to the Chora Church. Followed an ancient wall of the city. When arriving at the Church, it was encased in scaffolding, but still open. Wonderful mosaics. Good cafe across the street.

Treasure from the past. Actually it's been 7 years since I've been here but what a memory. My husband is the history person but the beautiful mosaic treasures here told stories from centuries ago. Would love to go back to Istanbul when peace returns.

Beautiful Mosaics. This museum has beautiful mosaics. We used Rick Steves' Istanbul guide to explain the meaning of the mosaics. They were even prettier than the ones at Hagia Sophia. We used the city bus to get there and took a taxi back to the New district. It cost under 10 dollars. The Chora Church is included on the 5 day museum pass.

A beautiful church with wonderful Byzantine paintings. Unfortunately part is under restoration, but what is open to the public is very nice and worth seeing. It is one of the oldest and preserved collections of Byzantine art in the world. It's a bit expensive (30 TL), but is free with Museum Pass

Stunning mosaics and frescoes. This place is a chore to get to by public transport so we took the scenic route and got the ferry to Ayvansaray, then walked up the hill with the aid of a GPS. The exterior is covered and the interior chapel is off limits, and the admission has gone up to 30TL. But we felt it was well worth the effort of getting there and didn't have the crowds of Hagia Sophia. We read up about it before going so that we knew what we were looking at and what to look out for. Would have got a 5 if not for renovations.

Well kept church . We have visited it after we have seen all the important sites in Istanbul. It is a Christian church and unlike Hagia Sophia, it did not have Islamic influence. The most important things to see here are the illustrations on the walls. If you don't have a guide, read about them before going there. We were shocked seeing a very obvious racism in one of the Illustrations.
Interesting - But renovations happening. A really unique church however the outside was covered in scaffolding due to renovations. The art inside is not what I was expecting. A beautiful place

Beautiful Old Byzantine church. An extremely old Byzantine church in Fatih district of Istanbul.Not very large a building, but well worth a visit to see exquisite paintings and tile mosaics.Best to read up a bit on the Internet before visiting so know which bits of special interest to look for. As of April 2016, half the church is closed for preservation which really restricts viewing the mosaics and painting but still worth a visit.

Construction Beware!. The church was under a large amount of construction when I visited and the outside was completely covered, a long with some of the rooms. However the entrance was still full price!It was also quite hard to find, even for my Istanbulite friend. Unless you are very enthusiastic about seeing every single old church and mosaic of Jesus, skip this one.

Amazing place, unfortunately under repair. Unbelievable mosaics, nice place to visit.
Unfortunately the main part of the church is closed for restoration.
Check that it is opened or you will be partially disappointed.

Amazing. Tucked away in a quiet neighborhood, this church astonished me. The gold murals are well worth the trip. I never thought much of Christian history until I stepped into this Church and felt a thousand years disappear. Of course, it helped that we had the place to ourselves and a private guide who drove us there.

Well worth a visit.. Off the beaten track and surrounding area not so appealing but a gem buried and well worth a visit.Surrounding area worth a wander round but tricky to walk from from standard tourist areas- worth a short taxi fare.

Limited by renovation work. The outside is shrouded in scaffolding and it's cover.Inside, the main area is closed off. That said, the mosaic work is wonderful and still worth the visit. We used the audio guide, which we found very good. The layers of history you find out about are fascinating. The mosaics are exquisite and tell the story of Mary and Jesus life, including things I had not known.Renovation has to happen, just a shame it was now. Perhaps more could have been done to show the closed area in photos.

See mosaics here and than imagine.... This is a place where large peaces of mosaics on walls and ceiling are visible. By looking at it one can try to imagine how spectacular Hagia Sophia was in its glory days. Just multiply that,with a gold background and paste it on spectacular interior.Great example of Byzantine art.

Spellbound by the mosaics!. We took a taxi to the Chora Church (not walking distance from Sultan Ahmet square). The church mosaics are beautiful with some very interesting depictions. I was astonished by the the colours and detail captured in the mosaics - many are beautifully preserved/restored ! Unfortunately the church is being renovated and some major parts cannot be seen (otherwise I'd give it a 5 star rating!) but the audio guide describes these so that you don't feel that you fully miss out. I think it is well worth a visit despite the renovation works and I would love to return when the work is finally completed.
Chora Museum. If you have time do not forget to visit Chora Museum. Tram or Metro does not go to there so take a bus from Eminonu to Ebirnekapu Charming Museum.

Pearl of Istanbul. It was worth to see the best masterpiece of the Byzantine heritage in Istanbul. The frescoes are better preserved than in Hagia Sofia. My tour guide Akin Güzel gave me the detailed description of each scene depicted on the walls. I was impressed!
Roman art. it iwas like reading holy bible there,it is another roman miracle that came to life with those epic mosaics which were so out of this world

Spectacular, my favorite thing in Istanbul. This beautiful little church knocked me flat. Small, tranquil, in a quite little neighborhood you have to walk a bit to get to...and stunningly beautiful. The wall paintings were breathtaking. The Chora Church is quite small, and the center portion of the interior is closed for restoration right now, but you still get to see plenty. The exterior is also scaffolded right now (April 2016)---but again, there is lots to see inside and it left me speechless. My husband and I walked all around maybe 3 times and I could have done it 3 more. Right outside is a little cafe where we had some tea and took a break in the shade. If I lived in Istanbul I would visit the Chora Church constantly.We took the tram to get there. Once you get off you have about a 20 minute walk through some kind of interesting neighborhoods. If you like a bit of adventure and wandering this one is definitely a must see. It's 15 Turkish lire to get in, but it's free if you have the Museum Card. Hours: 9-7 daily but CLOSED WEDNESDAY.
Spectacular mosaics, tricky to find. Well worth the hunt to find this ancient church with spectacular mosaics. Currently being renovated, but still worth a look.

Small, out of the way, but worth it. This small church is way worth the effort to find your way there. Great connection between the Byzantine and Ottoman periods. We loved our immersion in Islamic culture and history but your trip to Istanbul really won't be complete unless you make those connections. Beautiful Byzantine mosaics of New Testament stories.

Not to be missed.. Many tours, tourists miss this because it is a little off the beaten path, but not really. Don't miss it. Walk to it, public transportation is always great and crowded. Many English speakers and students anxious to help. Don't fall for the let me get you a map, follow me routine or you will end up in a rug shop... unless you are looking for a rug. This place is a hidden gem... well known, but Blue Mosque and Aya Sofya get all the attention, and are worth the time spent there as well. Research online and you will see why it is not to be missed.
Amazing!. Incredible mosaics and frescoes. Inner nave currently being restored and closed to the public, but the vast majority of the artwork is still accessible.

Beautiful small church. It's a little out of the way this church, but so worth making the effort to visit. While there are renovations happening, you can see the main frescoes and mosaics. They are beautiful. I'm not religious but that didn't stop me from being moved by the art. Tourist numbers are low so make the most of the opportunity. It wouldn't be the same with hundreds of people sharing it with you.

What a rort. I was charged 30 Turkish lire to see this 3 room church after a hill climb & so hard to find. Disgusted! In the middle of nowhere if you are not into Christian frescoes obsessively give a BIG MISS - 20 lire to see the Dolmebaci Palace w 2 tours. Think again. Review this place badly to get them to see sense please.

Disappointing . I visited this church recently and it is being renovated so only smaller amount is on display and the rest is closed off. It was quite hard to get to and find it not fully open was extremely disappointing

Restoration limits exploration. Apparently in 3rd or 4th year of what was to be a one year restoration. The mosaics in the corridors outside the church are available to view but not the church itself or the outside structure. Guy in the gift shop follows you around and limits your time to less than a minute for looking at the gift books.

Full of History...but still under restoration. This place is a gem hidden in a increasingly gentrifying neighborhood,. so it's definitely worth the trip and getting lost on the winding streets. Walk around and enjoy the sights of a very typical Turkish neighborhood. You will even see many kids playing games on the street, which is a sight we don't see much nowadays.Back to the church- it's beautiful, but it's still under restoration, so you don;t see the most important part. Nobody knows when it will reopen...
Spectcular!!. Fabulous, unique mosaics. Under renovation so only half are accessible, but wonderful and inspiring.
Needs restoration. It is out of the way, and takes some time to get to this destination. Signage is poor. There was a large area closed for restoration, and many of the mosaics are quite damaged.

Breathtaking . The mosaics and frescoes are breathtaking. You need either a guide (I had my Lonely Planet guide) or a good knowledge of the Gospels to fully appreciate it. It is worthy to stand and look at the details of the mosaics. Nothing to rush through. Pity that the main room was closed. It is easily accessible by ship or tram. I was passing by looking at the city walls which do not get the attention they deserve.
Amazing.👏🏻. İt's really amazing place. But so many area is close because they make restarotion. You can just see small area. Entrance is 15 liras. It will finish at 2017. (Maybe)

Worth a visit even when being renovated. Like many attractions in Istanbul right now (mid 2016) the Chora church is being renovated and maybe half of it wasn't accessible when I visited.But its still worth going to - its magnificent, and being off the tourist trail, there was only 1 other person there when I went.Very beautiful mosaics and frescos. When its fully open again, it will be fantastic.

Under reconstruction as of May 2016. And even though it was out of the way and most of it was being refurbished, I still loved seeing the mosaics. There is a listening tour your you can rent, if you like.

Lovely Mosaic Tiles art for Bible accounts of Mary & Jesus's life.. The details of Mary & Jesus's life story through the Mosaic Tiles art was fantastic!Unfortunately, there were a major renovation going on. Not able to see the external of the Church as well as the inner area.There are some souvenir shops & eateries available on the street lane towards the church.

Interesting mosaics. My wife and I visited the Chora Church. For 25TL apiece, they let us see the outer hall. The inside was closed for repair. The church was shrouded for repair. it was surprising that prices were not reduced due to very restricted access.
Great church to amaze. Avoid to visit until further notice, it has very limited access, not worth the effort, but combine with visiting the city wall.

Major repairs but I still loved it . We caught a taxi from the Hagia Sophia to here - we paid 20 lire - I didn't bargain as it was raining and there was 3 of us. This museum is undergoing some very big renovations and most of it was closed when we went. However what we saw was well worth it. As far as value for money goes - we had a museum pass so I wasn't worried about the cost. So long as you are aware that most it is closed so not to be too disappointed I think it is a beautiful church. Can't wait to go back when it's all completed.
Chora Church mosaics. Amazingly well-preserved mosaics. Nice to see the story of Mary's life told in tiles as well. Unfortunately the main part of the church was closed for renovation.
Another must see.. What a beautiful old church. The story of Mary done in the finest mosaic,beautifully restored. A guide helps to explain the story.
Renovation. They were at the moment renovating the church so it was basically packed and we didn't see much of it = shame

Worth a visit. It's one of the few cristian church in Istanbul and the mosaics and paintings are beautiful, even if some are not in the best shape. The story behind it is worth a visit, and it is situated on the Asian side of the city (by opposition to Sultanamet which is on the European side), with a different feel to the city. If you have time definitely make the effort of having a look.

LESS KNOWN THAN THE BIG MOSQUES BUT A FIVE STARS CULTURAL SITE. A medieval Byzantine Greek orthodox church converted into a mosque (as all antique churches in Turkey) and after that in a museum. The interior has beautiful mosaics and due to the prohibition against iconic images in Islam, some mosaics and frescoes have been covered behind a layer of plaster. The church/mosque/museum is passing through a restoration process.

Magnificent mosaics. We spent more than an hour admiring the superb mosaics in this church. The mosaics depict biblical stories, important in a time when most people were illiterate. The mosaics are as good as anything in Istanbul and certainly on par with the mosaics in Ravenna.Be sure to take a guidebook or explanation of the mosaics with you so you can fully appreciate the masterful art you'll see on the walls and ceiling.This ancient cuhrch is a must for any visit to Istanbul.

Only 1/3 of it was opened!. When we went May 14, the whole placed was covered in tarp cause they were doing restoration work. We couldn't really see the outside of the building. When we went inside, only 1/3 of the place was opened. We had a museum pass, I felt sorry for the people who paid full price to go see it because they didn't even tell us only 1/3 is opened. Also the place is not easy to get to if you are taking the transit to get there. Quite a hike after you get off the metro. And there was no signage to point you to the right direction either. That being said, i feel like the church is actually worth a visit once the construction is done. Because just the 1/3 of it that was opened was amazing. The mosaic work is beautiful and very well preserved. I am sure the inside of the church must be even better! And go get a museum pass! If you just go to 3 of those museums, it is already well worth it! When we got it, it's 85lira good for 5 days.

Some of the most impressive mosaics I've ever seen!. An area was closed for restoration, but the available mosaics and frescoes make it well worth the price of admission. They have been better preserved than many and clearly stem from an era when "the story" was told in pictures because the populus was illiterate, not simply unknown faces standing in a row.

This Gem does not have the Typical Christian Art. The Chora Church, built in the 6th century, was a surprise. I had not expected the 13th Century Byzantine mosaics to be in such good condition and SO different. Instead of the typical New Testament art work, it showed Mary in birth. Jesus growing up. And a less adoring congregation around a more earthly grounded adult Jesus. It's worth the taxi ride to the Edirnekapi neighborhood. Do it in the morning then walk back to Sultanahmet via the Fethiye Museum and Patriarchal Church of St George.

Mosaic Masterpieces!. "Chora" literally means "out in the country". Chora, the Kariye Museum is absolutely worth the trip out to see it. Outside of Ravenna, Italy, these are the most magnificent mosaics you would ever see. It really is awesome to see these radiant works, in this setting.
This takes the cake . It may not be big but the fresco and mosaics inside has to be the best that i have ever seen in Istanbul. You will not be disappointed.

Great Byzantine monument at Istanbul. This was our last place to visit at Istanbul before dinner at the famous Asitane Ottoman restaurant next door. It is a mosaic and fresco laden church telling the lives of Jesus and the Virgin Mary. We could only see three rooms and the rest are being renovated or restored. This will take many years. Most of the paintings and mosaics have been destroyed when it was converted into a mosque years ago.A must see for visitors to Istanbul

12.th century church. Originally it was a church built in the 12 century. Today this is a museum, with a collection of excellent tiles. A little bit far from downtown, but it is definitely worth to visit.

Closed for repairs - May 2016. I'm sure this is a very beautiful place, but only a tiny part of it is open, and the rest is closed for repairs and refurbishing. Don't bother going there until it is open again.

Important for christians - Historic Importance. Slightly far away from the old city, but a must go for Christians. They can see mentions of history about Jesus, Virgin Mary and the myth and the story which can be depicted in the church. It normally takes a maximum time of 1 hour. There was some renovation going on and some parts were closed for that.

If you go to Kariye, go to the Pages Bookstore next door and have a meal in the court yard too.. This is not in the center of town, but it is well worth the trip to enjoy the best unblemished artwork, also Saturday night live music at Pages and a good meal in the courtyard of the church. Wonderful night that few of your friends who have visited Istanbul will know about. You will feel like a local!

Amazing mosaics. Since I saw my first mosaic 20 years ago, I wanted to see more. We had the privilege of an amazing visit to the Chora church in Istanbul. The visit allowed us to see the story of Christianity from the gospel of James which is seldom known.The mosaics were spectacularly restored. It took two hours to see the lovely mosaics. We were the only guests (because of tourists fear of travel in turkey which we found found less)As an aside we visited the only shop there and purchased several ceramics done exclusively for this shop.

Best Religious Mosaics in Istanbul. It is a hidden gem in which you will have to walk a considerable way from public transportation or take a cab to reach but it well worth it. There are over 20 religious mosaics of the byzantine era including the Virgin Mary. You can do a quick tour in about 15 minutes or spend over an hour like we did to study and admire each mosaic. Very well preserved but they are scheduled to do some restoration soon. There is an adjacent cafe where you can enjoy some nonalcoholic beverages after you visit. Admission is part of the Museum Pass which I highly recommend buying if you plan to visit 3 or more museums.

Visit with a guide . This relic of a church is spellbinding with it's mosaics. We were lucky to be with a well informed guide as there is a ton of history with a story of the life of Virgin Mary which needs to have every mosaic explained to appreciate the significance. A particular must if you have any religious interest.

Don't miss this. Very historical. We had a tour guide and he really knew the history of this church. The biblical stories of Mary's early life was very interesting. I had never heard it. The tile work is amazing as is the very old architecture.

Renovations!. Going by the brochures and many books I've seen this is a must visit - but not till the work is completed as the best bits are not on view. Very disappointed with the visit as information on what could and could not be seen was very vague at the ticket counter. An so the entrance fee in its current repair state is unfair and a rip off. AThe person at the ticket booth just shrugged her shoulders when we expressed this and requests to speak with a manager/person in charge were met with " he's on his break" (11am).

High quality mosaics showing bible scenes very clearly. The quality and content of the mosaics and frescoes in this church are overwhelming. When I went one part was inaccessible because of restoration, but it was still worth the trip.

Definitely worth the trouble to get to. Our big destination today was the Çora Church Museum, a presumably de-sanctified 12th Century Byzantine church a few blocks down winding cobbled lanes from one of the gates in the old city walls. The tram trip took about an hour, what with one change of tram lines; but the trip itself was interesting, in terms of street life and people-watching. We got a fine, long view of the old crenellated fortifications. The church would have been worth the trip, even if the latter hadn’t been interesting. Although the sacristy was closed for renovation, the domed side chapels and arched corridors were rich in mosaics and painted frescoes. One entire section seemed devoted to the life of Mary, including her death. Another depicted various apostles and saints important to Orthodox Christians. A particularly fine mural showed Christ raising the just from the dead on the Day of Judgment. To one side, wealthy sinners appeared to be trying to sneak off under a red and gold canopy. Many of the paintings and mosaics were only partial, and some of the faces had been defaced. Nonetheless, the combined effect of these 13th and 14th Century works was inspiring, historically, aesthetically and spiritually.

Note: Major Portion Under Renovation--May Consider Waiting. We had read about the Chora and really wanted to see the ancient mosaics. Nothing on their web site informed us about the major renovations happening. The Chora is a decent taxi ride away from the Sultanahmet area--and the trams/subways do not go to that area as it is just outside of the periphery of old Istanbul. We hopped in a cab, paid about $20 US for the ride out. We got to the Church only to see it surrounded by signage detailing the multi-stage renovations happening. We went in and then only were able to see the outer areas of the church-- as the major portion was under renovation. This was really disappointing. We spent about 20 minutes taking photos of the few mosaics that we could see and wishing we could get inside to see many more. We walked around the building and didn't see anything else--more residential neighborhood than anything. It took a while to get a cab to take us back. Spending about 1/2 hour and $40 US in a cab was not worth the trip. Check to see if renovations are still underway before making the trip out there. They do accept the Istanbul Museum Card: I'm not sure what the cost would be for regular admission.
out of the way but worth it. tucked into an old neighborhood...the nave is currently being renovated but the remaining art is extraordinary

Amazing vibrant colors on murals throughout.. The church is under renovation in stages, so there is always some section closed for that work. What we saw was rather amazing, with colors you could easily believe are only a few decades old, rather than the 1500 years they actually are.The lighting is poor for overall photography. However, zoom in on details, and you will see how the lighting actually reinforces the glow of the halos on many of the images, and strengthens the image result.

Best mosaics I have ever seen!. Well, I could honestly give Chora Church a "Beyond Excellent" rating if TripAdvisor had it. These are, without doubt, the best mosaics I have ever seen. Chora Church is a bit out of town, but the tram ride is worth the effort. And it's interesting to see the outskirts of Istanbul at the same time. Even though they are from about the 10th century (just try wrapping your head around that!), the mosaics and frescoes are still rich in color. The mosaics absolutely glitter. Some are complete scenes from the life of Christ, others have patches where the mosaics have fallen away. There are people available to provide tours, it's a great idea. They can explain all the scenes you will see. The artwork of both the mosaics and frescoes is exceptional, they do not have a flat look at all, which is amazing considering their age. We were there on a weekday in April, and were two of about only 20 people in the church. If you have the opportunity, go see these mosaics. You will never regret it.
Almost overwhelming! . Almost overwhelming! I was excpected some paintings on the wall. But when i entered the church, i saw that everywhere was full with iconas!
A waste of money. Half of the church is not even accessible. Very confusing to find. The only cool part was the wall of Constantinople.
Chora. Amazing mosaics and a must see while in Istanbul. There is a lot of renovation which am told will last 2 more years, but still, there is a lot to see.
Out of the way, but worth it. You will go here for the moaics and they are amazing but also walk the ancient city walls near here for some amazing views.

Mosaics. Mosaics in good shape, covering the inner side of domes with beautiful color combinations. The inner part of the church was sealed off (restoration) with no idea until when. Despite that we were charged the full entry fee of 30TL (over priced)

Beautiful mosaics. I have seen in Istanbul were in this church.Unfortunately part of it was closed for renovation, but it was still well worth the visit.it is Very beautiful but extremely small. The area that's open for visitors are two narrow halls, and the actual church is closed. It's still worth the visit.

under renovation, still full price. thankfully this place was included in the museum pass, otherwise i would have felt extremely ripped off as they charged full price admissions but over half the church was closed due to renovation. the parts that were still open were amazing to see, and it is very pretty inside

Wait for the renovation to be complete. It's a fascinating sight, but it's a long way off the normal tourist-beaten path and is mostly closed for a multi-year renovation. As of April 2016, only two hallways are available to view. While still beautiful and interesting, they're not the main attraction.
Amazing Stay in Istanbul. A little restoration was underway way when we visited, but still with the time to see the beautiful mosaics.

Beautiful frescos.. Chora Church (Kariye Muzesi, current name) was initially built as a part of a monastery complex in the 5th century outside Constantinople’s (currently Istanbul) city walls, hence the name Chora. The interior decorations, the mosaics and frescoes, were done in the 14th century during the Byzantium period. During the Ottoman era in the 16th century it was converted to a mosque and recently in 1948 to a museum. Similar history as the Hagia Sophia which was a cathedral built in the 6th century, 9 centuries later it was converted to a mosque during the Ottoman era from 15-20th century and then to a museum in 1935.

Beautiful mosaics. We visited in November when much of the church was closed for reburbishment. Even so, it was worth the trip. The mosaics are stunning and the frescoes beautiful. Nearby you can climb the Theodosian wall for a stunning view over Istanbul.

Fantastic!. This is a hidden gem, tucked away in an area far away from the other touristy spots. But though some others have found it complicated, I thought it was rather straightforward. We took bus 87 from taksim which took us towards the city. We tgen got off where we saw the sign for the Kariye Muzesi... that's what the Chora Museum is locally called. We entered narrow alleys and must have walked about 10 minutes before seeing the place. But the signage was great and the route was perfectly easy to follow. Most of the museum is under renovation right now, but a part of it that you can visit, is simply gorgeous! Brilliantly done intricate work on the ceilings, mosaics, well preserved pulpits, ...wow! A must see if you have more than a week in Istanbul

Amazing!. Not the easiest place to find but well worth it! How ironic that it is because this church was converted into a mosque that its frescos and mosaics are so beautiful because they had been covered up for a few centuries.This museum is included in the Istanbul Pass and should not be missed. Hagia Sophia is grand and impressive but Chora is much more breathtaking.A must see!

Would have been great. We took a taxi to find this ancient church tucked away inside a tight neighborhood. I don't think we could have found it without a taxi.However, the entire outside is covered up and there is a trip roof over the entire complex right now as they resort the entire church. You are allowed inside for a fee (it is included in the fee you pay if you buy the 5-day museum card) but the only place to walk is in the outer narthex and to look at some of the mosaics on the wall and ceiling. No one is permitted into the sanctuary right now. This was disappointing but the mosaics that we did see were beautiful and then a nice lunch at the cafe next door.I would love to see the full church one day, but it seems that it will be closed for over a year during restoration (or so we were told).

Best frescoes in Turkey plus. Chora is probably my most favorite church in Istanbul..Yes, it is probably a tiny fraction of Hagia Sophia but..You will see the best frescoes in Turkey plus amazing mosaicsand if you are an early bird, you may even be the only visitor in this chapel size architectural jewel. Only disadvantage is that it is not near any other prominent attraction.But this is very implied in the name Chora, which means "outside the city proper" However, there is an authentic restaurant less than 50 meters away(Asitane) for lunch. It may require careful navigation around the menu, there are few dishes which are truly delicious.. Skip all starters go to main dishesand if you read carefully the ingredients, you may have the best meal of yourtrip.. Take no advice, ingredients should appeal to your palate.There is plenty of exciting deserts, consider this as well when ordering.If you do not consume wine (Turkey is not a place for wine!) not much financial damage will occur..

A Wonderful Historic Architecturally Significant Church with Wonderful Frescoes. I made a special effort to go to this church due to its historical significance. My eyes were treated to a feast of art and architecture. My camera never grew tired - I got lots of great pictures.

Must Visit. If you purchased Museum pass ( I strongly recommend every one to take it) then Chora Church is a part of it. Even though a portion of the church is open for visitors, other half is closed for restoration, its worth a visit. If you are staying at Sultanahmet travel is very easy, catch tram to Topkapi tram station (not the palace with same name) and then change to another tram and get off at Edrinakapi station and max 10 minutes walk to Chora church.
Stunning Collection of Mosaics. This church in an elegant neighborhood of Istanbul houses a collection of gorgeous mosaics depicting Biblical scenes in exquisite detail.

part of our tour with walks in istanbul. we did an organised tour with Walks In Istanbul and the Chora was part of the day. Even our kids enjoyed seeing the mosaics and our guide was very easy to follow with her perfect English!

Amazing Mosaics and frescos. This was a really interesting and beautiful church. Part of it was closed for renovations but there was still plenty to look at. Even the marble was incredible. It's small and you can get really close to the walls. There are some nice little gift shops in the area. We walked from here down to the water but we got pretty lost. It was still a fun walk. We passed all sorts of shops, houses, mosques, etc. As long as we were headed downhill it was fine!

Took my breath away + bonus visits nearby. The Chora Museum doesn't get the same crowds as Hagia, Blue or Topkapi because it's not as easy to get to relatively. To get there, take the M1 metro line to the Topkapi-Ulubatli station. When you exit the station look for the old Byzantine wall (sections of which are in decent shape amazingly) and walk along it uphill. After about 15min you'll come upon the impressive Mihrimah Sultan Camii (good visit too if you have time). Also just past that you'll come upon good sections where you can access the top of the city walls for awesome view. Chora Museum is just another 5min walk downhill through the neighbourhood from there.As others have said, the exterior is under restoration and parts of interior as well. But definitely do spend some time inside as you marvel at the well-preserved and dazzling mosaics.After the visit if you're up for more walking, you're only about 10min walk through the neighbourhood to Fethiye Museum. Though after Chora it will feel nowhere as impressive but the walk was lovely as you get a glimpse into their daily lives. After that, another 15min walk gets you to the Fener ferry terminal where you can enjoy water views and get back to Eminonu (New Mosque, Spice Bazaar, etc)

Absolute jewel, make the trip. This beautiful little church, which like the Ayasofya was a Byzantine church turned mosque turned museum, can be easily combined with a visit to the Theodosian walls and a walk through Fatih. The mosaics are in superlative condition, right down to the frontispiece picturing the donor himself offering it to JC.

Closed for restoration. First off, this is definitely not the easiest place to find, even for a local taxi driver. Location aside, we were very disappointed to find upon reaching the place that the main part of the church was closed for restoration. This fact wasn't highlighted on either their own website or on the Museum Pass website. We're lucky we had museum passes and didn't rent audio guides, otherwise we would have felt cheated. That said, the small part of the church still open is beautiful, and I'm sure the main part would be even better after the restoration is complete. Until then, it's probably not worth visiting, especially if you don't have a museum pass.

Stunning original frescoes and mosaics!. Interestingly, most of these frescoes were preserved so well because the muslims plastered over them when they turned it into a mosque. Then they were "rediscovered" when it came back into Christian hands. Beautiful!

Chora Church. A bit of a trek to get to the church as it is out in the suburbs but you can get there with public transport and a short walk.
The art work in the church is beautiful. Much of it has been restored and open to visitors with some areas still closed off.
Thoroughly recommended.

Beautiful. This is an astonishing building of early Byzantine architecture, 550 AD. The fresco's and mosaic's on the inside are beautful and certainly worth a look. Unfortunately for me, the building was under construction. So large parts of it were not open to the public and the outside was being restaured as well. Make sure you enter this with your museum card, as you should do everyting else in Istanbul.Also, if you can spare the time, take a walk through the neighbourhood and walk to the walls of Istanbul. On the north-west of the Chorakerk is an accesible point, it takes a few very steep stairs but the view is absolutely spectacular.

Worth a visit. As covered by other reviewers there is currently extensive renovation, but the mosaics and paintings are still worth a visit as they are pretty amazing. It's also worth walking around the site and the surrounding area, as there are lots of interesting old houses.Take the time to read the billboards outside the church, the English translation is rather amusing. The shops around the church are also quite good, though of course not the cheapest (but not bad).At the back of the site is the Kariye park, which is a lovely place to stop and it has a cheap cafe. It's full of mothers with children and council workers having a break, so you'll see a different side to the area.

Unfortunate Restoration. Though the Church/Museum has a beautiful architecture, the inside of it was rather unsatisfactory for the two parts of it has been in restoration for two years. Paying for the ticket the full price is not reasonable when there is very little to see.I would only recommend to see the outside, if you are not professionally interested in mosaics or history in any way.

An insight into a vanished world. This fine Byzantine church has survived with many of its mosaics and frescos intact. The overall structure is impressive and the detail of the narrative scenes of the life of the Virgin provides an insight into the beliefs of the time. Beautiful. (Note parts of the complex are closed as it is being progressively restored.)

Under renovation just now but still stunning interior. Fifteenth century church with fantastic mosaics preserved when it was converted into a mosque and they were covered in plaster. Now uncovered in this building now designated a museum they shine like almost new.

Spectacular. Growing up in Istanbul, i regretfully admit that i never knew the existence of this beautiful old church/museum. The mosaic work is so well preserved that you literally go back in time to such an amazing biblical experience. It is such a shame that many tourists visiting Istanbul never actually see Kariye. It is a shame to miss this great historical church. go and visit,you will not regret..

Staggering mosaics. The reason for going to this church (now a museum) is to see the mosaics. These are not only beautiful but important in showing the way in which Bible stories were presented early in the Christian era. Many of them relate to the Apocrypha rather than the New Testament and, unless you are an expert in this period, they will be selling meaningless without a guide. I strongly recommend that you pay for one. You will get so much more out of it.

Very limited access due to renovation work. A significant Byzantine church famous for its mosaics and frescoes. Giving the church/museum a rating was difficult because there was little to see due to extensive restoration work being carried out. What we could see was impressive. Is it worth a visit? I would say yes because the nearby land walls have been restored and they are worth seeing. The Church of St Stephen of the Bulgars is also undergoing renovation and at the time of writing could not be visited. It looks like a long term project.
Very nice, great examples of Byzantine religious art.. Hard to find unless you come directly from Fatih following the main street. The building is under renovation.

Eternal beauty. We visited museum in a very rainy day and when we went inside Chora Churh all problems were forgotten in a few seconds. Frescoes and mosaics above us are taking in other world, in biblical world, and it is also real diving in history. In our memory the Chora Church is a brilliant of our trip to Istanbul.

The country church. Chora Church is well off the beaten tourist path, but if you're interested in Byzantine art, it's definitely a place you want to visit. It was under restoration when my husband and I visited, but a security guard told us the restoration should be finished by June 2016. Regardless, the mosaics and frescoes that you can see make it well worth the visit. There's a nice, little park behind the church/museum and a cafe on the other side if you want lunch or just tea with some baklava! An added plus is the old wall of Constantinople which runs the length of the street near Chora Church.

After Aya Sofia - the most impressive place to visit in Istanbul.. The Chora Church is rightfully known for its mosaics. I visited this church 25 years ago and was in awe of the architecture and artistry. Revisiting it, I was afraid that I my memories had amplified the beauty of this place. Nothing was further from the truth. Seeing these mosaics again was magical. A must-see in Istanbul. Get here by grabbing a cab - about a 10 minute/20 Lira ride from Sultanahmet.

Beautiful mosaics, totally unique Byzantine church . Just take a look at the website for more in depth info. This is a beautiful church with much of the mosaics and frescos still intact. Wonderful audio commentary is available I recommend you use that.
An absolute must. We loved Chora, it is more beautiful than some very famous museums and sights. You get to see unique mosaics and frescoes from Christianity. Purely beautiful.

Byzantine art Church/Mosque/Museum. I visited this Byzantine attraction at the 10th time I visited Istanbul. Usually people go to more popular attractions however believe me this is one of the best Byzantine museums I have ever visited. The wallpaintings, color, authenticity is amazing. Even the museum in Athens isn't so attractive as this museum. Give it a try and you will not be disappointed.
definitely worth visiting. Top destnations for those intersted in byzantine art! To find it just go up from Ayvansaray pier.Chora located in very authentic area

beautiful. Part of the church was under restoration when i visited and I only had the chance to see a small part of it, the part that had the mosaics. Those mosaics and the wall paintings inside blew my mind away, they were simply beautiful. It;s not really easy to find this place but it's worth looking for. I took the bus from the Eminonu bus station, there are a couple of buses that can take you to the area and then you will need to walk for about 10 minutes or something! There weren't any guiding signs or anything, I kept asking people. The entrance fees are included in the museum card so if you have it you can use to enter the place without buying a ticket. The museum card is also available for purchasing from the ticket office there. This is such a hidden gem, would highly advise to see this place.

The church was closed for repairs. In 1970 and again in 1973 we managed to see the whole of this magnificent Church. Unfortunately in August 2015 the main church was closed for repairs, which left very little to see. For the time being and until they reopen the whole building it is not worth trekking so far from the centre for the little that is open.

Under construction. The Chora museum is currently under construction. We went there and were very disappointed to see only the side wing and entrance. It's quite an effort to get there as it's far from the other attractions. The paintings are beautiful and I imagine the inside the be stunning, but be aware, because you still pay the full entrance fee without seeing much.

Amazing Mosaics. The Chora church is a musuem of mosaics and frescos, no longer a church.Nearly every wall or ceiling had some amazing religious decoration. It helped to have a book explaining the meaning of each part of every picture although I guess the audio guides would be a good alternative.At the moment, and somewhatt disappointingly one main room was closed off and the whole of the outside covered in scaffolding for renovation work.   It cost 15TL to get in, audio guides are extra.It is a little hard to find and quite a long walk away from the better known areas of old historic Istanbul. You might want to take a taxi.

Restoration in process, so was underwhelemed by the visit.. We missed out on visiting The Chora Church on our last visit in 2015, so we were very eager to see it this time. We took the metro from the direction of the airport and exited at Topaki. From there we took a taxi and the driver found it very easily. as of March the admission was 15 lira, audio guides were 15 lira also. A guide was offering his services for 70 lira for the three of us. We declined. The main room of the church is closed due to restoration plus the exterior is covered with scaffolding. We are grateful to know that this beautiful place is being well cared for and restored. The signage on the outside explained some of the building's history and included pictures of things we would not be able to see. What we did see was beautiful and I am glad we checked this place off our places to visit. Compared to what we have seen in the Hagia Sophia The Chora Church left us wanting more. The neighborhood in which it is located is fun to explore including some of the tourist gift shops. Down the hill are some restaurants and bakeries.

Ravishing interior. Chora church is a little hard to find but well worth it. It has wonderful late Byzantine mosaics and frescoes on Jesus and the Virgin Mary. Truly a window to a mystical, forgotten people.
Amazing ancient church. A really amazing church with ancient byzantine frescoes and mosaics. Despite the reconstruction works it is really worth visiting for people interested in history.
Beautiful church!. We visited in 2013, the church is beautifully kept, all the mosaics are mostly clear and the audio tour is really helpful to understand all the paintings. A MUST SEE
Wonderful small church. It's not a big and well preserved church but there are not a lot of places where you can still see Byzantine art. It's takes 10-15 minutes to look around and to make photos.

Ancient religious site. Parts of the old church were under repair when we visited but what we were able to see were beautiful. The builders of the church took a lot of time and expense to make their house of worship magnificent.

HIDDEN GEM !. The Byzantine mosaics on the inside of this church are best representative example of the art of mosaics anywhere in the world!I make sure that I stop by to marvel at the gorgeous ceilings every chance I get !

Too much money. I visited the place, which took us some time to arrive and after paying for the ticket and entering I could only see a small room which was being rebuilt. Someone should have said something about the conditions of the place. I couldn't admire the beauty of it.

Golden Horn Ferry to Chora Church. The splendors of the Chora Church are covered in other reviews. I'm just reporting on a fun way to get to this rather out-of-the-way destination. We grabbed the Golden Horn Ferry at Eminonu and got off at Ayvansaray. From the ferry dock you'll see the historic Walls of Theodosius to the west. Cross the park and the street and start heading up the hill, keeping the walls to your right. Along the way to the church are some interesting sites: Tekfur Palace, Kastoria Synagogue Wall and Gate, Egikapi Gate and Surdibi Cemetery. (Unfortunately construction at Kazasker Ivaz Efendi Mosque made it impossible to view this Sinan-designed building or the Dungeons of Anemas and Blackernai Palace ruins.) No signs directing you to the Chora Church so if you don't have a good map you may need to ask directions once you reach the highest point of the walls, just east of a busy street. Note: We used CityMaps2Go for Istanbul (free app) and found it a great way to navigate the city. It took us right to the church. We retraced our steps after the church and enjoyed a beautiful sunset ferry ride back to Eminonu.

A Must Visit. This church was still under restoration when we visited. As there were nets and scaffolds surrounding the church we could not see the building structure from the outside. The church is very out of the way from all the main attractions. You can either take a taxi here but we took bus 37E towards Edirnekapi. You can either take a 37 or 38 as advise by the bus ticketman at Eminonou station.As the church was under restoration, we could only see a small part of the church - just before the main door to the prayer rooms! So technically, we could not see the inside. But from what we saw, it was so beautiful - the mosaics were amazing. Wished that we could have seen more.
Prodigious museum. A rare beauty the every traveler should take the time to visit. The architecture of the building is gorgeous.

Beautiful Church currently undergoing renovations.. What a beautiful church this is. The interior mosaics and frescoes are absolutely beautiful and despite only approximately 1/3 rd of the museum being open to the public due to renovations being done, it is absolutely worthwhile visiting.The name is apt in that chora means "outside the city", which it is.On entering, the mosaic panels in the two entrance narthexes depict scenes from the lives of the Virgin and Christ, as described in the Bible. Despite the fact that these were covered by whitewash when the church was converted to a mosque in the 16th century, they have been remarkably restored and cleaned.There are several curio shops, an open-air cafe and quaint cobble stone roads surrounding the Church, as well as as very well preserved old wooden buildings that are quite fascinating to see.To get there, exit either the Topkapi Tram line (orange line) or the Metrobus (brown line) at Edirnekapi and then follow the well marked sign boards that say "Kuriye Muzise" to get to the Church.

Small and out of the way but a MUST-VISIT. Among all the historic sites we visited in Istanbul, this small out-of-the-way church was by far my favorite. I liked it even more than more celebrated attractions like Hagia Sophia, Sultanahmet, or Topkapi Palace. The mosaics here are drop dead stunning. Entrance to Chora Church is 20TL, but it's free if you have the 5-day Istanbul Museum Pass. To get here by tram, take the T1 line to Topkapi station. Transfer to the T4 line and get off at Edirnekapi. From there it's about a 10-minute walk to Chora Church. Just be careful when crossing the big highways to get to it from Edirnekapi station.

jewel of byzantine art. Better known as the Church of the Holy Savior in Chora, this unassuming late Byzantine church is famous for its mosaics, which are among the finest surviving works of Byzantine art in the world. Originally constructed in the fourth century AD, it was rebuilt by Theodore Melitoches, the Byzantine Grand Logothete, or Imperial Chancellor, at the beginning of the 14th century. It's now a museum well worth a visit, especially for its wonderfully preserved mosaic and fresco cycles depicting the life of the Virgin Mary, the Passion and the Last Judgment. Above the doorway is a portrait of Melitoches himself, presenting the church to the Virgin enthroned. The church represents the final flowering of Byzantine art before the empire entered its death throes, and the mosaic figures also show the influence of early Renaissance art.
Nice historical site. The church itself is very old. You need a guide to make sense of the interior. It can be crowded and noisy with all the guides speaking at the same time.

Magnificent Orthodox Heritage. Couldn't agree more with the previous reviewer. Chora is most likely a one in a lifetime experience if I could say that for all the Christians who would like to enjoy first class mosaics. They called it the Byzantian Renaissance, I would say that every art lover no matter in which religion believes should visit it.Be aware of the fact that you won't be able to enjoy the outside part cause its all covered.Go because its a beauty.

Under Renovation But Still Beautiful!. I took the tram from Sultanahmet to Tokapi Station, then i took a slow walk cutting through a park. On the right side, is the ancient walls, then turn left and walked all the way down along the walls until you reach a busy main street. Here, a mosque exist. Crossed the road and ask the locals the directions to the Chora Church. Sadly, the main section is closed to the public due to intense renovation. Nothing much to see but the mosaics are truly beautiful and magnificent!

Stunning place well worth the walk.... i have now seen this place twice, The first time, many years ago, i arrived by cab. This time I came up by foot, through Fatih. Well worth the effort. First I took the Metro at Aksarai, got off at Topkapi-Ulubati and walked up the winding streets towards NE, visited pastry shops with the best baklava i the world and reached the Kariye Cami. As 20 years earlier, the mosaics were still there in all their splendor, waiting. It was like seeing a long lost love after 20 years and feeling time had not passed. This is a DO NOT MISS spot in Istanbul and one of the best in the world.

One of the best remaining Byzantine churches in Istanbul. When it comes to surviving Byzantine landmarks in Istanbul, none is more famous or recognizable than the Hagia Sophia. However, I'd encourage you to make Chora Church a top priority after seeing the Hagia Sophia for a couple reasons. First, it is tucked away in a very non-tourist part of the city, so it's actually relatively unknown and therefore has much smaller crowds than the top attractions. Second, almost every wall and ceiling is covered in frescoes and mosaics which are the main reason to go Because the church is small, you can see all of the Byzantine art that lines the walls and ceilings close up, and in many places there are pieces that tell stories from the lives of Jesus and Mary.Full disclosure: the church has been under restoration for some time now, and as of Feb 2016 it is still being restored. I asked one of the attendants if there was a projected finish date and he said that the restoration is ongoing and that they could not give an estimated finish date at that time. The whole church is covered on the outside, so you won't really get to see the exterior facade. Also, the main section of the church is closed to visitors; only the outer hallways and foyers are open. That said, you can still see 80% of the frescoes and mosaics as most are the aforementioned hallways and foyers. It is still certainly worth your time to make the trip to see the intimate and beautifully preserved Byzantine church.
Mosaic!. A must in Istanbul. Magic, quiet and sadly under renovation but absolutely worth a visit. Magic atmosphere.

Perhaps the finest Byzantine ensemble anywhere. The mosaics and murals in this church are simply breathtaking. The Hagia Sophia cannot hold a candle to this little church for the magnificence of its art. By all means, make the trip here if you can. The expressiveness of the mural that would have been behind the altar made me see Byzantine art in a whole new light.

under renovation but still amazing. Unfortunatelly the main part is closed to the public due to resauration (Feb. 2016). You can still see the most important mosaics which were among the most beautiful of it´s kind I have seen so far. You should probably rent the audio guide to get the mosaics explained if you don´t know too much about the life of Jesus Christ. I was raised catholic and remembered most of the storys depicted in the mosaics, but if you have a different faith I think you miss something if you don´t know what is depicted exactly. A little hard to get there but absolutely worth the visit.

Real atttaction at the outskirts . Historical mosaic museum 40 minutes by public transport from Sultanahmet. Beautiful mosaics and frescos from the byzantine era. Calculate around 30-40 minutes for visiting.
Just Amazing!. The Chora Church might be under repair but it is still a definite not-to-miss sight in Istanbul for it's history and sheer beauty
If you like old stones, this is the place!. This is a bit out of the main tourist area but certainly worth the detour. The church is absolutely breathtaking.
Beautiful site.... Lots of art to see and you have to love this beautiful old church&camii combine!Must visit if you are in Istanbul!

Luminous mosaics. I love mosaics ... but there is something about the power of byzantine art. Icons are meant to reveal the holy and these do... Sadly part of Chora was being refurbished so I missed some mosaics, but what we saw was stunning. Chora is also located in the old neighbourhood of Balat, I think, and it was pleasant to walk through narrow streets full of slightly run down, living charm.

Brilliant Mosiacs, Under Construction but Worth the Visit. The Chora Church, Kariye Museum, (Church of the Holy Savior Outside the Walls) was originally built by Constantine in the 4th century, the existing structure is from the 11th century. Interior decorations featuring mural drawings and Mosiacs are dated from 1320. The Mosiacs portraying the life of Jesus and Mary, Jesus's ministry and the frescoes portraying the theme of death and resurrection are breathtaking. The museum is out of the way and is currently under renovation therefore two hours at most is needed to view the museum and explore the surrounding Byzantine walls and historical Jewish area.

Mosaic palace. If you are into Byzantine art and mosaics is your main interest, Chora church museum is a palace for mosaics. There is no other place where you can see the life of Christ in a chronology as it is here. also, the Dormition mosaic is one of my favorites. Such a great work.
Amazing find!. We had no idea that this church existed. It was part of our tour package. The frescos we saw were every bit as beautiful and important to art history as any Giottos in Italy.

3-stars on the way to 5. This ancient church/mosque is 17 centuries old. Visiting it should be on your Istanbul list. It is a small site, but the restoration of ancient mosaics is remarkable. The site is under restoration/construction now and they've wrapped the building in a canvas cover that makes it hard to appreciate the architecture from the outside. On the inside, about 1/2 of the facility is open to the public. What is open is stunning, but in 2018 when the rest of it opens, this should be a 5-star attraction.
Chora museum. Visited Chora museum recently. Unfortunately it is covered from outside for restoration works. Inside has to offer beautiful mosaics and it is one of the must do in Istanbul.

Byzantine mosaics beautifully preserved. Although it's not in the history-packed Sultanahmet area, it's worth the cab ride to get a look at these Orthodox-style mosaics covering the walls and ceilings of this church. It's not a large museum so it's easy to see in under an hour. If you go around lunch time take the opportunity to eat at the Asitane restaurant just up the street.

best mosaics ever... Chora Church is an ancient Byzantine church, originally built in the 4th century, later converted into a mosque in the 15th century AD. Today, it is a must-to-see museum with the most beautiful mosaics in Istanbul.
Beautiful!. One of the most beautiful churches I have been in! Stunning frescos and art on the ceilings and walls, camera worthy!

Awesome mosaics that tell a story. Going into this church/mosque/museum may not be a must (because it's a bit out of the way), but if you're willing to take the walk, you'll be rewarded with a very unique experience. You won't find another church with such a story to tell on its walls.

Stunning mosaics; lots of restoration work. This is very out of the way from the rest of Istanbul, but if you love architectural details, you cannot miss this church. The narthex mosaics are in beautiful condition, and there's so much going on that it's hard to know where to look. It took us about 15 minutes to get to the church by taxi, and then we probably spent a maximum of 20 minutes inside. You could get away with a lot less if your cab driver offers to wait (but there were a few outside when we left.)We did not see the actual nave of the church, which was under restoration, as was the exterior, but based on pictures, it's really the narthex that's the focus.

Takes Time to Get Here, but Expect Lovely. I walked here from Eyup which meant walking along winding narrow streets weaving through a mountainous region, but that made it cooler to get here since you pass through a more traditional and authentic Turkey. The Kariye Museum is small and old, and if you've made it here, you're probably the person who enjoys detailed ceiling mosaics.

The exterior and main area of the church was under construction. Granted it's smaller than Hagia Sophia, the frescos and mosaics are still awe-inspiring. Go with a guide or read up your lonely planet, and you will learn so much about Byzantine art and history. My only disappointment was the fact that the main building was under construction (yet they charged the full price). I couldn't go anywhere near the famous Pietà fresco. Only two hallways was opened and you can finish them in less than 30 minutes.

Byzantine Glory. The Chora Church once was in the fields (hence the name, "Chora" in Greek), but now is in the Western District. The church has the best preserved Byzantine religious art in situ in all of Istanbul. Those interested in Christian art will find themselves in heaven here. Even those not interested explicitly in Christian art will find it a fascinating and well worth while stop on their travels. My tip: bring a little mirror so you don't have to strain your neck looking up all the time!

Yes, it's out of tha way. Go.. The frescoes and mosaics at this small church are magnificent, and can be admired "up close", unlike Hagia Sophia. The sanctuary was being repaired when we were there, but the narthex and side chapel had plenty for us to admire. A small pair of binoculars or a telephoto lens on your camera will get you close to the mosaics in the domes.
What a place!. Absolutely majestic, one of the most memorable museums i've ever seen. I've been there on a rainy day, such the perfect scenario.

nice. Byzantine era church is a building used as a mosque after the conquest, I recommend that you should not miss. In particular, mosaics and frescoes are the best examples of Byzantine recently. In both of the wall, present in both imagery mosaic ceiling it has reached little damage. As well as colored and patterned marble mosaic decorations are also available. I would advise you to see.

So stunning! I couldn't drag my husband and son out!. I love mosaics, I really do. And these are amazing mosaics. They are. But they must have some kind of magic hold on the men in my life, because my husband and son could not be separated from them! Part of it is John Freely's Fault (Strolling Through Istanbul) because he explains what everything is and what's there, what's missing, what's being restored, what's in fresco. But after 4 hours I finally had to eat something! Honestly though. These are stunning.

Wonderful treasure of Istanbul. If You have time You should visit Kariye muuseum in Istanbul. We spend almost a day in area- first visited Kariye museum (it was amazing, very nice mosaics and worth to visit). later we visited hamam not very far from museum. hamam for locals (not tourist attraction) and it was very nice experience also.

THE HIDDEN GEM OF ISTANBUL. Thanks God I got the time and the opportunity to go to Fatih area this time and see this wonderful piece of art of the Byzantine era, those mosaics and frescoes all around with gold leaves covering are really marvelous, the saints are shining reflecting the old Constantinople..This mixed and overlapping layers of civilizations that you see make Istanbul as a 1001 night story ..It’s simply like a dream as if ur in an old fading book you even can smell the years and years of civilization in this place ..i can’t explain more ..Maybe you need to visit and get this feeling.. im in love with you Istanbul . don’t miss Chora plzzzz

most important mosaics and frescoes. the naos is currently under restoration, but all the most important mosaics are accessible and not to be missed. you must read about the mosaic scenes to be fully prepared to appreciate this most significant and beautiful orthodox treasure.
Not worth seing. The museum is far from everywhere, poor and scary area. Museum is not interesting at all. Not worth a visit.

Beautiful little church. This is a beautiful little church with some very unique tile work. We tried to find it on our own but ended up taking an uber instead. The main part is closed for renovations so you can only visit the small alcove in the front and side. We had a guide book with us that helped explain all the mosaics which was fine. I don't think you would need to hire a guide for this visit unless you wanted a very in depth explanation. Worth a visit if you are up to trying to find it!

Scaffolding Outside; A Major Closure Inside. My excellent rating is for the famous mosaics and striking frescoes currently accessible in this former Byzantine church and Ottoman mosque. But the nave is closed due to restoration work, and scaffolding covers the entire exterior. Some people may prefer to spend their time elsewhere due to the work in progress, especially because coming here requires a taxi or a long ride on public transport. To save time, we took a taxi from Sultanahmet, which cost 21 TL. The admission fee is 15 TL Those who visit, however, will be rewarded by seeing the Byzantine mosaics and frescoes that exist outside the nave. They went on the walls between 1315 and 1321 but were covered under a layer of plaster when the church became a mosque. The art, which depicts the lives of Christ and the Virgin Mary, was restored when the building became a museum. I thought the side chapel was quite interesting with its scenes from the Old Testament. A fresco that shows Christ raising Adam and Eve from their sarcophagi was particularly impressive.The gift shop sells guidebooks that explain the mosaics and frescoes, and a guide approached us for hire to do the same. We opted to use a guidebook that we brought with us. There were only a few other visitors there when we went mid-morning on a weekday.

wonderful for art lovers. this 14th century church has exquisite mosaics and frescoes from the Byzantine era. It is small and you will need transportation from Istanbul to reach it, but if you love Byzantine art it is a treasure. The preservation of the colors and subjects of the mosaics and frescoes are priceless! Restaurants and shops around it so you can make a day if needed.

Amazingly gorgeous mosaics and frescoes!. This heavily restored Byzantine church contains some of the finest mosaics and frescoes in Byzantine art.
