It is one of the city's major attractions, and should not be missed, despite its distance from the Sulthanhamet. The church can be a bit hard to find, so it might be a good idea to cab there. Once there, allow for anything between 20 minutes to 2 hours to visit the church, depending on the level of detail you want to get into. My son and I followed the detailed descriptions available in John Freely's _Strolling through Istanbul_ and took two hours to see everything. There are also guidebooks available for sale on site. You can take photographs, as long as you don't use a flash.A visit to the Kariye Museum is easily combined with visits to the Mirrimah mosque, one of the most beautiful in the city, and to the section of the land walls that occupies the highest point in the city, providing spectacular views. We took the ferry to Avansaray, cabbed to Kariye, walked to the mosque and down the length of the walls to the Topkapi gate, where we caught the tram back to Galata.
Magical. This is the most beautiful place in Istanbul. We never visit Istanbul without going here. It's a bit out of the way but definitely worth the effort.

Surprising visit. Hard to find, but worth the effort of going there. Amazing frescos and mosaics. Particularly interesting if you know some of the main bible stories since you can easily recognize the different stories. For the moment it is being renovated so part of it is not accessiblz to visitors.

The story of Heavenly religions paint on the wall. Very nice church where you can read from the paints the story of many Prophets. from prophet Ibraheem, yaqoub, Virgin Mary, Jesus and Day of Resurrection. Very nice historical story.

Difficult to get to, not fully open due to renovation, but still worth a look.. The mosaics are beautiful and the church itself I can imagine would look beautiful too. The problem is the whole Church is under major renovation and you cannot see the outside because of scaffolding or parts of the interior. I think once it's completed it will be a must see for all.

Incredible mosaics. Be sure to use a guide. I am not sure if they have self guided tours. I think they probably do. You have to know how to look at all the gorgeous mosaics that tell Jesus' story beginning before Mither Mary's birth through the ascension into heaven. Words can not describe this church.

Mosaic heaven. This site, an old monastery, has the most beautiful mosaics I saw in all of Turkey. For me, it was more impressive, in its small way, than Haigha Sophia. It is an undemanding tour, with a restaurant nearby to sit a while for a cup of tea.
Incredible place!. The church was under major renovations... we couldn't go in the main chamber, but wow... even the entry hallways were incredible!

The depictions of the life of Virgin Mary and the life of Saint Anna are unique. Very we'll preserved. It is a must see.. A master piece of Byzantine art. A must see church. It is relatively small but is very well preserved. Don't miss the opportunity to visit it.

Most beautifully reserved mosaics in Istanbul. If you want to see all the scenes of Bible at one place Chora Church is a must. Mosaics from golden leaves are amazing and maintained very well. It is a small church however completely beyond expectations.

Intricate and beautifully preserved mosaics. Though not on the "big five" of Istanbul attractions, this small church has the most beautiful and intricate mosaics depicting the life of Mary. Really worth seeing and probably seldom crowded. Even if you aren't religiously inclined, the beauty of the mosaics will impress you.

The best visit of our trip. This is worth the walk, it is apparently not visited by many people but it is certainly stunning. It was the best building that we visited in Istanbul in my opinion and we saw a lot

Great and a must see in İstanbul. Great example of Byzantine art. Not as big as Hagia Sophia but decoration is much more greater!
The depictions you can't see in the other churches, Even the first seven steps of Virgin Mary can be seen in this church. Definitely you will get a terrible neckache after visiting this church if you spent more than an hour like me.

Byzantium Church. Beautiful Frescos and full of history.. I believe this church is now regarded as a museum rather than a place of worship. There is a small fee to enter but it's worth it, and I believe the money goes towards restoration work. We had a private guide for the day - Monica Fritz, who made the places we visited so much more interesting because she explains all the history. I am more interested in the architecture and art than the fact it's a church. I should imagine anyone with a keen interest in history or religion would find this place interesting.

If you have time to spare. The museum is around 30 minutes trip from the Hahia Sophia area a by public transport you can take the T1 to Topkapi then transfer to T4 then exit at Edirnekapi. I wouldn't call the surrounding area touristy at all; it's very local and a bit busy. The museum itself is under renovation from outside, but we got to see everything on the inside. The museum isn't too big so it took us around 20 minutes to look at the amazing Byzantine mosaics. Once you see Chora, I wouldn't recommend going to Fathiye museum unless you're taking a taxi directly to the place as the walk towards Fathiye museum is a bit rough and hilly.

Hard to get to but worth the visit. This is a beautiful church & worth the trouble it takes to get there. It is under rennovation & has limited opening hours but the mosaics are beautiful. This site is on the MUZE card, at least when we went. If you have free time, it's a definite do!

Well worth the effort.. Not easy to get to this church - need to take a taxi. However, the panels depicting often rather obscure Biblical themes and the mosaics are quite extraordinary. I would suggest visiting this church with a guide.

Iconic. Lovely mosaics, such design. Alas, it was partially closed for restoration when I was there so the entire church was not open. What was available to see was stunning. DO not miss the Byzantine aqueduct nearby or the Roman Wall.

Great adventure in the middle of nowhere. The Chora Church is a really great church with mosaic and paintings. It has also a very nice architecture from outside and inside. The location is actually in the middle of real old İstanbul. On the other hand, this area has been changed a lot and it is difficult to find this church a bit. So, i recommend to visit that church but i would like to inform you that this area is a conservative side of İstanbul right now. I recommend to go with a tour guide. Enjoy...

The History of Byzantium in one building. The church has some very beautiful art work and impressive architecture. Its construction and changes made to it since, reflect the tides that have swept across the area, and make it a microcosm of Turkish history.

Beautiful original Byzantine-era mosaics and frescoes. Amazing.. Small church in north-east Fatih, an ultra-conservative area of Istanbul, that have some beautiful original Byzantine-era mosaics and frescoes. Absolutely worth the trek to see this small church.

Gorgeous piece of history- don't miss it!. This church is not on all the to do lists for istanbul but I highly recommend it.The ceiling of the church is covered with mosaics telling stories of Mary and Jesus from the bible.The detail and pictures are absolutely stunning. Some of the mosaics were destroyed over time.Take the audio guide do you can get an understanding of what each mosaic is about.I recommend taking a taxi to get to this place.

Really beautiful and worth the trip. I went there early in the morning before the crowds arrived so had time to see the tiny naves alone and without rush. I didn't expect to be as beautiful as I found it. Really wonderful mosaics and frescoes you rarely see elsewhere. There is a restaurant next door that seems good but opens after 12.00 and that was too late for us, unfortunately.

My favorite mosaics in Istanbul. This place is fascinating. I would highly recommend using a guide to see this church as there are so many details in the mosaics that tell such wonderful stories. I would not have noticed them without a guide to point them out.

Beautiful. I can't begin to tell anyone how to get to this church as we were on a tour. It was a little distance from our hotel in Old Town. I can only say that it is a must see. It is small but very beautiful and in a nice area of wooden buildings and a few gift shops.
Fantastic collection of mosaics. Beautiful small church with nice collection of mosaics, impressive central dome and richly decorated corridors.

Amazing mosaics (even though you may only see half of them). Although relatively small compared to other sightseeing gems in Istanbul, visit to Kariye museum is still an amazing experience! Unfortunately large part of it is currently under restoration so if you have not seen or are not going to see Aya Sofia, the Blue Mosque, Basilica Cistern and Topkapi Palace, then the mosaics and frescos at Kariye may not be worth the trip. Having said that, I am still extremely glad I went and combined with a visit to a nearby Hammam, the trip away from the touristy center may be your most memorable day.
Touring Turkey with Nevzat. Nevzat was a very nice driver who went above and beyond his necessary duties to show us turkey. The agency was also very good

A real gem!. While the Kariye is not easily accessible by public transportation, it is absolutely worth the journey...The frescos and mosaics are incredible, and so impressive. Just be careful, your neck might hurt afterwards from looking UP for so long! The neighborhoods surrounding it are also a joy to meander around.

This cannot be missed. To start with, let me tell me you its a mission to get to. And if you have read my reviews about Istanbul you will know my true dislike of the Istanbul taxi system. So like a true Explorer I went out of my way to find the best way to get here the local way.Here's how I did it.From Eminönü Bus terminal take the bus number 38E to Edrinekapi. Get off at the stop Edrinekapi. You ll see a tiny Street where bikes are parked just off the same side you get off the bus. It ll look like you are in middle of nowhere but let that get to you. Once you your bearing you can navigate easily (download TripAdvisor offline maps) and it's as easy as that. Once again entry fee and a smallish church. Now many reviews said you need 30mins tops. Believe me that is not the case. If you love historical facts and have read the Bible this is truly the most awesome place you'll want to be in. I for one couldn't peel my eyes off the ceiling. So full of intricately art. Restored. Fresco and mosaic. Unless you see this wonder you will not believe a word of what I say.One more thing this is under restoration and has been for years so some parts are closed bur what is do get to see it beyond any words I can conjure to describe this place. Kariye museum or the church of St.George of Chora depicts the genealogy of the Christ and the Virgin Mary. Finally our trip back was a wonder in itself. We decided we wanted to take the ferry back to Eminounu. So we walked down the cobbled streets opp direction of where we came from and ended up walking along the most beautiful path way right up to the ruined city walls. It's a pleasant walk with less tourists around. Enjoyed a lovely cup of Turkish coffee.Once we figured out where we where and to save time we got another bus back to Eminounu. As I mentioned before if you have offline maps and the Metro maps you can figure out how to get there.. It's very logical.

Nice but not so attractive. They have the finest mosaic mural, each one is a bible story. If you are Christian, you will really like this place. The outfit for the building is under refurbishment when I visit there. Compare to another church in Istanbul, if you don't have much time you can just skip this site.

Beautiful frescoes. Unfortunately, the Chora Museum is not located in a place where it can be easily reached. Foreigners need to take a cab or a public bus a find a way to get off at the right stop (English speakers are not very common around that area).Even though it's smaller when compared to Hagia Sophia Museum, the surviving frescoes may be better kept than the ones at Hagia Sophia.It's a beautiful peace of art.

Beautiful mosaic and icons. The church has one of the most beautiful mosaics in the entrance and side area. Unfortunately, the main hall was closed for restoration and the external walls too so you couldn't see the architecture from outside or the main hall inside but still worth a visit but it's not easy to find

The only Byzantine church surviving from 1453 (I believe). Visited this church and was amazed. I believe this is the only church surviving 1453 almost intact from Byzantium and most of the frescoes are exposed.This is a museum and not a place of worship, as Hagia Sofia, but this one has a special aura. Maybe because it was difficult for me to find it, walking the streets of old Istanbul. Of course, you can jump on a cab and get there no problem, I do things a bit my way.Enjoy the place.

Great place, not-so-great atmosphere. This is an amazing place to visit both historically and architecturally, but unfortunately its atmosphere feels very museum-like, even more so than Hagia Sophia, and this is compounded by its small size. Still worth a visit though!

What a waste of time. We decided to combine our trip to Chora Church with a short Golden Horn ferry cruise. The ferry cruise part was great and cheap - Only 4TL or less with an Istanbulkart.Walking up to the church from the ferry dock though was exhausting. It's all uphill and through some questionable neighborhoods. Thank goodness for my smartphone GPS and Google Maps, or I'm sure we would have gotten lost.In any case, we came up to the church from the back side and immediately saw that the exterior was all covered in scaffolding. Not too big of a deal, since there's nothing special about the exterior.However, upon entering the church, we saw signs that the main nave was closed for renovation. That's pretty much the bulk of the church that is closed. What's left are some hallways that admittedly do have some nice mosaics and frescoes. But really ... that's it.After spending all that time getting to the church, it was a big letdown. With Chora Church being so far away from most other tourist sites, it's really not worth the trip. Without a museum pass, which covers this church, it's certainly not worth the price of admission.
Waste of money and time. This is under construction and you cannot visit any part of it except the entrance and the gift shop!

An astonishing gem.. We caught this astonishing, rather less hyped sight only because it was part of the day tour of Istanbul. The mosaics have been well restored and of a high degree of artistic excellence. Stunningly beautiful. In fact you can see how the style has evolved since the era of the Hagia Sofia mosaics which are also much fewer in number. This church seems to have been less vandalized. One can believe that shortly after the creation of these beautiful mosaics, the Ottomans took over the land and some of these artists fled to Europe and were part of the onset of the Renaissance. So, History and aesthetics-wise, this is a mustsee creation.

Moving Experience. Come early before the selfie-nuts arrive so that you can have a quite communion with ancient religious history. The frescos and mosaics are devine. It is a long trek from the center of Istanbul but well worth the effort.

Beautiful Mosaic Art!. We enjoyed this museum the most. It was first a Christian church. As such it's walls were covered with mosaics telling Bible stories. When it became a mosque, the walls and mosaics were plastered over. Now a museum, the plaster is being removed and the beautiful mosaics are being restored if possible.

Out of the way - but worth the visit. The main part of the church was closed when we got there, but still plenty to see. The visit won't take more than a half hour to see everything, but it is out of the way. We took the metro and then a taxi since it was raining... but then walked back to the metro after (about 30 min walk).
Don't miss this on your visit to instanbul. This out of the way museum is a don't miss. Small intimate with a great history and beautiful frescos
Frescoes are beautiful. The frescoes on the ceiling and walls are beautiful. However a large section is closed for renovation.

Just beautiful. The beautiful mosaics and frescos of Chora Church are really worth the little detour. A taxi from Sultanahmet is about 25 lira but if you're comfortable with using public transport it's not too far from the Edirnekapı tram stop. There were refurbishing works in progress on the outside when I visited but the main frescos were visible inside. Chora was part of the Istanbul museum card when I visited, meaning that if you get one to visit the main museums in Sultanahmet you can add a visit to this Byzantine pearl for free.
Fantastic tile frescoes.. Yes, worth the distance to find this jewel. And eat lunch outside in the patio restaurants adjacent.

Wonderful Mosaics. This former Church is now a museum. The mosaics and wall frescos of Christ and of Mary are outstanding. You would need to return a number of times to appreciate the richness of this heritage and to enjoy the biblical scenes portrayed.The mosaics are stunning, and so well preserved, they look as if they had been created recently.

Beautiful church (now museum). One of the nicest (and less visited) former churches in Istanbul. I have visited a couple of times and there is always a different section undergoing renovation. I would give it a 4/5 when I can see the whole place without renovation scaffolding
A favorite. Early images of Christ give us an idea of how he may have looked. It is a charming, quiet, small church that has survive for centuries.

Great old byzantine site but under renovation. Chora church / museum is in its current incarnation nearly 800 years old. When istanbul was captured by e the conqueror it was converted into a mosque, with the bell tower converted into a minaret and the extensive medieval art whitewashed and sometimes destroyed. When turkey became a a republic 90 years ago, it was converted into a museum. Many of the centuries old paintings / mosaics have since been partially restored with renovations that are ongoing. The entire inner sanctuary is off limits presently and for. the foreseeable future. However the art remaining is an excellent example of medieval christian art which is well worth seeing. This is difficult to find as are many of the secondary sites in istanbul. Travel books give directions but there is no direct route via public transportation and the church sits at a high altitude. Taxi is easiest and walking with a good gps is about three miles from Sultanahmet. We walked which took us though fascinating neighborhoods and gave us a good workout. Walking is not for the faint of heart or short of time. Four stars were awarded both for the interference of the restoration and difficulty getting there. Do not hire a guide just for this site as it is small and easily done on your own. Tickets are ten lire ($3.50 us) or free with the museum pass.
Excellent. All these images made with small rocks on the wallsastonishing. We shouldnt miss it . Thanks got we didn't
the best mosaics outside Ravenna. Thsi is a wonderful church. It is worth the effort to get to it - you can go by ferry or metro and taxi, but go.
Overrated attraction. Much of this church was closed for renovations and the audio guide presentation was very difficult to follow

Over priced and disappointing. When you compare the mosques to the Chora Church, the latter is not even in the same league. The mosques are huge and are free. The Chora Church is small and charges way too much for what is there. The frescoes are nice, but we felt cheated. The inside of the church was undergoing renovations. So, you could not enter and see the inside. Of course they did not tell you that when they took your money. They still charged full price even though you could only see the outer hallways. The best thing about the church was that is was only two blocks from the old city walls which were free and offered a great view of the city.

Chora Church _ Kariye Museum. he Chora Museum, Mosque, or Church) is a former Byzantine church, later Ottoman mosque, and current museum in the Edirnekapı neighborhood of Istanbul.[1] The neighborhood is situated in the western part of the municipality (belediye) of the Fatih district. In the 16th century, during the Ottoman era, the church was converted into a mosque, before becoming a museum in 1948. The interior of the building is covered with the original Byzantine-era mosaics and frescoes unearthed after its secularization.

Church of the Holy Saviour in Chora. he Chora Museum, Mosque, or Church) is a former Byzantine church, later Ottoman mosque, and current museum in the Edirnekapı neighborhood of Istanbul.[1] The neighborhood is situated in the western part of the municipality (belediye) of the Fatih district. In the 16th century, during the Ottoman era, the church was converted into a mosque, before becoming a museum in 1948. The interior of the building is covered with the original Byzantine-era mosaics and frescoes unearthed after its secularization.

Closed for restoration. Took us thirty minutes to get to Kariye Museum from Sultanahmet. The location is not very well serviced by public transportation so a taxi is your best bet. We went with high expectations and undoubtedly, whatever little we saw was beautiful! But it was too much effort for just seeing three halls that are currently open. Also, getting a taxi (for return) in the church's vicinity is clearly a matter of luck.

Beautiful mosaics but much of it is closed for restoration. We really enjoyed the Chora Church. The mosaics and paintings are beautiful and touring the church in the morning before most tourists arrive is a very peaceful and moving experience. But be aware that significant portions of the church are currently closed for restoration. We didn't realize just how much we had missed until we later read a beautifully illustrated book about the Chora Church and saw photos of many mosaics that were in the closed off area. Tip: they sell that book (about Haggia Sophia and Chora Church) in the Chora Church bookstore, but vendors outside have the same book for less than half the price.

A secret jewel in the middle of an Istanbul neighborhood. Must visit !. This is a place that too many people that visit Istanbul on a package tour don't know about it. I read about it and made plans to visit. It is a jewel ! The frescos of this Catholic Church are amazing. One of a kind. They even asked me how did I find out about this place. There is a small market outside. And there is also public transportation to get there. Few minutes walk from there is one part of the old town wall. Go to the top of the wall to see an amazing view of the town. The story of this church is very interesting. You only need a hour here, but it will take you 30 minutes in public transportation to get there.

Take a guided tour. The Chora Church was included on our tour from the cruise ship and I am so glad that we had a very knowledgeable guide who had written a book about the church. He was also a lecturer from the University so he was able to bring alive many stories from ancient Christian times that I had never heard. You definitely need a guide but don't miss it as it is an essential icon of Istanbul's earlier pre Moslem history.

Wonderful mosaics. This church´s lobby is filled with wonderful mosaics featuring the life of Christ and the apostle that were painstakingly restored after it ceased to be a mosque. It is now a museum worth the trip to the western part of old Istambul.

Great frescoes. Probably the greatest number of Christian frescoes in Istanbul outside of Agha Sophia. A bit of a trek as outside the old city walls. Just a street away are steps up to the top of the old city walls - a good viewpoint. Cafes and gift shops nearby. Under reconstruction externally when we visited, but still tremendous interior.
Go for the frescoes inside. A bit out of the way - outside the old city walls, but worth a trip for the frescoes inside. Truly magnificent.

Chora, not to be missed. We visited Istanbul in June, and one of our stops had to be the Chora church.This old church has some of the most fascinating frescos of scenes from the bible. Some of the stories I had never heard before. It was well worth the visit, they were doing some construction at the time we were there but that did not stop us from seeing Chors, you should too!

Remarkable. This was one of the most beautiful sights in Istanbul, definitely worth the trek outside the tourist district to see this beauty. It's only about 2 blocks from the Edirnekapi bus stop. Not to mention you can walk along the remaining original walls of the walled city of Constantinople. Those where amazing as well. The church is currently being renovated but despite that it was so breathtaking to see the images of Christ.

Best collection of icons in Istanbul. 13th century church now a museum that has arguably the best collection of Christian icons in Istanbul. The church is under restoration and only partially viewable but what you can see is stunning. Many of the icons painted on the interior walls and ceilings are incomplete, many are complete in detail with gold paint brilliantly reflecting the light. Well worth the 15 tl that it costs to enter. Better still most tourists haven't found it so it's not all that crowded especially around 11 am.

Stunning history of Greek Orthodox religion pictured on walls. Need to see this church with a knowledgeable guide as there is an incredible amount of history of the church, politics, symbology, and stunning artwork displayed here. quite remarkable!

Exquisite example of ancient religious basilica, with superb mosaics.. History richly presented, yes. But even with no interest, the place inspires even the atheist with the power of the human spirit, laudatory as well as contemplative and didactic. Walk up the hill while you are there, and climb the Walls of Constantine, best near the end of the day, to look over the entire city.

Very important and beautiful historical mosaicwork. If you have been to Ravenna in Italy, then you have seen some other beautiful mosaics, but those were much earlier than these. These are astoundingly detailed and moving, and even though the location is difficult to get to, it is worthwhile if you are a lover of mosaic art.

Gentle and poetic. in the midst of heavily populated area The Chora Church is hidden as surprise. Kind bus driver helped me to find the museum with beautiful Byzantine mosaics and I was sorry that the central part was under reconstruction. Fragile colors and shapes, nice gift shop, excellent restoration with Trip Advisory mark, everything was really in the mood for art. Blue and gold, silver and red, fire and death, sorrow and pain, all these were on the mosaics which I hesitated to visit two times before when I was in Istanbul. But they are really the prize for the beauty lovers.

Being restored but still worth a visit. There was quite a bit of renovation going on in the nave of the church when we visited at the end of October 2015 and we couldn't get in to see it, the outside if the church was also being renovated. We were still able to see the very impressive mosaics in the inner and outer narthex, though our visit was quite short- it took us longer to get there than we spent in the actual church. The museum isn't well signposted and is a bit off the beaten track- we got a taxi there and followed the old city walls back to the Topkapi metro station (though we wouldn't recommend this at night!). We'd love to visit again when the restoration is complete.
great for church lovers. a lot of it is under restoration, but still good if you have time to kill in Istanbul, has plenty of things to see inside
Under construction. Beautyful mosaics and really something special but the church part is closed now and also the outside facades and even roof is hidden because of constructions

Interesting, worth a visit!. This was my first visit to the Chora Church. It was difficult to visit, via the tram service, from my hotel but the friendliness of a local couple in providing final directions from the tram stop to the Church was warmly appreciated. Unfortunately, the Church was undergoing extensive restoration when we visited and so we were unable to appreciate the exterior and much of the interior. However, what can be seen was interesting. Worth another visit when the restoration is completed.
forget Aga sophia. this treasure of history not only has an amazing cherished history but its director will make anyone a believer..

Small - lovely but not much currently available to see. Like many of the older former churches tuned into mosques, now museums - this small church is undergoing renovations so that the dome and apse are currently closed. The mosaics that are viewable are lovely but small. There are the obligatory souvenir shops and a cafe outside. This church is not tram accessible - we took bus (thanks to great directions from hotel desk staff ) and found easily, cabs would work too. I would put it on a secondary list - worth seeing but there is so much to see of this amazing city, if you don't get there, don't feel bad.

Beautiful mosaics are one of Istanbul’s highlights. Located some distance from the city’s historic centre, the Church of St Saviour in Chora is definitely worth visiting (even though it is undergoing extensive renovation as of late 2015 with the exterior covered in scaffolding and some parts of the interior are closed). The mosaics and paintings on the walls and ceilings of the church are magnificent. They are the best of their kind in the city and should not be missed. Photography without flash is permitted inside.
Stunning place. Chora Church Museum shows stunning Byzantine mosaics. Full of history and beautiful art. Outside of the tourist area but worth a visit. Entrance and audio tour for 30TL (£7)
Most beautiful church. This was a last minute recommendation and was truly worth the visit. Small church with beautiful paintings.

Very well preserved mosaics and frescoes. This is a beautiful little church with some incredibly well preserved mosaics and frescoes depicting the life of the Virgin Mary, Jesus' life and the various miracles, etc. Parts were closed due to renovation, but still a magnificent church and well worth a visit.

Most amazing mosaics. It is probably best to take the taxi to the Church of St Saviour in Chora. It would be a considerable walk from the Galata bridge which would be an option if one wants to visits the sights on the way and back. During our visit in September the Naos (main church) was closed for restoration. However it is said that the most spectacular mosaics and frescos are in the outer and inner narthex and side church. We cannot confirm that statement, but it is true that the mosaics are wonderful and in very good condition and there are many of them. Most of them are complete. The frescos in the side church are less spectacular but lovely, too. I would rate the mosaics higher than the ones of Hagia Sophia, so try to make the detour and verify for yourself.

Magnificent church with well preserved frescos. I actually walked to the church from my hotel in Sultanahmet. Fantastic church! Amazing! magnificently preserved frescos. Don't think even twice: VISIT it!!!!! It's a must in Istanbul. From the church I walked back through the narrow streets and visited another couple of churches on my way. BTW, the hotel next door to it will give a password from their wifi so that you could download your google map. ))))

The frescoes and mosaics are great as is this old church that is now a museum. This old church is now a museum and has many terrific old frescoes and mosaics that adorn the walls and ceilings. Yes, part was closed when we were there but what was open was great by itself. We were very pleased that we visited it. Although some people took a taxi you can get within two blocks of it by local bus from the ferry docks along the Golden Horn. It's located in a neighborhood and not close to any other famous sites. There is a charge but it is included as part of the museum pass so we were glad we had purchased it.

The most amazing frescoes. Do take a guide for unless you are a history buff you may not understand any of the frescoes. There amazing scenes of Mother Mary's life. When we went some sections were closed for renovation.
Beautiful church. This was a last minute recommendation and I am very glad I did it. Most beatiful paintaings on the inside. Well werth visiting.

Long walk in rain and then church was closed!. It is quite a long walk uphill to church from Golden Horn ferry stop and not clearly signposted. Main body of church is closed for restoration but fortunately many of the best mosaics are in the areas still open

The unexpected highlight of our visit. This ancient intimate church has spectacular primitive Christian golden mosaics that meant far more to us than the Hagia Sophia, which is cluttered, and is essentially an ex-mosque.

Stunning mosaics well worth the trip. We took a taxi to visit this attraction. It was worth every penny! Free entry with Istanbul museum card. There was work being done so could not see everywhere. It is small and we were caught with several groups of tourists but did mean we got a bit of the tour too!

Worth a visit but under repair in Oct/Nov 2015. Iconic, spectacular murals and mosaic's - tough to get to, relatively speaking - take the Bus 38. When you're there be prepared for a small but beautiful structure with special icons and historical significance.
Small but beautiful church. Small but beautiful church. It had some fine mosaics and frescos. Part of the church was under restoration.

One of The most beautiful bizantine churchs in the world. Bizantine art is here at his most incredible intellectual, theological and artistic level. As an example, at the entrance (exonarthex), a christ pantocrator, with the definition of "christos o chora", and on the opposite a "Maria o. .chora.." (Mary the container", with a game of word on chora (in the field) and chora, philosophical word of space.A great anastasis (resurrection)

Well worth the trip. The Kariye museum is someway out, away from the main tourist spots- combining it with a wander along the Theodosian walls and a ferry trip, back along the Golden Horn made for a brilliant morning's site-seeing.First the journey there: you'll need a map (the hotel provided us with an adequate one)- we got the tram and then the metro to Topkapi (which refers to one of the gates in the old town walls-not the palace)- this deposits you right by the walls. We then wandered along (sometimes inside, sometimes outside, and sometimes on the city walls) travelling northwards. There are signs at the next big gap in the walls (at Fevzi Pasha c) that direct you to the museum.The museum itself is simply stunning- an amazing array of mosaics, interspersed with some fine frescoes- it'll take a good hour to take it all in. Our guide book was fabulous for deciphering the images ( some are not common in Western churches). There are a load of cafes with terrac seating if you fancy a break.Next we made our way down to the Golden Horn- this is where we did get a bit lost (only for a few minutes)- Don't follow the line of the walls all the way- head East to avoid the dead end that we ended up in ! We then caught the ferry down the Golden Horn from Ayvansaray- it runs on the same payment system as the Metro and tram. Boats leave Ayvansaray at 40 minutes past the hour and take 30 mins to go back to Karakoy ( where we got the tram back to Sultanahmet. We had a great morning and would fully recommend this little itinerary.

Incredible painting and mosaics. If you like Giotto's Arena Chapel, this is its Istanbul counterpart. Amazing frescoes and mosaics from the same era in the Byzantine style. Just a small jewel a bit away from the Sultanahmet bustle. Worth the cab ride. the restaurant across from it is a nice place to grab a snack or lunch. The museum store has many books, which I wish I had cased more completely.

Not easy to find but worth it!. This is a very old church which goes back to Roman times. It is currently under restoration so I was somewhat disappointed to find part of it restricted and it's outside edifice was shrouded so you couldn't see it. Nonetheless, the mosaics inside were well worth the effort to get there. I suggest you brush up on the facts before you get there because even with the audio guide, I found it a little hard to follow in some places. I noticed most people were with a guide so that might be the easiest way--I was alone. It is located at the top of a steep hill in a very old part of the city. Don't be daunted, however, because I believe some of the mosaics are very unique in their representations.

Fascinating murals off the beaten track. This is outside of the central area of Istanbul, but worth finding. There are lots of very well preserved and interesting mosaics to be seen. You can take all the time you need to enjoy this extensive collection of religious mosaics. Take lots of photos and enjoy these very rare pieces of history.
Nice. It is a very nice church full of mosaics. Unfortunately at the time of my visit, most of it was under renovation so I couldn't really enjoy everything there is to enjoy there.

Gorgeous mosaics, but open up the main church already!. It was well worth the trek to see these stellar mosaics, but a little disappointing to find the main area of the church was closed to visitors for renovations. This was a recurring theme throughout Istanbul (sections of Topkapi, the Archeological Museum, several smaller sites just east from the Kariye church) and very frustrating. What was available to see was impressive, but the lack of access is disappointing.

if you have a little extra time, 2nd day, see this site. v near the city wall this site is difficult to get to on public transit so arrive by cab. it is a jewel box and gets crowed early. a guide will really enhance your understanding of the site and an hr is more than enough time for a visit

Not To Be Missed…But Under Renovation.. This is a bit out of the way from the main part of Istanbul, but it can be reached by public transportation; we used taxis and that is what we would recommend. It is now just a museum and located in a residential area. The taxi had to drop us off about 1-2 blocks from it; the bus stop was further away. Extensive renovations are under way and are expected to last until 2016 sometime. They seem to charge the full admission charge even though about half the facility was closed to the public because of renovations- however, according to the guide book , more than 90% of the viewable works of art were in the section that was still open. The art expert in our group found this to be one of the best collections she had ever seen. Hint: they seem to regularly have a problem with their credit card machine, so bring a lot of cash...or be prepared for about a 20 minute walk (round trip) up and down a steep hill, with few sidewalks, to the nearest cash machine. The guide books(for a price) which are available here are excellent…albeit written in questionable English. Highly recommended

A must see for the beauty of the mosaics and religious symbolism. Chora Church has some of the most beautiful and accessible religious mosaics in Turkey. For full impact, you'll want to go with a guide or a guidebook to highlight the significance and order of the pictures. The whole church tells a story, which flows from the walls to the ceiling and back. Our guide was able to point out the story of Mother Mary from the time she was a young girl, for instance, and how the upbringing depicted on the walls tied with both ancient prophesies as well as nods to modern realities (for instance, why there was a baker/wheat in one picture - as much to do with taxes as anything else, in the eyes of some scholars!). Bring a camera with a zoom, or opera glasses. You can take pictures (no flash), but what you'll really appreciate is the ability to zoom in and see the incredible detail of the individual mosaic tiles. Your smart phone will take great photos but what you really want to do is pan around live and get a sense of the story, as well as the details.Go early if you can. The church fills with waves of guided tours. Ours stayed for three or four hours ... others duck in for an hour. Plan a neck massage afterwards since you will be spending a lot of time looking up!

Not easy to find .. .but well worth the effort!. This is one of the most amazing sites we saw in Istanbul. We went with a guide who explained the stories behind each of the ceiling paintings .. .and there were stories there that I had never heard before. The paintings are gorgeous. There were not a lot of crowds there (probably because it is off the beaten track). It did not take a long time to visit .. . but go . . . it is worth it!
Hidden Church. Beautiful and awesome So glad my private tour guide suggested this must see sight . The church was crowded but the holy space was quite

Gem of a small church with incredible mosaics. Spent about 40 minutes in this little gem admiring the amazing wall and ceiling mosaics depicting the life of Mary, the life of Christ etc. Stunning mosaics in a small out of the way church.

The magnificent Byzantine art!. If you love history, if you are inerested in arts, if you like history of religions, go to the "Holy Saviour in the Country" church, the "Hora Church". Yoy can admire the marvellous mosaics and frescos of the Byzantine era. But, please, before you go there, "google" it and read about the Byzantine civilization and Byzantine art. Read about the history and the glory of Eastern Roman Empire and the spirituality of Eastern Orthodox Christian Church. You can complete your knowledge and admiration, later on, when you go to the marvellous Hagia Sofia Church.

What a treasure!. When we went, the main area was closed for restorations. But the other areas open for viewing are as exciting to see for someone who is so interested in very beautiful historic mosaic works. It is a very beautiful Byzantine church and is like a time capsule in itself. Getting to this part of the city is easy enough by public transport and is really worth the trip.

What a treat!. This Byzantine church is so unique and well preserved considering. Finding and getting to this church by public transport is easy enough and is worth the trip. When we went, the main area was closed for restorations, but there is still quite to see in the areas that are open still. The mosaics are a treasure to see.

Great mosaics. While the church has some remarkably well preserved mosaics (probably the best we saw), the main body was closed for renovations. this was very disappointing after a 90tl taxi ride to get there. Investigate the buses if you chose to go, a we got back to the city very quickly and cheaply that way.

Amazing Mosaics. This small church is a bit out of the way from the main tourists areas of Istanbul but is well worth taking time to visit. The mosaics have been kept intact and are outstanding. There are also interesting frescos here as well.

stunning / Beautiful mosaics.... This museum is a bit away from the historic district...but totally worth the trek...the mosaics are really beautifully done and preserved. I went just around sunset time.. less crowded and the mosaics reflected the sunlight...divine! The main part of the church was closed for renovation...but what was available to see...was good!
Beautiful mosaics. This church is really unique and worth the visit. Be aware that most of it is closed right now for conservation.

Exquisite Mosaics. An inexpensive taxi ride from the Sultanahmet district, the Chora Museum is located just inside the ancient city walls. After the conquest of Constantinople in 1453, its mosaics were covered with plaster, only to be revealed in 1948, nearly half a millennium later. The building itself is now being restored and is completely concealed by scaffolding and plastic. Inside, too, the Naos is closed. But the beautiful mosaics still to be seen are worth the journey.

Fantastic byzantine mosaics. This Church is a gem of byzantine mosaic art, don't miss it. It is somehow out of the way from the Sultanahmet area but take a taxi and go, well worth the visit. Please note it is under constant renovation for the next 2 years.

Close up look at all the detailed work.. It’s a bit of a hike to this church from our hotel, so we took a cab there, visited the church and after had lunch at Asitane Restaurant then walked to the river and took a ferry back to Sultanahmet. The main part of the church is closed for restoration but the many mosaics in the front and side of the church are open to the public.

Beautiful Byzantine mosaics. this beautiful small church is well worthwhile visiting. The Byzantine mosaics are very impressive, depicting many biblical scenes, including the life and times of Mary's parents. Unfortunately when I visited scaffolding obscured the outside, but the story boards on the scaffolding were very good, providing information about the history of the church and photos of what it looked like. You can Use the Museum Pass. I took a taxi to get here from Sultanahmet area, based on previous posts. There are also cafes and shops close by. Also can see more of the city walls close by If getting a bus back don't confuse Topkapi suburb with Topkapi palace as I did.

Great Byzantine Mosaics!. This is where you will see the best byzantine mosaics in Istanbul. Taking a taxi to go to this Church is well worth it, don't miss it. Under restoration for at least another 2 years, so do not expect to see all of it
A special church often missed. The mosaics and art in this small jewel box was a treat. Our guide Emre was so informative and made thei visit so special!

Biblical stories in mosaic. Another very pretty attraction for Istanbul. It is not clearly signposted from the tram station so remember to refer to it by its local name - Kariye if asking for directions.The Asitane Restaurant is nearby but was not open at 11.30 am. They appear to open at 12.30 am.

Wonderful mosaics. Any visit, short or long, should include Chora on the itinerary. The mosaics are to die for so splendid are they. Chora is a stone's throw away from Mihrimah Sultan mosque, also worth a visit. Just cross the road by the car park and there are steps leading down an embankment then turn left and it's no more than 200m. Some of the best religious mosaics I have ever seen.

Lovely, but some parts closed. Nice mosaics at this church. Unfortunately, part was closed for restoration, so there wasn't much to see. Since it's a good sized hike uphill from the ferry, it was a bit disappointing. The path to the church is not well marked. We used our museum pass for entry. There is a cafe and some shopping right next door.

Breathtaking Mosaics & Frescoes... Completely Awe-Inspiring...Be sure to see this!. We visited Chora Church as part of a tour in September. From the moment we first entered the church, we were completely awed and speechless by the richness and beauty of the marbled walls, the artfully crafted dome ceilings and archways and the intricately adorned mosaics on the upper walls and ceilings. The current church was built about 1100AD after an earthquake damaged the original. Then the church was damaged by Crusaders in the 1200's. In the early 1300's, the Byzantine prime minister, Theordore Metochites, oversaw the church's reconstruction. In the early 16th century, the Ottoman Empire converted it into a mosque. The frescoes and mosaics were whitewashed over and remained hidden from daylight until the late 1940's when they were rediscovered and restored. The mosaics and frescoes are the most beautiful examples dating from the last period of Byzantine painting (14th century). When we visited the church, the Central Nave and Apse were closed for renovation. However, we were able to visit the three other sections of the church: Outer Narthex, Inner Narthex and the Parekklesion (side chapel). Begin your tour in the Outer Narthex, then the Inner Narthex and end in the Parekklesion. Inside the Narthex sections are richly adorned mosaics all across the walls and ceilings, depicting different stories in the bible. Advice: It's a good idea to have a guide or have a book to help you with an explanation of each mosaic. Rick Steves 's Istanbul book is a good one. The Perekklesion section was the mortuary chamber for Theodore Metochites and his family and is completely decorated with frescoes. Many of the frescoes depict the afterlife and salvation. Unlike other Byzantine churches where the dead were buried under the ground, instead they were laid to rest in the built in niches of the Perekklesion. Some of the frescoes are faded but it is easy to imagine just how striking and brilliant they would have been in their day.PLEASE see this church during your visit to Istanbul...You will NOT be disappointed. It is not located right in the heart of old town but you can take a taxi ride which is not expensive and totally worth every penny.
Impressive Mosaic. We had no idea that we would see such impressive mosaics! These and the history at this site gave us more insight in to the religious history than sites in Italy.

A Former Byzantine Church/Monastery with Perserved Mosaics. The mosaics of this once Byzantine Church are probably the most remarkable in what is today Turkey. Take the tour and you will not be sorry!
Try the bus. Most people get a taxi but a just ask a local which bus and it will take you within 200m. The people are so friendly and helpful you will have no problem...

One of our surprise favourite day trips. The unbelievably underrated and sublimely beautiful Chora church was a highlight of one of our last days in Istanbul. Even though most of it was closed off for restoration, the inner and outer narthex were open. The detail in the ancient mosaic and fresco artwork is jaw-dropping and the sense of the divine is palpable. My husband and I had the same reaction to this mini masterpiece in a city of stunning historical architecture - stunned silence. We couldn't wipe the smiles off our faces when we left. Highest recommendation.
beutiful orthodox paintings. a little bit off the normal tourist track but hard to miss as the tourist busses lead the way. Amazing frescos

The mosaics are stunning. It's worth a trek over to The Chora Church. (Take tram to Topkapi station, then metro east, 3 stops, to the church.) In October 2015 only the narthex was open. The rest of the church was under renovation. The area you see is small, but it's worth seeing if you have the time. The mosaics are amazingly complete and some of the frescos are stunning. There's low light, so be prepared when taking photos. My husband took great shots of the ceiling by putting the camera on the floor. Worked well. You will be in and out of this place in about 1/2 hour. There is a restaurant next door (didn't try it) and vendors are selling crafts around the church.

Amazing but get there before 11am. The Chora Church is located in the conservative Fatih neighborhood far from the main historical sites of Istanbul. It can be done walking but it takes a good hour, a good map, and a good pair of legs. The church is truly incredible as it has incredible mosaics that have remained mostly unscathed, retracing the life of the Virgin Mary. As it is quite a small church, I strongly recommend to try and get there before all the tour groups arrive, which is around 11am. After that, you will not be able to hear yourself think as it is quite small and you won't be able to take good photographs either.An absolute must otherwise.
A marvellous Museum. Make time to go to this church it has some of the best byzantium mozaics in the world. Note it is shut on Wednesdays

Great mosaics - location is a haven. Be warned in Oct 2015 the church is shrouded in scaffolding and the Naos (nave - central area) is closed for renovation. However, the other mosaics and frescoes are able to be seen. You'll get a crick in your neck, and be advised to take binoculars or a telephoto lens to see the detail - but well worth it. Church is by a lovely tree-shaded square with restaurant. Get tram to Topkapi station and change for Edirnekapi. The church is five minutes walk from Edirnekapi tram station... no signage at the station so turn leftish at the station exit and aim for the gap in the city walls... then go straight ahead and bear left (signs start to appear).The interchange at Topkapi tram station is a relevation - green belt - and you get to see a lot of the Theodosian walls on the journey.
Find it, you really should. It requires some steps to go there, but you should, it's very picturesque inside, I went there only on my 3rd visit but you should on the 1st.
Getting there is not easy but you should. This is not on the usual tourist roads, but you should care to go there, and to see it inside not just outside.

A haven. A bit of a trek by tram and no signage at the Edirnekapi tram stop (but a five minute walk if you don't get lost). Beautiful, peaceful situation with a tree-shaded square, and restaurant, outside. Mosaics great, but Naos (centre nave) of church is closed off at the moment for restoration and church is shrouded in scaffolding. I bought the book so I can enjoy the detail of the mosaics at home ...viewing them in the church involves a lot of neck-craning - it's probably worth having binoculars or a telephoto lens.

Stunning frescoes that have survived teh centuries. The bulk of this ancient church is now roofed over for protection, and the works of restoration have revealed spectacular frescoes of bible stories and the life of Christ and the Virgin Mary, amny in excellent condition.
Christian church. It is a christian church, being a catholic, I appreciated the tour.As a cutlural value, it doesn't bring too much value.All the best.

Amazing Mosaics. The church is just newly renovated, so most of the mosaics are now in a fantastic preserved/restaurated state. While the church itself is small if compared to Hagia Sophia, the mosaics themselves are of better quality. In one of the side chapels you can also find well conserved mural paintings

The Best!. Wow. This museum was the highlight of my visit to Istanbul. The mosaics and frescos were awesome! This church was away from the more busy tourist locations but because of this there were no crowds. We were able to take our time and really look at the beauty of this church and read about its history. If I had to suggest just one thing to see in Istanbul, the Kariye Church would be my recommendation.

Most interesting Byzantine monument. It is the most beautiful Byzantine church that you can visit in old Istanbul, just outside the city's walls. With excellent mosaics and frescoes, a place to "feel" the glory of Costantinople of the past.

Byzantine mosaics abound. This place was the first example of old mosaic work and 1000 year structures we visited in Istanbul - we were very impressed. It was fairly hard to find with no signposts easily recognizable. Even asking directions proved unhelpful - so I would suggest working out your route here very carefully. At the time of our visit only a small portion of the museum was available for visit so a little disappointing. If you only have a small window of time in Istanbul I would consider giving this a miss as there are numerous other mosques and buildings that have equally impressive mosaics.

A must-do when in Istanbul. This small museum is well worth the crick in the neck you will get from staring at the ceiling and walls for two hours. The most breathtaking mosaic work and frescoes I have ever seen in a lifetime of visiting amazing places. This musuem also holds the distinction of having one of the most comprehensive representations of the life of the Virgin Mary to be found anywhere. You will not regret this. Just go!

Compact site is packed with religious art. The mosaics and frescos at Chora Church are impressive and the stories that they tell are different from the bible stories many are familiar with from childhood. Currently the exterior is mostly covered and some major artwork is under renovation. The scale of the site is fairly small, but it contains a remarkable amount of artwork.

Major restoration work. When I saw pictures of this church the first thought that came to my mind was that it was an interesting looking structure. Unfortunately when we got there we found the whole church covered in tin roofing and scaffolding for major restoration work.The church is now a museum of it's beautiful mosaics, Kariye Museum (reviewed separately). The mosaics are beautiful.

Beautiful mosaics. The Church of St Saviour in Chora was built outside the original walls of the city of Constantinople in the 11th century. In the 14th century many mosaics were created in the church. These mosaics mainly depict the lives of the Virgin Mary and infant Jesus, and Jesus in his later years.We went to the church the day we arrived in Istanbul. It is on the western side of the old city. Unfortunately the complete exterior of the church is covered with tin roofing and scaffolding due to restoration work. Even inside some areas are closed. For the areas that are closed pictures of those mosaics with explanatory text are displayed outside the church.The mosaics on the arches, walls, ceiling and domes are beautiful. Some of them in relatively better condition some almost fallen off. They have an audio guide facility. Each mosaic is numbered and by pressing on that number on your audio guide you can listen to the description of that particular mosaic.There is a souvenir shop inside the church and some outside as well.

Simply stunning.. First visited this church in 1970. It has never ceased to enthral me on every visit ever since. If you want to get a glimpse back at Byzantium pre-1453, this is where you must go. The mosaics will also take your breath away. There are several genuine guides there, who will show you round for a gratuity. Be generous! You can get there by 28 Edirnekapi bus from Besiktas or Eminonu.

Worth going out of your way to visit. Although restoration meant that a large section of this Church was closed off, the visible frescoes and mosaics are stunning. It's a bit out of the way, but definitely worth the trip

In Restoration . Unfortunately this beautiful church is under restoration (according to one of the employees this process will take 2 more years), which is why only 30% of the church is open to the public. I advise to go only if you have a museum card.

Worth a visit. Not in the main historical center but easy to access via Metro. Stunning mosaics not to be missed if you have the time. We viewed with a guide and understanding the nuances of the mosaics made it worth the extra cost.

the main body ofr the church is under repair and is closed but they still charge full price. the gift shop is expensive yet have very nice things the mosaics are to die for so old so beautiful the stories told of the mosaics tell a different story of the mary and joseph story they portray joseph as a widower with three sons and tell how he vied for marys hand in marriage it is just so beautiful and the stories that are told are different and unusual the rest. across the street is decent with turkish food say some food for the local cats also you can catch a cab back do not pay 40 liras 20 to 30 is more like it or you can walk about 4 blocks an get a bus you have to see it
Beautiful. Currently only the outer rooms are available but they have amazing frescoes and mosaics. Well worth a wander around this area.

Great mosaics, little explanation . I would expect a church (or any museum like place) which charges 15 lira entrance fee to provide some basic reading material or explanation of the stuff inside... there is an option to rent an audio guide which I decided not to go for. A mistake in hindsight... there is absolutely no explanation to any of the amazing mosaics or frescoes in church which was a pity. Overall still worth a visit but keep a book or an audio guide with you.

Do not miss. It's a bit out of the main sites. But this is one of the most magnificent and historically important churches we have visited. Entry is quite inexpensive, but the experience is tremendous. You can easily get there using the metro system.

Lovely Church with beautiful mosaic work. 1) Little outside the Sultanahmet area. Cost about 35TL by taxi from Sultanahmet.
2) Currently (Oct-2015), renovation is on-going, so you wont be able to see half of it.
3) Beautiful Mosaic work on walls and ceilings.
4) Consider spending about 30 mins to an hour.
5) Audio guide is a little steep but worth it.

Spectacular mosaics. This church is not as accessible as sights in the Sultanahmet but it is definitely worth a visit. The mosaics are exquisite and amongst the most beautiful of any in the Istanbul sites. As the church dates from the early 1300s, the beauty and craftsmanship make them that much more special.

Interesting but hard to get to on your own.. I took the metro and then walked from there. It is a bit of a walk, and didnt have GPS so took me some time to find it. Also an uphill walk from getting off the metro on a hot day. Very interesting are old city walls. You can climb up on them too. The mosaics and paintings on the walls are really really old. I didnt take a tour as the place was under renovation and part of it was closed off. So there were lots of people in a small place and other tours were going on in various languages and I could hear a little of this and that from them. I guess these are from the 1300s or maybe a bit older. There are many tourist shops out front too, some with some interesting stuff. I also liked the old Turkish wooden houses in the area out front. These are real houses still lived in. If you have the museum pass, the 5 day pass, this is one of the included places.

Must visit. Many Istanbul visitors skips this church, mainly because it’s a little far from the center and the main attractions. But try to visit this church and considering it as one of the main attractions. In fact it is. The byzantine paintings of this small church are the best of the whole city. Hire a guide as there is a lot of information not to miss in each of the paintings.
Chora Museum. Amazing artwork but not a place to visit at the moment as its being renovated. Once this is done, I am sure it will be well worth a visit.
Fascinating. A wonderful old church which is now a museum and literally packed with frescos of the saints and New Testament stories. Frescos are wonderfully preserved and have vibrant colours

must see attraction. Awesome. If you like Byzantine afrescos and mosaics, this is the place. It's a small building but erery wall and ceiling is covered with images of Jesus, Mary and imporatnt Gospel narratives
incredible mosaics. The mosaics are fantastic, and well preserved. Don't miss this little church!! Hope more of it will be open soon. go early long lines but worth it!!!

Beautiful Byzantine Church in Istanbul. Saint Savior Church in Chora was built in the 5th century outside the walls of Constantinople. The building divides into three main areas: the entrance hall or narthex, the main body of the church or naos, and the side chapel or parecclesion. The building has six domes: two in the esonarthex, one in the parecclesion and three in the naos. This church has excellent examples of Byzantine mosaics and frescos that can be photographed.

Historical, beautiful Catholic Church, to Wall > Gold Horn > Eminonu. Could see historical fresco which has original color and picture. Beautiful itself.Not easy go to and back from Kariye. Edimekapi station (from Topaki, or walk from Topaki to Kariye along side with Wall) to Kariye by walk, after that visit to Surlar which is a part of local people's residential area not feel like travel area. I went to down and down with wall and finally could arrive Golden Horn and found a port "Ayvansaray' which could take a ferryboat to Eminonu and Karakoy. Port was beautiful and peaceful place of Istanbul.

A highlight of our trip. It's quite small, it's some way out of the centre, but this church turned museum was very high on the list of great things in Istanbul. The fairly well preserved mosaics, telling the story of Mary, and the frescoes are just stunning. Sadly, the centre of the church is currently closed for restoration, but it doesn't detract from the experience.We had a guide to explain the art, which was well worth the money, though I gather the audioguide is good too.It's included on the Museumcard, though rarely has queues.Reaching it is possible on public transport (e.g. using the metro/light railway), and gives you a walk near the land walls and through an interesting district of the city. A taxi wouldn't be too expensive and, if you do a deal, will wait and take you back or elsewhere.The large café/restaurant just outside is good and not overpriced.
Nice Church. At the moment of our visit, the part of the temple was in restoration process. Didn't have a chance to see it all. Worth the visit.
Kariye Museum. Lovely museum featuring ancient mosaics. The highlight was the story of Mary told through various mosaics.

Fabulous. I visited this place during a one week stay in istanbul. This church has some of the best mosaiques in town. Need to buy audio guide otherwise difficult to understand. Also brought monoscope to view ceiling mosaiques which was a good idea. Parts of the church currently closed for conservation but that doesnt matter as all important works accessible. A must if you are into history and art. Half an hour bus ride from Eminonu bus terminal. Taxi back into town.

Excellent Mosaics. A little out of the way, but if you have any interest in Byzantine history, it is well worth a visit. While many of the old Byzantine churches have lost most of their mosaics, the ones here are plentiful and are still in excellent condition.

A little wonder.. This church was unfortunately undergoing restoration when I visited, which meant the main body of the church was closed. It is still very much worth a visit, however, as the mosaics are spectacular and the frescoes are also wonderful.This church has the only representations of the life of the Virgin Mary as told in the Apocrypha in the world. It is about a fifteen minute walk from Ayvansaray pier, if you don't get lost, which I did (this is quite easy to do).It is covered by the Istanbul Museum Card. The audio tour is good. It should be noted that everywhere in Istanbul you have to leave a form of ID to get an audio guide to prevent you wandering off home with it.

Fantastic BUT about half closed under renovation and hassle to get to. The mosaics are incredible -- at least the ones you can see. If you have the museum card, I'd recommend going even with the difficult location. If you don't have a museum card, consider the hassle getting there plus the price of the ticket plus audio guide. (You need the audio guide as the labels are almost useless.)You can get there via the bus system if you are good at using it. Otherwise, you'll need to take a cab. While the cab ride from the Sultanahmet might cost you only 25 lira, the cabs on the way back will cost double that. Why? There are few of them near the church and they know it. Also, they'll want to take the long (and faster) route via the "seaside." In sum, I can't remember the ticket price but let's estimate: For two people: 25 lira cab ride; 2 entrance tix = 60 lira; 2 audio guides = 40 lira; postcards or trinkets = 20 lira; 2 cokes at cafe next to museum; 50 lira cab ride back to old city. Total approx 210 lira or $70 at present exchange rate or $35 a piece. Whether it is worth the money (and the time in transit) is up to you.

Beautiful frescoes. It is highly recommended to visit Chora church. It still contains beautiful frescoes and my favorite is with Byzantine emperor and Mongol princess offering earthy kingdoms to Jesus.

Incredible and detailed technique. A spectacular beautiful church located at Edirne area, that is now under restoration. The interior of the building is covered with gold mosaics and frescoes by the Byzantine-era, which represent all the significant religious events!

Iconic. The place holds unprecedented early christian mosaics and frescoes. The technique of mosaics is marvelous, the pieces are very small and placed in harmony.
There are for sure not too many places where you can see iconic pieces of such beauty and and age.
Must visit.

Significant restoration and limited areas to visit. The church is undergoing significant restoration at the moment, so in September 2015 we could not see the main interior of the church or any of the exterior. Two side hallways were open with gorgeous mosaics, but I wish we had at least been able to look through to the main portion of the church or had been told beforehand that restoration was going on.
Wonderful mosaics and frescoes. We loved this Church -- not crowded and an excellent explanation of the various biblical scenes in Rick Steves' guidebook.

What an unexpected surprise. This was one of our favorite attractions in Istanbul, a very unexpected surprise. Some reviews gave a tram stop, which we found to be incorrect. Take a cab, it's less than $10 from the Old City. The mosaics are amazing. Note that you are seeing just the outer areas as the main chapel is under renovation now. But it is well worth it. Note to avoid the taxis when leaving that are right in front of the Chora as they tried to gouge us on fare. We walked two blocks until another drove by. This church is well worth the cab in both directions though.
amazing mosaics!.... if anything visiting this place is the extrodinary mosaics....could be a challenge to find but once you get there its well worth it...

One of the oldest byztian church in istanbul. One of the best fresques examples that you can see in the museum. And there is tiny cafe shops around it.If you go there lunch time you have to eat Ottoman Sultan foods in Asitane restaurant
Well worth a visit.. Well worth a visit. The mosaic work is of a standard comparable to the ceiling frescoes of the Sistine Chapel

We LOVED this attraction. An amazing surprise. We read several reviews saying what tram station to get off--they were wrong. Just take a cab--it cost less than $10 from the Old City. We put the Chora Church/Museum in the top 2-3 attractions as the byzantine art work was amazing, there are little crowds as it is off the beaten path and you can cruise through the entire site in not much time--note that the main church is being renovated so you are basically walking through two outer areas. One note too: cab drivers parked there try to gouge double for fares back toward Old City. We walked two blocks and cut our fare in half.

Hidden Gem. This site was recommended to us by friends and even though a large part of it was closed off due to restoration work it was still worth the trip. A revelation in terms of religious history in Istanbul and simply amazing in the true sense of the word. We took a cab as it would have been impossible via public transport.
Beautiful Painting. Old but the beauty left here is cool. Quite far but still accessible. You have to walk like 5 min from the train station, but for me, worth it!

Chora Church. the mosaics and the restoration are amazing. while under restoration, the Chora Church was an incredible education from the ceilings. We only visited the outer halls and it ws well worthwhile..
Chora Church. Outstanding mosaics from the Byzantine period. To really enjoy the experience, try to go during an off-peak period. Once the tour buses pull up, it gets crowded very fast.
One of the best attractions in Istanbul.. This church is dedicated to the story of Mary. The mosaics and frescos tell the stories of the Bible. Take the ferry for a beautiful ride up the Golden Horn.

Wonderful place. Wonderful place. I had great difficulty finding it, and in the end gave up and got a taxi. Currently being restored but still lots worth seeing. Many excellent Byzantine mosaics which photographed really well even with my modest camera. Got there late morning and was closed until 1 so went in the adjacent cafe/ returns not which was very nice and good value. Beware of thieves in this area. A guy asked if he could clean my shoes, did so and then asked for 50 Turkish Lira, which I wasn't going to give, but he helped himself from my wallet!

Check to see if the museum is under construction still before you head there. The architecture is supposed to be the main reason why one would visit the Chora church. Just make sure that the construction/restoration work is completed before you head there. When we visited in Sept 2015, the whole thing was under restoration; therefore, not much to see. However, there is a restaurant serving Ottoman food (which is very different from modern Turkish food) just around the church that's worth your visit!

Boy do you need a guide..... This is the most amazing church. I liked it better than the Hagia Sofia!! It is dedicated to the early life of Mary, plus Jesus' miracles and his temptations. But the best way to see this is with a guide (or guidebook) that REALLY explains the place. I could have spent another 3 hours here, but then my minor in colle was Archaeology and Biblical Studies. I personally felt this was a treasure.

Not much to see, but what there is is prime. The main part of the church is still not open to the public, but we were able to see three relatively small sections which contain beautiful mosaics and frescos, making the longish journey by tram from Sultanahmet worthwhile. To get there take the T1 tram from the Sultanahmet stop to the Topkapi stop, then change to the T4 line to Edirnekapi Metro station. There at the exit barriers you will find a small Istanbul Metropolitan Municipality handout showing the walking route to the Kariye Museum. You'll also have an opportunity on your way back from the museum to walk on top of some of the old city walls.

Glorious Mosaics. This is a small church at the old city walls north-west from the old town. Although the nave is under restoration the three corridors that are open provide glorious 11th century mosaics and frescoes showing great expression of human emotions. Best seen over a leisurely hour to fully take in the glory.

Small, but historically important church.. Small, lovely church with beautiful frescoes. It is undergoing some work, but still a lovely example of a Christian church. Its worth having a guide to explain what you are seeing.

before seek to how you get permit to go inside. I really liked this small church.This is a 12th century church with 14th century mosaics which tell the life stories of Jesus and Mary. the ticket cost is 15 tl. I strongly offer you to see it ..you can go there with tram. Edirnekapı is the closest station. The museum is almost 20 minutes far from the station. You can ask anyone, because there wasn't sign to show it and so it was difficult for me to find it.

Nice mosaic museum. The worlds first mosaic museum or mosque nice atmosphere excellent ottoman work location was old town diffucult you can use tram t1 shood be get of topkapı ( have to visit 1453 museum ) after change other tram comes to edirnekapı to walk 10 minutes to here local people was helpful and friendlly you now classic Turkish people give us lokum and turkish coffee

awesome place. I really liked this small church. It is not very touristy and feels more authentic than the sultan ahmet area ... the sanctuary was "under construction" but there was plenty to see outside of it. Cost of entry is 15 lira. tricky to get to using public transportation. Take tram to Edirnekapi stop (orange tram line T4) ... then walk for about 15 mins ... best to ask people there for directions as there are no signs until you are within one block from it. We took a taxi to grand bazaar afterward for 20 liras
Make the trip. Real history. "Church" will sound like a new word to you after being in turkey for some time. But a visit puts everything in perspective

Spectacular mosaics but many in poor condition. This is a 12th century church with 14th century mosaics which tell the life stories of Jesus and Mary. The church is currently undergoing renovation and the nave was closed, but we were able to view the mosaics and frescoes in the inner and outer narthexes. They are very beautiful, despite the wear and tear.This site was very hard for our cab driver to find--make sure you get someone to write down the address and directions in Turkish for you to show to your cabbie.

The best byzantine mosaics in Istanbul.. The best byzantine mosaics in Istanbul. Monks hide them under cover before Ottoman invasion in 1493 so were almost untouched. Very well worth a visit. I strongly suggest after the visit to take a cab and drive side to the ancient walls of Theodosius, down to the Yedikule Castle at the southern end. To appreciate the grandness of old Costantinople. PS the best byzantine mosaics are in Ravenna, Italy.
LOOK UP. Look up , room after room and experience one of the greatest examples of ancient christian fresco's. Be sure to have a guide as they will point out points of interest you would miss.

Lovely, but wasn't worth the hassle. I enjoyed the beautiful mosaics depicting Biblical stories, but the exterior was undergoing major renovation, so I didn't get to enjoy that part of the church. Overshadowing the church's beauty was the fact that I got totally ripped off by my taxi driver. As a single American woman far from the safety of her hotel I did not want to get into an argument with him or accuse him of being a thief. Lesson learned on that. Should have taken the tram from Sultanahmet.

Worth a visit to see the most beautiful mosaics. This church contains the best mosaics I've ever seen and definitely worth a visit. It tells the story of Mary from the Apocrypha which is seldom seen. Audio guide was very good and I recommend it. If you go to this church it's also worth a walk around the streets of Balat which has fewer tourists and give a sense of the local daily life of Istanbul residents.

Main section of church closed under renovation, check to see what is open. My average score is based on the fact that most of the church is under renovation. It would be a 5 star attraction if fully open.I agree with other reviewers that this church is incredible. Even the 1/3 of the mosaics on view are spectacular.HOWEVER, if you pay full price for a ticket, you feel a bit ripped off. Why they don't discount the ticket is beyond me.Also, be aware that this church is not in the main touristic area of the old city, hence you will probably take a taxi to get there. When you finish your shortened visit, the drivers at the church have you at their mercy and will not haggle much on the fare.
No flash photography. The most beautiful examples of Byzantine art adorn the whole of the interior of this masterpiece. Definately not to be missed, the fresoes and mosaics are amazing
