not interesting place. I did not find any attraction at this place. If you are staying for many days then may be you should go there.

Partly closed due to restoration, not as good as Ravenna. Hard to get to & neighborhood is a little dodgy. Excellent Byzantine murals, but not as mind-blowing as Ravenna, Italy. No signs, so you need a guide or guidebook, Inner church closed for restoration.

A fine example of imperial Byzantine mosaics. Within the perimeters of the walled-city of Istanbul, you have this fine little Orthodox church, which has kept intact all of its mosaics and icons. Notwithstanding the fact that this is a small church, it gives you a prime example of what the luxury of old Orthodox churches was like, and you can only imagine the sheer magnificence of Hagia Sophia back in the days. The place is full of mosaics depicting saints and moments in the life of Christ and the church. You can get a very nice tour that introduces the mosaics and puts the Church on its historical context. It is a lovely stop if you are exploring the walls and you can enjoy the fantastic art in a relaxed environment, not so touristic as other parts of old Istanbul.

Beautiful mosaics, but quite pricey for 5 minutes of sightseeing. I was quite dissapointed by this place. The church itself is a very nice and unique, but the main part was under the construction and you still need to pay full ticket (15 TL) to get in and see three small hallways. Yes, they are full of old byzantine mosaics of a great value, but you see it all in less than 5 minutes. Plus there is a big souvenir shop INSIDE the church with a super bored cashier. The church is surrounded by many shops selling beautiful hand-painted tiles, postcards, souvenirs etc and huge terrace of restaurants and cafés like two meters from the entrance to the church. It is quite far away from the city, if you are staying in Sultanahmet and quite a walk distant from the nearest metro station. There are some signs on the streets, but you have to be extra careful not to miss them in order to find your way there. There is a lot to improve I believe, but it was still nice to see it.

Well preserved and beautiful paintings.. Me and my wife are catholic, it was so important for us to see this amazing museum in Istanbul. We were amazed when we see all beautiful freezes and painting. It is definatelly another must see place in Istanbul.

Brilliant mosaics. Well worth the trip!! Absolutely exquisite mosaics. This is one of the most important Byzantine churches that remains intact. It is a long distance away from the center of Istanbul, but a must see monument!

A very different "church" experience. The mosaics were beautiful, but you must either go with a guide or rent the audio guide to appreciate this location. In contract to most churches, the artwork here tells the story of the life of Mary, mother of Jesus - from before her conception to her early childhood and adulthood. I am not Christian but found it fascinating.

Yet another museum under renovation. The main hall is currently under renovatiin (sept 2015), as have been almost all the museums I've visited to one degree or another. The mosaics and paintings on the walls of the entrance to this beautiful byzantine church are really marvellous. Its just not worth the entry fee right now because the main part of the church is closed off for repair and renovation. I went here on my discounted museum pass, which made it fair enough, i suppose, but i simply wouldn't pay a full price single ticket for it in its current state of inaccessibility. Definitely go if you have the museum pass and time on your hands. Take the ferry from Enimonu (and back) for 4TL, each way.

Worth it... even during renovations. The main hall was closed for renovations, but the surrounding rooms and hallways are breathtaking. Even if you are not into 12th century Byzantine mosaics or history, it totally worth your visit. Just to admire this collection of unique Byzantine craftsmanship and the finest artwork. Nowhere else on earth, only found here. Also, just walking two blocks and you can visit the Walls of Constantinople, the old city walls with its ramparts, built between 408–450AD.
Out of the way - go if you have the time. A bit out of the way and most of the museum was under restoration when we went, but unique and interesting enough to make the trip if you have time.

Worth traveling too. Istanbul is like living in a museum many of which are in close proximity to each other. The Chora Church is one of the museums that is a little further away from the others and it is worth the trip.

a must visit church in turkey. Nice experience. Enjoyed walking through old parts of a city. A little bit far from main tourists objects if you have time then must visit this in Istanbul. Amazing architecture

Great mosaics. If you like mosaics and history this is a great place to visit. Some of the best preserved mosaics on the ceiling and walls. You can get some great photos here and the history behind them are really interesting. Not as old as most mosaics in Turkey but still just as amazing.

visual spectacular. One of the best visual treats in istanbul. Its my favorite place to go and I recommend everybody should. Its still under renovatiob so the main room is closed but the 3 areas you have access to are amazing and worth the 15 lira on there own. You can taxi from Taksim for less than 20 lira then walk upto the city walls after visiting the museum then walk down to fener and balat and see the old greek jewish districts
Small but beautiful. This is a relatively small church comparing it to St.Sophia and St.Irene, but the mosaics are undoubtfully marvellous and extraordinary.

Outstanding mosaics. Like almost everywhere else of any age in Istanbul this church is in the throes of restoration but what we were able to see was sublime. The mosaics are extremely beautiful in themselves and with a guide to talk you through the complexities of the way in which their chronology unfolds they really came alive. If you have an interest in early art history the stories around the childhood of the Virgin Mary will already be familiar but otherwise the Apocryphal Gospel of St James is apparently the major reference. We will gladly return to this church whenever we revisit Istanbul but meantime the full guide is a great reminder of its treasures.

nicely preserved church. renovation is ongoing but most of it is completed. fresco in the entrance part are lovely. well preserved and ancient church. worth a visit. There is a great restaurant right next to it called Asitane which makes Ottoman Palace meals. Also the cafe in front of it is a good choice for a quick lunch.

Strengthen Your Neck Muscles Before You Go. The frescoes and mosaics in this old church, hidden away in a far quarter of the city, are simply amazing. Because they are mostly high on the walls and on the ceilings, your neck gets sore from looking up. So, leave plenty of time to rest your neck before returning your gaze upward. It is one of the very best attractions in the city.On a side note, if you are in this neighborhood, stop for lunch at Asitane, a brilliant restaurant literally next door to the Chorra Church

Very interesting mozaics. Very interesting mozaics. It is included in museum card. However - right now more than a half of the church is renovated. Worth to see. P.S. If you go by foot and you will go across Topkapi district - be aware that it's quite a orthodox muslim district.

Outstanding. On my first visit to Istanbul with a Tour Group, there were many attractions I was looking forward to seeing (Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace etc) but - much to my surprise - the Kariye Museum ended up making the biggest impression.It's off the well trodden tourist track (15-30 minute drive - depending on the Istanbul traffic - away from the Blue Mosque/Topkapi Palace area) but - to my mind - should feature on everyone's 'must see' list.Why? Well it is far more compact and doesn't take as much time to see than many of the larger, well-known attractions. The quality of the Byzantine Mosaics are not only amongst the best I have seen but - with the aid of a knowledgable guide - tell a fascinating story.

Amazing mosaics well worth the effort to get there!. The Chora church is about 3km from Sultanahmet we got a taxi there. It is currently having work done on it so we could not go into all areas. The mosaics and frescos are brilliant and on a par with Basilica of St Francis in Assisi

Under renovation but most of it still open,. Don't miss this church which contain a whole depiction of the Bible through brilliant mosaics. It is wonderfully lit and photos without a flash are permitted. There are also some good frescoes there.
Just around the corner is a small wooden house in which a miniature artist sells fine depictions at a reasonable price on antique papers.
Worth a visit. Unfortunately there was quite a lot of this closed off on our visit and scaffolding outside but the entrance and mosaics are worth it. Beautiful.

Equals Aghia Sophia in quality of artwork. Amazing! Masterpiece of orthodox art! It gives contemporary visitor an idea of how the churche's decoration could serve as an illustration of Christian themes for illiterate congregation. The walls really "tell" stories to the faithful. Absolutely breathtaking, magnificent in a now unfriendly part of the city

Worth a visit but check the renovation schedule. The Church of the Holy Savior in Chora (taxis seem to know it better by the sign you'll see on the main street for Kariye Museum) is sadly missed by most visitors as it's not walkable from Sultanahmet but it's well worth the 10-15min taxi ride. The mosaics are beautiful and the church sits near the Golden Horn end of the old defensive walls outside the city, which can be easily combined with the church for a memorable half day.

Very small church.. The church is very small. If you love historical places, it is worth visiting, but otherwise there is not so much to see. I was enjoying walking through old parts of a city... Something unique to experience...

Magical. I have been living in Turkey for 6 months, that is most impressive place i have seen. Many foreigners, even some Turks did not hear of Kariye Church until I ask them but please visit here to witness the beauty of Byzantine mosaics.
Alter is under reconstruction. One of my favorite places in Istanbul but currently under renovation. Its still worth seeing for the great examples of architecture and Byzantine art.

Check to see if the main section (naos) is open. This had wonderful mosaics and history, however the main portion of the museum was closed for renovations, limiting the amount of view-able mosaics to a small number. I just checked the website again and it does not say anything about these renovations.
Nice mosaicos. Now is being restored part of it. Like vey much the mosaicos of this church. The best of Estambul. Also is in a neighboughhod of wooden old houses.A little bit far, but worth

Hidden Gem. Even though it is few miles away from all the famous attractions of Istanbul, a trip to Chora Church is a must. The mosaics are outstanding and depicts the pinnacle of Byzantine craftsmanship. We couldn't see the central part of the church as it was closed for restoration. Don't forget to look at the dome with the depiction of Jesus and his ancestors.

unbelievable, stunning wall painting and mosaics. find time and visit this absolutely stunning church... yes it might take pains to find it as it is located in Fatih, which it is not very popular district of Istanbul among tourist, but still the pleasure you will receive from visiting this stunning place will be unforgettable. it is hard to believe that these masterpieces were created so many centuries ago( the details about the church can be found in the internet).you cannot stay indifferent when looking at these wall paintings or mosaics; you simply feel happy and utterly lucky that you have the chance to see all these... and environment the church stand is another topic - you can relax in the nearby cafe or small restaurant and enjoy the pleasure of encountering with the real art (I mean the church) ...

Charming church. Charming church but a little over-shadowed by the many other architectural super-stars in Istanbul. Some good, very early, murals. Chora means 'in the countryside' as when it was built it was well outside the city.

unforgettable impression. to tell you the truth i don't think that i will manage to express in full extent the impressions that overfilled me when visiting this wonderful place...you can read about historical data in any informational site, but believe me the emotions that capture you when entering the church is simply comparable... you are dumbfounded, you find it difficult to believe that all those frescoes were created so many centuries ago...thanks to God they haven't been ruined and we have pleasure to see them. yes it is quite far but still find time and go there,,,
Must be visited. One of the best places that should be seen. Parking is a problem, so bettervto go with a taxi or city tour.
Chora Church. Well worth the visit, with some amazing Byzantine mosaics. When we were there they were nearing the end of the second restoration.

Beautiful Mosaics but Limited Entry. The glass mosaics in the entryway of this museum are incredible, but unfortunately we were not able to enter the main part of the building due to restoration. Somewhat disappointing. Our guide shared the history of the building and mosaics which was interesting. Glad we went there but wish we could have seen more.

Mosiac Heaven. The extensive mosaics were a pleasant surprise. Beware that the whole church is under renovation and we were able to see only a small area of the church. Even in the small area available, there were some amazing mosaics.

Do not miss this church. This building, former a Byzantine church and later an Ottoman mosque, is located a little far from the most popular attractions of Istanbul, but to me it is a hidden gem and the mosaics and frescos are true masterpieces of Byzantine art. Not so crowded like Haghia Sophia, Sultanahmet Mosque and the Topkapi Palace, it's possible to visit the church and enjoy the mosaics in 30-40 minutes. Ticket price: 15 TL. The Naos of the church, i.e. the main body of the building, was closed (august 2015) due to restoration works.

The one church to visits after Agia Sofia. The church, (museum strictly speaking) with the best frescos and mosaics in Istanbul. The Deisis mosaic of 1261 is unique. Its a smaller version but in a better state than the one in Agia Sofia. Furthermore, in the pronaos Mary and all her grandfathers dating back to king David maybe seen, as all stages of Jesus' life. Currently Chora receives a dome, ie weather cover.

Beautiful mosaics. This church is a real treasure and if you are interested in mosaics abd Christian art you must go and see it. It has some of the most beautiful mosaics I've ever seen. The visit can be combined with a walk through Balat down to the Golden Horn and a ferry ride, beautiful!

Extraordinary mosaics. Part of the adventure was finding it, catching a bus from Eminonu then exploring the old area and stumbling upon the Theodosian walls, before coming to the church itself. The mosaics are staggeringly beautiful, as bright and intricate and affecting today as they were more than a half a millennium ago. It's a beautiful way to access the Byzantine history of Istanbul. A lovely garden too, and a relaxing restaurant.

Beautiful mosaics. Unless you are extremely knowledgeable about the Christian religion, I recommend a guide take you here. The mosaics are detailed and exquisite but I would have been clueless as to the stories they told without someone explaining them to me.
Nice interior. A little bit far from main tourists objects, but you can visit it if you enought time in Istanbul. Nice architecture and interior, paints
Super. Vry interesting place for tourists from Catholic countries and who interesting history or art, nice mosaics and wall paints
nice. small müze you can go there just its hard to find this place and expensive too in istanbul müze all very expensive we really dont like it this...

Life of Mary, Mother of Jesus. This museum is most interesting/fascinating/informative/beautiful (I run out of superlatives). The mosaics and frescoes on the ceilings and walls follow the life of Mary and Jesus. Did you know that Mary came from an affluent family? I took as many or more pictures here than any other site in Istanbul. What a wonderful treasure.

Amazing to see to the Christianity in the past. This church is really historical with nice mosaics. What I really love is its historical atmosphere. One might be able to see how Christianity in the ancient days. Besides the famous Hagia Sophia, this one is a must-visit in Istanbul. Definitely recommended.PS: The only thing that makes me not giving five stars is the renovation blocked many parts of the church during my visit.

Absolutely Exquisite. Do not miss it, and if possible enjoy the knowledgeable guide.. As the taxi drive who brought us here was the worst of all the cheats,the time here was the precise corrective. Your hotel, or guidebook, reports that this church/museum is undergoing renovation. There is still much to be seen ( the guide here is wonderful) and perhaps the most beautiful, intimate place in Istanbul ( in it's own way, like the Brancacci Chapel in Florence, an experience not to be missed).Very different from some of the fancier, flashier places.Do not miss it.

amazing mosaics. one of the less known hidden pearls of Istanbul must see place I love the mosaics and still today doesnt matter how many years passed the colors of the marbles amazed me which are very rare and unique the architecture the art the smartness will amaze you more than todays tech.

Not To Be Missed…But Under Renovation.. This is a bit out of the way from the main part of Istanbul, but it can be reached by public transportation; we used taxis and that is what we would recommend. It is now just a museum and located in a residential area. The taxi had to drop us off about 1-2 blocks from it; the bus stop was further away. Extensive renovations are under way and are expected to last until 2016 sometime. They seem to charge the full admission charge even though about half the facility was closed to the public because of renovations- however, according to the guide book , more than 90% of the viewable works of art were in the section that was still open. The art expert in our group found this to be one of the best collections she had ever seen. Hint: they seem to regularly have a problem with their credit card machine, so bring a lot of cash...or be prepared for about a 20 minute walk (round trip) up and down a steep hill, with few sidewalks, to the nearest cash machine. The guide books(for a price) which are available here are excellent…albeit written in questionable English. Highly recommended

Must see for every person with even a minimal interest in art. Apart from the fact that the central hall is not open for visiting as it is undergoing restoration, you can still see 70 percent of the IMPRESSIVE bizantine mosaics and frescos. This is included in the 5 days Museum Card, and they offer you an audioguide if you're interested.Be warned, the place is not very easy to find, cause the whole temple is under a protective provisional ceiling for restoration of the exterior, so it's very deceptive, and there are no signs until you're there, as usual in Istanbul... Just go with a map and don't walk too far from the Imperial Wall, as this place is pretty close to it.

Chora Museum, a giant picture book in Istanbul.. Chora museum's interior looks like a giant picture book. This feature makes the museum unique in the world. It was aimed to teach religion in public through these mosaics depicting Jesus and Mary’s life when literacy is not widespread among Christians.

Outstanding Byzantine Museum!. Splendid example of Byzantine artwork! Constructed as Chora Monastery outside the Constantine walls (IV century) its original name was Church of the Holy Saviour in the Field, and this is why it is still with this name since "Chora" means countryside. Formerly Ortodox Christian Church, and after a mosque, they covered this incredible mosaics and frescoes with plaster, that, after being transformed into a museum by President Ataturk, they have been under restoration since 1935 up till nowdays. Right at the entrance, these admirable frescoes depicts the life of Virgn Mary and Jesus in a chronological way....sublime work! Certainly very far from the city center, you should take either a guided tour or a taxi to get to this invaluable museum!

Hard to Find. This museum is not easy to find. There are no signs pointing the way after you get off of the tram. The whole outside of the building is buried under scaffolding and parts of the inside are closed to the public. I was glad I had the museum pass as I don't think it would have been worth the money otherwise.

Well worth visiting!. Extremely beautiful mosaics - rent the audio guide. If you have two or more in your party, take a taxi. This church is well worth a visit and there is a pleasant café nearby. You won't find so many tourists here!
Mosaics and more. I didin see something like this before in all christian churchs For me the best mosaics and ruins of history is here
A jewel. This church is really a jewel of Byzantine art. very well preserved and beautiful mosaics. It is located close to the Theodosian wall, so both destinations should be visited together.
A highlight of Istanbul. It's out of the way but was one of the highlights of my visits to Istanbul. Numerous old, beautiful mosaics--and that's even with the main sanctuary being closed for repair.

Excellent Frescos and Mosaics. Getting their on your own takes a bit of planning and execution but even though the main body is being restored I would thoroughly recommend what's left.The main items are on show and are stunning,difficult to interpret so a

Outstanding place!. Beautiful byzantine art in the kayire museum. 70% of art are still good maintain. The visitor will see the nativity art as bible mentioned.
The place is in middle of village at sub urban of istanbul. The visitor need to take train from istanbul and walk about 700 m from closest train station.
Fantastic. Mosaik & Paintting as well. The places is really hard to find but it is really beautifull. Better visite in the evening
Beautiful frescos.. Really neat, beautiful frescos. Helps to have a guide describe the scenes to fully appreciate the experience.
Increadible. If you love art and bysantine art this museum is unmissable. This is the construction in Istambul where I saw the more quantite of bysantine mosaic and affrescos, many of them complete.
Christ the Pantocrator.. Typical Byzantine architecture and stunning religious mosaics, including Christ the Pantocrator and other traditional scenes.
One of oldest churches in town. Must-see cultural heritage of Eastern Christian Byzantine architecture. The remaining mosaics are just stunning!

Restoration at the moment. Too bad that the main area of the church and outside is not visible due to restoration. Otherwise, the frescos and other images are abundant and amazing. Really.
Also, be careful taking taxis hear from sultanhamet as they will most certainly scam you. Do not pay more than 30tl from that area

Beautiful art. Unique neighborhood. This place was beautiful. I liked that the neighborhood was outside the traditional tourist area as well. We walked to the ferry a few blocks to a mile away, and took it back down the golden horn. It was awesome being on there with all locals.

Excellent but postpone until renovation is over. Excellent but postpone until renovation is over. It is quite a small place and half of it is not accessible (I think they reduced the entrance fee to reflect this). It is still worth it for the magnificent frescos and mosaics which are centuries old yet very well preserved.

Byzantine mosaics. Worth a visit even though much of it is closed due to restoration. What we saw was beautiful and captivating. Not easy to get there so we used a taxi. From Sulyeman Mosque it was 48 lira.
Wonderful Christian Church. Don't leave from Istanbul without a visit to Chora church. The best mosaics in the world! True art!!

Church of St. Saviour in Chora - Byzantine mosaics and frescoes. The Church of St. Saviour in Chora has some of the world's most precious Byzantine mosaics and frescoes. However, it does need to be "refurbished".
Orthodox history. Very good place to bring out into relief the orthodox religion. You don't need a taxi, only a good map of Istanbul. In front of this, there is a good restaurant.
Gorgeous. Loved the Chora Church, sooo beautiful. Well worth a visit and do stop and have cay in the nearby cay shop :)
Church of St Saviour. very small Church connected with Ayasofya nothing special about it. you may find many other church in Istanbul much better

Magnificent medieval mosaics. I visited this museum in July of 2014 and again in July of 2015. Both times the main nave was closed for construction/repairs. However, both narthexes have enough gorgeous mosaics to merit the ticket. You will probably have to take a taxi to and from this museum, which requires advice. Get a quote in advance, or demand that the meter be used. It will probably cost more to return back to Sultanahmet or the Old City, because the taxis in front of Chora think they have a captive audience. Don't hesitate to argue and bargain. Don't pay more than a few lira more than what it cost you to get there.

Chora Church. This very ancient building had a wonderful history as the very first Christian Orthodox church to break away from the Roman Catholic church.The murals were both beautiful and fascinating.

Fascinating!. This is one of the oldest churches in Istanbul that was never a mosque. The artwork inside is stunning, and unique. Get the audio guide, as it gives a lot of information about what you are seeing on the walls, which the guide books we had didn't. There is renovation and restoration work being done in the body of the church as of Aug 2015, but it is still worth visiting. We got a cab there from our hotel as it wasn't near us and felt this was the right call, rather than wandering round trying to find it, as it is in the middle of a residential area, not on a main road. Having said that, definitely find time to see it if you can, if Byzantine art and religious history is your thing.

Awearsome Art and History on display. The Museum was truly amazing and very well managed. Paintings on the walls and celling's are very captivating. There's a large souvenir corner with beautiful gifts and books for purchase, but the price was quite high and you are not allow to take photos of any books on offer there.Getting there takes a bit of planning unless by taxi. Otherwise a slow up hill 30/40 minutes walk from Eminuou. The entrance was 35 Lira. There are plenty of cafes and local shops around. Recommended but plan ahead.

Amazing!!. Hagia Sophia is awesome, but this small church is just as dazzling, and since it's small, you can get up much closer to the astonishing narrative mosaics and frescos. Rent the guide or buy the guidebook, to really "read" all of the iconography on the life of Mary and Jesus. You'll get much of the New Testament recounted in the artwork. We ended up spending 4 hours here!
Lovely Architecture. One of the most breathtaking belongings of Balat District of the oldtown of İstanbul. You'll see some perfect wallboard works and lovely hosts and guides around.

If 'half' was this amazing, I cant wait for the rest!. Amazing mosaics and frescoes adorn the walls of this historic church. Although the main areas are still in the renovation stage, the spaces that are available are breathtaking. If you are interested in religious history or simply a lover of craftsmanship and art this place will with a lingering sense of awe. A MUST SEE in Istanbul and a good value for the 15 TL entrance fee.

Simply Beautiful. This Christian Church is also called The Kariye Museum. At present it is being restored in phases and is due to be completed in 4 - 5 years. However it has the most amazing mosaics. You are allowed into the parts not being restored.

Golden beauties of mosiacs. The central rooms were closed when i was there but I was so blown away by the beauty of those mosiacs I don't know what else could have made me any happier with my visit. It is well worth heading out there to see them. I loved it!

Very impresive old church and You must see that mosaics. Very old small church that is made after mosque from her and now they make restorations to bring her back how she looks before, whit great mosaics from early Christian era.
Mosaics are Amazing. This is another place worth visiting, there is allot of mosaics and Fresco's here. The History is amazing.

Lovely Mosaics. This is off the beaten path as it is a good half hour away from the city, but well worth it. The mosaics are beautifully preserved and the history is fascinating. Unfortunately, renovation is on currently so we could not see the main Church.
Must see!!!. Beautiful church decorated with exceptional beautiful mosaic!!!! A must see! In July 2015 there were restorations going on (central part of the church) but still there is a lot to see.

Great mosaics - still under renovation. Lovely old Byzantine church with some amazing mosaics on the walls and ceilings. I went by public transport so it took me a while to find it as its off the main drag but that is all part of the fun of exploring and you meet the locals! Worth the time and effort.

Very Impressive Despite Restorations. While the main room was closed for restoration, the entry foyer has some incredible depictions of the Christian story. I recommend seeing this treasure if in Istanbul.

Worth the visit!. From June 2012 travel)
It is far from the tourist and busy spots of Istanbul, but its worth the visit! You just have to ride the bus and you're there. It will only take you an hour to visit the place and go back to Istanbul proper. Even so, it's woth the visit!

Under renovation. Beautiful (based on what is opened) but the main hall is closed for renovation. The whole church is under cover since they are also renovating/fixing the exterior. I don't think it worth paying just to see this museum since so much of it is closed but its included in the museum pass. BTW The Wall of Constantinople is within walking distance of Kariye Museum
Magnificent. This is well worth visting. It is an enormous church with so much history for Christians and Muslims. The restoration of this building ongoing and the art work very old.

Beautiful place..a must must go. The walls and ceiling had such lovely mosaic work.It feels amazingly calm inside.Although a small section of this place was closed but still going here is worth it.You might want to check if the whole church is online,otherwise you will miss some or the other beautiful mosaic.It cost 15TL per person.

BEAUTIFULLLLLLLLLLLLL. I loved the mosaic work on the ceiling and walls.Its all golden and the light shines on it making it so bright. Unfortunately one of the sections were closed so we missed seeing it.Pls do check this online before you go.
Not rMosaic better than Hagia Sophia. A true gem; not to be missed. Also try the excellent Asitane restaurant, located next to it, for delicious Ottoman cuisine.

Worth a visit - walk over from Sultanahmet District”. We walked all over Istanbul and did spend the day walking over from our hotel in Sultanahmet. It took us a few hours but you can stop off at shops to buy water on the way. We visited the various mouments and mosques on our way- including the aqueducts, the Suleymaniye Mosque, the fatih mosque, the old walls of Istanbul and then on to the Chora church. A great day to spend discovering Istanbul. This part of Istanbul has hardly any tourists but is also very interesting. Grab a map or use your phone GPS to guide you. Our hotel recommended we do this walk. After the Chora church we walked down the hill through all the narrow streets of old houses to the water front and caught the ferry back around to the main Sultanahmet District . If you have transport card you can use this or simply buy a ticket at the office. The Chora church was one of my highlights in Istanbul. The mozaics are so old and have so much history. You can use your museum pass to enter. Unfortunately not all the church is open at the moment due to renovations. However , you still get to see some amazing paintings. The staff at the door spoke very good English and were able to give us directions afterwards. They also have a nice gift school on site where my son bought a history book. After you leave the The Chora church you walk down the hill through a maze of narrow streets and markets and shops. We got very lost however it did not matter in the end as we managed to come out along the water front and could then find the ferry stop. Although this looks to be a poor part of Istanbul we did not feel unsafe and actually asked for directions a few times.
Tells a story. where you can find the story of the prophet Jesus Christ and St Mary. lovely decorations and tiles within the church.

Disappointed. This is extremely out of the way from the main parts of Istanbul where most people are likely to stay. Moreover, the entire outside and about 80% of the inside were blocked off due to renovation and could not be seen. However, the part that could be seen was lovely. I'm sure it was not worth the time, effort to get there and the full ticket!.

Out of the way, but worth it. It is out of the way, but it has amazing mosaics and frescoes. The nave was being renovated when I visited a few weeks ago, but they said the work would be done in August 2015. So if you are in Istanbul and love art and history, make time to go.

An unexpected magical surprise. An absolute must. It was a last minute addition to the itinerary, and it was definitely the most surprising. A little disrupted with the massive conservation efforts in place, but the artwork inside is something I have never seen the likeness of.
Praying time. Have been there on a sunday morning and it was a praying time,was very multiculti in there and amazed with its beaty and history,do recommend to go and visit there.

Don't miss it. If you like Byzantine mosaics this is the church for you. Though the Nave was closed when we went there, there are still incredible examples of mosaic art in the Narthex, and frescos on the side chapel. Beautifully excecuted, these mosaics are among the best and most famous in the world.

Helps to have a guide. This gorgeous church has hundreds of stories to tell in mosaic and mural form. These images are so detailed that it is easy to miss the richness unless you have a very good guide. The placement of a tree branch or an animal depicted in the background of a mosaic can hold a lot of meaning. We were overwhelmed with the imagery, even having done some research beforehand. We overheard a group of English speaking tourists enthusiastically thanking their guide and giving him many compliments. We considered purchasing a book from the bookstore to give us some explanations about the murals but then decided to hire him instead. We were glad that we did and thus I am happy to recommend him. Serder donmez is a licensed guide from the turkish ministry of culture. He can be reached at guiaestambul110@gmail.com or guideserder@ yahoo.com.tr

Incredible Museum/Church. Had wanted to go to this museum many times, but finally made it this time. Such a beautiful place. The mosaics and fresco is one of the best i've ever seen in the world. Definitely worth a visit. Would definitely love to go back when the restoration is finally finished on the outside. Can't miss this when you are in Istanbul. Not as easy to get to as the other sights, but much easier than some have suggested.
Charming Museum. Definitely worth a cab ride to see this charming museum that has beautiful mosaics. It continues to be restored.
Most in tact Church from Byzantine period. The mosaics here are stunning. Also some unusual themes such as Peter & apostles ascending into heaven. The images promote Christian devotion.

Wow. The mosaics were gorgeous. Had studied these in history of art lessons at school and to see them in situ was a treat. Unfortunately some of the museum is closed for renovations currently but a fairly good photographic display was out the front to show what we missed. Still a very worthwhile visit.

Slightly disappointed. While exceptionally beautiful, this is EXTREMELY out of the way from the main parts of Istanbul where most people are likely to stay. Also, the entire outside and about 75% of the inside could not be seen/ were blocked off due to renovation. However, the parts that could be seen were very lovely with the gold leafed mosaic tiles. I'm not sure it was worth the time and effort to get there.

Very little to see as the church is being renovated. We came from Sultanahmet area to see this church and we were disappointed to see that it is being renovated and only a few areas were open. The mosaics we got to see were beautiful but I feel that the trek to this church was too long for the amount of stuff we got to see.Hagia Sophia has mosaics too, we saw them and got a feel for Byzantine Art.i have to mention that we used public transportation and we walked some ( the neighborhood is not the nicest one but the people were helpful and guided us to the church). There are souvenir stalls and a cafe by the church if you would like to have a coffee, snack, and do some shopping there. I would go back to this place when the renovation is over.

an istanbul must see. it is ravaged by time but enough stands for you to enjoy teh beauty of mosaic work
and to get an idea of how ethereal the aya sofia must have been when it was filled with such reverential art !
the bonus ? walking there and back discovering different neighbourhoods

Best Preserved Mosaics and Frescoes. I was surprised to see such well preserved wall decoration. Mosaics and frescoes telling a lot on stories from Bible. A must to do in Istanbul although located out of center.
under repair at the time we visited. The Chora Museum has such beautiful mosaic work from the Christian era and I understand the maintainence work is integral to keep the history going.

A must see church in Istanbul. the story behind the pictures is what makes this church unique--so try to understand what the tiles portray and what the church stands for. interesting ancient church that was protected and continues to stand after such a long time.

Magnificent Church/Museum. The Chora Church is fantastic. It is a pain to get to and I recommend a taxi but well worth it when you get there. Undergoing restoration work when I visited, there was still plenty to see. Having visited Istanbul many times, this church was on my 'to do' list for ages and so glad I visited. A glory of the Byzantine age! Well worth a visit. Fee required and no student discount.

Nice church with mosaics. The church is behind some blocks, we asked somebody in a store where to find it.It is nice, has some mosaics in it. I saw a Biblical scene that I never saw before, Jesus Christ held by one hand from His Father and from the other one by the Virgin Mary, His Mother. It was worth for me to see this. The entrance fee is 15 TL, but it is included in the Museum Pass.

Fine architecture, word class pictorialism, worth coming to town for that only. Expert opinion abounds. This establishment offers in terms of mosaics and frescoes the finest distillates of that art in their context- world class, stop. We have 14th century mosaics, using a more liberated, but in no way profane or clumsily redefined.The Lives of Christ and Virgin Mary are the pictorial narratives. Sad to have missed the best of it. The travel there was a minor adventure in itself, helped by the detailed instructions from the friendly staff of the Tourist Information office in the Hippodrome. Sadly, most of it was closed for renovation/maintenance. Oh well, one has to have an excuse to come back again....: )

Brilliant mosaics, magical location. Unbelievable mosaics (better than Aya Sofia), in a miniature early Christian church by the old city walls. I would rank this higher than any of the Mosques (as a building and experience)

The Ultimate Surprise. I go to Istanbul to see how Islam has expressed itself in sacred and secular forms, both modern and traditional. I didn't expect to be interested in the Byzantine world, aside from Hagia Sophia. I was in a restaurant in Sultanahmet when my neighbor started talking about the Chora Church and though it was being restored and scaffolding was everywhere, it was not a place to miss. Others told me that too. I took a cab to the spot and I instantly realized I was in a special place. Small, perfectly scaled, set in an open area designed to spend time meditating on the exterior of the church, I was taken in by its welcoming size and exquisite art and architecture. The fact that it was "wrapped" Christo-like by delicate scaffolding added to its almost surreal and special nature. Inside the galleries were mosaics and paintings that would take several visits to begin to absorb fully. Though the main sanctuary was off limits as of March 2015, there was plenty to be astonished by. Walking in the surrounding neighborhood only added a fuller appreciation for the delicacy and power of this richly documented bit of church and architectural history.

Mosaics. This is not in the tourist area and will likely require a cab ride unless you are really into a hike. It is nice. The main part is under construction and not at all visible. The area around the museum is pleasant. If would not put this on my must see list yet if it is of interest to you then go.
Christian heritage. Under Construction but so worthy a visit. Far from other places. The color of bizantine mosaics are still so vivid it is hard to believed they are millenaire.

Most beautiful mosaics in Istanbul. The Chora Church is a small church filled with beautifully detailed mosaics of the life of Jesus Christ and the Virgin Mary. It is located in a peaceful and serene setting in the middle of a busy typical Turkish neighborhood. It is difficult to get to this great church, but definitely worth the journey. I took the Big Bus blue route and got off at the Patriarchate stop (#13); I then took a taxi cab to the church which only cost 10 TL ($4 USD). The church reminds me of a Catholic church and it has an abundance of beautiful mosaics- many more than the Hagia Sopia. However, I do like the famous deesis mosaic in the Hagia Sopia the best. If you are into beautiful churches, do not miss this awesome place!
Another important site. This ancient church has a story to tell and is well preserved. Worth the effort to go and visit. Again a good guide will tell the whole story.n

Under construction. We got off our Hop On Hop Off bus to visit this church. A mistake. We had to walk through a questionable neighborhood. When we arrived we found that most of the church was closed for a remodel process. It is beautiful, but we did not see much of it. i would wait to confirm the construction is completed before I would visit.
One for the connoisseurs. Yes it is a bit of a trek - visited in late June and bulk of church is being renovated. Maybe for the true art / architecture lover ,we were underwhelmed .
Amazing mosaics. Even for a Greek, this is a church with amazing orthodox mosaics! Do not miss! Only difficulty: a bit far from means of transport, taxi is the best option

WHAT BEAUTIFUL MOSAICS. If not for anything, one should visit this place for the beautifully preserved mosaics. The are some of the best I have ever seen, and given how old they are, the are just breathtaking. This place is a little out of ways, and close to the Forum Mall (which should be visited if travelling with children, like us, as it has a nice Sea World, Jurassic park, Playing arcades, and a huge food court to have a good meal at).There are many gift shops just around the Chora Church, and if you find something you like, make sure you bargain (30-50%)There is a taxi stand right outside, but when we came out we did not find any taxis, and had to walk to the main road.Just like with some of the other major attractions, some cab drivers ask for crazy prices (always ask for the meter), and sometimes it is better to catch a cab for a few hundred yards away from attractions. You will save money!
Best murals. It was way worth the trip to get there. We took the tram form old town which was cheap, and fun. The church murals were amazing. We spent over an hour viewing and taking pictures amazing

Don't be put off -- this is worth the visit!. We took the tram line from Cemberlitas (at the Grand Bazaar) to the Pazartekke station where there are several hotels including a Holiday Inn. We asked the doorman at the closest hotel to get us a cab to the Chora Church Museum, which cost all of 10L. Outside the church we had perhaps the best meal of our vacation, at Asitane, which specializes in old Ottoman recipes from the palace. I can't recommend it highly enough. A beautiful and quiet garden setting, with a cool breeze. Plan for two-and-a-half or three hours for both a leisurely lunch and the tour of the church. Even though the nave of the church is under renovation, don't think that the church is not worth seeing. There is a cab stand outside the restaurant where we took a cab back to our hotel for about 20L
Beautiful bizantin church. Beautiful bizantin mosaics. One of the most conservative bizantin church .Far from the central city but you can reach it by metro easily.

History told through magnificent mosaics. A MOST !. This visit was the jewel of my memories of Istanbul. The life of Jesus in Byzantine Glory, on mosaics that for 14 centuries have withstood the test of time. Nothing I have ever seen in mosaics around the world compares to the glory of Chora. A Most if you are in Istanbul.
Nice place. It was little difficult to find and locate for us as we had skipped it before but then later we decided to visit this site after our hotel staff told us. It was a nice place to visit.

Very disappointing. This is not an easy place to get to, and once we got there we were underwhelmed. Because of the restoration work you can see nothing of the outside of the building. Some of the inside was not acessible, although most of the frescos were in the parts you can visit. Possibly in order to protect the frescos the interior of the building is kept in very low low lighting, so much of the detail and vitality of the works is lost. I saw much more detail back in the hotel in the photos I took, than I was able to see on the day.My advice, don't go, use the money you save to buy the book with pictures and text, you'll get a lot more out the book than you would from a visit.

Astounding. I had no idea that this little church had such remarkable Byzantine treasures. Hands down my favorite mosaics in Istanbul. Added bonus: only 200 yards from the Theodosian walls (you can climb them for superb views).

Beautiful though small. I visited Chora church via the tram/metro from Kabatas at the end of T1 line which was close to where I was staying.. Overall it took approx 1 hour travelling time. On T1 you have to change at Topkapi stop and catch T4 tram three stops to Edimekapi. Going from Taksim on M2 line would I'd think be much quicker. Either way is cheap. It can be confusing coming out of the station at Edimekapi as it leads out onto a major intersection with no obvious signs of which way to go. However, there is a map on the wall of the station and the member of staff there will also be able to provide you with a copy. The road signs will appear once on to the main road - Kariye - it is approx 10 minute walk to the museum down a couple of quiet side streets.As mentioned many times the museum is undergoing a major restoration so only a few places are open. I know that people have gripes about the cost 15TL but in England you would pay that and more at museums for parking your car. By my conversion it is about £3.60. In my opinion this was the most impressive of all the sights I saw on my Istanbul trip. The mosaics are so beautiful and the detail that is able to be seen is truly amazing. They are true works of art depicting stories from the bible. Whether it is because people dont visit becasue it is undergoing restoration, or it is not in the central run or maybe it was earlier in the morning but there was a calmness about the place and it didnt come across as overun with tourists and i was able to stand for long periods admiring the fine mosaic pieces. Highly recommended

The Santa Claus Connection. A bit out of the way, but this five-sectioned thousand-year-old church has the most sumptuous display of frescoes and mosaics.. They include saints (including an excellent picture of St. Nicholas of Bursa, the American Santa Claus), images of hell, heaven, the Virgin Mary, All in excellent condition, displayed in a typically Greek Orthodox system of naves and arches, all photographable (though No Flash). Two caveats. The images are so complex, so filled with symbols and historical figures, that either a guide--or a cheating browsing of the guidebook in the gift shop is essential. Also, in mid-2015, some of the rooms are being re-constructed. Still, there's enough to satisfy even the most jaded museum-goer. A few minutes away is another church (Fethiye Muzezi), more limited, but with nice surrounding gardens.

A big part is closed off. The Church is beautiful, but due to maintenance and restoration work, much of the church is closed off. The things we've seen were beautiful, but not that impressive. Maybe the closed-off part is more impressive though.

Beautiful historic Church. We enjoyed seeing this beautiful historic Church. It was originally built in 527-565. Later partially destroyed and rebuilt. Worth seeing- then be sure to walk to the old city walls (very close) and climb them for the view- the highest part of the wall is a very steep climb.

Beautiful but an effort to find. We went with my young daughter and my older parents in law. The church itself is beautiful and quite an amazing thing to find in Istanbul. It has a real air of ancient tranquility. However, it is located in an area of the city not often frequented by tourists and it's hard to get to. There are also some of the remnants of ancient city walls nearby, which are worth a look. Beware taxi drivers on the way home trying to take advantage of naive tourists!

Tear-jerking beauty. This was one of the places we had to see on our visit to Istanbul. It isn't the easiest place to get to; it is in the Edirnekapi borough that is on the south side of the Golden Horn and to the west of the old city. The nearest tram stop is Edirnekapi so the best way to get there is either by bus or a yellow death machine, aka taxi.We took one one of the latter, with the fare from Ortaköy being a very resonable 20t/£5. Crickey, in London that would just about get you to the end of the street. If you're taking a taxi, remember that the museum's Turkish name is 'Kariye'.Much of the exterior is clad in scaffolding and some of the interior rooms are closed off for renovation - a very necessary task given the age of the structure and fragility of the contents - but what is on display is more than enough.It is hard to describe but it's fair to say this; a) it is even better than you imagine it will be and b) it moved me to tears. Even if you are not spiritual in any way you have to marvel at the intricate and painstaking nature of the work, which is awe-inspiring. You have to remember that this was the ancient equivalent of social media; communicated a given message in the available medium for others to appreciate.It is quite dark inside and flash photography is not permitted. I had to use a highish ISO of 1600-2000 to be able to get the pictures and you will want to be able to capture photographs of the interior as the frescoes and mosaics are so beautiful, plus to capture the sense of permanence that they possess.The entrance fee was approx. 30t/£7.50 which was ridiculously cheap considering what you are privileged to see there. If you are religious, it is a joy to be able to spot stories from the Bible portrayed on the walls and ceilings.It is testament to the power of religious understanding that this place has survived, given that it was subsumed by the Ottoman Empire in the 15th century and became a mosque for almost 500 years before being converted to a museum. It was one of the first churches established after Emperor Constantine brought Christianity to Byzantium, dating back to the 5th century. It is a unique collection of ancient frescoes and murals that are part of a UNESCO world heritage. You only have to recall what our national 'hero' Henry VIII did in the dissolution of the monasteries to appreciate how important tolerance is to a national's identity and history.We spend around 30-45 minutes here and would come back again on a future visit. Perhaps the most entertaining part was the taxi ride back, when the driver decided to go down one-way street...the wrong way...and then proceeded to do most of the rest of the journey this way. In between emergency stops for vehicles crossing who weren't expected to us emerging from the wrong side. Scary and hilarous in equal measure.

So-so. After 5 days, maybe I was blase or OD'd on churches, gilt, mosaics, but the Chora didn't wow me the way I thought it would based on the guide books. (Note that due to the large restoration project, the exterior was shielded and the main part of the church was closed.) There were still a lot of mosaicsto see in the two long entry areas and the adjoining area had a number of vibrant frescos.) The audio guide was helpful in identifying the mosaics and pointing out key features.I followed the Rick Steves directions to take the public bus from Eminou and that was very interesting to go through more local areas; one whole stretch of the commercial street featured store after store of wedding gowns - quite elaborate!There's a cafe right next to the entrance of the Chora and an upscale restaurant, Asitane, just next door so two different, but good, options.

Beautiful. I have gone there twice. It is a beautiful building, with brilliant work of art. Totally recommend it for those who love photography. There are a few shops around the building that are good for souvenirs. A little expensive, but nice. You can also buy some inside the museum. I recommend this place for sure, just should tell you that you might end up having some pain in your neck when you leave, since most of the art is on the ceiling.

Must visit for frescoes. This is a little gem in the Fatih area of Istanbul. This ancient church is a must visit for anyone wanting to have a glimpse into early Byzantine Christianity. The frescoes are exquisite and one remembers them after. A must visit.

Chora Church and ancient wall expedition. A visit to the Chora church should be on the list of any visit to Instanbul. It is a beautiful church with unbelievable paintings on the walls and ceiling. Nearby are the old city walls which can be climbed which provide a great view across the Golden Horn and city.It is worth the distance to travel however there is easy access by tram and a 5-10 minute walk to the church from the tram station which takes you through the old walls. Ask for directions before leaving the tram station.

Great example of a Byzantium church. Charming unusual little church with lovely mosaics and paintings. Unfortunately, when we went in May, it was partially under restoration, so you couldn't go into the nave. Get the audioguide, it's better than most. it's a little out of the way, so pair it with a visit to the nearby city walls. There's also a charming little art store around the side of the church, selling those Ottoman-style replica paintings done on old paper. Much cheaper than the similar stores at the book bazaar down by the Grand Bazaar.

Far from other sites but worth the trip.. This was not in the center of Sultanahmet, but is still worth visiting if you are interested in Christian history. The artwork there was amazing... Jesus is awesome there along with other figures from Christian history. Plan on a cup of coffee or an ice cream in the cafe near the entrance.
Chora Church. Unimposing entry belies the magnificence within. Remains of mosaic and fresco wall and ceiling decorations are incredible

Currently undergoing restoration (June-15). The outside of the church is currently covered with scaffolds and a roof. On the inside, you can not see the main area of the church, just the surrounding rooms. The mosaics and frescoes you can see are still magnificent.

Definitely Go!. I am so disappointed that the church was under construction when we went in November 2014. The sanctuary was closed off, so I know we missed some of the mosaics in there. However, the quality and beauty of the mosaics is unrivaled. They are stunning! We did have to walk a bit to find a taxi after we left, but it was worth it!

The Chora Museum. The Chora Museum is undergoing renovation at the moment...the 15TL admission fee you pay is for a really small area, but it is beautiful and the mosaic works are just extraordinary .

Church, mosque, museum.... Worth a visit, not only on account of the gorgeous mozaiques, but also because of the quiet oasis behind the church/mosque/museum. The nave of the former church is closed for restoration, but the two narthexes and the parecclesion give a good impression of the beauty of the place. Have some food and/or a water pipe on the large terrace in front of the church!

Giotto was right.... although it is far from the historic center , it is really worth visiing this small church converted into mosque converted into museum...you will appreciate Giotto , the great Italian master..he visited this church(back then) and told that it was the most beautiful mosaics and frescoes he has seen in life...

"Amazingly Splendid Mosaics". Currently undergoing renovationswhich is always good to preserve such wonderful and splendid Byzantine Mosaics. Yes it isunfortunately out of the main touristy area. We took the T1 fromSultanahmet to Topkapi stationand changed to T4 line to Edirnekapi. We asked the security gentleman at the station for directions and he gave us a flyerfrom a stand at the turnstiles whichhad the route to the museum.The walk was about 10 minutes

Beautiful Mosaics. The Chora Church is a little out of the way compared to the other sites in Istanbul, but absolutely worth the journey. First off, in visiting you get to see a part of Istanbul that many tourists often miss. While visiting the Chora Chruch, my boyfriend and I walked through the neighborhoods and quiet streets that were largely residential, and along the old outer wall of the city. It was a nice perspective of the city.When we visited, the museum/church were under pretty heavy renovation. This was admittedly a little disappointing as the price of admission was unchanged. Still, the mosaics we were able to see were breathtaking. It's amazing how well preserved and ornate they are. We had been unsure about visiting, but after seeing the beauty were very happy with our decision and would recommend it. One thing to note, though, is that the church/museum are small and often are a stop for tour groups who arrive on buses. It becomes hard to move around when groups are there. Try to go early or late to avoid tour times. One g

Fine collection of Byzantine art - magnificent frescoes!. Try to walk around the exterior first to get an idea of the full impact of its architecture. Striped marble, six domes, arches, rooflines and a minaret at the side. You enter through the side door and the majority of the lovely mosaics are in the alcoves of the porches. Twenty mosaics depict the life of the Virgin Mary in the inner narthex and in the nave there is a beautiful mosaic of Christ sitting beside his mother's coffin. You can take photographs but flash is forbidden so difficult to focus without tripod. An absolute gem!
Not to miss. This church has some of the most incredible paintings on the inside walls. Even so the center of the church is closed for renovation, it is a must to see in Istanbul.
A Perfect History. This is a real history! It is located in Fatih which is an easy accessible point. If you visit Istanbul, this museum should be in your visiting list.

Interesting bizantine church. We visited chora in the same day we visited Mihrimah mosque and St. George Cathedral. We used only public transportation and walked from sultanahmet to chora. It is not impossible not even very dificult, and I don't think there's need to take a taxi (which would make the visit much more expensive)Take a day to explore the area, eat at asitane restaurant, visit chora museum and Mihrimah mosque, enjoy Istanbul. The city is huge and there is much more to see beyond Sultanahmet.Chora church is full of frescoes and full of history, I really enjoyed my visit there eventhough the main naus was closed to restauration. We had the museum pass (wich we used before to enter Topkapi and Hagia Sophia) so we didn't have to pay extra to enter chora. But even if you don't have the museum pass I think it is worth to pay the tiket to see this church.I sure want to go back some day when the restoration works are finished to see the whole church.

Must See for Byzantine Mosaics!!. This was right next to my hotel, so I walked about 30-50 meters and there I was. Its it being renovated in three stages. So in May 2015 then main room was closed. The two main halls were open with all their beautiful mosaics from the Byzantine Christian times. This is a must see.

Hidden gem. However it was not easy to find a way there, I think I used few buses to get there, great mosaics covering the whole space worth the long trip. however I would not say its a must see for someone being for the first time in Istanbul - so much off the regular touristic sites- which is an advantage indeed..

Start your day here amazing and perfect prelude to Other religious sites. Whilst small this site amazes in its rich history and remarkable Christian mosaics. Well known images from the bible are displayed in mosaic that you can get so close to you can touch (but of course you don't touch) co pared to roman sites you feel part of the church not just a tourist here and give its setting in an predominately muslin country the churches restoration and care give speaks volumes to the authenticity of turkeys secular society. Whilst it's ten minutes extra drive I strongly reccomend. Although I would say it's next seen early in the day before some of the grander in size and significance sites

Currently under reconstruction- mostly locked off. A fantastic Greek church of amazing mosaic, but at the moment its covered in scaffolding and inside is mostly closed off for reconstruction work.what you can see is still great, but wont take you more than 30 mins.also you can buy tickets here for all the sites- something not advertised in the centre- get it- it will save you time and money!!This site though, has to be sorted quickly as visitors are currently missing out but still paying full entrance fee.

REALLY ATTRACTIVE AND ANTIQUITY LADEN INTERIOR!. The Chora Church, later a mosque, is a real beauty. We found the strikingly beautiful mosaics and frescoes a step up to the more famous museums in Istanbul such as the Blue Mosque, Topakapi and Sofia. The mosaics are in fact breathtakingly gorgeous.

Must see!. An absolute must see for anyone visiting Istanbul! The mosaics were in such good condition compared to others from that time period and it's so much calmer than the Hagia Sophia despite being from the same time period. Absolutely beautiful!

Wait for the restauration to end if you can. I read in here that the church was under restauration, but never imagine that I coul see so little. The church is really out of the tourist path, so it is a relief to see so few tourists, but the part which is open is so small that I was wondering if it was worth the trouble. I read here that it is not easy to go using public transportation, but actually it is pretty simple, I got the metrobus at Mecidiyekoy (easy connection with green line from Sisli) and stopped at Edinerkapi, the walk was easy, also went to the lovely Mihrimah Mosque, less than 5 minutes away and finished as advised here by a fellow traveller, with a walk until the pier to take w water taxi until Eminonu.

Worth the trek. Beautiful church and setting. The murals are fantastic. You can take the tram (one connection) and get dropped off a few blocks away. Pair this with a walk on the Roman walls. Have lunch at the nearby restaurant, I forget the name, but you will know it if you head that way - a little pricey, but well worth it. Don't be afraid to walk around, we did and discovered a part of Istanbul that many may not see. Beware of the shoe shiners -- they may drop a brush, or offer to show you how to get up on the wall -- its all to get you into a shine -- your choice on taking them up on it -- but perhaps best not to get started in that direction unless you want to.

Stunning mosaics in a brilliant little church. I was very glad to make my way out to the Chora church (which is not as much of a trek to get to as the guide book suggested) because the mosaics were spectacular. Entry was included with my 3 day museum pass. I don't normally get the audio guide at places like this but it's well worth it because it's not dear and has excellent information about what makes the Chora mosaics quite rare and special. The church is being restored and rennovated which is of course great, but it means some of it is closed off. It's still definitely worth a visit and was one of the highlights of my time in Istanbul. There were'nt many people there when I visited which made it so much better! It's also in an interesting part of town worth spending time in to get a different feel of the city.

Apocrypha!. I can't remember the last time I wrote that word. The mosaics in the church are stunning for their beauty but also for the uniqueness of the story line. I am not aware of another set of mosaics like it.

Lovely mosaics, but still under renovation. The mosaics and frescoes here are beautiful. However, it was still under renovation at the time of my visit. It is a significant distance from any other tourist attraction. I took a cab to get there, and then walked down the hill and took the ferry down the Golden Horn back to Eminonu. This was pleasant. One could do it the other way, but the hill is steep. I preferred downhill vs. uphill. If you are interested in Byzantine mosaics it is worth the visit.
wow. Amazing, amazing mosaics. The frescos were impressive, but not as amazing as the mosaics. Frequented by tour groups, but if you are patient, they will leave and you can have a better view.

Wonderful Byzantine church. The frescoes and mosaics are some of the finest in the world. You're back more than a thousand years ago in this wonderful museum. You also get to see the walls built by the emperor Theodosius too!

DO NOT MISS This Church. This church is awesome a little far from the other attractions. You can pick taxi ride for about 15 minutes (ask first for the fare). I think the one of the best example Byzantine art besides Hagia Sofia. Take the audio guide! It was the first church on this site was built in the 4th century as part of a monastery complex outside the city walls of Constantinople. This is the reason for the "in Chora" part of its name - chora zonton means "in the country" in Greek. The present building dates from the 11th century and decorated in the 14th. The Church of St. Savior in Chora (formerly the Kariye Camii and now the Kariye Müzesi) in Istanbul contains one of the best-preserved collections of Byzantine mosaics and frescoes anywhere.
under renovation. Visiting the Chora Church was still worth it even though it is under renovation. Absolutely stunning.

Worth a visit - Take note Restoration work in progress. Firstly the site is experiencing a tremendous amount of restoration and preservation work, you cannot view the church from the outside at the moment and a large portion of the inside is also cordoned off. So not seeing the outside of this beautiful church is a tad disappointing it is great seeing the level of effort being put into maintaining the site for the future. The mosaics themselves are some of the best I have ever seen and the masterly level of the craftsmanship present is incredible. The city walls is also a short stroll from the church and is a welcome reprieve from the hustle and bustle of the manic center of Istanbul. *Just a good tip, my girlfriend was wearing shorts on her trip out here, take note the neighborhood comes across as quite conservative and she felt a bit uncomfortable in her shorts which is normally perfectly acceptable in the city center of Istanbul so to avoid any strange feelings cover up)
Very impressive. It is a must go place in Istanbul for its importance in history, art and religion. The gold mosaics are very impressive.

Definitely worth the trip. The mosaics are some of the most famous and beautiful works of art form the Byzantine period. The apse is under repair at the moment but most of the finest pieces are visible. It is worth renting the headset for more insight.

Incredible Find! Best Mosaics!. This charming church is a little out of the middle of things. Take a taxi and have them wait (cost us 10TL to have him wait). The major part of the church is closed for restoration but it is still well worth the visit. The mosaics are incredibly well preserved.

Best Mosaics in Istanbul. This charming church is a little out of the middle of things. Take a taxi and have them wait (cost us 10TL to have him wait). The major part of the church is closed for restoration but it is still well worth the visit. The mosaics are incredibly well preserved.

Under renovation. If you are time restricted visit elsewhere, if you have a muzeumkart it is worth it, beautiful Byzantine paintings make it worth the visit easy to find really there are signs in English off the main road in Fatih
Nice Byzantine,under renovation!. You can only see a very small part of this church due to ongoing renovations, hardly worth the 15TL entry fee unless you have Muzeuum card go elsewhere

Under renovations!. Got there easily by taking the tram with one switch along the way and then a 10 minute walk to the church.The church is under cover at this time due to being in phase 1 of a 3 phase renovation. So you don't get a great outside view of the church. Inside, the entry way and the west section of the church is open to visitors but the main body of the church is closed off and out of view from visitors.That all being said, the areas that you can visit have beautiful mosaics that have colours that are so strong, it is amazing! Then when you enter the west section, there are some beautiful frescos. Having a guide book or a guide will inform you more about the little things to notice. Still worth the visit even under renovations!While in the area, Mihrimah mosque! After that, walk down to the Golden Horn along the old city wall and see some real Turkish neighbourhoods. Take the ferry back to Emininou station and visit the Spice Market!

Can be skipped. More than 85% of the church is under renovation and off limits for visitors. There are some nice mosaics but it will take less than 15 minutes to go thru. It is way out of the way and the only way to reach it expeditiously is by cab - costs about 70 lira round trip and 60 lira for the entry fee. If you are on a limited time budget, then this would be last on the list.

Don't waste your time visiting for a while. Its currently undergoing major works (May 2015) and about 80% of the Church is closed off. and its still in Phase 1 of the works.We spent about 15mins looking around what was there, but spent about half hour travelling there!Its best to check in advance the state of progress of the works before venturing out there.Included in the Museum Card.

Fantastic mosaics. Easy ferry ride up the Golden Horn then a 20 minute amble up the hill following the old city wall gets you there.The main part was closed for renovation but the 2 entry halls and the side chapel were open. Definitely worth the visit to see the many mosaics portraying biblical events relating to JC.

a bit of a trek. but well worth it. The outside is under renovation but inside is spectacular. After visiting the church we walked down to the water, a bit of a hike, but well worth it. Saw the local's Istanbul.
A lovely place. A bit hard to find but well worth a visit. Beautiful inside not very big but still managed to quite a bit of time there
A quiet one. A bit hard to find but worth the effort. Beautiful inside not very big but still managed to spend quite a bit of time there

Spectacular!. The mosaics and frescoes are treasures. Unfortunately the nave was closed for restoration when we were there in early June, so we did not see the entire church. However, a good portion of the art is in other parts of the church, so we probably saw the majority of what is most important. The taxi drivers that hover down the street will take advantage of tourists so if you can snag a taxi dropping somewhat off closer to the church, try to grab it.

you cannot lost it!. This little church has incredible bizantine mosaics, although part is under restoration. The expresion of the figures in the scenes represented is very realistic. It is worthy to study in advance what are you going to see, museum shop has several books.
Best for post-Justinian mosaics. An important Byzantine monument in Istanbul. Do not miss for post-Justinian era mosaics and frescoes.The naos was closed for restorations.
Best for post-Justinian mosaics. An important Byzantine monument in Istanbul, do not miss. Exquisite mosaics and frescoes.The naos was closed due to restorations.

Far more impressive than Hagia Sofia — and a tip for the adventurous. So beautiful and moving — a real pleasure to visit, away from the crowds of Sultanahmet. Highly recommended.Walk up the hill five minutes and you can climb precarious steps to the top of the Roman Aqueduct, for views all across Istanbul. No tourists at all when we were there, just three friendly local kids. A bit scary climbing back down, but you're in no real danger. Yalla! as one of the kids yelled down to me in Arabic — come on! Do it.

A small distance away from the main area worth the trip. The trip to get here is an adventure in itself, I travelled by bus and that was entertaining enough when the bus leaves the major roads for the narrow streets. The bus drivers must have 3 arms, 1 for the steering wheel, 1 for the mobile phone that must be compulsory for all Turkish bus drivers and 1 for the horn as they blast double parkers and other road users that try to push in. Even getting out to tell other road users what they thought. I spoke to someone who went by taxi and that seemed even more of a thrill ride. When the bus reaches the end of its route it’s a short walk to Church of St Saviour in Chora. This is a location that is included on the museum pass.Unfortunately there is restoration work taking place at the moment but what is open makes the visit worth while. In my opinion the frescos here are better than Hagia Sophia and there are more of them and they are generally more complete.
Greatest Spot. One of the best main architectural places in Istanbul, very spiritual and peaceful atmosphere. If you're interested in mosaics and frescoes do not miss!
Don't buy in the gift shop!. This site is wonderful. Go see it. But, don't buy books there. The same materials cost half as much just outside in the shopping area.

Savour St Saviour. This is a must visit for people who love simple old churches. Chora (known in Turkish as the Kariye museum) has the most fantastic mosaics which will take your breath away. Although currently under restoration, there is still plenty to see and to enjoy.

Worth getting to. A bit out of the way but worth the journey. Wonderful mosaics and wall frescoes.Be careful you don't get ripped off getting there as we did. Taxi fare should not be more than 40TL each way fron Sultanahmet district and should not involve going outside the walls.The revations are mostly complete.A bonus if you go by taxi is seeing a more tradtional non-touristy part ipof Istanbul.

Beautiful. A few miles from Istanbul's 'tourist center' in the Edirnekapı District is a tranquil oasis of ancient history.
The frescos and mosaics depicting the life of Mary and Jesus are beautiful!
The small gift shop is worth visiting.
There is an outdoor cafe nearby; a perfect place for a cup of apple tea.
Under construction. Check to see if the construction is completed before you visit. We were disappointed on arrival to find that a large portion of church was closed. Otherwise, a beautiful place.

Outside the City. It's under renovation but worth visiting to see the mosaic and frescoes. Less crowded than the more popular sites being outside of the city but a tram would take you a short stroll away.

A Reward Out of the City. Less crowded than most popular site as it is out of the city as the name implies. It is now a museum. It is under renovations but the part that is still accessible is worth the visit. Easily reachable by changing trams line, it's a short walk from the station where a map to the church is available. It's as easy as that. You have the bonus of some old walls nearby that you can actually climb to the top of; the sight up there must be magnificent but I didn't dare the climb.

Interesting and nice mosaics. Hard to get to by public transportation.. We visited in May 2015 and the interior is closed for renovation. So you can only view the mosaics In the outer section. A tad disappointing as we had to sprint there to arrive before the 6pm cutoff for ticket sales. If you take the express bus there and walk from the stop, do NOT cross the bridge into the cemetery. The cemetery was beautiful and fascinating, but we could not find an exit at the other end and had to climb a wall to get out!!

size doesn't matter. although small compared to the behemoths of Sultanahmet, the frescoes and mosaics in Chora church are well worth the effort. We walked from the old city via the grand bazaar, sulimaniye, the aqueduct and faith cami and would pick this site over them all. Although the main body of the church is undergoing restoration you can still see the wonderful mosaics and frescoes. Make a day of it and walk back via Fener and the Golden Horn.

Must see if you're into early Christian churches. We walked from the Galata bridge along the foreshore which in itself was very interesting but the Chora which at present his undergoing restoration work was fantastic them murals and frescoes were well worth a look and the area around the church/museum is also worth some time. make sure you have a "istanbulkart" for easy access to public transport.

Surely worth a visit. Absolutely stunning frescoes and paintings. Not a big church but it can still take your breath away. Its a little further away from other tourist attractions and but you can still access it on public transport (train) and a little bit of a walk.
