Beautiful frescoes. A very special Museum depicting the story of the Virgin Mary in it's well restored frescoes, in a way I've not seen before. Another gem well worth visiting.

Disappointing. Dinner reservations nearby, so we arrived a little before 6. Unfortunately, though tix should be sold until 6, the man behind the counter was ready to go home, and couldn't bring himself to open his cash box--would only admit us if we had day passes. Too bad. Our only bad experience in all of Turkey

Absolutely beautiful church with incredible mosaic art and marble walls. We visited Chora Church and were thrilled that we did. The Byzantine mosaics tell the story of the Virgin Mary and the birth of Jesus. We had seen the mosaics at Ravenna and these are more sophisticated and produced later in the Byzantine period. The book that pictures the mosaic art is very detailed and I am delighted to have it. This Church has recently been renovated and the mosaics, incredible marble patterned walls and beautiful floors are truly worth the visit. We also ate at the cafe across from the church and enjoyed shopping at the ceramic store, Kariye Pasha, that was next to the Chora.

A Hidden Gem. Travel out to this little Church is a must do when in Istanbul . Go by bus for the fun of it and walk down to The Chora Church as its plumb in the middle of some sort of housing estate . Get the Tram back to town . A really great place with super mosaics . This place is a real treasure.

Feels like a pilgrimage. Exquisite Byzantine mosaic compositions that depict the narratives of the Christian faith. The musuem is popular and can be crowded so it is best to arrive early (9am).For those sub poor vision, I recommend a book sold in the musuem shop (70TL). It has good pictures of each mosaic panel, and easy descriptions.

Disappointed.. when compared to the Hagia Sophia.. We expected quite a lot but were disappointed. It was a very small and isolated building. Far away from all the touristy attractions and took us a while to walk through the alleyways to find the place. After visiting the Hagia Sofia and the blue mosque, I guess we were disappointed by the size of it. The church surely has a lot of historic importance and had some beautiful paintings.. but to me it wasn't wroth the travel from Sultanahmet.

Mosaics not seen elsewhere. This is a bit out of the way for the typical tourist in Istanbul, but well worth the taxi fare to see a church with the most beautiful mosaics I've seen on travels to many cities. Though some of the church is being restored, you are still able to view many precious mosaics that tell the stories from both the new and Old Testament, though the focus is on the former. The sense of movement and facial expressions are awesome. I strongly suggest going with a private guide. The person we used for several day in Istanbul, is Cihan Sevil, whose English is near perfect as is his command of history. Email: chnsvl@gmail.com

Wow. The story of Jesus and marry written in the wall and ceiling in form of hand painting great job. The painting still in great shape and will tell you the whole story in great visual story, we had wonderful tour guid which help us understand story which make it very interesting, you really must see it

3 because it is under restoration, if not 4 . As mentioned in the title it is currently being restored so that you cannot see the outside of the church at all and a lot of the inside is not accessible. However, it is worth s visit. The mosaics are outstanding. There is a fair amount of history. I would recommend walking down towards the Bosporus afterwards through the windy residential roads and see a non touristy/rich area of Istanbul.

one of the most beautiful surviving examples of a Byzantine church. in the Edirnekapı neighborhood, The interior of the building is covered with fine mosaics and frescoes. a must for all tourists seeking attractions that are highly rated.

Be aware of renovations!. There are some really beautiful wall and ceiling paintings here, but some of it is currently closed for renovation. It is a little way out of the centre......so less good value than it would usually be maybe....although the Asitane Restaurant nearby is excellent and well-with a visit if you are a bit more adventurous with the food you'll try!
The magnificent church. I was wondering about why people want to see this church. I think , i know it. You should see painting of church. they are amazing.

Do not miss this. Chora Church is out of the main tourist part of the city near the Byzantine wall. It is hard to get to it and not well signposted but do not give up you must see this church. The main body of the church / Mosque was being renovated but the treasurers are the frescos and mosaics from the Byzantine period before you enter the main sanctuary. They are stunning and the best we have seen. The ones in Hagia Sophia were fantastic but these outshone those.

Off the beaten path, but the best preserved mosaics in town.. Chora Church is currently having restoration done on the main dome, but it's still worth the trip if you are in town for more than a day. The best art is found in the corridors surrounding the dome anyway. I've traveled all over Turkey, and I was astounded at how well these frescoes had been preserved and how beautifully they illustrate the Biblical narrative, reminiscent of European cathedrals. Because of its out-of-the-way location, it is typically not crowded. The site is surrounded by lovely gardens and has clean restroom facilities. The gift shop is small and most items were very reasonably priced.Make sure you have a good camera for use without flash. Transportation is tricky, but there are public buses and minibuses that stop nearby. It's near the Theodosian walls, so while strolling back to the bus stop we walked along the top of them!

Under renovation. This museum and the surronding area has a great feel but I was disappointed not to be able to see more. it is currently undergoing restoration and most is closed to the public. What is open has great examples of early mosaic work and early architecture. Worth a visit but be aware that you will only see a small section.
Please swap with the Church of St Saviour review above.. This was meant to be the place reviewed. Please revise. Please see note above. A wonderful place to visit as i said.

Astounding gem.. This church (present buildings are C11th but the site is much older) contains some of the greatest mosaics in Istanbul within a beautifully compact building. It is not so well known a site in Istanbul but a visit is a must. After going there, we walked down a steep hill and caught a water taxi along the Golden Horn for 40 lira. That capped off a great morning.

Near Theodosian walls. We had to take a taxi to get here. You could take a complicated route via bus (which only accepts the transit cards), but this seemed like less of a good idea than taking a taxi. If you have been doing your reading, you know taking a taxi is a shaky thing in Istanbul. We happened to make it there and the driver merely kept our change. We considered this a success. Even though the nave is closed for repairs, this was a stunning and beautiful church. Not crowded at all. Many young people were there drawing sketches of the mosaics and frescos. I think this is definitely worth seeing, but the inaccessibility is very much a problem. I cannot recommend taking the taxi's, even though sometimes it works out. If you are adventurous though, this is worth seeing!
WOW. This is history! "No flash" allowed so ensure you have right camera or setting though the picture cannot capture the WOW feeling!
WOW. This is history! If you wish to take picture "no flash" so ensure you have the right camera or setting however the pictures will not capture the feeling, the WOW factor.

Conservation work in progress but still a must-see. This church is now a museum where you can see wonderful Byzantine mosaics and frescos. The central area of the church is currently closed for conservation work, but there a still a lot of beautiful art to see

A Heaven for a mosaic lover. A rather small but very famous Byzantine church outside the city centre. Wonderfully preserved mosaics that belong to the most famous ones in the Byzantine mosaic art. You can travel by a local bus or take a taxi which is the easier option. Absolutely worth a visit!

Hard to get to. We walked up from Hop on bus. Not easy. Plus the main part of church is closed for restoration. What we saw was nice, we just did not get to see it all. If you go get a guide to explain the art to you. We did not and should have.

One of Istanbul's top attractions. Many of the other reviews are quite right about the beauty of this church. Well worth the effort to get there. Easiest and cheapest way is to take a bus from Eminonu Bus Station on the south side of the Golden Horn. 38E takes you via the aquaduct and along Fevzipasa Avenue. Get off when you reach the old city wall (which also adds to the trip). As at June 2015, part of church is closed off for renovation, but still worth 15TL. Best to get the bus back into the city. On reviewer generously describes this part of the city as 'gritty.' Not worth strolling through.

A treasure hide in the middle of the city!!!. The Church of St Saviour in Chora, is an important example of christian art maybe one of the best in Turkey. The church has not only the expected religious mosaic figures but also a good part of the church is dedicated to mosaics that explain some of the apocryph spells. It is in a very hidden location in the city not in the normal touristic routes one must to go on purpose to visit this Church.

Incredible mosaics and frescos but under renovation. I've divided my review firstly into the museum and then secondly getting there as it's a bit off the standard tourist path. The museum is under renovation and has scaffolding and boarding outside so you can't see the outside structure. The main chapel inside is also closed. However the outer halls of the chapel are still open and these contain most of the mosaics and frescos. From the guide books I read that there are very few mosaics in the main chapel other than the depiction of Mary's soul ascending to heaven. So it's still definitely worth visiting as what you can see is incredible and represent the best examples of surviving Byzantine art. You will see all manner if Christian themes depicted from judgement day to the resurrection. For me this was only second to Hagia Sophia in Istanbul. Outside is a nice restaurant and also lots of shops selling associated souvenirs. There is also a small bookshop inside. Another tip is buy the museum pass as this attraction is included for free. As for getting there I didn't want to use a cab, so decided to use public transport. From Sultanahmet I took the tram towards Bagcilar and changed at Aksaray station onto the red airport metro line and went 2 stops to "Topkapi - Ulubatli". From there it's a pleasant 15 minute walk past remains of the old city walls so I suggest you download Ulmons "CityMaps2Go" app for your smartphone and get the offline Istanbul map (free). It uses GPRS so you don't pay any data charges. In fact I used it throughout my entire visit and found it both accurate and essential for getting around. In summary despite being off the tourist path and being under renovation it's still a must see site.

Beautiful site although getting there was a struggle. We enjoyed the Chora Church and wonderful byzantine mosaics despite the adventure in getting there. After numerous attempts to find an honest taxi driver in Istanbul (we were not successful in over 2 days as all 6 we tried to work with wanted over 5 times what they charge locals), we bought bus tickets and were sent on a bus to get to the site. Unfortunately, neither the person directing us to get on the bus or the driver must have understood as we were dropped off 20 minutes away and then had to ask about 10 people to get there. The return was easier. Take Bus 38E on the Eminomu station. If anyone finds an honest taxi driver in Istanbul, you should write down their name as they may get an award.

Beautiful interior, well worth the trip. This church is being restored currently but most of it is still open and the wonderful mosaics and frescoes are visible. It is very small and can get very crowded with tour groups - a bit of patience until they move on is repaid. We combined it with a walk along the City Walls having taken the tram to Topkapi, which made a good day out. Excellent and unique cuisine at Asitane next door also recomended!

Christian history. Unfortunately we had too little time here, but what we saw was amazing. Do some research or get the headphones. There is so much to see in such a small church.Give yourself plenty of time.How do these wonders last

Main area closed for restoration. An impressive church given its size, but disappointed by the fact that the main area of the church is closed for restoration. You can get fairly close to the church by rail then walk to it. I used my iPhone with CityMaps2Go to get to it (the iPhone gps shows you exactly where you are on the phone resident map so no need for data usage like when using Google maps)

One of the best sites to visit in Istanbul. The mosaics and frescoes (1315-1321) here are numerous and simply stunning. The outside is nothing special, but when you walk inside, the beauty is breathtaking. It is not to be missed. When I return to Istanbul, this is at the top of my list of places to return to. Extra bonus: the cafe right behind the museum has great food at very reasonable prices.

Kariye museum - the most important Byzantine church in Istanbul. The finest mosaics in Istanbul. Area surrounding the church is delightful. Excellent cafe in from of the museum. A must. Link this visit by continuing to walk into Balat the old Jewish and Greek area.

Not easy walking destination but defiantly obligatory to visit in Istambul. Breathtaking mosaic and frescos. Very calm and reflecting atmosphere. Small but cozy yard. Not easy to reach but definitely deserves to visit and steering.

Mosaics. In view of culture and history you should not miss this place. Although you need a taxi to find your way and altough they are doing restauration works, the mosaics are outstanding and unique. It is not crowded and definitely deserves your visit.

Fine mosaics but nave closed. The Chora church is in a suburb and we made the mistake of going by bus - very slow. Even with only two people it's better to take a taxi. Wonderful mosaics in the Narthexes, although suffering somewhat from neglect. The Nave is undergoing serious restoration & will be shut for a while

The Chora Church and Museum. The neighborhood near the Chora is described as "gritty". I took a taxi from my hotel. (60 year old female traveling alone much of the time.) The immediate area is fine and touristy. The taxi trip passed some areas that seemed very conservative with lots of women in full-coverage burkas. The actual church/museum has gorgeous mosaics from the early Christian Byzantine era and is definitely worth the time to get there.

Impressive christian wall paintings. Chora church is small but impressive due to the good conditions of the very old paintings on the walls and the ceiling. Sometimes too many people in the room, but if you take pictures with a good zoom you will enjoy the stunning details at home. Don't miss to take a Cay tee outside under the trees.
Worth a visit. It's a shame that so much of it is being restored, but what there is to see is well worth the visit. We travelled by taxi, the most exciting taxi ride ever!!, and not expensive.

Beautiful. Beautiful church and frescoes. Well maintained and enjoyable. Well worth a visit! A little tricky to find but worth it. We went to Asitane restaurant next door after for lunch - which was excellent.
Excellent Example of Bizantine Art. Classic Design with some well preserved murals . A nice introduction to that time in th I s part of the world.
Must See. This is a must see in Istanbul. It contains some of the best Byzantine mosaics. There is a great restaurant, Asitane, nearby, for your after sightseeing meal.

absolutely worth visiting. Byzantine church with incredible mosaics and well worth the lug out to where it is . Interesting depiction of stories that are not in the bible such as the birth of the virgin mary and her life before the immaculate conception. Stories about Jesus' miracles depicted on beautiful mosaics which were not destroyed by the ottomans but covered up when it was converted to a church

Had to buy the book!. This church was converted to a mosque in the 3rd century and fortunately the mosaics were covered with wood. When discovered, the mosaics tell stories and confirm stories only rumored.
Had to buy the book to gift our priest who is a biblical scholar. Amazingly beautiful!

Fabulous mosaics and frescoes. Not the easiest site to find as an independent traveller but well worth the effort. The entire church is covered in restored mosaics and frescoes depicting Jesus' life in fabulous detail.

Chora about to be closed for renovation. We visited Chora Church May 25, 2015. It is scheduled to be closed for renovation in June 2015 and will be closed for two years. Don't plan to see it if you visit Istanbul during that period. It has a fascinating history though.

Worth the extra distance. The Chora Church is a little bit farther away from the rest of Istanbul's major sites, but it's worth the extra effort to see the amazing mosaics and frescoes. The entire place is quiet with an almost magic feel. I also enjoyed visiting a Christian church in addition to the many mosques of Istanbul to get a more complete picture of the city's history.

Inspiring. This rightly has the reputation of being one of the most beautiful churches in Istanbul.Its architecture is of several ages but much of it is early 14th Century. The great attraction of the museum are the frescoes which have survived the original church being turned into a mosque in 1453.

Vestige of the glory of Bizantium. We knew that there aren't so many ruins and traces of Bizantium in Istanbul, but we tried to seek them as possible as we could. This Church of Chora is the most beautiful vestige of Bizantium, I think. We loved very much.

Unmissable Chora. This church is unmissable but far off the main tourist track so make sure you find it. There is also a great family-run reaturant over the road from it so you can make a good half day visit to the area.The Chora church is under major restoration works at present but you can still see many of the astonishing 14th century Christian frescoes and mosaics. There is an order to the frescoes and it would be worthwhile buying the guide book in the small shop before you look at the artwork because following through the Biblical stories in the correct order adds to the quality of your experience. There are some fun changes in perspective to look out for.This was probably my second favoutire building in istanbul after Haghia Sophia - not to be missed!

Mosaics. A visit to Chora church is worthwhile but the main space is not accessible as it is under restoration. The mosaics are easy to photograph being quite low down. Have a look at the new mosque being built nearby and the defensive walls
Fascinating. This is a building that tells some of the early religious story of Istanbul. It is well worth a visit and the shop has some good mementos of the trip.

Beautiful mosaics. If you enjoy mosaics and frescoes then this is a must. The only problem is that by the time you have finished looking up at ceilings and high mosaics you will have neck ache - worth it though.

Hard to find. Using the Rick Steves book directions. We took the tram and light train. His hint to eat at the hotel restaurant next door was spot on though. I was glad we took the effort to go see it.

we were ripped off. this would have been a good attraction except for the fact that the middle of the museum was closed for repairs. nevertheless they still charged the full price of 15 lira for what little there was to see. either make it free or close the church. nevertheless it was situated near the walls of edirnekapi and worth a visit if you climb the stairs of the walls to get a panorama of one part of Istanbul.

Worth a trip. If you wonder what Hagia Sophia might have looked like during the Byzantium period, you'll want to check out Chora Church. Its frescos are spectacular. It's worth a taxi ride to visit this splendid site. Just make sure the taxi meter is on and reset before you take off!

Main hall closed. Looks like they're still renovating. The main hall is closed and the whole outside is covered. What there is to see is impressive though. So once it's open and uncovered should be awesome. But that might take a while

Mosaics & Frescos. Though much of the building was under renovation and not open for review, this sight was one of the most beautiful and spiritual places we visited in Istanbul. We did get there right at the opening time so we had the advantage that it was not as crowded.How lucky for us that the mosaics and frescoes were covered with plaster for such a long time, so we have the pleasure of viewing them so many centuries later.Though a bit more difficult to get to, the Kariye Museum is well worth the effort.
Amazing!!. Really worth a trip although it's slightly further up from other tourist attractions. You may need to note that the main chapel/nave is under restoration for a while, though.

Beautiful gem of a church!. The mosaics in this little church tell the story of Mary, the Mother of Jesus, starting with her parents and going through her ascension. I visited it with a guide who wrote her masters thesis on the mosaics, and therefore had a fascinating glimpse of the man who sponsored the mosaics and the stories they tell.You will see a lot of mosques in Turkey, but few churches - be sure to visit this one!

If you love churches and mosaics, can't be missed. The mosaics at this church took our breath away. They chronicle the lives of Mary and Jesus, with amazing detail and also with a loving and human quality I have rarely seen in any church or cathedral. Instead of trying to "scare" you into believing, this set of outstanding mosaics brings you in with its tenderness and affection for the christian story. Also aesthetically upstanding in every way. Do not miss this site.

Brilliant mosaics. The mosaics are some of the best you will ever see. Whilst this is away from the main sites, it is easy to get to. We walked to and from the old city and the walk alone was all part of the experience.

Amazing Church- Art work had survived remarkably well.. A must see with wonderful mosaics in pretty good condition. Recommend and it is easier than many of the more famous monuments.We were mid afternoon and visited without the hordes of people.Thoroughly enjoyed. Suggest 1 plus hour .

Spectacular Murals and Mosaics. We visited and whilst there is continuing restoration, came away amazed as to the well,preserved art work from Christian times, which gas survived whilst covered with Pasteur during the Ottoman era. But it reflects brilliantly the last art work if the Byzantime era.
Well worth an hour during your visit to Istanbul

Glorious Artwork. This Church/Mosque/Museum had wonderful Christian Wall paintings and mosaics depicting the life and times of Jesus and the Apostles, mainly from the 14th Century. The frescoes and mosaics were protected by wooden screens and remained intact during its time as a mosque. Now that it is a museum, the Turkish authorities are renovating the building.
Best mosaics.. The church, and surrounding area are very interesting. There is a little house very close by. One can find very nice pictures or glass made by young and well known artists.

A Gem!. gorgeous mosaics in better repair than Hagia Sophia. It is small so more accessible and intimate. Take a cab and have them wait because it is a ways from the tourist sites. But watch the meter on the way back. Somehow it went much faster and we made the driver let us out early and walked since we did not have that much cash.

Best Byzantine mosaics in the World bar none!. we walked from the Topkapi tram station. This is a bit misleading as it is outside the northern land walls and nowhere near the Topkapi Palace. From the station, and you can catch the tram at Kabatash on the coastline near the Besiktas area, you walk along the wall, over a dual carriageway- there are traffic lights but they only work night and early am, so use the subway!Tricky navigating will take you to the Chora Church. Built originally outside the city walls the Emperor Theodosius enclosed it when he had the walls rebuilt.The church carries little known stories of the Nativity and related aspects. When we visited some renovations were underway and main areas of the site were closed. You benefit from audio guides or you can buy a descriptive book.The mosaics are a marvel, go and see for yourself. The mosaics are of the quality of those that once adorned the inside of the Hagia Sophia.

Majority under restoration. This is a highly rated site to see in all guide books and even though it's a bit out of the way I thought it should be visited. Plus it's covered under the museum pass. I had read that some sections are closed for renovations but was not prepared for almost 70% being blocked off. All you could see were two small hallways in the shape of an L with the gift shop at its corner. The frescoes and mosaics that were visible are beautiful but that took all of 10 min to see. And be careful taking taxi getting there. Some take you the long way and pretend to not understand as your driving there. Our meter showed 80 tl and the direct route from old town should be approx 25 to
Must to see. This is the one of Christian site that survived the best. I love golden mosaic. I just can imagine how beautiful was original church.

Must Place to Visit. This church has some of the best mosaics and frescoes in Istanbul It is much smaller and more intimate that Aya Sofia. We went via the mosque at Eyup (reached by ferry) which was also a treat. Too far for us to walk to Chora but a cab ride was easy and inexpensive.

Church dedicated to Mary rather than Jesus. Though this is a church where the frescos tell the story of Jesus' birth and infancy, I felt that this was dedicated more to Mary than Jesus himself. That's the feeling I was left with. Wonderful paintings. Avoid flash cameras. If possible carry a small stool to sit in front of each fresco. The detailing and the preservation is worth spending time on!

Brilliant example of Byzantine mosaics. Chora Church was a highlight of our recent trip to Istanbul. Strangely, some guide books don't mention it but it is truly one of the great sights in Istanbul. The Byzantine mosaics are among the best we have ever seen.

Worth the trip. While the Chora Church is a little off the beaten track, it is well worth the journey. The mosaics are stunning and even though part was under renovation, we were able to get a feel for the whole church.

Beguiling history. The Chora Church is a little away from the hubbub of the Sultanahmet area. Which is both good and bad, the bad being you'll probably come here on a guided tour so you may not get the time you want here and the good being that it will give you a sense of being in a different part of the city.Essentially the reasons for seeing this church are to see a piece of history, a very old church that had its mosaics covered over when the Ottoman Turks took Constantinople but which were later uncovered again when the church was turned into a museum.As per so many of these places there was restoration work going on at the time of my visit. It's par for the course. But what could be seen was still impressive and gave a sense of what the place must have been like all those centuries ago. The wear on the doorsteps and the sense of antiquity that hung over the building as a whole were enchanting.There is (of course) a tourist shop there and you can buy books and DVDs about this and other top sites in Istanbul as well as the more usual tourist tat. Also there is a market and a couple of places to grab a snack outside.One downside was the fact that you didn't seem to be able to get a shot of the whole building. Mainly due to everything being built up so close to the church itself. There was no sense of occasion walking up to it because you just walk down a laneway, past a restaurant and then you are suddenly there.All up a highly recommended opportunity to get out of the centre of old Istanbul though not exactly away from the tourist crowds!

Elliot and Jennie in Istanbul. Chora Church is quite small, and a little away from all the other main attractions, in a very old part of the city. Undergoing major restoration work at the moment. Filled with very old paintings on the walls and ceilings.There are also cafes and market stalls nearby.

Beautiful Church Interiors!!!. The Chora Church Museum is being renovated and its exteriors are completely covered with scaffolding and boards. Nonetheless, 75% of the interiors are open now and are gorgeous. The church is small, but is FULL of amazing mosaics and frescoes telling the story of Mary, Jesus , etc. the art us similar to the ones found in Hagia Sophia. There is a small museum shop that sells nice souvenirs and books. The audio guides help. There is an art shop located behind the church that sells original art by young artists and art students. We found great pieces at reasonable prices. And bought 4 that have been framed together. I am regretting not buying more. The only negative is its location, far from the city center. We spent 40 Turkish Lira from Sultanahmet to get to Chora Church.

magnificent mosaik. Without being necessarily an expert of byzantine art, you will be fascinated by the beauty of the mosaic of the 14th century, absolutely stunning !We recommend to have a guide with you who knows the subject as the explanations and analysis of the Iconic Art in this Church is very deep and interesting. It is the worldwide reference of mosaic of Bysantine Art.
Beautiful mopsaics. Although the main church is under renovation, there is still plenty to marvel at. Fabulous mosaics and wall paintings.

Absolutely fabulous!. This church is redolent of history; unique in its story telling; and is home to some of the best mosaics and frescoes in the world. It is a relatively small church and a visitor might be well advised to read a little about the art and history of this extraordinary place to get the most from the visit; and, on leaving, to purchase a DVD or museum book to preserve the memories.
Get a guide. You will miss too much without one.. There is so much that is unique and wonderful about the early Byzantine church and its art that a guide is indispensable.
out of this world. If you like Byzantine art, and are a huge junky for excellent craftsmanship, you should definitely visit this place. One of the most beautiful mosaics you will ever see.

A gem. The crowds have found this delightfully historic gem prized for the mosaics which are mostly in pretty good condition. A guide (book, audio or person) is indispensable to understand the chronology of the mosaics. Outside there is a pleasant garden cafe with decent facilities.
Very beautiful paintings. The central nave was closed. The rest is really beautiful, but it is a small area to visit and admire the paintings.. Not easy to get there without a car.
Beautiful mosaics. Unfortunate that some was closed for renovations, but the mosaics were detailed and have been well preserved.

If appritiate Art this is a Must to see. Unbelievable 4th Century Mosaics of Icons, What time and elements could not destroy humans did.Than, because of Tourism with very high cost experts did a fantastic work to recover most of them.An expert painter at the time would have a great difficulty to draw an Icon in such detail that was done with mosaic's To get there catch a cab negotiate the price before and also if he is willing to wait to get you back were you start As is difficult to find public transport out of there unless you are willing to walk I will not recommend this after DarkOn your way back it is not to far to enjoy a Turkish coffee or Tea at Pierre Loti with fantastic view of the Golden Horn

Some beautiful mosaics but Nave closed; location not easy to get to -- watchout for scurrilous cabbies.. I have to agree with some of the reviews that the mosaics here are stunning, but after reading about the site and making the journey (more below), the fact that the Nave was closed was really disappointing. The accessible mosaics and small scale of this church/mosque are a nice counterpoint to the Hagia Sofia. The location is hard to get to, and we had our one negative experience of our trip when we were taken for a ride (literally and figuratively) when leaving from a cab that was waiting in the Sultanahmet area. The driver took us round and about, and through the really remote back streets surrounding the neighborhood and dropped us off at a back alley where we could see the site about 50 meters distant. We then had a verbal tussle over the amount of cash tendered. On the way home, we made our way to the main road -- about 200 m in other direction -- and flagged down a cab and made it back in half the time and half the fare.

Tucked away treasure. Not the easiest place to find, unless you are on a tour, but worth the effort.As soon as you step inside the history of the place immediately hits you.Take time to move with the crowd through each section. I guarantee you will have a sore neck from looking up at the ceilings.

Wonderful!!. Kariye Museum is a MUST if you are in Istanbul and love art: it has some of the best mosaics (very well conserved!!!) and affreschi you could ever see!!!! When we visited (beginning May 2015), half the Museum was closed for refurbishment. That being said, it is definitely worth a visit: it is less busy that the other Museums-Mosques, the mosaics are breathtaking, the neighbourhood is lovely for its architecture and history (it is possible to visit the historic city walls for free!!). The Museum can be reached by boat from Golden Horn, alighting at Ayvansaray, then walking up the hill alongside the historic walls. Access to the Kariye Museum (The Chora Church) is free with the Museum Pass - however, do bear in mind that during very busy times museums run out of passes; so do try several places in order to buy it!!!!!!!!!!!
Fabulous. If you like mosaics and frescoes, this is your place! Many, many beautiful mosaics and some important frescoes, as well. Better preserved and more of them than in Hagia Sophia.

Worth a guided visit. The ceilings reveal impressive historical art presented as a detailed visual story. The mosaics and paintings are often stunning and a knowledgeable guide brings this important and complex story to life.

Very nice to see, bit out of the way. We walked here from Sultanamhet, and, although it was quite a distance, it was worth it to see some of the backstreets of Istanbul, which you wouldn't normally see - we came across a street market in full swing - great for pictures - there is a nice park just below the church, and the church itself is well worth seeing due to its antiquity and the restored decoration....

A must visit for anyone interested in history of Christianity.. This was a real discovery for me. Despite that the church is undergoing exhaustive renovation, the rooms that are open present a true marvel, treasure of knowledge. You can see one of the rearest items in the history of Christianity - the entire life of the Mother of Christ. And it is all done in absolutely stunning mosaic. This church tells you a story that you will not find in the Bible or any other biblical texts. Truly amazing. Not far from the church is the old Christian monastery (Greek orthodox). That is also a place to visit. Deep inside the monastery is the well with holy water. It is said that it has healing powers. It is up to you, whether you believe it or not, but place is simply beatiful.

Heaven for art lovers. We tried finding the church on our own and it was not easy, but thanks to a very helpful young man on his way home from school, we made it. Restoration work was in progress, so exterior photographs were not great. However, we were allowed to take photographs (without flash) inside. The frescoes are awesome, and one could spend hours admiring their beauty, not an easy task to do with tour groups coming and going. However, if patient, select a spot against a wall to study a piece you find interesting and wait for a calm moment between groups.I was glad that work was being carried out to preserve this site.

Must see. Absolutely must see and worth the trouble of getting there, the most amazing and beautiful mosaics ever! Wonderful! Great cafes and cheaper gifts arround the church (which was turned to mosque, now museum). Museum Pass will get you in for free. Buses from Eminonu. Do not miss for anything!

Must see. One of the most beautiful and most powerful thing (places) to see in istanbul. Its outside the walls, so many tourist unfortunatelly skip it, but it is an absolute must see! Trust me! The most beautiful mosaics I've ever seen in my life, and trust me, I've seen loads of them! Definitely worth it! Explore some buses to there, its not that hard, there are a couple of buses from Eminonu that take you there.

Mosaics' delight. The mosaics at this church are well worth seeing. They tell the life of Christ. There was a section that was under restoration, but overall, its worth a visit. The mosaics are very well preserved and have good color.

Must-see for an religious art lover. Mosaics and frescoes are captivating. You can see them very close, as the building is not so huge as Hagia Sophia and most of the mosaics are in a good condition. Great example of Christian art heritage od Istanbul.

Nave closed for renovation. we only got to see the surrounding halls because the nave is closed for renovation / preservation. Soon the whole church will be closed so I guess we were even lucky we got to see a part of the Chora, very, very old structure in Istanbul. However, our tour guide did not give an accurate description of the mosaics, we just read the correct one in a book.
Roman age constraction. I like the fresco, on wall as well as ceiling, but renovation continue going on for long so some part, we couldn't see. but it look magnificent,
Such a lovely gem. I am so very happy we got to visit this gem. Loved the mosaic and the history of the church. Its a bit out of the way but so worth the "track".

Great church. One of the ortodox church which is still in best condition. You can see a lots of frescs in perfect condion and wall paintings from a early age of the fifth century. Also the surroundings are very interesting to visit. If you are not afraid to walk it makes sense to walk down to the Bosporus at the Balat Park and have a Turkish coffee watching the ships padding by.

Under repair. It has beautiful mosaics but most of the church is under repair works and cannot be seen. Indications to go there are not very clear, but getting there, and see the real Istanbulite life around makes it totally worth it
Ensure this on your list to see. Despite being a little out of the normal sight seeing area, this mosque and all its stunning mosaics and frescoes is an absolute must see.
Amazing mosaics. Do not miss this one, try to go with a guide to explain you the meaning of all the mosaics. it is magic and not too crowded

Best mosaics. Despite being from Italy, I never saw such beautiful mosaics. This place is really a hidden gem- ideally you would go there with a guide to explain you all the bible scenes from the various mosaics. Impressive!
Magnificent. Some of the best preserved Byzantine mosaics in the world. Simply a gem and should be a part of everyone's Istanbul itinerary.

Exceptional!. With its 14th century frescos & mosaics, this basilica is one of the most fascinating places in Istanbul. Take a local ferry (4TRY/ticket) and then walk along the old city wall. Get a taxi on your way back.

Worthwhile. This is a worthwhile visit! These frescos are beautiful.
Half of it was closed during the visit, but we still enjoyed it. Visit Kofteci Arnavut while you're there, try the amazing tripe soup!

Wonderful mosaics. This little church, dating back many centuries, houses the most wonderful mosaics and frescoes. Our guide and friend explained that some of the mosaics cover stories from some gospels other than those agreed to be part of the bible, which decision was made at the first convocation of the Christian Church at nearby Nicea. The craftsmanship is amazing. Part of the building was under renovation and so some of the best marble work was not able to be seen, but having seen it before, it is a tribute to the skill of craftsmen having no tools but the most basic, cutting marble with sheep gut, water and sand, sawing away to achieve a handspan of progress a day.

Exquisite mosaics. Despite part of the museum (which is also known as the St. Saviour Church in Chora) being under restoration, what you are able to see is perhaps even better than the beautiful mosaics of Ravenna.

Wow, wonderful mosaics all over!. Amazing art... the museum is being restored now, so that one-third is closed off. In time the other two sections will be closed and the restored section reopened. So, 2/3 will be open for visitors to see.

Beautiful...worth the visit!. It has beautifully preserved mosaics, and you can get much closer to them than at the Aya Sofya. Only drawback would be that restoration is ongoing so some of the mosaics might not be available to view. Your neck might also get a little sore from staring up at the mosaics...but its well worth the pain! :)

Partly closed, but still impressive. The nave of the church was closed for renovation when I was there, but over half the total area was still open. The frescos and mosaics were of outstanding quality, though not large. The modest size and rough finish of the church contrasted with the fine quality of the art, suggests that the founders were of modest means but spiritually rich. Only about 20 tourists were there when I was. Kariye is located in a remote part of the old city (but still in the core of the modern city of 14 million). I gave up trying to find public transit there and paid 25 TL for a taxi from the Grand Bazaar. Probably too much. I walked all the way back to Topkapi through real Turkish neighborhoods with no tourists. Consider that option.

beautiful mosaics. Kariye museum is a beatiful place to visit. It has special mosaics for art lovers. one of the best preserved bizantian art spot. Even if one don't know the stories behind the pictures, it is lovely to examine and dream of the artists putting all the little colored stones to make the tales alive.it is also close to ruins of an old Bizantium palace.

Best mosaics in Istanbul. Much better than AyaSofia. Really beautiful site. Don't miss the opportunity after to take a taxi and drive around the ancient walls to Castle Yedilkule to complete the visit !
Beautiful!. Beautiful ancient Christian church, worth a visit. Only drawback is that it's off the beaten track. Interior is superb.

A hidden Byzantine gem-Aya Sofya's little sister. After marvelling at Aya Sofya, we were fortunate to come across her little sister - the Kariye Museum, a mosaic laden church. Virtually all of the interior decor (sparkling mosaics and equally impressive al frescos) dates from 1312 and has endured five reconstructions. Like its big sister, it has been a church, a mosque and is now a beautifully preserved museum. A little out of the way but certainly well worth the effort and without the crowds or queues. Oh and while you're there, treat yourself to a dining experience like no other at the Ottoman inspired restaurant Asitane next door...my next review!

Stunning Frescos. Virtually all of the existing frescos on display, date from 13th century and depict the life and times of Jesus. Flash photography is strictly forbidden inside as it damages the fresco over time. Well worth seeing.
Beautiful building, worth a visit. Christian mosaics uncovered are beautiful. Small cost to get in, and short taxi ride to get there. Surrounded by cafes for a pitstop afer your visit.

Splendid. Tucked away near the land walls it's a bit of a challenge for the independent traveller but your efforts will be rewarded with some of the best Christian mosaics you are ever likely too see.

Beautiful story via frescos. The frescos tell the story of Mary, mother of Jesus, and her parents, and her childhood, her marriage to Joseph. Stories I've never heard of seen before. A lot of the fresco's are damaged by time, but still a delightful place to see the story in frescos. Do take a guide so he can explain the story to you. The inside was closed for renovation when I went in April 2015, but the frescos were outside which is why I got to see them.
Christians must see!. best church to visit in Istanbul. Better than Hagia Sophia. It's a very old one and kept well. You would see the mosaics untouched.

Mindblowing, even for a seasoned traveller. Just stepping into the church (half closed for restoration) and my breath was taken away by the mosaics. We arrived after 3 and stayed till after closing time, and only left almost half an hour after that. Yet there are really only three (big) spaces open (April 2015). Every picture really does tell a story. We thought we knew our Christian stories but there were new ones here.
renovation. a fantastic place but unfortunately right now the main part was closed for viewing. However, it has to be done at some point.

Chora Church is a real gem. Much less crowded than Hagia Sophia.This is a church turned into a museum, other names are Kariye Müzesi, Kariye Camii, Kariye Kilisesi, Chora Museum.For me, it is the most beautiful Byzantine church in Istanbul.Location : Edirnekapı - municipality of FatihHow to get there if you stay around Beyoglu-Taksim : take the bus no:87 from Taksim to Edirnekapı directionThe interior is covered with wonderful mosaics and frescoes.You will also enjoy the little streets around and the cafes right in front to have a tea or breakfast.I really loved my breakfast under the trees after our visit in the morning.

Worth a Visit !. One of the place where you can admire the best preserved mosaico, from Byzantium time. The Area it is not the most popular and touristic, but you will experience the true Istanbul. Near by is located the great defensive wall, which unfortunately is falling apart due to bad maintenance.

Sadly, the main church is closed for renovation. We saw this marvel in 2008. It was spectacular, one of the best surviving examples of Byzantine mosaics. It is mostly closed for renovation. Only the entrance areas are open, with only a small area of mosaics available to see. I don't know when the church will reopen, but when it does, do not miss it!
worth a visit. Even though the Chora Church is partially under restoration, and it is not possible to see all, it is still worth a visit. Beautiful mosaics and frescos from Byzantine era.

Beautiful!. No visit to Istanbul should fail to take in these beautiful mosaics and frescoes. It is slightly awkward to get to but you can walk up from Aksaray or the Golden Horn side (30-40 mins). Or get the metro from Aksaray to Topkapi (not the palace!) and then 15 mins along the old town walls, turning right at the main junction and right again after about 200 metres on the other side of the wall. Its a bit tricky but any local will know where you are going by then if you ask.

Really interesting site. Small site, but well worth venturing out of the centre of Istanbul for. The mosaics are beautiful. The admission price is very reasonable and because it is not near the centre it is less busy than other sites. Cameras are allowed as well.

Do not miss this.... The Church of St Saviour in Chora was built by Constantine the Great, but was rebuilt in the late 11th century (and is the one we see today). The frescoes and mosaics are amazingly beautiful and largely intact, dates from 1312, and were funded by the wealthy Theodore Metochites. The mosaic above the door in the inner narthex shows Metochites offering the Church to Christ.The mosaics depict the stories of the lives of the Virgin Mary and Christ. Arm yourself with a good guidebook that describes the scenes and be prepared to be stunned by the beauty and intactness of the mosaics. After the mosaics, go look at the no less beautiful frescoes in the side chapel which was a burial chamber for Metochites and his family. The frescoes depict scenes from the resurrection (loved this one in particular, showing Christ breaking down the doors of hell and rescuing Adam and Eve from their tombs) and salvation, the Last Judgment and Entry into Paradise.Parts of it (Central Nave and Apse) were undergoing renovations when we visited in April this year, but the outer and inner narthex and the parekklesion (i.e. the side chapel) were open. It was a feast for our eyes!!

Beautiful mosaics in a lovely neighborhood. Some of the best mosaics I've ever seen. This former church/mosque is undergoing restaurations, so not all of it is accessible, but the parts that are open are worth the visit! It's also a nice combination with a walk along the former city wall.

A small but beautiful wonder. Tucked outside the core sightseeing areas around the Aya Sofia and Grand Bazaar, this church has fantastic mosaics in one section and terrific frescoes in the other. Although the main body of the church is closed for repair, it is well worth the short taxi ride from the Grand Bazaar area. Highly recommended for ancient art lovers.
absolutely splendid. wonderful Byzantine art. out of the main tourist drag but well worth the visit. in the middle of restoration when we visited but when it's completed it will be magnificent

Absolutely beautiful - don't miss it!. This small museum, formerly a church, has the most amazingly beautiful mosaics of Christ's life and Mary's life. One of my favorites was of Mary as a toddler taking her first steps. Best way to get there is by taxi since it is a little out of the way, but it is absolutely worth your trouble to get there.

One of the Gems of Istanbul!. When we arrived at the Kariye Museum, (Chora Church) we bought our tickets and then were offered a guided tour for an additional fee. We are so glad that we consented and paid the relatively small extra fee. In addition to mosaics of biblical scriptural accounts, the mosaics tell less well know stories in mosaic form of the stories of Mary's birth, childhood, and life as told in the Apocrypha. We would never have seen and understood this without our guide, Sedar Donmez, who was wonderful at showing and explaining in great detail. An amazing sight! The Chora Church is definitely out of the way, but that makes it more interesting. It is out on the edge of the old city and the city wall is visible throughout the old neighborhood of small winding streets. Just next door to the church/museum is an excellent restaurant the serves great Ottoman food.

Amazing mosaics (and go see/climb the old city walls!). If you love mosaics (or just want a jaunt away from the busier tourist areas) you MUST go to this museum. The mosaics are stunning.A few tips -- if you are going in the summer, bring a fan. It gets very hot in there -- bring a guide or a guidebook (we had Rick Steves). The mosaics are pictorial representations of many bible stories (particularly those of Mary and Christ), so it is helpful to know at what you are looking (and in what order to look). There are also a lot of bible characters and saints that you would not necessarily be able to place if you did not know who they are. -- go walk on the old city walls! If you head up Kariye Cami and take a right on Vaiz, you get to Hoca Chakir, which runs right along the old walls. If you then head left (aka with the wall to your right as you are walking), you will come to a staircase that will take you up onto the walls. If you are feeling adventurous, continue walking to a *second* staircase that offers you a higher view (accessed by a ladder-like staircase that looked more intimidating than it ended up being). Definitely an impressive view from either staircase, and there aren't many people up there, so you get to enjoy the experience alone or mostly alone (unlike most other places in the city)
Being Renovated. It is definitely a taxi ride away from most hotels or other sites. From the little we could see, the mosiacs were beautiful. Smaller than other churches.

History, art, spirituality. It is a great joy to view Byzantine churches as they were centuries ago. Chora is now a museum, but there is the chance to see original mosaics, Byzantine craftsmen masterfully executed. Wednesday is closed. The local name is Kariye Müzesi and it is about 10-15 minutes walk from the church Vlaherne

Interesting discovery. Thanks to our guide, Selma Elise Numanoglu, we discovered this christian church coverted in a museum.She explained us the story of each ceramic and frescoes which cover the old and the new testament.Very nice and interesting.

Chora Church. The mosaics at the Chora Church, now a museum, are amazing. Nit is worth the trek to western Istanbul to see them. You can check out the old Roman walls around the city at the same time.

So beautiful we cried.. Truly beautiful place out near the city's Western walls. Worth a trip - even if you get a cab (we walked from the Spice Bazaar but that might not be for everyone!) The mosaics and frescoes are sublime and many people miss this treasure.

Don't miss!. Must be one of the most important sites in Istanbul - as well as underrated. It isn't that difficult to find - on foot is better in my opinion , even though the surrounding area isn't really a spectacle. Well you've probably heard all about the mosaics, and yes they're all true. Even if you don't care about the mosaics think again it's totally worth it. Then it's also close to the Walls and the Patriarchate so you can combine. Do it people you won't regret!
Beautiful mosaics. This was a bit of a trek out of the city but well worth the effort to visit. Lovely mosaics and paintings which have been restored.

Take a Taxi. The best way to get to this museum/church is by taxi and then you should walk down the hill back to the downtown part. The building is currently under renovation so you cannot see the exterior. Also the nave is closed for repairs as well. The main frescos/mosaics are in the other alcoves of the church with the must-see in the chapel to the side (very crowded especially when there is a tour group there). Be sure to keep looking up and around you or you just might miss something beautiful...

Under restoration, important parts open to visit. The church is currently receiving a roof. A complete metal structure is currently built above and around the Church. This is considered the jewel of Istanbul, with the mosaics of Deiisis and Jesus in the Pronaos. The mosaics were made after the reconquest of 1261 and have shades and perspective. Unique masterpieces of art! Currently though, because of the restoration, (only) the main church hall, Naos, is closed. However, the mosaics, frescos, and important parts are outside and may be vistied.

Glad I Went. After checking in to my hotel, this was the first place I went (by taxi). It is quite removed from the downtown, but the mosaics are exquistite. Sadly during my visit, the exterior was undergoing renovation and the nave was also closed for this purpose. The main mosaics to see are in the outer areas which are still open. The side chapel is very popular thus crowded, but worm your way through the tour groups and see it. Most of the famous mosaics are straight up, but be sure to look all around you at the walls as well. When you are done and ready to go back downtown (if you have the time), walk as you get to go through the local neighborhoods and see people just living their lives.
Spectacular mosaics and frescoes. Very different from other mosques and churches we visited. Lots of history. Small area in which to view mosaics, which can be very crowded.

A must- well worth the trip out. Do not hail a taxi in the Sultanahmet area to go here. We did and were very badly fleeced. Walk a little away from there towards the grand bazaar and you should be ok. We were on the other occasions we got taxis from the grand bazaar area. Or, get the ferry and walk up by the old walls. We couldn't do that, as we had planned to do so, as the weather was atrocious. There is an excellent guide book with stunning photos. The mosaics are outstanding, as are the frescos. Take binoculars.
Worth the search.. This church has fantastic mosaics that are in incredible condition and often still in completeness of biblical scenes that are not normally depicted.

Stunning display of frescos and mosaics. Well worth the trip off the usual tourist path - and frankly, quite easy to get to, if you didn't mind some walking. Even with the nave of the church closed for renovations/restoration, this was worth the trip and the 15TL admission price. The mosaics here are simply astounding. Bring binoculars! I regret that I didn't have a way to get a closer look at the ceiling work. I ended up purchasing a book just for the photos.This attraction is part of the Museum Pass Istanbul card program. In addition to the admission fee, you also receive 10% off at the shop.And, in the event of pouring rain (like the day we visited), the café across from the entrance to the church has some of the best kunefe we ate on our entire visit.

Under Restoration, But Definitely Worthy of a Visit as Mosaics Were Incredible. The mosaics and frescoes in the three areas available to visitors were the BEST that I saw in any of the churches, museums or other venues in Istanbul. However, this Church is under a major restoration and none of the exterior is visible. Only three small chambers are available and, of course, they are very crowded, because all the groups of tourists are crammed in together. Despite those negatives, I would still buy a museum pass and visit this Church. It is mesmerizingly beautiful. (I would not bother to buy an audio guide, because there are only 6 points available to be described and the audio guide was relatively expensive.)

However preferred Hagia Sofya. The mosaics at the Hagia Sofya were equally good, so the Chora Church can be avoided if you don't have more than 2 days in Istanbul. There's not much to see of the old city walls. Poor part of Istanbul.

Beautiful Byzantine Mosaics. This small church is off the beaten path but still popular with tourists, particularly if you like Byzantine religious art. I have read that the mosaics here are the best outside of Italy, and there are many frescoes also. The church is undergoing restoration, so you may not be able to see everything when you visit. Go anyway--this is a unique site where the masters of mosaic art adorned the church walls with exquisite church art.
Great Mosaics. This is a great place if you like mosaics. It can be tricky to find. Also, nearby there are the old city walls that you can touch.
Stunning. Even though the restoration is far from complete, the uncovered mosaics were breathtaking. I look forward to a return visit.

Magnificent art. The small church is a museum, and the frescoes are deserving of the designation. The experiences was enhanced by our knowledgeable guide who explained the chronology and the imagery of the art. Do NOT miss. And as a bonus, next door is a small restaurant that serves delicate Ottoman cuisine.

Wonderful experience. The place is undergoing restoration works but still offers such a great treat on visit that I wonder what it will be like to visit when it is fully open and running for the visitors to experience the church and its full beauty. The mosaics range to a long period back and because of which holds a lot of astonishing stories and elements to it. The surrounding areas of the church too is quite peaceful and adds to the serene and beauty of the place

Impressive Mosiac Images. This had the best, and well-preserved mosiac tiles in all the churches in Istanbul. It'd be more captivating for one who is familiar with the biblical stories, as there were many different scenes depicted by mosiac on the walls, and ceilings. A must-visit if you're interested in Christian art.
Preserved Christianity. A very accessible and interesting Byzantine/Ottoman era church now being restored and open as a museum. Guides can bring the brilliant mosaics to life

Stunning. A highlight of our trip to Istanbul. The mosaics and frescos are some of the best in the world. Easy to get to by taxi and taxis are not expensive. Easily combined with a visit to the Eyup Mosque and Pierre Lotti Cafe. The area around Chora is interesting, has few tourists and is quite different from other parts of Istanbul.

well preserved mosaics. Unfortunately right now they are renovating the outside of the church (for a few more years...) but the inside is still very interesting. The mosaics are well preserved and tell stories from the Bible. Must see even if you are not a church goer.When you go there you HAVE to have lunch at Asitane, the ottoman restaurant next to the church. It was one of the best meals we had in Turkey (see my other review of the restaurant)

Chora church Istanbul (Kariye Museum). Our tour guide took us to this wonderful church on our Istanbul tour. It is one of the few that has had mosaics revealed after being used as a mosque for a number of years. The inside is one of the most beautiful really old churches tha mosaics exposed years after being covered up.

Very interesting and beautiful. After visiting Hagia Sophia, where you can see a few mosaics in the similar style, we were told we had to visit the Chora Church. Even under construction it is very much worth the visit, the golden mosaics are not only nice to see, but also very interesting as they are telling a story throughout the church.A strong advice - get a map or clear directions before heading out to Chora, and learn the Turkish name for it (Kariye). If you're not familiar with the city, it's easy to get lost in that part of Istanbul, and since it's not in the touristic centre, the locals really try to be helpful, but mostly don't speak English at all.

MUST-visit while you are in Istanbul. The mosaics here are simply the best-preserved in all of Istanbul. They are gorgeous, even if you're not hugely into the whole Jesus thing. A fun game to play is seeing if you can recognize the scenes from the Bible without checking the guide. While you're in the area, avoid the pricey souvenirs in the plaza across from the church, but definitely stop by Asitane next door (life-changing!!) and (on the way from the bus/Metro) climb up the old land walls for a taste of Byzantium!

Mosaics and Mother Mary. When Istanbul was a very new city, the people there were pagans. In Istanbul there were temples to Artemis and Athena., They recognized the importance of women. When Constantine took over, the cult of women continued with the recognition of Mary, Mother of Jesus. This old church is covered with mosaics telling the story of Mary. While it is being restored, not all of the church can be viewed, but enough of it can be seen. It is stunning and lovely. The area around the church is also a lovely area. Sit, relax, drink some tea, and go for a walk.
Spectacular mosaics of the life of Mary. This church is truly beautiful. It presents amazing mosaics portraying the life of Mary and showing an aspect of Christianity that is not often seen.

Take a cab. We took a taxi here from our hotel first thing on a Sunday morning. Traffic was light (I'm guessing, relatively) and we enjoyed our ride along The Golden Horn and past Constantine's walls to get here. This is a small, modest byzantine church, lavishly decorated with frescos and mosaics inside. Having visited the Hagia Sophia the day before and being wowed by its immensity and scale, we found this church an intimate gem. Predating Sophia with its own history of ruin and restoration, it tells a wonderful story. Do see it.
Best church ever!. It's a great example of Byzantine Art.With its apocryphal Gospels mosaics, it's unique in the world!

wonderful church for those who enjoys Byzantium. great place is interesting for those who wants to compare the mosques and сhristian сhurch. but the way there isn't clear: if you take a tramway - you have to go a lot along the old city wall. so it's better to take a bus #37
Not miss the mosaics. The best Bizantine mosaics in the old Costantinople.From there you can enjoy a long walk along the city walls.

My Favorite in Istanbul, So Far. Make time to stop at Chora Museum. Although off the beaten path. the mosaics are phenomenal and tell the story of the Virgin Mary. High end gift shop within the museum was nice too. You may take photos without flash or a tripod. There is an entrance fee. Lots of souvenir shopping outside the entrance as well as an interesting cafe.

Worth seeing despite renovation work. We weren't sure about visiting because we knew parts of the church were closed for renovation, but as of mid-March there was still enough to see that we were glad we made the effort to get there. I have never seen such beautiful mosaics!

Revisit into the Old culture. The slow uncovering is an on going process. Every few years one revisits one will find something new uncovered.
It is an old masterpiece worth visiting in a lifetime and visiting it brought alive Dan Browns novel which one had read. In fact various parts of Istanbul were brought alive.

Beautiful church worth a short visit. Unfortunately, it was raining and freezing when we went here, otherwise we would have stayed longer to study the mosaics. Truly beautiful - I had to run back to look up the history of the church and the art. Even with the inner church closed for refurbishing, you can still see the majority of the mosaics.

Mosaics. This is a beautiful little church. It is currently undergoing restoration which means that the main dome is closed to the public, however the mosaics in the remainder of the church are also beatiful.

Just incredible.. Give yourself a few hours for this one. It's a bit out of the way, but it's close to the Spice Market, so it can be paired with that for a day trip. It would have been worth it to have a guide, because the history is fascinating, but a good guide book will also do. The main dome was being restored, so sadly we couldn't see that, but the mosaics and frescoes we did see were beyond gorgeous, amazingly detailed, and so well-preserved. Don't miss this.

Simply Spectacular. A bit out of the way, but just spectacular. Fabulous mosaics. You can see it all in an hour. Part of it is closed for renovation, but at least when we were there, all the best parts were open.

Chora Church and Istanbul City Walls. The Chora Church, know for its Christian mosaics, is most easily reached from the Old City by taxi. At our visit, March 2015, the nave was under renovation so a great many mosaics were not visible. We were able to see the mosaics in the two long hallways that lie just within the entry, and some frescos. The church lies on a small square with a café and a few tourist shops. Toilets are in the café. From the church, a short walk uphill along the street next to the cafe ends at the massive city wall. There is a stairway without railings leading to a small area, again without railings, on top of the wall. Following the wall to your left for a short distance, one can walk through an entrance gate (now transected by a large roadway) to view the outside of the wall. The wall is impressive and worth a visit but the areas away from the gate are not particularly well maintained. When ready to return, one can flag down a yellow taxi for the trip back to the Old City. It will help to have your next stop written down to help the cab driver understand where you wish to go.

Kariye Museum. It certainly has the most preserved mosaic and frescoes of Byzantine icons. It also is in restoration so access to the nave was closed. Nevertheless, it's worth visiting despite the circuitous route you have to take to get there.

Wait till renovations are done. it is currently undergoing renovation so much of the church is closed to visitors. The mosaics are beautiful, as is the architecture, however its quite a trek and a 15tl fee. However there is not much left from the Byzantine empire and this church is a little gem, just a shame that currently you can't fully explore it. However it does deserve to be saved for future generations

Highlight of My Trip. I have been to Istanbul many times and I waited much too long to see this breathtaking Church...now a Museum. Please move this to the top of your travel list. It is a little out of the way and under construction but the mosaics and frescos are incredible. They are more complete/less damaged than in Agia Sophia or the cave churches in Cappadochia. Do take advantage of the audio tour that is available for 15 TL. But only turn it on after you have given yourself time to gaze in wonderment. We took a cab ride to the Church on an overcast afternoon and there were very few people inside. We wandered and gazed at our leisure. I could not believe the skill level of the artists who created the mosaics. The face of the Virgin Mary, a suffering mother, was echoed in the Pieta centuries later. Do not miss this incredible experience.

amazing mosaics and frescoes. it takes an important role in byzantine art and its strongly suggested to see the museum during your travel in Istanbul. I think its the second most important place of byzantine empire in the city.

Stunning and shouldn't be missed. For tourists visiting Istanbul for only a few days, it's difficult to squeeze in the Chora Church, but it's really essential. The frescos are some of the most exquisite in the world. Photos don't do it justice. You really are transported upon stepping inside this unbelievable place. Yes, it's under renovation, but don't let that deter you. How this structure has withstood all that history is unfathomable, but it's here, so see it. Also a great opportunity to either climb, or at least, get close to the walls. Don't pay more than 12 to 15 lira for a taxi from Sultanahmet or Taxim. Careful at night (but you're just fine during the day).

Wonderful Byzantine mosaics. Not that easy to get to, but totally worth the trip. The intimate scale makes the mosaics seem more powerful than the comparable ones in Aya Sofia or Ravenna. And the nearby wall ruins are impressive too.

An incredible find. Full of beautiful old frescos. A bit of a distance from the main tourist areas but worth the trip. I recommend getting a cab and having them wait for you to finish the tour. The original church at this site was built around 530 years after the death of Christ. The qualities of the Frescos are breathtaking.

Great Mosaics. Quite hard to get to but the mosaics are well worth the effort. Hidden away - we took the tramway 1 to the city wall, walked along the inside until we reached a mosque on the top of the hill, turned right and then followed the signs.
calm and peaceful. I vist church everydaym due to my istanbul visit I go here, these place is very calm and peaceful and i feel like i am more closer to god.

The greatest mosaics in Istanbul. The Church of St Saviour in Chora, also known as the Kariye Museum, is a 14th Century masterpiece - it was adorned throughout with mosaics, and most of these have survived. There are four main 'rooms' in the church - the outer porch, the inner porch, the funeral chapel and the main nave. When I was there the main nave was closed for restoration work, but there was still enough to see in the rest of the church. The funeral chapel is decorated with frescoes rather than mosaics but they are still spectacular.

A Roman imperial art museum - Mosaics. The word 'mosaic' makes us think that tesella (small colored stone tiles) have something to do with muslims, actually they learned their architecture and most of their artistic skills from Greek and Romans and afterwards when Europeans saw what muslims had learn they thought it was something made by themselves completely and called 'turkish baths' the Thermas that had been used for millenia by greek and roman, and the same happened with church architecture addopted for mosques or tile work later called 'mosaic'. Chora is a wonderful place to go see fine mosaics from about 15 centuries ago.

Extraordinary. A Must See.. This is a spectacular small church/museum. It is a little out of the way and it is under renovation, but when we visited, only the Nave was closed, and most of the good things are in other parts of the church. The mosaics are absolutely stunning. They are almost overwhelming in their richness.The frescos less so, partially because they are faded, while the mosaics are not, but they are great too. For my money, this is the number one place to visit in Istanbul. Read up on the mosaics before you go. They tell the whole story! This is not a big place, so your visit doesn't have to be a long one, but it will be worth it.

Absolutely Amazing!. We walked from our B&B in the Sultanahmet area to this museum, which took just over an hour to get there. Our route was easy to follow walking along one of the main roads leading to the city walls. As we neared the church there were signs pointing out the correct way. At this time the exterior of the church is covered in scaffolding but the museum is still open. Using our museum card for entrance and Rick Steve's Istanbul guidebook to describe the interior we spent a very enjoyable time. The mosaics are amazing and well worth the time. At present the main part of the church is closed for renovations but as the majority of the mosaics are in the inner and outer narthexes you miss out on very little. Definitely make a trip to this little church to see some of the worlds finest examples of Byzantine artwork,
A MUST to see. No much to tell, if you like art and history, this church/museum is a must. The place by itself might be a excuse to visit Istambul

fantastic early mosaics.. Good to have a guide to explain the mosaics and frescos; interesting as well as beautiful. Renovation of main church prevented entry to this part but best stuff is in the entrance and side chapel anyway.

God still lives here. The oldest byzantian Church , 5 century , mosaics showing life of Mary and the Christ ...was amazed about beauty ...also frescas very well preserved ...A must for all lovers of Byzantian art

Exquisite. The church contains the most beautiful mosaics and frescos I have ever seen. Unfortunately the government confiscated it from the Patriarchiate, but at least it is not a mosque, and it is being preserved. When we visited, a large part was closed off for preservation work, but what we did see was inspiring. It is well worth a visit.

Best Church to see in Istanbul. I love this church. I've been several times. The ceiling shows the story of Mary in gold mosaic. It has a very interesting history. Nearby is also a place called "lovers Lane" you can look over Istanbul it has a cute little tea room also. This place is a must see!

Definitely worth it!. The mosaics are spectacular. A step back in time as this Church was built a bit over 500 years after Christ. This was my favorite stop after Topkapi Palace. Was an expensive cab ride bit worth every penny.
old old old..... The main hall is under renovation at the moment so it was a shame we could not access it. Amazing bit of history even though small.

Rip off while restoring!. The Church are in the process of being renovated, so only the entrance hall is accessible. But still they charge the FULL price of 15 TL. We could not enter the church proper. Outside, they also say that the only the NEON is closed. AND they also charge 15TL for an audio -guide!

Anti-Climax. I visited here with two friends and our host. We discovered, after we paid and went inside that the only area open to public was the outer hallways. The interior part of the church was closed for remodeling/repairs/restorations. Interesting paintings and mosaics otherwise.
The best mosaics ever!. The Chora museum is a hidden treasure and a must see for all tourists.The mosaics are well preserved and breathtaking!

Chora Church = Worth A Visit. This was my second favorite site in Istanbul. Only 15 Lira to visit, the mosaics in the church are impressive. I highly recommend travelers to give this a visit.
Only problem that may deter people from seeing this is that it is located a bit far away from the main points of interest.
historic extraordinary mosaics. the most beautiful mosaics in this special early Byzantine church, depicting early Christian stories.
Beautiful. Beautiful designs and paintings. Didn't take to long to go thru it as part of it is closed for renovations. Had some great mosiacs!

excellent mosaics. even though it was converted into a mosque, mosaics are all well preserved as they were all covered by plaster ( icons , faces are not allowed in mosques ) u can see all details virgin Mary' and Jesus Christ' life on mosaics, excellent museum to see it, from eminonu u can get bus to there or with a cab from sultanahmet should be 15 turkish lira and entrance 15 turkish lira too

Beautiful Church but undergoing restoration. The Chora Church is beautiful and contains some amazing mosaics which have to be seen to be believed as the detail and intricacy is amazing.However, be warned that there is currently a major reptoration programme taking place and, when we visited in February 2015, the parts of the church open to the public were extremely limited and the main areas of the building which contain the majority of the mosaics was closed.Unfortunately, there was no indication when this will re-open but it will be on my agenda to revisit when it does.

If you like history go. We took a bus there (no.87 from our delightful hotel Armada Pera) and felt like locals . A short walk through snowclad streets to a little gem. It 's better if you know the Bible to decipher the paintings but it is fun to work out what these fabulous mosaics/frescoes are about. Beautifully depicted scenes of Mary and Jesus and the saints. Go if you like art history. It is special. Rivals the Ravenna scenes but more intimate. We were in Istanbul for the 2nd time so it was perfect for us .

Great. Chora museum is a must see in istanbul with its unique mosaics. It is second to Hagia Sophia remaining from Roman times. Typical christian histories were described in the mosaics to teach the newly christian istanbul of konstantin of those times. Artistically, the mosaics give important clues about the art perception of byzantium and the architecture of the building is also a mile stone in the byzantim history. The museum is walking distance to some other historical roman and osmanli sites. The district of museum itself a old jewish quartier. The jew who escaped from the brutality of europeans in medieval age did refuge into istanbul and they were given that place to settle. However, today there are no jews, instead there are conservative muslims. The district is safe but home to many islamic sects but it it is still nice to walk around and take street photos.
