Nowadays, the whole region is being replanned. Most of the buildings will be demolished or renewed and the rich turks will be replacing today's owners. So these are last few years to experience the natural being of the district. So,do not miss it :)

The Mother of God. I always like it when I go into an Orthodox Church and see "The Mother of God", arms wide open and welcoming me up on the ceiling. The frescos and the mosaics are great. It's not a waste of time to take the tram out to this site, taking the tram is fun too.
Quite the best. Despite the renovations and the snow this was a highlight of our visit to Istanbul. The mosaics and frescos are beautiful and it's possible to see them up close. Well well worth it

Outstanding Frescoes. A visit to this tiny gem outside the city centre is certainly worth the taxi-ride. St Saviour is brimming with Byzantine frescoes and mosaics that sparkle with personality and colour. It seems quite incredible to be so close to works of this era and what’s more with fewer visitors than the big Istanbul attractions. An absolute stunner – try not to miss it!
Gobsmacked!. The most amazing Byzantine mosaics, rival Ayasofya. Wouldn't miss either whilst in Istanbul. A little out of the way, taxi is the easiest way to get there and not expensive

Impressive mosaics. The trip to the church was easy with the train systems and well worth the visit. The interior mosaics were unbelievable and the majority were still intact. I will never forget this special place of worship and was able to get many photographs.
Mosaics of Kariye Museum. Frescoes ,mosaics, and, wall paintings of Kariye are very well protected and fantastic. I strongly recommand to go there if Istanbul will be visited.

Excellent mosaics and frescoes. If you love mosaics and frescoes this is one of the most important place to visit. Please find a book or a guide of the place and spend some time in front of each and every picture you see. There is a whole history behind.
Best mosaics and frescoes. Anastasis frescoe awaits for your visit. It's probably the best preserved one in Istanbul. I also recommend to have a Turkish style tea in the garden cafe nearby.

quite impressive. very impressive mosaics and wall paintings
but due to restoration too crowded and interior section can not be
visited.

Ruined yet worth the trip. It is an effort to get there as it is not very well known. The mosaics are a true work of art, painstakingly created by the experts of the olden Byzantine empire. It is probably impossible to restore the lost work despite modern technology as the artistry is probably missing. See it before it disappears.

A Gem but Under Renovation. Definitely worth the trip (take a cab) and you can visit the Theodosian Walls nearby, but the church has been under renovation since 2012 and only a portion of it is accessible. Some good souvenir shopping there as well.

Excellent, the only but is that the inside is closed. Anyway it worths the trip. You heve to thake a bus from near Galata Bridge to get there. But is a short journey and you will see perhaps the most beatiful bizantine tiles in Istambul. In the lobby you have a lot of biblical scenes, that you surely understand. Anyway they have an audio guide. You have also some freshes paintings very, very beatiful. It can take you a few hours, bur surely you will not regret it

Well worth a trip. Take a bus from Eminonu by the Galata Bridge through lots of interesting neighborhoods and then, you come to this great little church. It is just a wealth of grand mosaics from early Byzantine times. As said before, the exterior is nothing grand or glorious but inside, WOW. It is not usually on the tour circuit so, if you have independent time, it is definately worth the visit. They had an audio tour-worth the money. Gave you lots of information.

Golden mosaics overall. First, I hesitated if I should go to this church which is further than the center of the Old Town. But I am so glad I made the trip, it has overall mosaics on the ceiling and the walls and they are pretty good preserved, better than those in Hagia Sophia.

Under renovation at present. Even though this was mainly being renovated and only a small area to visit, the mosaics and frescos were magnificent. We had a guide with us who explained all to us in glorious detail.

An istanbul gem. The Chora church may not be as easily accessible or grand or lofty like the Ayasofya or Sultanahmet instead its an intimate building unpolished on the outside but glittering with mosaics on the inside. The mosaics in this building are the most colourful and glittering I have seen.This is a must see destination. Its located in a historically interesting area of istanbul. You could just wander around the area to experience how istanbullus live and last but not least combine the visit with a meal at Asitane restaurant literally next door.What better way to spend half a day in this absorbing part of istanbul.
One of the best mosaics I have ever seen. This church has an amazing number of mosaics related to the biblical life. There are colorful and mostly very well preserved. A must see in Istanbul!!!

Absolutely beautiful!. This hidden gem is a little out of the way, but well worth the trip to find. The bus loop can also be a challenge but the people of Istanbul are so lovely and helpful that if you point to the location on a map or show the name, likely you'll be directed. We actually got the bus ride at no charge, they were so willing to help, and when we got off, we thought the guy was going to walk us down, lol!The murals and tile work are all incredible here, with every nook and cranny having something to see. It can get quite crowded when the tours arrive, so if on your own try to plan for mid-afternoon. The area around the church is pretty un-touristy, and we walked back to the Grand Bazaar area from here, which was a hike, but a great experience. Recommended!

Its a must see!. Many people comes to Istanbul for about 2 or 3 days. They visit Hagia Sophia, Blue mosque, Grand Bazaar and Bosphorus. Many of them miss Chora Church, which is standing in the old city like a hidden treasure. It is even more interesting than Hagia Sophia about mosaics and frescoes. In the corridors of the church, there are the life of the Virgin Mary and Jesus Christ following a pattern. Mosaics are about 800 years old and they are in very good condition. Some of them seem like they are made just yesterday.

For the love of mosaics. Getting at the place can be a bit tricky so try hiring a guide or using local transportation to get you at the place. The church is a must visit for the beautiful frescoes at the place. Though the renovation work was in action while we visited the place but still the trip was a wonderful experience. It would have been much more sweeter if they could have allowed photography there.
Beautiful. I loved the mosaics, but when we visited there was a renovation and we didn't see it all. The small part we got to see, was brilliant.

Favorite Off-the-Tourist Path. It will offer a good challenge in finding the way. Afterward look around the neighborhood at the incredible historical row homes. You'll be amazed some of them are still standing.The officers are very strict on their no lighting policy while taking photographs inside the church. Such is life. So buy a book to keep a memory of the pictures, and instead just take the real thing in without all the equipment!This church is simply amazing.
Breathtaking. The mosaics in this smaller, out of the way church will leave you breathless. Well worth a visit. Easily accessible with public transport or taxis.

A bit out of the way, but worth it!. Chora Church was highly recommended because of its mosaic murals and frescos. We decided to go find it via Tram! The tram took us to the general area, went to a hotel and asked for more directions, took a small yellow mini bus, and a kind lady on the bus said: Kariye Musee? ...I said yes, and she smiled and nodded. We got off at a 'stop', followed her as she practiced her English with us, and she took us to Chora Church. Worth seeing, great experience, wonderful people!

How Did They Do That?. The mosaics at the Chora Church are astounding. I have a new appreciation for the early eastern church. The artists designing and making them were exceptionally talented. My husband and I spent significant time identifying Biblical scenes depicted. Some were quite new to us! Part of the church was under restoration when we visited, however I believe it is still very worth the extra time and effort to travel there.I would hire a guide if touring the church again. There are so many mosaics to see that it would have been nice to have listened to a person instead of attempting to look all of them up in a book. (A book describing the Chora Church mosaics is worth taking home. People have found ours fascinating.) Go.

Lovely.. Make sure that you book a guide, they are very reasonable and can help you appreciate the experience more by telling you the stories so you can concentrate on admiring them rather than reading and hunting for the particular section yourself. I have done it both ways, but it was a much more enjoyable experience with the guide. Excellent.

Under construction. I was disappointed it was under construction... Could not go in the church, yet they charge the same amount just to see 2 hallways. These were probably the most impressive two hall ways I have ever seen however. Glad I went to see it.

Real mosaics. Even if the location is a little bit hard to be reached, if you have a little bit more time to wander on the streets and suburbs of Istanbul and if you want to see some great byzantine mosaics and paintings, you have to be here.
Absolutely beautiful. It is a must see in Istanbul, have a guide if possible because you will notice and understand so much more!
A must see. The mosaics are amazing. I recommend the audio guide to fully understand and appreciate even more the treasures to be found in this church. Maybe the most amazing piece of art I've seen.
Heaven. I viist for peace and i get it...I was stay there for 2 hrs, very peaceful and clean place God stay here i will visit again, may god full fill my wish..

On Restoration-. We lived in Balat for most of our stay in Istanbul so Chora Museum was on walking distance from our place. But like what other mentioned, the main part of the museum was closed due to the renovation. However it still offered you an astonishing view inside.
Beautiful Byzantine mosaics.. You back to ancient time, are very well preserved. It's worth going up there, although it is a bit far from all the major attractions in Istanbul.
Detour. Personally, I think this is the one of the most gorgeous and wonderful mosaic - laden church in Istanbul.

Not worth it unless you have a pass. It was a disappointment. The main naos was closed due to restoration and only a small part of the church was open for viewing. Would not recommend anyone to go until the naos is opened again. UNLESS you have a pass and lots of time. It's a little far away from the rest of the Istanbul attractions.

Partially closed for renovation. Much of this museum/church was closed for renovation when I visited, so it wasn't really worth the trek out to it, although there was some nice artwork on the walls and ceiling of the small part that was open.

Pretty Mosaics. Small, far away but pretty none the less. Worth the journey if you on the 5 day pass (they DONT sell the 5 day pass at Chora! Buy it before hand!) Otherwise the trip there takes longer than exploring it, and is pretty but not worth 15TL.

Astonishing window into Byzantium. Many of these mosaics are roughly contemporary to Giotto's Scrovegni Chapel and just as revolutionary. This church is one of the greatest cultural treasures of the western world. I am shocked I had not heard of it before. Great experience!

mosaics, architecture. Go for the mosiacs. If you have the museum card, entry is free. Beautiful mosiacs that you can see up close. the architecture is interesting, too, for the brawny arches and sturdy feel of the whole thing. I walked it from the Hagia Sophia (about an hour through Istanbul), and loved the walk on the warm sunny day. Worth it if you have the time.

after Hagia Sofia must be visited. It's quite out of the main touristic spots. but tour operators do organise tours here. And If u want to come on your own there are busses passing close by; get off at Edirnekapı stop and walk around 300meters. It's a very old church, converted to mosque and then finally to museum. It has been used as a monastery n cemetry in its early centuries... There are Magnificent fresks to see inside... For tourists those 72 hrs musuem passes are valid here.. at the moment this musuem is not working on WEDNESDAYS...
Worth seeing. The main part of the monument museum is closed for works. However it remains worth seeing. Impressive mosaics depicting the story of Virgin Mary

Beautiful Mosaics, arrive by tram!. For some reason it seems like a lot of people think the only way to get here is by bus or taxi. We arrived from Sultanahmet by the tram (line T1 to line T4) to the Edirnekapı stop. It was very easy, clean, safe, and modern.The mosaics were awesome, and the church is definitely worth the trip to get there.

Hard to get to. You need a taxi to get there. It is hard to find another taxi to go back. You don't need more than 1/2 hour to visit this site. Get a good map to be able to visit the nearby historic sites. The streets are confusing and no one speak English there :)

really interesting. You can't get into the actual have because of renovation work.but the mosaics are of a wonderful quality.interesting to hear a different slant on the Christian version of Mary and Joseph story,

Beautiful Mosaics, arrive by tram!. For some reason it seems like a lot of people think the only way to get here is by bus or taxi. We arrived from Sultanahmet by the tram (line T1 to line T4) to the Edirnekapı stop. It was very easy, clean, safe, and modern.The mosaics were awesome, and the church is definitely worth the trip to get there.

Definitely worth seeing.. I really can't say too much about this place. A church that is now a museum, with the soul taken out. Nice unique picture mosaics on the Nativity of Mary. Of course this is as result of Turkey, being essentially a Muslim country. Fair play to their preserving it as a historical place to visit.
Great Bizantine Art. A bit difficult to get to it, but well worth the effort. Although there are busses, a taxi is very affordable from most parts of the city.

peaceful and beautiful. This is a bit off the main track of the tourist haunts but worth the taxi fare. It is full of marvelous art and history. The mosaics and frescos are absolutely beautiful and deserve some time to appreciate thhem.
A Must See. The biblical mosaics here are incredible. This site is outside of the old city, but is well worth the effort to get there.

Great frescos. Worth a visit. We walked here from Beyoğlu as part of a day out to Eyup. Great frescos and mosaics but entry is relatively expensive (20 TL) given much of the church us closed for restoration.

Worth the effort. We really loved the mosaics in Turkey and found this church well worth the effort. We caught one bus there. It was worthwhile just for experiencing a more residential area of Istanbul. The mosaics are wonderful.

Very interesting but under construction. Our tour guide was excellent. He explained the history and the majority of each fresco. Some of the building was under construction so we were not able to the view. Overall, I was glad to have gone.

Not worth it... Unless you're bored. We had an extra day in Istanbul and decided to walk out to the old city walls and Chora/Kariye. The real adventure was getting there and finding the place, which took us two hours - including getting lost in the conservative suburb of Fatih and accidentally arriving at the Fetiyhe Mosque.Chora itself is mainly closed for renovation. Only a couple of rooms are open, with medieval mosaics on the ceiling. It is about as exciting as it sounds, and not worth making a special journey unless you're passionate about Byzantine art. I think we spent fifteen minutes inside the church.

Amazing church. This is my 4th time in Istanbul and my first time to the Chora church and what a shame.
It is absolutely stunning, the most beautiful church mosaics I have seen as well as a great area around it. Highly recommend it.

A container for the uncontainable. The mosaics tell an awesome story. We were asked to Join a Rick Steves guided tour (the guide saw our Rick Steves guide book). The explanations given by the guide made for an incredible experience.

Absolutely stunning; worth the trip. The museum isn't actually that hard to get to using public transportation. I simply took a bus from Eminönü (I think 38E) and got off at Edirnekapi. There's a big sign pointing down a side street to the museum a couple blocks before the stop, so I just back tracked to that and walked down the side street to the church. To get back to Eminönü I just went to the other side of the Main Street and got a bus that said it was going there. The mosaics and frescoes in the church are absolutely stunning. I definitely think it's worth buying a book describing the church at one of the stands outside to understand exactly what you're looking at. If you have more than 2-3 days in Istanbul, you definitely should go see Chora. I didn't go on my first trip to the city and am very happy I did the second time I was there.

Don't Miss this!. Although there are currently renovations taking place in the main sanctuary, the outer hallways are filled with beautiful mosaics of the Christ story. The architecture was breathtaking and it was a great place to start a day touring of the city walls. They also have a nice gift shop.
Not to be missed. This little gem is a cab ride away from the centre of town, and worth the trip. It is one of the most beautiful churches with 13th century Byzantine mosaics.

Chora Church. It was a facebook comment while we were in Istanbul that alerted me to go and see this amazing church. Mosaics and frescos by the shedload. There's restoration going on but it does not deter from the wonders. Included in the museum pass so it is not to be missed. Short taxi ride from the Blue Mosque and Aya Sophya. Don't miss it!
Must!. Very interesting frescoes and mosaics. And after the visit take a pleasant walk down the hill, along the old City Wall, towards Halic Park. Take a boat at Ayvansaray and see the Golden Horn.

Under construction, same admission. It's a wonderful church. Beautiful mosaic. I just hope they could reduce the price since only a small part of the church is open due to construction work. The postcards inside is pretty I bought some too.

Beautiful. I wish the Aya Sofya still looked like this church. I suggest to see them both on the same day.First Aya Sofya, then our to Chora. When you are out at Chora, make sure to trek a bit on the old city walls.

A perfect example of the glory byzantine era. I must say that I was really amazed by thic church. The icons on the walls are exceptional and considering that they stand there since 14th century is really impressive. It was a pitty that when we visited the site there were works in progress and parts of the church were inaccessible.
Was undergoing restoration when we went. However, the mosaics that were visible were marvellous. A little bit out of the way but we then walked down to the Golden Horn for a boat trip.

Absolutely stunning mosaics and paintings.. This is a jewel in Istanbul.Mosaics are spectacular and so colourful because they where covered with plaster over centuries(when it was converted to mosque). That plaster protected mosaics and paintings so we can enjoy it today.Definitely worth to get audio guide.Main part of church is under renovation - which is a shame- but it is still worth to see the rest.Stunning!Have a good trip.
Worth the trip. This church is in the outskirts of the city. It is unique as a Byzantine church but also has beautiful mosaics featuring the life of the Virgin Mary.
Gorgeous!. itś too bad that this site is too often missed. it has a remarkable set of mosaics. the most beautiful work of art I saw in Istambul

Sine qua non. If you love Byzantien Art, Orthodox icons or medeival art, Chora Church is a great belvedere... Rİght now, some sections are under restoration but even only open parts will make you feel happy with its very high quailty mosaics and frescoes... Hotel building itself and surrond is another reason to visit...

Fabulous Byzantine mosaics and frescos. This old Greek church has the best preserved Byzantine art in Istanbul, a real pleasure to see after Aya Sophia where the art heritage has been ruined. It is a bit tricky to get to, and the nave was closed for restoration when we visited, but it is still well worth the effort

Shame that the church is closed for renovations... we visiting this church after having visited the Greek Orthodox church. Very intersting, with amazing mosaics, unfortunately the main church is closed for renovations, which is something we hit quite a lot...

A great collection of mosaics in a small package. The number and quality of mosaics and frescoes from the later Byzantine Empire make this church one of the most important repositories of Byzantine art in the world, hidden away in an ordinary middle-class neighborhood, near the old city walls.

A must visit site.. it is a historical church that was turned into mosque during religious upheaval of the country. As a result of that, all the beautiful micro mosaic painting were then covered up by Islamic drawings. And the beautiful paintings is now recovered for the world to see. Gorgeous.
Should not be missed. The frescoes inside this small museum and former house of worship are incredible. Included is one of the very rare depictions of Jesus' step brother, another son of Joseph.
Beautiful -- but note under construction. The frescoes and mosaics are impressive. What we could see what beautiful -- but most of the church was closed for renovation work.
Don't overlook this gem. Despite undergoing renovations there are still a number of fabulous frescos you can see at this former church. Gorgeous
old frescoes. Get there early to avoid the tour groups. It's a very small church and not the easiest to find. Walk the streets around too, very quaint.

must see. Chora museum is a unique piece of architecture. Its frescoes and mosaics are much better preserved than in Hagia Sophia. I was astonished to see scenes from new testament depicted in vivid color mosaic, as if there were not maintained since Byzantine period. When looking at the frescoes you feel that you are travelling back in history, it feels you with joy and leaves you with the feeling that you discovered a piece of Christianity which is so native and warm. Even though this site is not centrally located and is off the beaten track please don't be reluctant, go and see it, since it is a pure pleasure !!!

Mosaics Superb. Rennovation going on at time of visit, only able to see the inner and the outer narthex, gift shop area and one other space. Surprised they did not reduce the admission charge because of this.

Most beautiful byzantine mosaics and frescoes. As many others have stated here the Chora Church is well worth the visit even though the Nave is currently closed, the inner and outer narthexes plus the hall to the right of the entrance make the visit worthwhile. This will also give you a chance to walk through some residential streets of Istanbul that you might not normally encounter. We took the ferry from Eminonu, which was a scenic and quick way to arrive. The ferry stop is a little hard to find, walk past the bus depot to get to it. You can also ask anyone for the Avansary ferry. The ferry runs fairly frequently and you can use your Metro pass. Once you arrive at Avansary use a good street map to find the Chora, basically keep the land walls (also intersting) to your right as you walk up to the church. Watch the return ferry schedule, they run about an hour apart so time your visit to get back for the ferry, or do as we did and walk all the way back to Eminonu, it took us about an hour but was a fascinating look at Istanbul city life along the Golden Horn, many families barbecueing, families fishing, personal boats tied to the wharves,etc. Scenic walk and great exercise.

well worth a visit. Excellent museum with paintings and mosaics from the Byzantine era. Currently undergoing restoration, you can only visit the Narthex: the Nave is not accessible. Still, beautiful things to see.

really off the beaten track but so worth it.. we took a taxi from our hotel but people claim it is only a 10 min taxi ride from the hagia sofia area, can't verify this. great byzantine mosaics, lots more than you'll see at hagia sofia and since the church is small it is easier to see and enjoy the mosaics and frescoes.

Make the trip! It's worth it.. You can take the T4 tram to Edirnekapı station. They have printed maps to direct you to to the museum.Currently it's under restoration and the Noas was closed when I was there on Nov 27 2014.I wished they reduced the entrance fee like some other museums have done in Eastern Turkey. The audio guide which cost 15 lira isn't the greatest. They need to rework it and tag with separate numbers to help understand the mosaics - I think.While you're there, wall down to the old city wall and get an excellent view of this city on a clear day. There are 2 sets of steps. The one to the turret is more dangerous as the treads are shallow and some are broken.
Wonderful. It is the best ancient church I have even seen in Turkey. It is worth take half day to see all the details. If you can hear every painting's story will be better.

Empty Old Church. This building is undergoing renovation/restoration with large nets to control birds hung about 15 feet above the floor. The interior is practically stripped with no significant religious art on display.
Our guide stated the space is used occasionally as a musical venue.

Byzantine brilliance. Thanks to the previous reviewers on Trip Advisor for the very helpful hints on getting to this church which involved an intriguing bus journey through the suburbs and asking quite a few locals for directions. Yes, much of the church is under restoration but the mosaics that are on display are incredible and mesmerising. The level of detail is simply outstanding. Make sure you look at the neighbourhoods around the church as they feature some of the characteristic houses of the old Istanbul. There are also some gift shops outside the church which offer Turkish art and crafts at cheaper prices than in the major tourist precincts.
another incredible place. but far away from the center in an area in which you have to care a little bit, go by taxi; incredible mosaics, to be seen one by one with a good guide

Marvelous painings. Mosaics and painings partly very well preserved; site in restauration process, it is now not possible to see the navis, but still great place to visit. After the visit walk down to Balat and Fener, wonderful aerea!

Amazing little gem. One of our favourite experiences in Istanbul, we combined it with a visit to the Theodosian city Walls which may be viewed only a couple of blocks away. This is not a vast site, so an hour or so inside the church is sufficient.
wow !. what a beautful little chuch ! the most impressie frescos I have seen - some still being restored, but stunningly beautiful.

Beautiful Mosaics. It is far away, but it sure worth a visit! Considered as one of the best example of a byzantine church. Most of the mosaics are very well preserved. I also liked walking around this area. It is residential with the old city walls along the edge.

amazing mosaics, currently some areas under restoration so not visible, but wonderful nevertheless.. Close to the walls of the city, and some of the more out of the way streets, Byzantine palaces and views, so worth walking around a bit as well as visiting the church.

Amazing frescoes and mosaics, but much is closed. This would easily get 5 stars normally... but it was frustrating that so much of the museum is closed right now, especially given the entrance price is steep. But the frescoes and mosaics are absolutely stunning and part of the cultural patrimony of mankind, so how do you put a star rating on that?

Some of the most beautiful mosaics in Istanbul. The Chora Church is small but beautiful. The mosaics are perhaps the most interesting in Istanbul. When we visited there was major work going on, so we were able to see only the front section of the church, but just that was definitely worth the trip. We were there on a Saturday, and while there were a number of people in the church, we still were able to enjoy the mosaics. It's worth spending some time reading about the church to help understand the symbolism and the stories. This was one of my favorite stops.

Not to be missed!. This place was incredible and should be on everyone's "must-see" list when visiting Istanbul. It is a bit out of the way, but worth the effort to get there if you are not part of a tour group.

Make the effort to see the Chora Church. Take a taxi here as it's a bit off the beaten track but well worth the visit to see the astounding mosaic and frescoed ceilings. The outdoor cafe right outside is perfect to sit after your visit for lunch or a coffee and watch the scene. We saw a bridal party!

Beautiful, ancient, Christian mosaics. This museum contains some beautiful, ancient, Christian mosaics that are are very good condition considering their age. This is a relatively small museum, but the contents are high quality and are well-worth seeing. An hour or two will suffice.
Impresing mosaics!. Quite impressing mosaics. First church, then mosque, now it's a museum. Unhapily half of the building was in reconstruction during our visit.

Beautiful old church a mosaic lover's paradise. The Chora Church, as it stands today, is at least one thousand years old, but parts of the church apparently date back at least a further five hundred years. The church has had a long and chequered history, at one stage becoming a mosque, but now functions as a museum and has been largely restored. To get the full value from a visit, it is important to either join a group with a guide, or even better hire a personal guide (as we did). The reason for this is that the beautiful mosaics and frescoes on the walls and ceilings depict in chronological order the life and times of Jesus Christ, and without a guide it is difficult to follow. These are remarkably well-preserved mosaics with many being entirely original, and only a few having missing tiles. Flash photography is strictly forbidden and staff enforce this. One of the best ancient churches in Istanbul and strongly recommended.

Most beautiful mosaics and frescos. It is a little out … but, the Chora Church (Kariye Museum) is well worth a short taxi ride. Of all the places (and we saw everything), this is what I would say you must not leave Istanbul without seeing.We were in awe at the beauty (in amazing condition) of the mosaics here … and we saw all the "sites". This, I would recommend to go to first -- to be sure you don't miss it.Patricia Gutierrez

Lovely. Is the best preserved Byzantine Church in the area, the mosaics and frescoes devoted to Jesus and Mary are nothing short of breathtaking. And usually there are no crowds, meaning that you can take your time. Is recommended to listen to your audio guide.

More old stuff to love. Maaaaaan. This place was hard to find by public transport but we got there!! This place. Wow. This place and its old mosaics so well kept. What a jewel. Also if you like looking at tourists look at things through their camera this place is pretty cool for that too. Come on, you know what to expect. Worth the trip? Of course, unless you're a total philistine or you hate churches. Or if you're a couple and only one of you likes this stuff, leave the philistine at the tea garden and head in on the guided tour as your lesser half ponders why you're so cool and into this amazing stuff while he isn't.
Artistic. The mosaic colours are splendid. Sad that so mush is damaged. A little walk from the tramway. The church is under restoration so unfortunately could not see all of it.

A hidden treasure of Istanbul. The Chora Church is located outside of historic Istanbul. To visit this museum we booked a tour which started from our cruise ship. The church was converted to mosque centuries ago, so all mosaics and frescoes were covered with plaster and wooden panels.Today it is still under reconstruction. But even those partially restored mosaics take your breath away. We were surprised to see the life of Virgin Mary from her birth described in details in those mosaics. I'm planning to visit this museum again. It is a gem!
An astounding gem. This is a small and slightly cramped church, but well worth the squeeze and neck cramp to see the truly beautiful mosaics.

Wow!!! Iconic. Many travelers put chora church in bottom of their travel itinerary- Big mistake!! What a beautiful peace of architecture stunning located on the hill top. This is not a place for architecture marvel, but the paintings inside this church are certainly one of the best in the world.

Stunning. Small church with beautiful place, amazing art and mosaics. Helps if you have a guide or a book to tell you what the bible story of the images are. Entrance fee was 15tl pp. Currently parts are closed for renovation/restoration which was a shame, but still lots of beautiful mosaics to see.
No words for it - the oldest, beautiful mosaic tiles. Shimmering gold, small rooms, mosaics that are unbelievable - you must not miss this - go and look at everything in the old church

Beautiful but Disappointing. We walked from Ataturk Blvd all the way out the main shopping street to the church in eager anticipation of viewing the church's mosaics. However in mid/late October we were dismayed to learn that most of the church was actually closed for renovation/restoration allowing us to view only the small sections near the entrance. While these were spectacular, the limited viewing was very disappointing.By the way, the entry fee was not reduced at all, adding insult to injury.Visitors should also be aware that the area around the church is somewhat seedy and gets progressively worse as one leaves the church for a side trip to the city walls. Hopefully, the work will be completed soon but be sure to check prior to a visit so that you're not disappointed.

A Taste of the Byzantine Empire. I have heard rave reviews about the Chora Church and their wonderful mosaics but it was only 2 days ago that I finally made it. Yes, it was worth a visit. Even though part of it is under renovation, what remains is very impressive. If possible, incorporate it into your itinerary and get a taste of the Byzantine Empire

Paintings and mosaics. The colors are vibrant, beautiful. The guides do not always know the saints depicted...and may tell you they are all St. Paul, who visited Turkey and was imprisoned outside Ephesus.

Best Church in Istanbul for Elaborate Mosaics and Frescoes. Everyone visiting Istanbul will take in the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sofia, the major tourist attraction in the central city. But our friend Nathan took us to this smaller Church that has the most amazing mosaics telling the life stories of Mary and the prophets on ceilings as well as on the walls; also extensive frescoes, all of them in amazing good condition. Better still you are allowed to take pictures as long as you don't use the flash. There was much less waiting time than at the big tourist attractions. This is definitely one of the must see places and less expensive than the Blue Mosque or Hagia Sofia.

An out of the way jewel!. After fighting the crowds to see the sites in the Sultanahmet area, it was a pleasant surprise to find this jewel on the edge of the walled city. As the best preserved Byzantine Church in the area, the mosaics and frescoes devoted to Jesus and Mary are nothing short of breathtaking. And there are no crowds, meaning that you can take your time, listen to your audio guide (recommended), and absorb the artistry. While it is remote and requires a taxi ride, this is well worth the trip!

A MUST VISIT IN ISTANBUL, THE CHORA CHURCH. This small church is famous with the frescoes on the walls. The frescoes showing the life of Christ is unique in the world. I suggest to visitors to take a guide or take the advantage of the audio guides. You must stay at least one or two hours to see the mosaics and frescoes. Near the church there is a Turkish restaurant where you can have original Ottoman cuisine.

immaculate. The rich and byzantine fine mosaics and frescoes which adorned the walls and ceiling is simply immaculate and astounding as its been retained much as of it for hundreds of years. Should come here and experience the sight although its located a bit off from major city attraction, not so many tourist is you go in the morning.

A meaningful surprise. This little church has amazing mosaics. I would suggest that visitors take advantage of the audio guides which we didn't. I think that we would have enjoyed and certainly understood the mosaics even more with the guide. A bit out of the way, but definitely worth the trip.

Exquisite and unusual. The Byzantine mosaics in this small 12th century church are simply exquisite! They tell, in detail, the story of the life of Mary, which is in itself most unusual. The mosaics are in excellent condition, and the small size of the church means you can get quite a good look at them. The audioguide was well worth getting, as it provided excellent information about the church, its mosaics, and murals.This place is not as well known as many other Istanbul sights, so was not too crowded. In fact, we had to show the taxi driver where it was on the map, as he didn't know about it!

Be Sure To Visit. Regardless of your religion, or even if you don't have one, you can't help by be impressed by the frescos and mosaics on the walls of this church. This is a highly recommended spot to visit.

Little known byzantine church. The mosaics about the life of the Virgin Mary with her parents, the history are one of a kind. It is a little byzantine church, currently a museum, in a friendly environment, with a great little café near bye.

A bit out of the way. A bit out of the way but easy enough to get public transport to, the quality of the artwork and mosaics here are very good -- better that most other places, but you need to take the time to read up on the history or get an audio guide to get the best out of the visit.

Beautiful icons from the Apochraphal Bible.. The Chora a Church is a diamond among a city of precious gems. Take the time and effort to travel to see this beautiful place. Make sure you get a tour guide. Well worth any expense to learn all you can. Do not miss.

Beautiful mozaik.. This monastery is a not in the center, but if you'll stay for more than 3 days in Istanbul you should find time for it. Is not really big, but antique with rich interior and details. Really worth to see it.

A better preserved mosaic compared to Aya Sofya. If you are a fan of the Byzantium mosaic, this is the place to go! Easily accessible via public transport (alight at Edirkenapi) this small church is tucked nicely in a neighbourhood. Its an amazing piece of art and I am amazed that the mosaic was better preserved than in Aya Sofya. There is an audioguide and you can even use your 85TL musuem pass to get in. Thereafter, the old city wall is just nearby and you can catch a nice view of the city!

A beautiful gem with hi-res mosaics in a charming neighborhood. You can get here with a single bus ride from the tram stop at the Beyazit/ Grand bizarre. It takes about 20 mins. just ask the driver and he'll tell you where to get off and where to go.The church's main point of interest for me was how the mosaics focused on the life of Anne, Mary's mother. It's undergoing some restoration but still most of the interior is accessible and worth the 15 TL entrance. The painting and mosaics on the inside is intimate and very detailed. It was worth getting the audio guide for 10 TL as well.Be sure to check out the wood houses on the way to the church, they represent an older classical wood style of row house. There is also a very nice ceramic till shop, just off the grounds. The salesperson is from Belgium and very helpful with the hand painted ceramic work being sold and the city as well.
Beautiful but a lot of restoration so much of it was closed.. This was a beautiful church, well the parts we were able to see due to lots of restoration underway.

Lovely!. A wee bit away from the other sights of Istanbul - involved a longish bus ride from Sirkechi. But worth every bit.
Note - The main part of the museum is closed for restoration works. However the gallery has lovely frescoes that can be viewed.
A visit to the adjoining cafe would not be a bad idea :-)

Christian/Muslim/Christian. This now again Christian Church, is undergoing restoration.The wall fresco's detail "OUR LIFE" over the centuries, they were plastered over by the Old Rulers when the church was tyaken over by the Muslim Rulers, now all the plaster has been removed and the wonderful painting revealed, telling the story of life in paint.

A little gem. It was a tough walk from Ayvansaray but worth every bit. We surveyed every fresco with help from the audio guide and the Rough Guide to Istanbul, and it was awe-inspiring. The judgement day fresco and the series on Mother Mary were fabulous.

mosaics. This church is out of the way but a real must to see the amazing mosaics. At the time we visited there was massive reconstruction happening and only the front area was open to the public but still really worth it. Combine with the great walls surrounding the city

Off the main track but absolutely worth getting there. This one was a bit tricky to get to - we spent about 20 min trying to find the right bus from Eminonu. But effort was absolutely worth it: it's a hidden gem full of mosaic icons. Rich history, well preserved. Audio guide was very helpful, so I would highly recommend getting one. It's partially closed for renovations, but the part that we saw was still very impressive.After the visit we ate at the cafe next to the entrance. Food was great.
super. kora church is e super place with old arcutecture clors in the church is perfect also pictures athmosphere in there very old and beautifullll....

Gem. Amazing frescoes. Although this church is far from from the center of Istanbul, it is worth seeing . The frescoes are so well preserved. Your neck will be stiff from looking at the beautiful ceilings. This is a unique church.

A little bit out of the way but worth the effort. This former church then a mosque and now a museum is well preserved and presented. The main sanctuary is closed for refurbishing but the outer areas contains some excellent murals and paintings. See it with a guide to get the whole story!

A top site on our visit. Amazing frescos. Definitely rivals Rome and Florence. It's under renovation so you won't get to see everything. Don't miss the tile sellers next door (particularly the one farthest from the church itself -- by farthest I mean a few more feet away). Great selection across the full price range, including the middle (~60-100 TL) which no one else seemed to have.

Under restoration. I was so looking forward to seeing this Church
with the mosaic ceilings so I was very
disappointed that the main church was closed.
Their wasn't any notifications until you went inside and
no one explained anything. Very dissapointing.

Go for the Mosaic's --. watch your backpack and purse and all your belongings. not a pretty part of town but worth the visit. the workers have been on this site for some time but it is worth a trip inside to see the tiny tiny mosaic's that have been pieced together. all a work of art.

Wow! Wonderful mosaics and frescoes. The Chora Church is currently undergoing renovation but, in spite of some areas being closed, there was still plenty to see to make this a “Wow!” visit – wonderful Byzantine mosaics and frescoes. Being a small church, you get so close to the mosaics. It's well worth getting the audio-guide to learn about what you're looking at because there are no explanatory signs.The church looks difficult to get to at first glance. I was considering a taxi, as many recommend, until I came across these directions in another Trip Advisor review. They're spot on – very easy to do on public transport. Plus you get to see some of the old land walls.DIRECTIONS (as supplied by MCN-Travels,Monterey, California, 11 October 2014):Take the Tram T1 to the Topkapi stop. Transfer to the T4 Tram, going in the direction of Habibler. Get off at Edirnekapi (3rd stop). Go up to street level.Go left around the corner. Walk to the end of the block and cross over the auto thoroughfare, past the old walls, and into the old city. Immediately cross over to the left-hand side of the street and then turn left onto the first side street inside the walls. From there, walk until you come to the third side street and turn right. The Chora Church is straight ahead, about two blocks down the street.

amazing. This church its out of the touristic center, so make sure to get a cab to go and another one to come back! I've got a bus on the way back and almost get roubed! My "lucky" was that I found a Police man on the way,....But the mosaics deserve your time!

Due to restorations is not worth it!. First of all, this "museum" is COMPLETELY outside of the city center. I needed to take a tram and then a bus and then walk forever in an area that was not as pleasent as you may expect! It is super difficult to find and at the end, you finish visiting it in less than ten minutes! Is just a small corridor with some frescoes and mosaics, nothing more! Unless you are REALLY into art, I really thing this place is not worth the effort to get there.

Byzantine at its best. One of the more difficult museums to find (and not in a nice neighborhood) Kariye is a stunning example of Byzantine mosaic and frescos. Minuscule when compared to the Hagia Sofia but far far better preserved.

Worth the trip. We combined a visit here with one to the old city wall which you can easily travel to by tram. The church is hard to find so make sure you take a map- we met lots of lost travellers searching for it. Although part was closed for renovation, there are so many beautiful mosaics in excellent condition to make the trip worthwhile.
Must see. This site contains one of the world's finest collections of Byzantine frescoes and mosaics. They are in superb condition.
go for the mosaics. This museum is a bit off the beaten path, but worth a visit. It is well preserved, and beautiful. Just a few blocks away is the old city wall.

Partially closed for renovation. The Kariye museum is a must see but potential visitors should be made aware that the museum is in the process of restoration and that only a section will be available for visitors. What is open is amazing as photos will attest to but for 50 TL or just over $20 US it is hardly value especially compared to the Topkapi or Hagia Sophia (same price or less) where you can spend hours exploring.We were able to visit on or 3 day Museum Pass as the Museum of Turkish and Islamic Art is closed for renovations. Normally you must buy the 5 day pass to access the Kariye Museum.

Best sightseeing spot in Istanbul. We’ve just spent 2 weeks in Istanbul & seen most of the major sights. To be honest we found the famous ones around Sultanahmet a little disappointing. But then we decided to visit some of the City Wall (well worth doing) & Chora Church. Walking in, our initial response was ‘Wow!!!’ The frescos & mosaics are just beautiful & all the better for being seen up close. We spent a couple of hours there – working our way round the inevitable tour parties –who all seem to ‘do’ the place in about 15-20 minutes.According to the guidebooks, most of the artwork appears to be in the outer foyers (a pair of narthexes) so that -although the main ‘church’ was closed for restoration and the outside partly scaffolded – you get to see most of the import things. It is well worth making the effort to visit. This was the highlight of our holiday.

Visitando museos y castillos en Anatolia/ Visitjng castle a d musium in Anatolia. This church converted into a mosque, is a o ur very Lara of the mixture between Muslims and Romans; in all its aspects, already that you can observe them in their fresh with the different images of the western culture and religious prayers with the Ottomans, its structure was modified based on the u edtructura Amezquita and adapted culturaoccidenta wing.

Hidden Gem. Before coming here, I had never heard of Chora church so I wasn't sure what to expect. Once I stepped foot inside, I was mesmerized. The mosaics and the frescos were amazing. This idea that someone painstakingly put all these tiles in the right order and pattern to create these images truly blows my mind. Anyone interested in art history, mosaics, or frescos should make this part of their trip.

Mosaics Galore. Quite an impressive collection of mosaics most in fine condition. Bit off beaten path but well worth the effort. Museum store was well stocked with Chora Church books which offer detail on all of the mosaics.

Beautiful. Aside from the Hagia Sophia, I think that this is the "church" really worth visiting because of its beautiful frescoes and mosaics. it is really comparable to the world's best destinations for christian arts, like ravenna and the vatican. i visited this all the way back in 2003, and it is as beautiful as it has been.

Breathtaking. I am not religious, but entering the Chora church had a divine feeling to it. The mosaics were spectacular. Looking at the images in the guidebook could not prepare me for the vivid colours, details and master skill of the artist that made them so many centuries ago! I would recommend getting a good guide who can tell you the stories behind each scene. It is small, intimate place, not grand like Hagia sofia. But it still managed to make my jaw drop. I definitely would not miss it when in Istanbul. It is a bit further away from the other sites, so if you don’t get an organised guided tour, I would take a taxi. The entrance fee is 15 liras. It is closed on Wednesdays. There is a small souvenir/book store inside, and some stalls with nice souvenirs outside.
still nice to see. some mosaics are still very nice , nice colors , you will feel that like you are in hagia sophia museum, but more smaller and beautiful i guess
MustseeinIstanbul. The mosacis are definitely worth the bus ride out from city center. Stunningly beautiful. My husband and I both consider this stop as one of our top highlights in Istanbul.

Woderful history and mosaics. This is a wonderful Byzantine monument and should not be missed. Unfortunately, Part of it was closed for repair but the mosaics in the open parts were exquisite and told a wonderful story of Mary and the birth of Jesus.

It was a bit of a disappointment. Although the general impression of the church was nice, it was something that I would not regret if had missed. It is too touristy around, too crowded, the price is too high for a such a small church a big part of which is closed for restoration.

Wow….. That was the word I used when I walked in. You won't believe the beautiful Byzantine mosaic walls and ceilings and frescoes…. You can easily spend an hour here, we went with a guide, well worth it.

Worth going out of your way. Not easy to get to, tho we happened to be within walking distance. It is close to the town walls which can be climbed in a couple of places for good views. The church has beautiful frescoes and mosaics. Unfortunately part of the church is being restored and cannot be viewed. It would be good if the doorway to the restoration area was safety glass then visitors could view what was being done. You can walk down the hill from there to the Golden Horn to get the ferry back to Eminonu. Interesting in itself.

What a fabulous experience.. This is worth seeing! You must either take a guided tour or have a copy of the Lonely Planet or similar that will talk you through all the pictures one by one, as the walk through the church tells the story of Jesus through these fabulous mosaics.
Beautiful mosaics. Fascinating history. A bit far from the most visited attractions, we only went to Chora in our third trip to Istambul but we would recomend everyone not to miss it

Taking the tram from the Sultanahmet District to the Chora Church. The wonderful Byzantine-era mosaics of the Chora Church are well worth a visit. There is plenty to see, even though part of the museum is closed for restoration. This historical attraction is a bit difficult to find if you are trying to use public transportation. We got lost on our first attempt. If you plan to take the tram from the Sultanahmet District, the directions are as follows: Take the Tram T1 from the Sultanahmet to the Topkapi stop. Transfer to the T4 Tram, going in the direction of Habibler. Get off at Edirnekapi (3rd stop). Go up to street level, go left around the corner. Walk to the end of the block and cross over the auto thoroughfare, past the old walls, and into the old city. Immediately cross over to the left-hand side of the street and then turn left onto the first side street inside the walls. From there, walk until you come to the third side street and turn right. The Chora Church is straight ahead, about two blocks down the street. Enjoy your visit. Note that the museum is closed on Wednesdays.

Excellent Byzantine frescos and mosaics. As others have said, it's a bit difficult to find, but the neighbouring folks have probably heard requests for directions in many languages, and one shopkeeper helped us to find the Chora. We visited on a pleasant day on 6 Oct. 2014, and the site was fairly crowed.Once inside, there is a dazzling array of 700 year old mosaics and frescos, in amazing condition considering the various earthquakes and conversions (to mosques and museum) that this church has undergone over the centuries.One section was closed for renovations, but the remaining sections are still well worth the search to find it, and the nominal entry charge (TL 15). Highly recommended.

a nice place, lovely mosaics and frescos, out of the way. We went to Chora and although the nave was being reconstructed, the rest of the site was accessible. As with many others, our first visit was 25 or 30 years ago and the site was empty.Now it is crowded with tourists, including several tours. Still, we found the place most exciting, and the english audio guide helped. The mosaics are all over the place and the frescos are marvelous.A must see site when in Istanbul.

Please tell me a more impressive church. After seeing a lot of churches throughout Europe, this one really resonates with me. Like in a Jerusalem kind of way (never been). Well worth the effort to get there, and away from the hordes on the main drag.

Impressive mosaics and frescos and you can take as many pictures as you want but no flash!. This is one of the most beautiful examples of mosaics and frescos of the latest Byzantine painting (14th century): The Chora Church (Kariye Mosque meaning in old Turkish a village or the countryside). The visit can take two hours and yes! you can take as many pictures you want but not flash and tripots are allowed. It is recomended to get an audio guide to have as much information as posible of the beauty you are looking.Here more pictures and info of Chora Church - Kariye Mosque :http://phototrekistanbul.blogspot.com.tr/2013/12/chora-church-kariye-mosque-photo-trek.html

Worthwhile visit even during restoration. I was a bit disappointed to find the site undergoing restoration. My first visit was 7 years ago, when I encountered no other tourists.The site has been 'discovered' which means it will now be taken care of.Even though a major part is inaccessible at this time, it is still worth the visit.
Chora. Took the tram and had a wonderful day away from the crowds. Beautiful church with magnificent mosaics and frescoes, and yes, some is closed due to restoration work

Well worth the minor trip. Well preserved Orthodox church with mosaics and ceiling paintings in good condition - actually better condition and more visible tha the Hagia Sopia. Not very crowded.
You have to get 10-15 minute public transport bus to see it (or a taxi), but well worth the trip.

Ferry up the Horn to visit Chora. We were in Instanbul in May and took the ferry (5TL) up the Golden Horn to the Ayvansaray Kapisi ferry stop and then walked up to Chora. I haven't done the tram ride up, but this was such a nice break from the tourists I highly recommend going by water! We caught the ferry just north of the Galata Bridge (so pass all the guys advertising Bosphorus cruises). It was on the other side of a big parking lot for buses and such. Anyway, the boat was farly big and hardly anyone on it (much like the boat we took across to the Asian side) ... you can get your tea if you like. It stops a couple of times but you just stay on until you see the Ayvansaray dock. It's quite small but well posted with a big sign. We hoped off and walked through a big park/garden until we got to the Old Wall. We followed our nose in the general direction of the Church which is uphill through a residential area. The streets are narrow and there were even some neat dilapodated old Ottoman houses. Found a great view at one point and you could see all the way back to Topkapi! Sheep skins were drying on a fence and kids were playing in the cobbled streets ... this was real Istanbul. The church is under renovation so you can't get into the main part of the church. This is the oldest part. The parts you can go in are all around the outside, the narthax which was built by the Byzantines (I think it's 14th C) and so has the amazing mosaics you invision when thinking of Chora. From here, we walked up the hill further until we reached the Old Wall again. This was really great as we found a spot to climb and the view was amazing. The wall is REALLY HIGH! We also bought pomegranit juice from a vendour with a little outdoor cafe and wandered the outside of the wall as well. One of teh original gates is just across a main road, which has been blasted through the wall, so that was interesting to see as well. We walked back all along the base of the wall, passing some other restorations of an old prison and then back to the ferry. This was a great way to spend a few hours, highly recommend it!! I only gave Chora 4 stars because we couldn't see the actual inner church and we didn't realize that until after buying the tickets ... we were bummed. But still very happy to have seen the mosaics that we did! Buy e-tickets online before you go through the Muze ticketing site. Not the "Museum Pass", these are individual tickets that you buy and print out, although you pay the same price as if you purchased on site, you bypass the lineups. You also don't have a time frame to use them by like with the Museum Pass... no rushing! You can get them for Goreme Museum in Cappadocia, Ephesus and several others... they were well worth it!

Charming but under repair. I liked the mosaics, the ones that I could see. The frescoes were also impressive. A lot wasn't visible but it was still worth the price of admission - beautiful tiles, beautiful mosaics of Jesus, his mother, etc. We took a bus to get there and it was a short walk to the museum. We had to ask for help to find it but the walk was short. Worth seeing if you have the time to spare for the ride out to it.
Under renovation. What we saw was amazing but only a small part as it is under renovation. Best to stay away until finished in about sept 2015

Amazing Church. I took the funicular and 2 trams from Taxim. It was little hard to find in the maze of nearby streets so I just asked a local who pointed the right direction. The mosaics and frescoes are truly amazing and make the trip out here an unforgettable experience even if one of the rooms is closed for restoration. It was also interesting walking in the nearby streets to see another part of Istanbul. I took a bus back to Taxim which was faster than the trams. At the bus stop a local even asked me where I wanted to go and pointed out the correct bus.

we should do more of those...... The last time i was in Istanbul i decided to do only the old city or Constantinople. That was one of the best experience in traveling, strolling around the Chora and other old churches, temples....from every part of old Europe, eat a pastry, drink a coffee, etc.... The chora has been saved and rebuilt by the American people and if you have just 24 hours in Istanbul just go over there and visit this church it is not only gorgeous but This is peaceful. and we needs that now for this part of the work

Chora Church. This is a gem away from the main tourist drag but easily reachable by tram/metro if you can work out properly where you are going. It's also near the city walls. Fantastically beautiful frescoes. Partly under renovation at present so unfortunately you can't see all of it. Nice little shop and a cafe facing it on the hill slope. Absolutely beautiful church.
Wow!a jewel!. I have never seen before such beautiful and fine mediaval mosaics.its really a gem,worth the long walk
Just stunning !. The mosaics and frescoes were simply astounding. Definitely the highlight of our visit to Istanbul..

Very unique church. I was lucky enough to have a private guide walk me through the panels and point out the differences between these mosaics and others you might see throughout the world. It was fascinating to see how the life of Mary was portrayed, even for me (an atheist).

Worth the effort. This is a little distance from Hagia Sophia etc., but it's stunning. The mosaics are in fantastic condition, and there are some really old frescoes. Not on the same scale of size as the Hagia Sophia, but makes up for it in quality.

Beautiful Constantionople. If the Hagia Sophia blows you away by it's sheer vastness, this church/mosque/museum will blow you away through the stunning Byzantine works of art lying within, that astonishingly survived a millennia. Though one of the hardest sights to visit in Istanbul (unless you are on a tour, which we were not), it is definitely an incredibly rewarding journey to take into the old, traditionally Greek western suburbs of Sultanahmet. This is truly one of the greatest examples of a Byzantine church in the whole of Europe with mosaics and frescos that will simply blow you away. The mosaic filled domes are the most astounding part of the church though it was also interesting to see the differences between the beautiful older byzantine art that tended to be frescoes (painted) and the later, more famous art that was applied through mosaic (small pieces of stone and tiles plastered on a wall). We took a taxi from the centre of Sultanahmet which proved to be relatively easy, but it took quite a while to find a taxi on the trip back. This is an incredibly interesting and beautiful site that should be visited by all.

Impressed after getting past the initial first disappointments. My plan was to start with the further-out and far-flung sites of Istanbul before attacking all the popular sites in Sultanahmet so Kariye Museum was first on my long wish list of places to see in only two full days. I knew of the buses from Sultanahmet, but my hotel concierge warned me it would take an hour or more due to Istanbul's traffic and advised I take a taxi to save time. Good advice except my taxi driver was unfriendly and not upfront about the fare, but since my hotel told me the max I should pay, that's what I negotiated and presented. Arriving there, I was greeted by hawkers, scaffolding, restoration signs, tourists sitting at the adjacent cafe, and another unfriendly ticket lady. It's 15 TL per adult, unless you purchase the 85 TL Museum Pass, valid for 72 hours beginning from your first museum visit, and you get to bypass the lines waiting to buy tickets. Once inside, the mosaics & fresco are truly wonderful to behold and easier to view since Kariye was orginally a more intimate sized "church in the country". Once Times readers' underrated destinations of the world, now it's listed among the top 30 must-see museums in the world. Patricia Schultz, author of the book, “1,000 Places to See Before You Die.” ranks The Kariye Museum in Istanbul alongside such internationally celebrated art museums as The Guggenheim Museum Bilbao in Bilbao, Spain; The Hermitage in St. Petersburg, Russia; Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam; and The Museum of Modern Art in New York City. Make time to see it before they close the sections for restoration where most of the mosaics & frescoes will be closed from public view (estimated dates are Jan. 1, 2015 to Aug. 24, 2015). You will NOT be disappointed once you get past the hawkers, scaffolding, and restoration signs.

Chora Church, amazing!!!. It is located close to Theodosius II's monumental land walls. A masterpiece of Byzantine Art. Beautiful mosaics and frescoes!!!You can go there by bus from Eminonu, or by taxi.

Slight disapointment, but enjoyable!. Having walked round in circles for a while (no sign posts!!) a local took us to the entrance of this museum, where we were greeted with the white restoration information boards explaining that the main part of the museum was closed. Our hearts sank, after walking miles from hotel we were both looking forward to seeing this. However, on entering, there was lots to see. The areas were quite cramped, with lots of 'walking tour' groups pushing around, but once there were gaps, got some stunning photos. Will visit again in the near future to see whole building in its magnificent splendour.

Byzantine beauty. It was a church, then a mosque, now a museum. The church, or a version of it has stood here for centuries. And waiting inside are beautiful mosaics. During our visit of September 2014 the central part (the nave) was closed for renovations. We were disappointed, but once inside realized that almost all of the mosaics and frescoes are outside of that part of the church - there is lots to see. Fantastic glittering mosaics on the ceilings, the walls, even down low were we could examine them quite closely. They are not pristine, but there is a surprising quantity of them. The church is a remarkable example of the Byzantine history of the city and worth a visit. We took the ferry up the Golden Horn and disembarked at Ayvansaray. We took a walk outlined in our Lonely Planet Istanbul book. The walk took us along the ancient city walls and was very hilly. The last bit were you turn for the church is not marked from this direction, which meant we blew past it and added considerably to our walk. It was all very interesting. But consider a bus or taxi for a more direct route!

Beautiful mosaics and frescoes in this 13th century church. A little difficult to find (non existent signposting) but worth the effort.Beautiful mosaics particularly and also some lovely frescoes.The nave is closed for restoration but the most notable mosaics can still be seen.Sublime atmosphere helped by a modest number of visitors (such a nice contrast with other very crowded attractions in this city).Pleasant outdoor restaurant adjacent to the church buildings.Best reached via Golden Horn ferry to Avyansaray pier followed by an uphill walk or,more conveniently, by an 87 bus from under Taksim Square (and a short downhill walk).One of Istanbul's finest attractions. Strongly recommended.

Istanbul's top highlight. Now, this church is not an easy find. You have to work yourself harder if you, like me, are planning to reach this place not via roads but by the Golden Horn ferry(highly recommended). You need to get down at the Avyansaray pier and follow the Byzantine era walls lined right up the hill. This would take a good 20-25 mins to reach on foot but then you are treated with a very different and least touristy side of Istanbul. And the rewards for such a hardwork is just fantastic. Brilliant frescoes adorn the wall here depicting Biblical scenes. The audio guide is just brilliant. Strongly recommended to purchase one of these so that it helps you get a good idea of all the frescoes put up. Remember not to use the camera flash inside. I would rate this place higher than the Hagia Sophia for the sheer amount of intricate works that this Church houses. Most of them have been well kept. Plan to linger around for 2-3 hours to let this place grow on you.PS : Since this is a very old church, many of the rooms may not be accessible to the visitors on account of renovation works etc. It was such in my case at least. But whatever part is open for public views, do make it a point to visit this iconic place. These are the moments in your life that just take your breath away.
Amazing Mosaics. This beautiful church has so many magnificent and intricate mosaics that it is worth the detour from sultanahmet to go see.

Stunning. Absolutely amazing mosaics. Unlike the Haghia Sophia and other Byzantine churches in Istanbul this was never converted, and so didn't suffer the purge of Christian icons/frescoes/mosaics. Well worth a visit.

INCREDIBLE. Is one of the MUST places to visit as a tourist in Istanbul. It is very tiny and cute. Not a large museum however the history that it has quite large! You can see many mosaics inside. I do not like to share more info about it. Just visit it ;)

Byzantine hidden treasure ;) a must-have tour!. Don't miss this small museum which was a church once upon a time, then a mosque and since 1945 a museum. Closed on Wednesday. Opening time: 9 -18 in summer (until 16.30 in winter). It costs 15 TL (+15TL with audioguide). The main aisle is closed due to restoration works. However, the lateral aisle called paracclesion and the inner and external narthexes are rich of byzantine mosaiques. So cute and detailed that you don't stop looking at them. that's one of the most superb monuments that I have ever visited in my whole life. Higly highly recommenderd.So you can get a taxi to get there or simply by foot (if you're well trained it takes more or less 1 hour from the gran bazar - 5 km.) I DID. It was fantastic.*_______*

See the Bible with your eyes. Chora is not visited by every tourist but it is actually a gem that must be seen. Located in Edirnekapi, quite far from the center of the city, it can easily be skipped. However, visiting Chora will be one of the highlights of your trip as the frescoes and the mosaics there depict scenes from the Bible beautifully and it is hard not to be impressed.After a visit to the Chora Museum/Church, a meal in the nearby Asitane restaurant will give you an idea about good Ottoman food.

Don't waste your time. This church is well off the beaten track. We walked along the remains of the old wall and went there as a side trip. We passed a mosque along the way (Mihrimah Sultan Mosque) and went inside. It was far more interesting and beautiful than the Chora Church and it was free! I don't know why they call the church a museum as there is nothing inside other than the painted walls and mosaics and a gift shop. It is currently covered in scaffolding and half of the inside is closed for renovations but you'll still pay 15 lira to get in. We also wanted to buy our museum passes here but were told they don't sell them (contrary to the information provided on the official website). So if you still want to go to this church and you're thinking of purchasing a museum pass to do it, make sure you do so before traipsing all the way out!!

Magnificent Church. This is a fabulous example of Byzantine art and is remarkable. Make sure you see this! Its not that hard to get to and is worth the effort. You don't need a tour. Its really lovely

Very disppointing because most of it was under construction.. also hard to reach. Unfortunately, it is under renovation.. and probably will be until the early 2015. Don't go there until then because it is very hard to reach and there is not much to see.. The area where it is located is quite unfriendly.. I advise to go there by a taxi or by a bus, not by foot.. I think that the museum will be great after the renovation, probably next year in the summer, but for me it was dispapointing, not to mention that the fee was the same (15 TL, which is approximatively 5,5 euros, for an adult) even if just a little part of the church was opened.

The enigmatic mosaics of the Virgin Mary. The Chora Church isn't easy to find. It is of the beaten track from the main sites of Istanbul but it is a well worth journey. My first impression was I was looking at a church dedicated to the nativity or the birth of Jesus Christ, but some of the mosaics were not all that right. It was half a way through that I read and found different clues that I was actually contemplating the birth of Mary Mother of Jesus! This church was actually consecrated to the devotion of Mary and the paintings follow the apocrifs gospels. (those thousands of gospel that talk about Jesus and Mary and all the events of that time that have not been recognised by the Roman Catholic Church) I felt I was peering through a keyhole of history.

So worth it!. I had little expectation about this site. I had always thought that the most breathtaking part of my Istanbul trip would be the mosques, specifically Blue Mosque (it is lovely, btw) but this church was just as beautiful if not more so in some ways. First off, it's a little bit off the beaten path, meaning it isn't situated in the tourist trap that is Sultanahmet but that also means taxi drivers my try to scam you on the fare price to drive out here. Make sure the meter is on!The paintings and artwork in the church are amazingly well preserved and the audio tour is so worth it and is relatively inexpensive, something like 15-20 TL I think, and it's offered in multiple languages, which is very nice. The artwork tells the story of Christ but actually starts a little with the story of Mary--the audio tour explains all of this. To walk through the entire church with the audio guide took maybe about 20 minutes. It's also apart of the museum pass kart, so that was nice as there was no added expense charged to us, we just flashed the card and we were let in. I think because this place is a little further out, this explained why it was not crammed with tourists, the church is fairly small but seemingly bigger than the Blue Mosque and there's a cute little gift store in the corner that sells some nice memorabilia.

Katiye church. Magnificent church. Although because maintenance at the main part of it we did not enjoy our tour. If we did not have bought the museum card I do not think it will be worth to pay the price.

If you love history you will love it. No matter the religion that you believe, this church shows the perfect tiles uncover under a tick layer of plaster as a master piece, from times where the catholic church ruled in the old Constatinople, it is impossible to describe such beauty, even the photos cannot show what the eyes can see.

Takes your breath away. This is one of the most beautiful places I have ever been. Walls and ceilings covered in frescos and mosaics which will take your breath away. A bit out of the way, but if you go to anywhere in Istanbul this has to be the place.

fantastic church. this is an abosolutely fantastic chuch,the reliefs on the the ceilings and walls contain so much colour still, it`s amazing and so much detail.well worth the trek out to and you can aso see the walls of the city from where the great battle took place, nearby there is a panorama museum which explains the battle of the city and well worth a visit also.so use the public transport network and it`ll cover all the stops you need.unfortunately parts are closed for restoation works currently

Church become museum. This very interesting temple was built up in two different centuries and you can easily observe the from the different parts of the building. Now a days, can be visited as a museum, with its interesting fresques . Just a small information, there is a resraurant just next tis museum, with a menu from the old automan palace meals.

A Gem. Hard to find, but worth the effort. The museum is undergoing a major restoration with only a third of it open, but it's still worth the visit. Rent the headphones and skip a docent-guided tour. it's many times difficult to understand the docent's accent, but you can easily replay the headphones.

History, and sublime art. Byzantine treasures in a city owned by Muslims for hundreds of years that survive do so by a combination of luck and tolerance and accident and so it is here. The final (?) phase is their restoration in our present transitory position of tolerance and respect in a currently stable secular society but, in how many years might none of those helpful conditions remain? Go now! For me, with an excellent and scholarly guide, it was a revelation to learn of the suppressed history of Christianity and to see the hidden history revealed on the fabric of this building in mosaic and fresco. The word used often was 'apocryphal' and there the clue is 'The Apocrypha', defined as writings of dubious value' therefore excluded from the Bible. Without wishing to ruffle feathers and leaving it to you to decide for yourself what written word you consider as fact or fiction or legend or any word you choose, just go and see this as sublime ancient art inspired by belief.

Off the beaten path. This is a small church that is frankly somewhat of a challenge to get to. But the mosaics are not to miss if you're into 11th century Byzantine mosaics and frescos. Stunning. Would give it five stars if it was easier to get to. If you're a history buff, this is worth the trip.
A real find of history. Early church frescoes are being restored to their original beauty. Visited in 09 and ther was a need to restore. A short taxi from Sultenahmet area is well worth the ride

Wow..... I cannot believe the mosaics in this place, they are incredible. It was as shame they were plastered over, but perhaps this is what has preserved them. They was renovations going on while we were there, so would love to come back and see it finished.

Nice to still be able to see the mosaics in real life. It was a very humbling experience being able to see live the original bysantine mosaics. A place not to be missed in order to get the feeling of all the phases Istanbul went before getting to the present form.
Breathtaking. Just when you think you may have seen it all you end up here. It is a spectacular sight and story. A must do!

A Gem. This is the church to see for a sense of what the Hagia Sophia was like before the Orthodox Christian and Muslim iconoclasts erased the art. Parts are under renovation, but it is well worth your time. See the city walls while you are there - just up the hill and to your right.
Kariye Museum. The church was being restored so much was not open to visitors. Getting there was as interesting as the church
Beautiful!. It has great mosaics and frescoes and is a great example of Byzantine mosaic art which describe the life of Jesus and the Virgin Mary. It has 6 domes.
