Seraphim. An amazing jewel! For the first time in my life I learned what a seraphim looks like. Cherubim I already knew. I loved going there, and the outside is very interesting also, and there were no other people!
A hidden gem. A must see. Beautiful mosaics and not so many tours. Get a taxi in and out and spend at least a couple of hours in this wonderful place.

a little gem. We stayed in the hotel next to chora church. As such it clearly is a must to visit. If you come from the city center, you should like to see churches, look at pictures and identify stories from the bible. If you have some time left, it is definitely worth to come out here from the city center. Take a boat to close by and stroll up the hill through a nice neighbourhood, with occasional great views.
A little expensive. Found it expensive for what it was. Glad we went still a beautiful place , but way to expensive! Too touristy , other better places to see for free:)
Its a must see in Istanbul!. Chora church is surprisingly beautiful. Don t miss it! The church is kept very good. You don t find else where such a masterpiece.

Worth taking your time over. This gem of late Byzantine art has got onto the tourist route and can get quite crowded. Let them dash past.Buy the guidebook (using your Museum Pass to get some discount) and let it enthral you with it detailed descriptions of the mosaics, as some of the panels tell stories from the Gospel of St. James, i.e not from the more familiar evangelist Gospels. The workmanship is superb.

Worth a visit!. Yes its a little out of the way and under restoration, but its still worth visiting to see amazing byzantine mosaics. Give yourself a morning to visit the church, maybe get a coffee in the square outside, then walk up to the old city walls before getting a taxi or bus back into town. The trip there and back is a cultural experience in itself as you pass through local shopping streets! A must for anyone interested in history, art or culture.

The Major Byzantine Site for paintings and mosaics. Rather out of the way (transport needed) but a magnificent collection of 12th century paintings and mosaics. Note especially the painting of Christ's descent into Limbo.

Amazing, will go again once restoration is complete. The church was under restoration and we could only see a portion of it, but it was worthwhile to go there as it was better than Hagia Sophia in terms of detail, but smaller in size.

Pretty Amazing. The church is ticked in a residential neighborhood, so it's a bit tricky to find, but it's definitely worth the trip! The mosaics and frescos are far beyond anything you will see at St./Aya Sophia. Yes, the main church was closed for renovation, but better see some than none. Don't miss!

Incredible mosaics. The church of St Saviour in Chora is not in the main tourist area (Sultanahmet) but is well worth a visit for its glittering Byzantine mosaics and frescoes. Although the staff at our hotel advised us to travel there by taxi, we decided to try and get there under our own steam at a fraction of the cost. We took the T1 tramline from Sultanahmet as far as Topkapi. At Topkapi we followed the signs to the T4 tramline and took the tram as far as Edirnekape. At Edirnekapi we walked across the road to the city wall and, turned left keeping the city wall on our left. We used the map in our guidebook and a bit of common sense to determine when to turn right to the church but for greater accuracy you can check out street names on Google maps. The walk to the church took about 10 minutes. You will need four tram tokens per individual to get there and back from Sultanahmet. At the church, we hired an audio guide which helped to a certain extent but also confused us a couple of times when we couldn't find the mosaics to which the audio was referring!

The best Byzantine mosaics in the world. One of the great treasures of Istanbul and less visited than other major sites. The intimate setting and the preservation of these mosaics make for a most beguiling experience. Follow the sequence of scenes around walls and ceilings of the various rooms close up. They were all made in a short period around 1320 (the time of Giotto) and exude a foretaste of the coming renaissance. Although the Nave (the main domed room) was closed for renovation at the time of my visit just to experience a small part of one of these mosaic cycles is a privilege. Go!

One of the least known pearls of Istanbul. This church dates back to 300-500 AD and has been modified in the years after. I heard quite some good stories about this church and the photo's looked really cool. Although it is a bit further away from the city center we decided to go to this church. One big hall was being renovated but I think the other parts were truly amazing as well. The amazing paintings and mosaics decorate the whole cealing and large parts of the walls. A must see in Istanbul and maybe even THE highlight of my trip to Istanbul.

Wonderful mosaics and frescos. Some of the stories represented in the mosaics and frescos are easily identified, but some taken from popular (at the time) apocryphal gospels not included in the standard New Testament editions and therefore a detailed guidebook or audio guide is a must.
Amazing piece of history. Ancient mosaics that depict the early life of Mary. Cafe next door is quaint and quiet. Worth the trek.

currently under reconstruction. FYI - currently under reconstruction, Closed on Wednesdays, limited viewing, am sure it will be great when fully restored, will have to go to Istanbul again,travelling there with public transport is a bit of a trek but do-ableif your guide books says take a bus from Taksim squire, the bus station is underground, it isn't really a station as the bus stop on the road, so be ready with your cash for the driver!

Impressive but difficult to get to. Friends raved about this church and it was impressive. However, we probably would have skipped it if we were more pressed for time. A large part was under construction. It is not part of the MuseumCard so an extra fee is required. It is hard to get there by public transport so taxi was really the efficient way to go. Once there you are at the mercy of non-metered taxis to take you back so excellent bargaining skills are required.

Very disappointing. Most of it is closed for renovations. Certainly the big ticket items. Yet they still charge 15 lira to get in. Would not recommend it until all the renovations are finished. Just not worth the effort at the moment as it is quite out of the way.

So impressive. Historic. Cannot describe how impressive the restoration has been. The early Christian church has unbelievable mosaics. Worth trekking to..we took the trams, transferring once both ways. And then walked 20 min, past part of the western wall. Very easy.

Spectacular Heritage from Byzantine. Locates in one of the oldest district in Istanbul, Edirnekapı. It is not close to any other tourist attractions but by it self it is a value. It used to be a Byzantine church from the 13th c. and turned up into a museum. The mosaic works inside is amazing. The main dome is under construction at the moment.
Renovation going on. When we visited a major renovation was going on and most of the rooms were closed for that. However if you have museum pass it's worth to visit.
under renovations. The Chora Church was under renovations when we visited and until it is completed it is not worth the time and cost to visit.

Worth the Trip. The Chora Church is not on most organized tours but definitely worth a trip to see the wonderful mosaics. Unfortunately, there was a very limited amount of the church opened as there is extensive restoration work currently being done. After visiting the Chora take a walk along the top of the Old City Walls for a great view of Istanbul.
gorgeous. We were unlucky, most part of the church were under restoration and closed. We could see only the corridor. But however, it's worth going.

A bit out of the way!. Many people miss this amazing church being a bit out of the way and not much to do there after seeing this site. Don't be fooled, it is worth your while. Take a taxi and asked to be dropped in front of it.For me the mosaics there are better than the one in Santa Sophia and the energy very different. You really feel yourself in a Byzantine Church.Also you can take advantage to eat at one of the best Restaurant for authentic Ottoman Cuisine: ASITANE, don't miss it.

wonderful mosaics. The second best mosaics I saw (the best were those in the Zeugma Museum, Gaziantep-Turkey). Although we could see only few mosaics it worth pushing the stroller up the hills for more than 30 min. I strongly recommend getting there by a taxi as there is nothing interesting on the way to the church. I also recommend eating at the nearby asitane restaurant which serves different food from the ottoman royal cusine.

Disappointing!. I was so looking forward to see this! However, it was the biggest disappointment in an otherwise fabulous city. The place is tiny, far from everywhere; the mosaics are few. Most of the place was closed, perhaps due to repairs. Sorry, but not worth a visit. To try and make the best of the taxi ride, we went to the walls, which are very close. The walls ase magnificent, but are unkept, dirty, without any information... Also a disappointment.

superb. beautiful mosaics of XIII period of so called renaissance of Byzantium - Palleologian period - a must do!!all frescoes and mosaics are in very good condition and survived in much wider variety than at St Sophiathe aincient walls of Constantinopole are in walking distance and vert interesting to walk byFatih area - where the Chora is located used to be Greek area of the city- now in ruins, though worth seeing...the facades still picture a very elegant area and you may reconstract in your imagination how beautiful the area was

Must See . A remnant of Constantinople, the Kariye Museum is currently in the 2nd stage of a 3 stage restoration. Despite seeing 2/3rds of the church itself, i'd deem it worthy of your time in Istanbul regardless of whether you have a week or a day.

Amazing mosaics. Although part of the museum is under restoration right now, it is a must see, as the ancient mosaics in this little church are exquisite. I had my neck hurting by looking upwards. It is a serene and tranquil place besides its artistic and historic value, as it is far less visited than the other sites in Istanbul. If there was a bed to watch the mosaics comfortably I'd still be there.
absolutely beautiful. Stunning compact little building unfortunately partialy closed for renovations during aug14 but neverless really worth the effort to visit.

Unbelievable murals. This is a small museum out of the way from all the other big sites, but so much of the artwork is so well preserved and so beautiful it has to seen. The walk from the Golden Horn commuter ferry dock to the museum is through neat little neighbourhoods that I never felt unsafe in.

Great example of a glorious time. There is much to see and admire here. Though the art work belongs to another age, it still tells the stories well. In an age when reading and writing was the privilege of the elite, this is how stories were told and remembered.

Walk there, take your time, and marvel. The Chora Church (chora meaning outside) is located near the old Theodosian Walls of Constantinople. The small little church, built by emperor Justinian, who also built the Hagia Sophia, is a beautiful, stunning example of Byzantine mosaic. The gold artwork is unforgettable and aside from having to navigate awestruck visitors, you can just stand and gaze at the technique and artistry of the church.If you have the time, consider walking up to the Church. Perhaps 60-90 minutes, the walk will give you a snapshot of Istanbul outside the tourist area. Chora Church is hidden away and you'll miss much of the city if you don't give it the chance. There's tourist souvenirs and restaurants if you want to relax afterwards. Dedicate some time to this site; most people do not.

Better than Aga Sophia. This historical church is outside the city walls but the history behind the walls is an amazing part of centuries. The curator and the president Mr. Mehmet is an educator and if you get a tour from him you sre one of the lucky ones.

The Chora Church.. We got off of the jump on and off bus and took a taxi to the top of the hill. Only cost 10 lira by taksi. Unfortunately the main church was closed for renovations. The side and entry spaces where amazing. It would have been excellent if main sanctuary was open.
Very impressive. Under restoration when we went but still worth the trip for what was available there to be seen. An important historical site and the mosaics and frescoes are just stunning.

Most unusual frescos. Having seen many frescos and mozaics, this was the first church were the life of Jesus' mother Mary from birth onwards was depicted as well as judgement day with Jesus holding Adam and Eve by the wrist and Satan tied up in a bundle in hell. Unusual from the usual scenes of nativity, last supper, etc.

a real gem. The mosques are great but after seeing a few I found this church a delight to visit. It feels so intimate, so different, yet so delightful. It is stunning inside in its simplicity but with amazing paintings and mosaics on the walls and ceilings, with gold mosaic tiles glistening in the sun. The area there is also peaceful, which makes a nice change from the hustle and bustle of Sultanahmet. Go and visit the old walls which are close to this afterwards. It is great to walk around the district there and see men sitting playing games, smoking and drinking tea.

Beautiful mosaics and interesting history. This church, that was turned into a mosque and then into a museum throughout it's existence, has endured with its beautiful mosaics, that were restored, since they were previously covered with plaster.

Under restoration, but still my fave site in Istanbul. The most amazing mosaics I have ever seen, worth 1/2 day. The restoration works still allow to see the most interesting paintings and mosaics.It is possible to go by tram with one interchange at Topkapi, getting off at Edirnekapi

Splendid mosaics. This church/museum is well worth a trip. it has some of the most beautiful late byzantine mosaics, in a fairly good state of preservation. The current restoration works block access to the inner room, but you will miss only a few mosaics.Notice: this site is to far from central Sultanahmed to walk, but is accessible by bus. If you take a cab, ask in advance the price (we have been badly cheated...)

Beautiful church; renovations leave something to be desired. A hard-to-find but beautiful example of Byzantine mosaics, the Chora Church is a sight to behold. It is small enough to do within 20 minutes. When I was there, the audio tour stall was closed, which left me without much information. There are no brochures, placards, or books available for purchase under $50. The renovations have (as of now) closed the central section of the church, about 1/3 of the small church.

Disappointing conditions and under restoration. First, I have something against a religious site being called a museum. It is a church and not a museum. Otherwise, all historic churches and mosques in Europe should be called museums. This just to show you how disrespectful the authorities are to non-muslim sites in the city and their unwillingness to acknowledge the historic significance of this church. In this day and age, this kind of revisionism is in my view unacceptable. Second, as fantastic as this site is (as seen by the numerous rather useless reviews for this site) it could be a lot better. The inside in the summer is humid and hot with no ventilation which makes the experience rather uncomfortable, not considering the damage that these conditions can cause to the artifacts in the church (no wonder they're restoring it). There are a lack of descriptions for any of the church or mosaics (yeah, some of us don't want to dish out the extra dough for the audio guide). Third, the ticket office did not make it clear to us that the main part of the church was under renovation. I wouldn't have gone. What's the point of seeing the minor parts if you can't see the main nave of the church. It's not even mentioned predominantly on the main website. I wouldn't have gone if this was the case and waited till the restoration was completed to see the entire structure as it's supposed to be seen. All in all, I felt that a place of such historic significance should've been treated with more respect and care. As in the few other remaining Byzantine relics that remain in Istanbul (and there are very few) one gets the sense that it's more there to make money rather than preserve historic and cultural identity.

Most of the museum is closed for renovation. What was open was nice enough, but after seeing other greater sites in Istanbul and Turkey in general, I'd suggest waiting till the restoration is over. Other people who had traveled some distances to visit were quite disappointed at what was available at this time, July 2014.

One of the best. I think Kariye museum is the best example of late byzantine art. The mosaics and the frescoes are breath taking. If you can please go when the cruise ship guests are not there. Lunch period is good time to visit. There will be less people.

Incredibly beautiful. As the others wrote, it's a little difficult to get to, but it was magnificent! There were many frescoes on the most of the wall . They were incredibly beautiful. I didn't want to leave there.

A must see if you have an interet in the history of Christianity. As everyone knows, Istanbul is very secular. I personally hope it stays that way. It is a beautiful city on the Bosphorus with a rich history and many attractions that date back to ancient times. In particular this Church has a uniques set of mosaics and Frescos that tell the history of Jesus's parents and his birth and childhood. I found it incredible and had never heard or seen a history of Joseph and Mary. This should be a must see.

Beautiful. Beautiful mosaics and murals inside. Free entry with the Museumkarte. Although the main space is closed for refurbishment most of the artwork is in the areas which are accessible. Excellent tea garden just outside and we also climbed up onto the old walls nearby (only for the agile) and had a great view over the city.

Don't look down! . This great little church out west. It's a bit far from the other Istanbul attractions, but definitely worth a look if you have time. The draw are the mosaics dating back hundreds of years, of biblical significance, such as that of Jesus and Mary. The pictures are stunning and the attention to detail incredible and are littered across the ceilings and walls. So don't look down, or you'll miss it all! Unfortunately couldn't see everything as part of the church was being restored, but glad we went.
Smallest but greatest site. Make a point of stepping away from Sultanahmet for this jewel of a church, absolutely stunning in spite of the ongoing work that closed a large part of it. Must see.

Atmospheric. I missed this church the first time we were in Istanbul, so this time, I was determined to see it. It's a little hard to get to, but the frescoes are so beautiful and so well-preserved, it was worth the effort. We took the tram to Eminonu, then crossed over to the Otogar and waited for a bus. If you're pressed for time, take a taxi.

Do not miss this experience - best Byzantine Church in Istanbul. This was an humbling experience. The art is incredible - but it was more of a spiritual experience for us. Not easy to get to - but worth the effort. We took a taxi to the church and then walked back after touring the nearby City Walls. If you are on a package tour that does not include this Church/Museum - strike out on your own and visit.
Wow!. This is quite a find. Beautiful and with much historical significance. Really cute part of town where you can sit have a nice meal accross from the church.
Magnificent. Absolutely breathtaking almost a magical experience. You cannot miss this attraction!Dr. Mohamed Abdalla Tillsonburg

The most amazing mosaics I have ever seen. The Kariye museum = the church of Jesus Christ the Savior in Chora (= in the country, outside the Constantinean walls of the fortified city), is a bit out of the way but well worth the effort. The most convenient way to get here is by the number 4 tram (connect to it at the Topkapi station, where you can switch from the Number 1 tram from Sultanahmet). For me, this is the most unforgettable sight in Istanbul. Never (not in Ravenna, Sicily, even Haghia Sophia) have I seen mosaics with such subtlety, so nuanced, so three-dimensional. Breathtaking. The best features of Renaissance painting, in mosaic art of incredibly delicacy and elegance. The frescoes are also impressive, also have that three-dimensional quality. The artists have made use of architectural features in a very sophisticated way. DO NOT MISS THIS GEM!

A great museum filled with beautifully detailed mosaics.. Having visited Istanbul several times I was looking for a less busy attraction to visit in the heart of the city. I chose the Chora Museum based on previous reviews and I wasn't disappointed. If you love mosaics, it is not to be missed as the amount of detail is spectacular. I was with a local guide whose knowledge of the biblical images was prodigious. If pays to let the larger tour groups pass so you can view the images at length and in peace! Located inside is the obligatory tourist shop and across the road are some great tea shops. Walking to the site through the maze of streets was a delight and it was lovely to witness the daily life of the locals.

An Istanbul favourite. Getting there is part of a culturally authentic experience and great fun. We took the Big Bus blue tour, and got off at the 2nd stop from Sultanahmet, at a waterside park. Using the GPS on our iTouch we navigated our way up the steep hills for 30 minutes through local neighbourhoods - past schools, churches, mosques, children playing, women shopping, men lounging or working, graveyards, colourful, tall, woodframe homes, and abandoned buildings - where we were the only tourists - and this is high season. We took the road less travelled to the Chora and the more direct downhill route back (saw other tourists on return trek). Both were wonderful. Smiles and "merhabahs" go a long way with locals. The children were engaging and some happy to practice their English on you "My name is ---, where are you from?"The Chora itself was stunning. Even though the main part of the church was closed for restoration, the balance was breath-taking. Not crowded and very intimate space. We were glad we rented the headset (tip: bring a splitter and share a headset) as each scene in mosaic, as well as the history and significance of the place, was described in appropriate detail. Recordings were about 30 minutes in total. We saw a couple people with guides, but perhaps counter intuitively, preferred the headsets for flexibility and maneuverability.We had tea at the little restaurant just opposite the Chora. Lovely setting, nice place to relax. But the service was dreadfully uneven, and despite the number of waiters, many guests were frustrated. I would not recommend against it, but reserves of patience and equanimity may be required.

an interesting walk!. we choose to take the tram near our hotel, the erboy, as far as we could and then walked through many neighborhoods until we got here. had an amazing lunch along the way at "kucuk ev", had our shoes polished by a man who was a double amputee, passed a school that was having a celebration for it's last day, and watched the men come streaming throughout the area respond to the call for prayer at the many mosques that we passed. tucked away we came upon the museum. it was still under renovations. fodor's states that the finest byzantine artworks in the world are here. well work the walk, including all that we saw along the way.
Amazing pre christian place. Wonderful mosaic, especially the Pantokrator!!! One of the best places in Istambul. Quite to difficult to find by foot, far from center and metro.

Mosaic Magnificence. This gem...tucked away from the historic district but just as glorious if not more so than the monuments in Sultanahmet district, is nothing short of a jewel of the Byzantine era. If you like mosaics you MUST seek out this. Some sections are also beautifully painted. It's much less imposing than Hagia Sophia, but you are embraced with a special historic intimacy here that rises above the other popular favorites.

Worth the effort getting there. Still under renovation, so expect boarded off sections, but well worth the effort getting there. Those parts which have undergone renovation are superb. It's small inside, so best go early !

Interesting mosaics on ceiling. We enjoyed our trip to the Chora church and the history surrounding the relocation of the Greeks and Turks that our guide provided. This is a very well preserved church that is also extremely old. Many biblical stories are depicted on its ceiling and are worth seeing. It is also a nice walk back to the city. I would suggst taking a cab there as it is a little out of the way.

must visit!. This place is a bit off the main attractions downtown, but it's not so hard to reach, it doesn't take so long to see, and the quite frankly you can see a lot in such a small place. We went there the last day on our trip and I don't regret it the least bit. Unfortunately at that time part of the church was closed, but the drawings around were enough.

Simply Gorgeous. If you are on a short trip to Istanbul you will be advised to skip it but if you really want to experience Byzantine art do not miss this amazingly gorgeous and well preserved church. It took almost 45 minutes from Taksim (funicular, tram 1, and then tram 4). It is in an old residential neighborhood. I strongly suggest to take a direction from the tram station before you go. And please do spend 15 liras on the audio guide. Otherwise you will not be able to understand or appreciate the art and different stories depicted in those beautiful mosaic and fresco.
Family holiday. Amazing mosaics of bible stories and being so well restored. Church partly closed for restoration. So very ancient and amazing to see. Loved the whole place.

Off the beaten path, but worth the search!. A little difficult to find, but worth the search. The outside of this church is disappointing, but the interior is incredible. I recommend hiring a qualified guide to translate the story told in the paintings. Amazing!

Closed on Wednesdays. Made the mistake of taking a taxi there on Wednesday, it's very difficult to reach via public transportation. After finding it closed (my fault, I didn't read the guide book carefully enough), it was a long but interesting walk through genuine Istanbul neighborhoods down the hill to the ferry service. It never seemed dangerous as we were there in afternoon, but I would definitely avoid in the later hours.

Startling mosaics. Mosaics all over the building. Parables, scenes from the life of Mary, Mary and the saints, Bishops. Actually we walked. We took the main road up behind the university, a long straight road until we eventually turned right and there it was. It is out of the way, but really worth the effort.

Take a taxi - but well worth it. A little out of the way (Chora is Greek for outside the city). Even though half the church was under restoration it was still worth the trip to see more of Byzantium. There is a great little cafe beside the church to have lunch.

Same as Hagia Sophia. There I just found similar Icons as in Hagia Sophia and the church itself is smaller. Maybe non Christian's eye cannot detect the difference.But the ferry trip from Eminonu to Ayvan Saray andthen 30 minutes climbing a hill to reach there was fun.(The area was not so dangerous as manyguide books say partly it could be because of walking during the daytime). On my way back, I lost the way to neaby Metro station and ended up with riding a Metro & Metrobus. Specially the latter was very unique. When I asked earlier about the ferry riding point for Golden Horn Line, all the four locals did not know and recommended me to take a bus instead. Finding the location was a kidn of Treasure hunting.

Outstanding mosaics. This is a small Orthodox Church that is under renovation right now, but still well worth the visit. It is a bit away from the main sights. A cab ride from Sultanahmet was less than 20 TL, and included a ride through the gate breached by the Ottomans in the siege of Constantinople. The name "Chora" did refer to the location of the church outside the walls and in a remote area at the time of construction. While some of the reviews indicate frustration with the current renovations, you are only missing out on 3 mosaics inside of the main part of the church. Most of the mosaics, and all of the most interesting ones, are in the entrance hall or the side chapel.

Magnificent mosaics. It was a bit of an adventure getting here by tram and metro (we'd have gone by bus if we realised that each stop comes up on a screen by the driver!) But it was well worth it. As others have said, the church itself is closed for renovation but actually most of the mosaics are in the narthex and side chapels, so in fact you can see nearly all of them. But you do end up getting a bit of a crick in the neck. Entrance is included in the 3-day Museumcard which also includes Ayasofya, the Topkapi Palace etc.

A (rather hidden) Gem. I remember reading a couple of reviews about Chora Church before we left so I made a point of looking for it when we were in Istanbul. It isn't close to all the other sights but rather out of town central, close to the ancient walls. But most definitely worth making the trip to. We caught a bus which was easy enough. The church is only tiny but absolutely covered in Frescoes and Mosaics. We did an audio tour which was great as there was so much to see and it ensured we didn't miss any thing. The exterior to the Church is really beautiful and very peaceful. We were able to make our way to a part of the dilapidated wall from here and managed to find a place to climb it which gave us great views back over the Old City.

Not to be missed!. Not easy to get to. And when we went, they were renovating parts of it - so couldn't see much. But what we did see, blew me away. The amazing mosaics and frescoes seem to come to life! Well worth the trip.
A beautiful Church. I visited this Kariye church as one stop on a day tour I was a part of. I didn't know about it ahead of time, but was in awe of the detail of the mosaics on the ceiling.
A Historical Mosaic Gem. Amazing mosaic's depicting scenes from the old Testamente. Learnt a lot from the guide. The Church is being renovated, so could not see parts of it, but well worth a visit.

Ancient. So fascinating. A relatively small church full of ancient artifacts. Feels like one has steeped back to mid evil time. The art work of tiny gold and colored mosque tiles is worth the visit. A must see.

Moved me to tears. I visited this church over six months ago and just thinking about it now makes the hairs on my back stand up! The simplicity of design of the building is beautiful but nothing prepares one for the riches of the mosaics. Make the effort to visit this monument - it's well worth it.

Worth the visit. It's a beautiful place, the mosaics are awesome and the details of every scene are incredible. It's worth to have a guide or a book that can explain at least some of the scenes since there are some that are part of the life of Virgin Mary that are unknown for most of us. Outside the some small stores with really good prices for souvenirs.

essential. One of the 6 or 7 places to be seen in istambul.the most moving byzantin church in the world ?the building dates from the 11 th century and the mosaics from the 14 th.Gorgeous !! you may spend hours watching the mosaics's details. it's located in the suburbs of the town, not so easy to reach.Don't try to take a bus from Eminonu ( long and tedious wait ).you'd better take the tramway from Sultanahmet and get off at Edirnekapi station.and then a 2-3 minutes walk to the museum.Don't linger too long in the Fatih streets around.it is'nt the most secure area of Istanbul.But don't hesitate to go to Chora: a lot of tourists and probably of policemen. so it' s safe.Enjoy your visit !! Entrance = 7€

Pleasantly surprised. I visited this church as one stop on a day tour I was a part of. I did not know about it ahead of time, but was in awe of the detail of the mosaics on the ceiling. Don't miss Jesus healing the leper and the crippled man. The detail is amazing.

Under restoration but best Christian mosaics still visible. This stop is not on many Turkish tours - maybe becuase it has a strong Chsrtian? Dont be fooled by other recent reviews as the part being rennovated has only a few of the best mosiacs. The quality of the 14th C Christian mosiacs (tiny, colorful, expressive faces) you can still see are the finest in the world. These are moslty in teh domes, or vaulted ceilings of teh outer araeas so you have to bend your neck to see them. Yes it is small - have a guide or audio set so you wont miss teh black angel and Mary as a tot to teenager!Next door is a tile shop with demonstrations of how to make teh painted pottery. Well worth a visit too. Museum qulity modern pieces upstairs.

A beautiful Church- turned Mosque and Museum. Beautiful Building with walls covered with mosaic illustrations and pictures of dignitaries and stories from the history of the ancient land. One can read much about the history of the museum on line, but you can only experience the the beauty and the awesomeness of the structure and its holdings while visiting the placeHighly recommended

Pity about the restoration. but still worth visiting to see the amazing mosaics that are still open to view. make sure you don't have a stiff neck because its a lot of looking up and we found it challenging to get to and involved a lot of walking.

Chora Church. Incredible mosaics in the narthex and inner space. Nave is closed for restoration. Mosaics in near-perfect condition. Very nice restaurant across the street. Take a taxi as it is difficult to find.

A Waste of Time. I had read wonderful things and really wanted to come. We took a long tram ride and had to ask directions several times, trying to find the church and museum. The fee is high and much of the interior was closed to the public. We spent all of 10 minutes inside.

Off the beaten path and under restoration but worth the trip. The mosaics are impressive. The location is Fatih is quite a distance from the city center. We walked back through the suburb of Fatih, through the University district and got back to the Grand Bazaar in about an hour.

Almost worthless site AT THE MOMENT. Today, at the 27th, we went to the Kariye, bought the ticket, but were able to get only to the hallway and the passageway on the right. Yes, there were some nice Byzantine mosaics, but the whole tour took like... 10 minutes. The main hall of the church was closed for restoration. So make sure it's REALLY open in full before you go there.Also, the taxi driver apparently rigged the taximeter cause he charged us 47 liras from Sultanakhmet. So don't trust the taximeter blindly.
A little gem. Although currently being partly renovated it is still well worth a visit. The mosaics and frescoes are awesome.

Byzantine church. Located in the Edirnekapi district this is one of the last surviving byzantine churches in Turkey and the place has some really beautiful mosaic works. There are majorly three sections to the Kariye Museum, the entrance hall, the main church hall and the side chapel and each of them carries some unique and beautiful mosaic works but sadly most of them are falling apart and a restoration project is currently undergoing at the place and because of which only certain sections are open. The only problem with the place is that it is situated quite far from the city center and you have to rely on a cab to travel to the place.

Out of the way, but worth the trip. In the Sultanahmet district there is little of the Byzantine era. If you like history, the church has some of the most impressive mosaics and frescos I have seen. Added value--see the wall of Theododius II that saved Constantinople from invasion on the land side and Mihrimah Sultan Mosque, another Sinan mosque. A taxi up Fevzi Pasa Ave. from the Suleymaniye was $9.00.

A must-see for the frescoes.. The Chora Church is enough out of the way that it is not swarming with tourists. That allows you to linger and gaze at the incredible mosaic frescoes that survive from the late Byzantine era. It's close to the city wall on Istanbul's west side and an inexpensive cab ride from the Old City. Highly recommended -- a real jewel!

I was a church, than a mosque now I'm a museum with unique mosaics and marbeles. Sorry for the long title, but I was trying to find a perfect title to define The Chora Church. This little church was built in byzantine period, with the conquest of İstanbul It was converted to a mosque like Hagia Sophia. Chora has a world wide reputation with its mosaics and marbles. Unfortunately marble section is closed due to renovation works. But you are still able to see wonderful mosaics works. Mosaics has a chronical order. They first began to tell life of Mother Mary, how did she born, how did she marry and how did she give birth to Jesus. At the exterior narthex, life of Jesus was explicated. It is better to visit museum with a guide, it is a small museum but there is too much to understand and see. Entrance fee is 30 TL, during the summer time you can visit the museum till 19.00 but last entrance is at 18.00. And please note that; it is not easy to find museum, due to location of Chora. I suggest you to take "metrobüs", get off at "Ayvansaray" station than take a cab. If you are able to use your GPRS It would be nice walk at the area.
must see. I'm strongly recommend for visit and slowly observe it. You can buy some intresting book inside about history of this place

Beautiful Mosaics. This is a very small church with beautiful mosaics. I think it would be best to be with a good guide here, although most guidebooks do a fairly good job. It is crowded and expect your neck to ache by the time you are ready to leave.

worth going all the way there. Amazing mosaics and frescos, a little gem, well kept. The church is small but I thought it was very different from the other things you see in Sultanahmet. Last admission is at 4.30 so make sure you get there earlier.

Worth a taxi ride for sure. The Chora church isn't near public transportation so a taxi is the way to go. When we went a lot of the church was closed but still, it is impressive. Imagine building a dome with brick. Even more impressive when you learn that the black death was raging when they were racing to finish the church.

Undergoing Restoration. It is a little difficult to find, but well worth the trip. Even though it was undergoing restoration when we visited, it was still beautiful (and included in your museum card, if you purchase one!) Definitely worth the trek to find!

Byzantine Church. A partially restored area, different time period than most of the
sites in Istanbul. The Chora Church (Kariye) is still being renovated, just the outer areas are available to visit for now; still worth the visit and is in a outer area away from the main Old City Center (we took a cab)

Worth a visit. Yes, it is a little off the beaten path. We took the tram and metro and walked to get to it but the mosaics are amazing. They are beautiful. They glitter and gleam. You can see how tiny the tiles are in some mosaics. I ended up with a stiff neck from looking up so much. I want to go back when the restoration is finished. BTW there are some restaurants on the main street which offer good basic food very reasonably priced.
Exquisite mosaics and frescoes. Quite difficult to find but well worth the effort. If you tire of queuing at the Hagia Sophia, this is an outstanding example of 13th century mosaic and fresco work.

Byzantine beauty. What a hidden gem! We were recommended to go here by our guide as I am a big fan of Byzantine art and it certainly did not disappoint. It cost us 25TL from the centre of town to get there as it is just inside the city wall and difficult to navigate by public transport but it was probably the highlight of our visit to Istanbul. The beautiful mosaics are still being painstakingly restored and the outside of the building was also being worked on but what you can see is truly marvellous. The bible stories are brought to life and are alive with colour and intensity. It is such a pity that more people do not get to see this place as it is top of my places to see in Istanbul.

Under restoration. Even though the place is under restoration and half of it is not accessible I would still say that this is a gem that should not be missed with so much to see and experience. This once a church holds a lot of amazing frescos and mosaic works all over the place. The place is located in the edirnekapi district and it was built as a church in 16th century and went on to become a distinguished mosque under ottoman rule and now it is a museum with some of the finest works In fresco and mosaics.
Astounding. The paintings and murals full of vivid color and of historical significance make it all come alive and you will take loads of pictures trying to capture the magnificent beauty.
A must see. Stunningly beautiful mosaics and frescoes. Very busy and unfortunately couldn't access all of the church due to work being carried out but still a must.

Absolute Gem, A Little Off the Beaten Path. What a fantastic visit - my boyfriend and I did this our last day in Istanbul and I am so glad we made it. Everywhere you look, the church is filled with the most stunning examples of mosaic and fresco work. Seriously, your neck will hurt by the end of the visit because you will be entranced by the beautiful, artistic work. The church is undergoing a major restoration, so the main sanctuary was closed when we visited (June 2014), but worth a visit regardless, as the two narthexes and side chapels are simply stunning. Be advised - it's not the easiest place to get to. We took the tram from Sultanahmet and it required a transfer plus a little walk (which is pretty uphill on the way back). The area it's in is the antithesis of touristy, which my boyfriend and I actually enjoyed. Also, right off the main road on your way to the church, there is a strip of restaurants with great, simple lunch food, including doner kebabs prepared by gentlemen who look like they have been practicing their craft for years. While they didn't speak English, they were so patient with my butchered Turkish and were some of the most hospitable and gracious people I encountered on my trip!
Chora. Best Christian mosaics outsider of Ravena. Sadly the central nave was being repaired and not open. Alas.

Undergoing restoration. The church is undergoing restoration at present but is still worth a visit to see the outstanding mosaics. The 32 bus from Galata bridge got us there although we had not realised you have to press the button to request the bus to stop. We found entry was covered by our 3 day museum pass, although I could have sworn the sign where we bought it claimed it was excluded. It is also close to the old city walls and you must see them. Also, whilst there, look at the ceramics shop outside - of course it lives on tourists but they have some more interesting stuff than most. Don't accept their first price.
Worth an hour or two of your time to see.. Great mosaics and artwork. It's on the western side of the old town, so I'd recommend spending on a taxi to get you to and from. Well worth the visit.

Not to miss. The Chora Church is the most charming and beautiful church I have ever set my foot in, considering I have visited countless other magnificent churches in Europe, including the Vatican. It feels very peaceful, homey, down-to-earth, and grounded inside. Impressive frescoes and mosaics still survive till today in vivid colors retelling the story of Christ. Built around 400 A.D. (before the land walls,) we admired the domed Byzantine architecture that is later adopted by most churches. We reached Chora Church by bus. I think it gets you the closest, unless you take a cab.

Fascinating. Do not miss if you have interest at all in the history of the Christian faith.The main section was closed due to renovation, but the visit was still very worthwhile. Make sure to get the audio tour earphones to get the full understanding of the mosaics.

A Must See In Istanbul. Dont miss going to the Chora Church. The Byzantine mosaics are stunning, and you won't see finer examples anywhere. Even with a significant portion of the museum closed for renovations, there is more than plenty to see to justify a cab ride from Sultanahmet. I consider this a must see in Istanbul.

Superb mosaics but tricky to get to. We consulted several locals and The Rough Guide on how to get there. The Guide said tram (which doesn't go there!) while locals said bus which seemed more hassle than it was worth so we opted for a taxi which was expensive but worth it-cost us 30TL there and 40TL back. The mosaics and frescoes we saw were superb, probably the best preserved I have ever seen in their glittering gold glory. The main part of the church was closed for restoration which was a pity as it made the visit quite short. Still it is worth going to see. You can also have a look at the massive city wall too while you're there
Beautiful Church. Wonderful display of Byzantine mosaics, one of the best in Istanbul. Worth a small cab ride from Sultanamet.
incredible mosaics. Great masterpiece. Never to be missed. Tell the entire Christianity story with so many beautiful representations.

Chora Church - Worth the side trip. Beautiful old Byzantine Church with impressive mosaic work. The church is undergoing restoration (as is much of Old Istanbul) but that shouldn't deter you from seeing this significant building.
Small but worthwhile. Often overlooked, the Kariye Museum is well worth a visit! Small but fascinating, with intricate murals all over the ceilings. A little expensive though.
Super mosaics. It's a trek out to the west, just inside the old city walls, but an extensive gallery of Byzantine mosaic decoration. When visited, part of the church was being restored.

The most beautiful mosaics in Istanbul. The mosaics in this Byzantine church are the most beautiful and complete in all of Istanbul, and perhaps in the world. Go early in the morning to avoid the crowds.

Excellent mosaics and frescos. Those amazing Byzantine mosaics and frescos are some of the last remains from the late empire. The church was partially closed for renovation works, therefore we could not see everything. My only complain is that the bookstore staff was awkwardly rude and gross.
Chora Church. A steep walk up the hill from The Golden Horn but the mosaics are brilliant, best I've seen.. Sadly it was half closed for renovation.
fascinating. Some of it was unfortunately in repairs but it is an impressive site. The ancient paintings come to life and are really worth the trip from the center of town.

Under renovations. Interesting to see the fine detail of the small mosaics used, unfortunately major renovations restrict access to a large part of the Chora church museum. We did not enter the museum section.
A must visit. Extraordinary Byzantine gold mosiacs. Tells the story of Mary and the birth of Jesus.one of the more beautiful exhibits
Mosaic. Unique mosaics in a unique place. A little hard to find on your own with an exciting walk through Fener.
A must visit. Though it is a small church compared to the hagia Sophia, the mosaics on the walls are really outstanding telling all the biblical stories. A must visit on ones itinerary to Istanbul

Excellent. Small but an excellent site to visit. You need to get a bus from Eminounu bus station, which takes about 20 mins. Also your 3 day museum pass does not cover the entry for this. You will need a 5 day museum pass or pay 15 Lira for entry.

Amazing mosaics, but under restoration. The mosaics that are visible are remarkable for their artistry. The extent of the church closed for renovation was disappointing, but much needed.The church is a bit out of the way, requiring a 3-bus trip or a taxi. There were taxis outside when I wanted to leave, but I think the driver over-charged (disappointing but not surprising).You can buy a museum card here, but plan carefully. The card is only worthwhile if you're planning to visit at least 3 of the sites it covers. Chora Church is not one of them.

Jaw dropping good. Likes: There is only ONE Chora Church Museum! The attention to detail by the craftsmen & artists involved. It is really labouring for the glory of the Creator God.Dislike: some restoration work going on, but it's understandable as the building & interior is very old.

The best frescoes in Istanbul. Take a bus from eminonu to edirnekapi - lot of buses, just ask at the bus stop. From there a 5 minute walk away you will see some of the best preserved frescoes you will ever see ! We got a neck ache just staring at all the wonderful images! You can sip tea outside the church to bring a perfect end to your day - be a bit careful, the church closes by 6pm even though lonely planet mentions it as 7 pm.Also, visit the Mirinmah sultan mosque at edirnekapi itself post this visit !

Some of it is closed to renovation, but still worth a visit. The Chora Church is one of the ancient attractions that Istanbul offers, as it is dated to the 3rd century. In this small museum you will find truelly amazing mozaics that were well preserved and are very impressive.I visited the museum in the end of May and it seems like a big part of it was closed due to renovation works.By the way, there is two nice places to eat around it.

Beautiful church, still under restoration. This church is quite far from the other sites and we paid the taxi driver 50 Turkish Lira to get there from the old city. The church itself is beautiful and the frescoes were really amazing. However, we were disappointed that half the church was closed for restoration so we felt a little cheated that we had to pay the full fee to see only half of the church, as we had hired audio guides too but no-one informed us of this until we discovered this for ourselves when we were inside.

A real treasure.. This lovely old Byzantine church is loaded with mosaics and frescoes. It's a small church and it is easy to take it all in. It's not centrally located but not too far from the Sultanahmet district.

Mosaics and frescoes are amazing. Just amazing, Istanbul keep a real gem in suburbs. Mosaics and frescoes are well kept, shining, spectecular. Nowadays interior is in restoration, but still worth for a visit. You may visit there with museum pass (one valid for 5 days). Also check Pammakaritos Museum and Asitane Restaurant if you go to Chora Museum.You may check the link for details; http://backpackingistanbul.com/chora-museum.html

A definite Istanbul highlight. A bit further away then many of the other attractions but with a fraction of the crowds of the other sites it has truly world class awesome mosaics that need to be seen to be believed. You will not be disappointed.

Must see byzanthine Church. Kariye Museum (=Chora Church, former byzanthine church) Must see. Open 9-19.00, closed on Wednesday Admission 15TLR (included in museum pass). The audio guide was also 15TLR, which we found a bit out of proportions, as we are a family of 4, we didn’t do this. Also the a part of the church was closed for restauration, still worthwhile. By the way, it’s very small.You can combine with the ancient city wall and if you like Kariy you should also see the Fethiye museum (mosaic), This is an old church, similar to the Kariye, but most of it is now a mosque, however they preserved a small part as a museum. It’s really small, but beautiful fresco’s. They also have a small garden where you can sit and relax. Very peaceful, very old (some of it 3000 BC). 15 minute walk from Kariye.

Amazing mosaics and frescoes - must visit!. Having first visited Ay. Sofia, I did not expect that I could be wowed by any other mosaics. I was so wrong! Because of the smaller scale and cosiness of the church (in comparison to Ay. Sofia), the mosaics and frescoes are closer to you, so its easier to appreciate and admire the details. The level of detail, the technique used, the colours of the mosaics and frescoes are stunning, especially considering their age! Believe what you hear - they are the finest examples of Byzantine Christian mosaic. The Resurrection fresco is supposedly the most beautiful depiction in the christian world . It is tucked away off the main tourist areas but don't be put off! You'll regret it. If you intend to visit Ay. Sofia, Topkapi Palace and Chora Church I would recommend buying the museum pass - it saves time!

Breathtaking!. The walls and ceiling of the museum-former church) are covered with biblical paintings that are, in some cases, in pretty good condition. Bring a bible and a good guide and spend hours looking up and around.

Not all of it open, but great anyway. After visiting mosques and palaces, we came here to the Chora Church. Only part of it open due to areas being renovated, but what was on view was beautiful. We didn't take any photos inside because though you could use a camera, you could not use a flash. There was something very quiet and peaceful about it. We took photos of the posters outside instead and we were surprised how well they came out. The paintings in the domes are amazing, as are the wall paintings and mosaics.Would recommend.

Best attraction in Istanbul. This church was by far the most impressive thing we saw in our 7 days in Istanbul. The mosaics were absolutely incredible. Unfortunately the annex was closed for restoration but the our parts of the church were completely worth it. And as just 15TL this was the cheapest museum we went to the whole trip. Totally worth the cab ride. Also, stop by Asitane for dinner afterward!

Brilliant Visit. Whilst on holiday in Turkey with (Travelsphere) we had a guided tour of this beautiful church. The interior is absolutely breathtaking. The mosaics and frescoes on the walls and ceilings all tell a story of early Christianity and no matter what your religious beliefs are and taking in account when they were created you cannot help to be impressed. This is a must visit when in Istanbul.

Beware...majority of it is under renovation. We came here from sultanahmet which was at least a 35 minute tram ride where you have to switch from the T1 line to the T4 line at the topkapi station. From there it is at least a 10 minute walk. If you don't have gps on your phone, good luck finding it.Entrance is free with the 5 day museum card and there is no discount given for the 3 day museum card. The full price is 15TL.Also beware that the majority of the property is closed for renovation and you are only allowed to see a very very small part of it. At the end, we wish we could have seen the entire place and didn't think it was worth the time to trek out there to see only a small part of it. I would recommend going here only if you have extra time and have seen everything else you want to see in Istanbul.

Go if you have extra time . If you are staying in sultanahmet or taksim, this is really out of the way. At least a 35 minute tram ride and another 10 minute walk in an area which is sketchy. You cannot get in with the 3 day museum pass and free entry is only allowed with the 5 day museum pass. Entrance fee is 15TL. Also, most of the place is still under renovation as of this writing and you are only allowed to see a very small portion of the place. We did not think it was worth the journey out there. Will probably be better once the renovations are done and the entire church can be seen. That's why I say only go there if you have extra time and have seen everything else there is to see on your itinerary.

Frescos and incredible mosaics. If you enjoy art then visit the mosaics in the entrance to Chora Church. The mosaic pieces are so small that much detail and emotions show on the faces. The many panels tell a detailed story of Mary as a child until after the birth of Christ. Our guide from Equinox Travel, www.equinox.com.tr, gave interesting descriptions of each mosaic scene (such as noting Mary's feet shown bond just after birth to show she is still a virgin) Frescos adorn a 2nd area.
You should see this. In a city with a mosque on every street corner, one of the few ancient churches to visit and much older than the most Western European churches.
it is a must to visit. Beautifull fresces. A place that is sending you directly at the begining of christianism. It is a must to visit

Worth a visit. Amazing mosaics, especially when you consider how long ago they were created.The church is not in the Sultanahmet area of major sights, but it was straightforward getting there – take the tram from Sultanahmet to Eminou, walk to the bus station and grab a bus. (Check with your guidebook/hotel on what number buses.)BTW, it was under renovation when we were there. The nave was closed but the two narthexes were open, and the bulk of the mosaics were there.

Chora Church's Amazing Mosaics. Glorious gold permeates all the panoramic panels. The mosaics are in amazing shape considering the earthquakes and their age – they are nearly 700 years old. Did you realize that using glass tiles (tesserae) was a particular feature of Byzantine mosaics. The gold is gold leaf sandwiched between two layers of clear glass. Also, the tesserae were set at slight angles to the wall, so that they caught the light in different ways. Note: no grout between the tiles. Why is "The Anastasis" fresco (Christ liberating Adam and Eve) so significant? For the answer as well as photos and descriptions of the mosaics see http://terraencounters.blogspot.com/2014/05/day-4-am-chora-church-mosaics.html
Under renovation. Fantastic mosaics but a large part of the church was closed for renovation so we did not get our money's worth.

Amazing mosaic filled Byzantine church. Though huge mosques like the Suleymaniye,and Blue are better known, this little gem is hidden away in Chora. The story of Christ is told in mosaic tiled murals which are outstanding. It is definitely worth a visit.
Magnificent mosaics. Away from the heart of Sultanahmet, but definitely worth the effort -- glorious byzantine mosaics telling the story of the family of Mary, mother of Jesus.

Well worth trekking out to see!. The mosaics are very impressive even though the main part of the church is closed for restoration. Dined next door at Asitane - specialising in Ottoman cuisine from the 17th century - very worthwhile to blow your budget on!

The Gem of Istanbul. If you are into Byzantine art, this is a must. The frescoes and mosaics are simply spectacular. The audio guide is well worth the small price, as the mosaics are not laid out in a manner that is easy to follow without some sort of guide.
Wonderful mosaics. A bit out of the way, but worth seeing this museum. The mosaics are spectacular. We also visited the old city walls and enjoyed lunch at the cafe just outside Kariye Museum.

A true monument. An ancient church that has been turned into a museum due to the magnificent mosaics and murals that it contains – it is not the easiest place to reach using public transport and is not accessible using the 72 hour Museum pass. It was undergoing renovation at the time of our visit so that the exterior was mainly shrouded with two major parts of the interior being closed off.

Must visit. This is a small museum/church a little further out of town so not that busy. It is simply amazing and probably the highlight of the trip - make sure you make the effort and get out there.The only downside is that part of the church is undergoing restoration and could not be visited.If you are in İstanbul must visit!
Great Mosaics. Fascinating church with outstanding mosaics - well worth the visit. Like much of Istanbul is very deep in history - would highly recommend for part of a visit to the area.

Impressive!. Although part of the building was closed for renovation, and despite chattering tourist groups, the church, with its multi-layered history, seemed to breathe a holy spirituality. Well worth thr effort of finding one's way there.- and worth reading up on its history before visiting. Amazing frescoes.

Restoration works limit what can be seen but go anyway. The frescoes and mosaics that can be seen are worth the trip on their own. When finished walk three minutes uphill and see the City Walls. We had a long, but interesting walk back down Fevzipasa Avenue and Halicilar to the Tram as the taxi out to Kariye was expensive.

Great ceilings. The Chora Church is somewhat out of the way near the city walls - probably best to take a taxi although getting one back was more tricky (we couldn't find a driver prepared to use his meter - the usual its very busy story!). When we visited (April 2014) most of the church/museum was closed for renovation but entry was inexpensive and the mosaics and wall paints you can see are fantastic - worth a visit but not a must-see whilst the works are on-going.

My favorite in Istanbul. This was my favorite! Loved the late period Byzantine mosaics. Not a large place but so full of beautiful mosaics telling the stories of important events in the lives of Jesus and Mary. Take time to put the story to the mosaic and it comes alive for you. There are great books in the little shop so you can study the mosaics more closely on your own.

Wait for the Restoration. The whole place is undergoing a phased restoration & the only parts open are the inner & outer narthex, thus the main interior & the garden are closed off.Those mosaics & frescoes still on view are, indeed, spectacular, but they are only a fraction. Not only is this disappointing (although one appreciates restoration must take place) but the full price is still charged (both entry & audio guide), which is cheeky. Also, the same number of visitors are crammed into a much reduced area, which further detracts from your visit.Having seen the full set of mosaics a few years ago, it is most definitely worth visiting, but only when the restoration has been completed.
Magnificent frescos. Magnificent old church busy being renovated. Pity that most of the building is closed off to the public at the moment making it quite a short expensive visit.
Nice mosaics. Impressive old church with really nice mosaic showing the life of Jesus. A portion was undergoing renovation at our visit, but most was open to view.

Absolute Masterpiece. White-washed for centuries, the richly painted and mosaic-laden sparkling walls of the Church at Chora (the countryside) are a marvel to behold. Harvard University's Dumbarton Oaks institution in Washington DC took on and delivered a splendid work where centuries of world art history converge, from Byzantine to early Renaissance styles. The stories of the Bible come alive blow-by-blow while the history of this city reminds the visitor of just who was this generous donor in a most beautiful "Deisis" (the Prayer) featuring Christ, the Virgin Mary, Emperor Isaac Comnenus and the keeper of the church, Melanie, at the inner court. The location is indeed hard to reach as most younger taxi drivers don't know it. Armed with a map, however, any tourist should be able to direct them. There are also tram lines of a more circuitous route for the unhurried visitors.

Beautiful mosaics. The Chora (Kariye) Museum is in Edinekapı area which is the outskirts of the old town. It is not too far from Grand Bazaar and it is worth the visit. The Asitane restaurant next door is a winning choice with its authentic Ottoman dishes.
amazing mosaics. This is one of the best byzantine churches in the region. Although reconstructed several times during the centuries, you can still feel there the early byzantine atmosphere...

Extraordinary, beware the renovations. Despite much of the church being closed for renovations, there is still a lot to be seen here, with some of the most spectacular mosaics in the world on walls and ceiling. The simple cafe on the hill facing the church is good for lunch or a break after your visit.

For the history of Istanbul, to start here is a must. If anything, see Chora before Hagia Sofia to better understand what its hidden glories might be. An added bonus is that Chora is located in a tranquil old neighborhood which still contains wooden houses with balconies overhanging the quiet streets, as well as probably the most outstanding shop selling Izmik pottery. The manager is happy to show the museum and explain the history and style of the ceramics. It is the only place I will buy ceramics. There is a lovely park as well surrounding the church and a shaded outdoor cafe, as well as other restaurants nearby. It is on the same side of the Golden Horn as Hagia Sofia, Blue Mosque, etc., but you should probably take a taxi or a car.

restoration at the Chora Church. Finding this church was a real challenge! We went by tram (as suggested by other Tripadvisor writers - thank you), but our map wasn't good enough for the last bit and our Turkish is non-existent so local people weren't able to help much! But it was really worth it when we did eventually get there, despite the main part of the church being closed. (I might skip a visit if they're onto Stage 3 of the restoring though, which bars access to almost all the mosaics.)

The masterpiece of the Byzantine's art. A visit not to be missed in Istanbul.The mosaics, paintings in the dome of this museum are staggering. It was quiet a feeling to re-imagine the glory of Byzantine Empire's faith and tradition by simply looking at the paintings.A masterpiece of the Byzantine's art. A classic structure.

No to be missed. Chora Church is not in an area easily accessible to public transportation but it is well worth a visit. Naturally the mosaic work is unbelievable and the story of the lives of Mary and Chris puts a different prospective than the traditional bible story we are taught. Quite fascinating.

was quite a bit off the beaten path. getting there was part of the adventure, which was fun. it is a small church with very very detailed mosaics and frescos. Made sure to have a guide book or audioguide to explain them in more detail or it isn't worth the time.
Don't miss this!. The mosaics and paintings in this Byzantine church are an unbelievable treasure. Just wish photos could do them justice.

Amazing. Simply visit this place, it worths it and I advice to be with a guide. Which makes these places interesting is the original stories. There are many frescos and I loved to hear what they all mean. The place is not so big so it doesn't take so much time. It is a must see place when you visit İstanbul.

It is under renovation and there is not that much to see. Don't bother until restoration is complete
The mosaics are not too high on the roof and wall so you can see them ok
If you want mosaics go to Ravenna in Italy
Fantastic mosaices and frescoes. A little hard to find! But once found it was definitely worth the traipse round the surburbs - beautiful.
fabulous tile art. Well worth a visit to see the exquisite tile art. The main part of the church was closed, but what we saw was excellent.

Tricky to get to but worth it. This Church is a bit off the usual tourist track but most definitely worth the trouble finding it. Restoration work is in progress but most areas are still accessible. The frescos and mosaics are amazing and tell various stories. It is worth finding someone to tell you about the different mosaics - like the one of Theodore offering the Church to Christ and the one showing the genealogy of Christ.

Superb mosaics and frescoes. This museum is slightly off the beaten track (although close to the northern part of the walls, which are often included in coach tours), but very well worth the effort. From our hotel in Sultanahmet, we took the T1 tram to Eminonu, and then the 38E bus (10 stops).If you liked the mosaics in Aya Sofia, you'll love this church. The walls are covered with mosaics and frescoes, many of them in excellent condition. In most cases, you can get much closer to them for a really good look.As others have mentioned, the main body of the church is closed for restoration, so a few of the works can't be seen, but most of the more important ones are on view.If you go on a sightseeing tour on Mondays, when Aya Sofia is closed, the tour companies will often bring you here as a substitute. However, this approach undersells the Kariye museum, which is well with seeing in its own right. Highly recommended.

A Byzantine Gem. The surviving mosiacs and wall paintings are a tantalizing reminder of the richness of Byzantine religious artistry. Sadly, the inner part of the church is closed for 2 years as part of an on-going renovation programme. Luckily the outer parts of the church which contain all the classic mosaics, are open. But beware because these parts are due to be renovated in coming years and will be closed to the public.

Mesmerizing & Beautiful...A Must-See!. So well worth it to visit the Chora Church and its magnificent byzantium frescoes and mosaics. It will leave you breathless. The church itself is small & quaint but the sheer number of mosaics and stories told on the walls & ceilings are plentiful. I really liked that it was less busy than some of the other sites we visited. Try to go mid-morning to avoid the larger tourist groups and take your time once you're in there... We took the tram directly there from Eminonu (bus #37E or 38E). It was easy to find though we noticed quite a few couples arriving via taxis too. A hidden gem for sure!

Fantastic mosaics. The main church is closed for restoration during 2014, but most of the mosaics are in the outer parts and are accessible. Fantastic depiction of Mary's life from the Apocrypha not common to most bible stories (such as father Joachim). The mosaics are very well preserved. The audio guide is not brilliant. It's better to have a guide book with a map of the illustrations, which is easier to follow. Be prepared for neck pain, the mosaics/fresco are all high. You can take a taxi but it can be a wild ride. We went by tram to Topkapi, and then light rail to Edirnekapi (maybe 40 mins). You need to walk under the wall. It's a left turn on Savaklar Cd, crossing road at traffic lights. You then follow Fevzi Pasa Cd until you can cross it, and look for signs for a left turn to Kariye. If you reach a soccer stadium you've gone too far. Download Google maps before you take the tram, and it's easy. There is an outdoor restaurant right beside the church, and a nice one (Asitane) close by. The walls are less than a 5 min walk, and definitely worth climbing. Walk back to a main road before taking a taxi (the nearer ones are waiting for unprepared tourists). We went late (about 3.00 pm) and the crowds were low. Most of the cruise trips are probably done by then.

Stunningly beautiful. Floor, ceiling, walls covered in the most beautiful religious mosaics you have ever seen. Stories depicted by the mosaics are wonderful. Turkish Orthodoxy teaches that St. John accompanied the virgin Mary to Turkey after Jesus died, and she remained in Turkey the rest of her life. The mosaics depict many wonderful stories about Mary and the holy family that I have never heard. I really think this is my favorite historic spot in Istanbul. Our tour guide lost his voice explaining the meaning and the stories behind all the mosaics. A bit crowded. Definitely see this church with a guide, although a self-guided tour may be available at the church.
one of the most important things to see. it's a hidden treasure. not easy to find, but absolutely worth it. amazing mosaics and frescoes!a must see!

Wonderful. Friends told me to go, it's pretty hard to get there (a short bus ride from the Galata bridge, but the traffic was horrible), but it's worth the pain. The paintings and the mosaics are beautiful, no words to describe, the church is small and intimate.Watch out: there are restoration works in the church probably they will last for another two three years.

Mosaics and paintings!!. Small and beautiful window into the history that's a bit far from the main city but worth the trip. We found the interior - mosaics and paintings more interesting than the ones in Aya Sofia, which is more impressive from the outside.The audio guide was a bit hard to follow but we enjoyed nonetheless. Go for a guided tour if you are interested in learning more about the mosaics and the paintings. 1 hour is enough to see the place. Some parts are closed due to restoration.Also, do try 400 year old ottoman recipes at Asitane restaurant next to the Church after you are done!

Worh to try. If you staying sultanahmet you need taxi to go cos it s complicated to reach there but it s worthy.and it is cheap entrance when you compare hagia sofia.and it s beatufull as well.you will love it.

Amazing place. Partially inaccessible because of restauration works.. You need to take a taxi to reach this museum because it is too far away from everything in the city to walk. Unfortunately it is hard to reach by public transport because you need to take several busses. Taxidrivers in Istanbul are terrible. We have been ripped off when we took a taxi back to the city. The driver pulled the "changing money trick" on us and as we were off guard, it has cost us 80TLR. Be warned !The museum itself is amazing. The mosaics and the frescos are very well preserved. We did not use an audioguid so i cannot comment on that.Unfortunately the nave of the church was closed when we visited but I saw it on photographs and it is the least interesting part of the museum.

Wooovvv. I think this was one of the highlights of our trip through Greece and Turkey. The mosaics and the frescoes were incredibly vivid and the explanation of our guide made it more interesting. It is a bit far from the main city, but do not miss it.

the Chora Church. Visiting the Chora Church in Istanbul is a remarkable experience - and a step back into history when the church used beautiful depictions of the life of the virgin Mary and Christ to encourage and instruct its members. The walls and ceilings are full of beautiful mosaics and paintings - whose artistry and use of color, scenery and story convey the importance of the events they depict to any viewer. The large number of well preserved and/or artfully restored works are easily viewable and give the viewer much to marvel at in the relatively small and compact space. I highly recommend visitors putting this high on their agenda in Istanbul.

Amazing Mosaics. Even though the size of Kariye Museum (The Chora Church) is not very big but it contains a lot of amazing mosaics all over the ceiling and walls illustrating scenes from the life of Christ and the Virgin Mary. It is one of the oldest churches dating back to the 11th-century. When you are done, there is a small cafe outside the Church that serves fast food, but my recommendation for a good meal is to go to Asitane Restaurant which is near the entrance to the church. The Church can be easily reached from Sulanahmet by public transportation. Take the tram to Topkapi, the light rail to Edirnekapi, then a short walk. It is open from 9:00 am to 7:00 pm; Admission 15 TL (included in Museum pass). It is closed on Wednesday. Enjoy it.

Fantastic. In spite of the fact that renovation is being done in the main area, don't let this stop you from visiting this church. The audio tour is pretty interesting and MOST of the mosaics and murals are actually in the areas that are still open.Go early to miss the crowds.

I Have a Regret. This was my 3rd time in Istanbul. At the first 2 times I didn't go to this museum. But this time I had few free time and had a chance to see the museum. IT WAS AMAZING... All of the Architects should see it. Amazing Mosaics. I guess next year I will also go the place to see again.

A little gem. \this is a comparatively small church for Istanbul, but contains some absolute gems and should not be missed. Restoration work is currently being carried out, like so many of the cities' attractions, but this in no way detracts from the beauty of the place.
Must see. Difficult to find but what a joy to discover. This place is best to visit before closing time (18.00 summer time) or early in the morning.
for art lovers. the mosaics are absolutely amazing. The place is very nice though it's quite away from other sites. I would recommend this place if you are in Istanbul for more than 2 days!

Beautiful but Not a Must See. If you have the extra time to walk around Istanbul, the Chora Church is a lovely place to visit. We included this site as a stop during our walk from Eyup back to Beyoglu (a little detour from the Golden Horn boardwalk) -- if you love to walk, this is a great itinerary.
Spelndid. The mosaics and frescoe were impressive. Pity that some of this church was closed due to renovation wors, nowhere was announced. But anywhere I would have gone to see it!

Small and under renovation. Chora church or Kariye Muzesi - This is undergoing a renovation currently (April 2014) and hence most of the church is not accessible to to the public so it may not be worth the trouble of getting to this place (bit far from major Old city attractions and little difficult to get to for a normal tourist) and paying 15TL entry fee. I would suggest going there after the renovation is complete or if you are really into mosaics and frescoes as there are a few good and interesting ones to see in the accessible areas.Avoid the souvenir shops outside the church/museum as we found the really expensive when compared to Grand Bazaar or other places.We had a tough time getting there by the Metro and most of the local people we spoke to for directions didn't know Chora church and Kariye Muzesi or museum is better known. Also the brown coloured direction boards that are commonly used in Istanbul is in Turkish and says Kariye Muzesi and does not have any other names (Chora Church/Musuem) on it.

Old Marvel. A small church that has survived many fires, bombing, and just natural erosion. takes no more than 45 minutes at best to see. However takes you a good 45 minutes to get here from anywhere in Istanbul. Get an audio guide the very least to understand everything thats there to learn.
CHORA CHURCH. under renovation at the time of visit not much to see, can still go in but only about a corridor to see. Cannot by Museum Card from this area either

Amazing mosaics and frescos. Did the lonely planet walking tour from Aryansaray(?) - and ended up here - very nice and much more pleasant than bloody topkapi palace. go for the joint ticket and save time on queueing.
Just marvelous. A museum full of spectacular mosaics and frescoes. A must visit for anyone interested in Christian Byzantine art.

Stunning. We were overwhelmed by the beautiful mosaics and frescoes.
