The restoration work is outstanding and although there is still work going on it (some of the areas are closed) it is worth a visit just to see what is there now.We used public transport to get to Ulubatli (Tram T1 & M1) then walked along the old city wall to get to the museum then used our 3 day museum passes to get in.

Moasics galore. For those interested in Byzantine art and/or mosaics this site is a must. Don't expect to buy a Museum Pass here even though all the posters and websites say you can - ticket staff (sitting next to a sign advertising the Pass!) refused to sell me one and kept repeating 'Topkapi'. There were many people in the church when I visited so I didn't appreciate it as much as I would have liked. The mosaics and frescoes are certainly worth study. Combine this with a visit to Haiga Sophia and Fethiye church museum (around the corner a little from Chora and with few tourists) and you will gain a good sense of Byzantine art and architecture on different scales.

MOSAICS worth to see. I visited Chora museum, after years together with my friends. It's under renovation at the moment but most of the mosaics can be seen. Some departments of the museum is closed. Entrance fee is 15 TL for per person. Public transportation is available from Taksim, Eminönü.It's also a great experience to see the neighbourhood of the church. There are well preserved old wooden houses. The restaurant in front of the Chora serves good food.

Another taste of Istanbul. The church mainly exhibits the Christian storyThough some of the parts have been destroyed but it is still rich of cultural meaning and it's quite different from the Islamic It is a bit far from the Sultanhamet area and locates in the residential region(though I've ask the direction from the locals in Turkish, many of them do not know where is it)so it's better to bring a map with you!

Very interesting but felt a little disappointed. maybe I have seen too many beautiful churches in Romania and Bulgaria, but was a little disappointed. Also the main sanctuary was closed for restoration. Still you can see all the mosaics and frescoes.

WOW!. Go. We had a day of mosaics, first the mosaic museum then the Kariye. The cab fare from Sultanahmet is well worth the price to be delivered on the top of the hill above the museum. (40TL for 3 people) The food is great at the restaurant on site and a short walk away one can climb the city wall for a breathtaking Istanbul view.Do not miss this church. It is different than anything else you will see in Istanbul. The mosaics were plastered over for many years thus keeping them safe, so during discovery and restoration their true beauty has been maintained. Such elaborate detail and rich colors. The frescos are also well maintained. Words can't describe the experience of seeing these works of art in person. Just go - you will not regret it.

Beautiful gold mosaics. Well worth the visit. A short taxi ride away from Sultanamet (15tl), a little church with the most lovely mosaic ceilings. Not as grand as Haya Sophia but it makes up for it in gold and detail. It is included in the museum pass we purchased.Getting a taxi back is a ripoff as the drivers will overcharge, but the bus is a short walk away and if you have an Istanbul kart it is super easy.

Difficult to get to, but worth it. The mosaics here are fabulous works of art. However be aware (April 2014) there is restoration going on, so the nave isn't open to view -but the best bits are not in the nave anyway, so you haven't lost much

Amazing. Should be on one's top spots to visit in Istanbul! The Chora Church is stunningly well-preserved, featuring ancient mosaics: biblical themed scenes, it was jaw-dropping. Although the church is very small, it is certainly well worth the visit. Be sure to get an audio guide, as it is necessary to understand the background of the images. It is a bit of a challenge in getting there, we came from Sultanahmet, we had to take the metro and walk a little bit.
Kariye Museum. Beautiful mosaic and frescos it's an old Byzantine church, historical place you should not miss when visiting Istanbul

The part we saw was amazing. The main part of the church was closed for renovations and they really didn't tell us this anywhere until we were inside the church. Still recommend it if you have time, but since it is out of the way from most of the other sights in Istanbul, it may be best to check on the renovation status.
Nice place. Very old nice place price is not expensive but also very bigger but we like it we spend there time like 15 minute because there's not sp much tjings to see it but its okay we like it...

Highlight of our trip . The church is just amazing, the mosaics where stunning, so worth the visit, reason for 4 stars is that the main hall was closed for renovation, but most of the mosaics are out side anyways so didn't matter much. We took the bus from eminonu to edirnkapi, and when u get of the bus u will see mihrimah sultana mosque ( which worth a visit too) go to that first and then just before the bus stop there's a sign that says karye museum follow that it's just a 5 min walk downhill real easy, Highly recommend
A must-see. The mosaics and frescoes are magnificent. Church is away from the other sights but well worth the effort to get there.
mosaics & frescoes. considered one of the best examples of byzantine religious art.500 years of plaster preserved fabulous mosaics and frescoes.

Renovations. I thought the mosaics in the church were beautiful and exceptionally done; however, over half of the church was under construction. Due to this, I think that the entrance fee of 15TL per person was too much for 2-3 rooms of mosaics. There was not enough to see in the area or in the church for that price and the price of a cab to get there.

Small but beautiful. The mosaics here are impressive even though it is a small church. It is out of the way and I would recommend getting a taxi there. There are some souvenir stores and a cafe/restaurant outside the church.

Closed for renovation. unfortunately the Church was closed for renovation, we were able to see less than 10% I think from it, and this was really nice and I expected to see a wonderful architecture inside.As it is now, it doesn't worth to visit, especially that it is far from other attraction and you need to go only to see it.Just check if it is open, and then I believe it worth to be visited

Absolutely beautiful! Breathtaking murals.. I loved the beautiful murals and mosaics in this building. I went around them several times. The charming views of every day life in the corners were really captivating and could easily be missed if you rushed around, only looking at the larger sections. The ceilings were very inspiring. A hand-held mirror would be a good accessory as my neck ached after viewing these!The worst thing about this museum was that the main part was closed for restoration - very disappointing. I hope I can see it on my next trip to Istanbul. What we did see was still worth the visit.This museum is VERY hard to find and I think a taxi would be the best option for anyone with mobility difficulties as you can not get there by public transport from any direction, without a tortuous walk.The little cafe over the square is also very good for recuperation.

The museum was under restoration. Restoration is still going on, but it is possible to see part of the church and its great mosaics. The café opposite of the church and a good restaurant nearby are worth visiting.

Exquisite. The Chora Church is beautifully proportioned on the outside and uniquely decorated on the inside. The craftsmanship and artistry displayed there are superb. It is also an instructive look at the dominant themes of Christianity of the time, much of which emphasis has shifted by the 21st century.

Chora Church is closed for 2 years for restoration - Artwork Can't be Viewd!. Sadly, you will not be able to view the beautiful mosaics and frescoes in the Chora Church for the next 2 years. I took a taxi ride to get there, after hearing so many wonderful things about the artwork. Imagine how bummed I was when upon arriving, I found that only a tiny section of the vestibule is open for viewing. Admission was still charged and along with the taxi ride, it cost me close to $100. I truly understand the need for the restorations - many mosaics are in desperate need of repair and it must be done now or they will be lost. But for now, do not waste the time and money - you will be sorely disappointed. Spend more time in Old Istanbul exploring the Istanbul Archeaological Museum you won't be disappointed!

GORGEOUS. Another great museum experience in Chora Church, or as the locals call it Kariye Muzesi! This church sits in the outermost western area of Fatih, so I'd suggest cabbing it if you are staying in Sulthanamet - It's not really close to much ... but it's time on a plane train or in an automobile is way more than worth it!Little history lesson here: The original church was built in the 5th century, and it used to be outside the walls of Constantinople (now Istanbul) - who knows when Constantine the Great reigned? Very good - up to 337. When Theodosius II built his walls in 414, the church was included just inside the walls. So, my point here is that what's really great about the location is that you can see the famed Theodosian Walls if you visit - they are just up the street (2-birds-with-1-stone kinda thing). They're way cool!Chora Church, much like the many churches turned mosques in this area, had fallen to acts of the Iconoclasm (just in case: en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ic…), and many of the frescoes and mosaics were covered with plaster. It's a shame because restoring them has taken their toll. I would have to say, however, that of all the places we visited in Turkey, the art in Chora Church was the most plentiful and best kept, making this site not to be missed. Walking through this church is a history lesson in itself - The Nativity, the journey of the Magi, the flight into Egypt, the Second coming of Christ, the Resurrection, the many saints, Christ the Pantocrator and the account of the life of the Virgin Mary, are among the many mosaics and frescoes in the Church. In contrast to visiting the Hagia Sophia and other sites in Istanbul, the staff is pretty relaxed at Chora - they don't want you snapping flash fueled photos, but there is lots of light, which allows you to get some great pics if you know how to play with that natural light. The grounds are beautiful as well - spend some time in the garden if you are there in Spring (bit.ly/12vAOAf). While they have the audio tours available for rent, I did not take part in that, so I can't comment on the value and validity, however, I did hear others stating that the audio tours at Chora were worth it. Istanbul itself is pretty hilly, and Chora Church sits up high. If you have the opportunity, the right shoes, and the weather is nice, take the walk back DOWN into town when you are done. The views are amazing.
Mosaics. Excellent mosaics. Get the audio guide for full appreciation. Beautiful and atmospheric. Take a taxi from central Istanbul or The Golden Horn

Antiquity and art. The remaining mosaics on the walls of this small church tell interesting stories, including the life of the Virgin Mary. The quality of the mosaic and fresco works in this building are amazing considering their age and the cultural turmoils they have withstood. Well lit so visitors can appreciate the full beauty and historic impact of what they are seeing.

Loved it. Beautiful old mosaics and frescoes. Nice, unhurried and unpressured shopping nearby. Just out side the city walls. It is a nice break from the hustle and bustle of central Istanbul, Worth the visit.
Beautiful and surprising. A small church with beautiful and well conserved mosaics, far away from the main tourist attractions.
Stunning. A big chunk was closed for restoration but what we saw we loved. Golden, glistening mosaics and beautiful frescoes.

Reason to go outside the city walls. Chora Church is an amazing showcase for mosaic art. The inside of the church and the chapels are covered with one mosaic after another. The byzantine frescoes are also beautiful to see. Wandering through the church is like reading the bible, as the major events in Christianity are displayed one after the other. The church is easily reached by cab, bus or a ferry and short walk. Treat yourself to lunch at Asitane located next door and you have an afternoon filled with Ottoman and Byzantine history. The ruins of the walls of the city are also located nearby and are interesting to see and walk along.

Intimate and Lovely. This was probably my favorite sight in Istanbul. This is a small church outside of the historic city center near the old city walls. The mosaics are breathtaking, take binoculars to get a better look - or a camera with a telephoto lens. The nave was closed for restorations when we were there - too bad, but it would have been worse if either the inner or outer narthex had been closed, that is where the majority of the mosaics are. The church is situated in a charming little neighborhood - take some time to walk around and get a sense for a Turkish neighborhood.
beautiful. The church's main body wasclosed for Restoration but the parts that were ofpen were well worth seeing. so this is a limited review.

Stunning frescoes and mosaics. Jaw-dropping 12th century art all over this little church, now a museum. It is being renovated and parts will be closed on a rota, but there's so much to see, this isn't a problem.

Beautiful Byzantine Church!. Beautiful byzantine architecture, marvelous mosaics and frescoes! Perfect mix of colors and very expressive depiction of biblical scenes! You'll love the atmosphere and will want to spend considerable amount of time just staring at those beautiful mosaics and frescoes!

If going by cab, have a map and mark it on it.. The Chora was definitely worth a visit, however it took me 4 tries to find a cab driver who knew where it was. BUT HE DID NOT. Luckily i had my iPhone and Google maps and was able to direct him (once i realised he did not know where he was going!) somewhat more expensive than it should have been, but still an interesting bit of sightseeing.

Amazing Mosaics. Unlike other reviews, the whole church was open when we were there. The only reason I gave this an 'average' review is because it wasn't one of the highlights of my trip. The mosaics were definitely gorgeous and amazingly preserved, but I couldn't really hear anything that my tour guide was saying because of the very high acoustics and other very loud tour guides. I would have loved to hang out in the cute little market that was just outside.

Stunning. We almost passed up a cab ride out to this gem. Unfortunately Chora Church is situated away from the other attractions in Sultanahmet so many people miss out but it is worth the trek. The church has some of the most amazing and best preserved mural work I've ever seen. Unfortunately the main dome area was closed due to renovation so we missed out, but I can only imagine how splendid it was given the artistry of the rest of the church.

Not a must see, but worth it.. I had the museum pass so I went out to see it. It is away from the tourist areas and sort of an expensive cab ride there. The church was going through renovation at the time so there was one room I did not see. The gold mosaic tile is stunning and amazing depicting stories from the bible. Other than that it isn't much. If I had to pay for it I might be a little disappointed but since I had a museum pass it was worth it.

in restoration. Chora is beautiful and transport us to an ancient time of the Byzantine art and religiosity. The problem is that you will see a small portion of it for the main room is closed to restoration. As they don't advise you before entrance, it is a bad surprise.Anyway, the surroundings are very pleasant once you are there. If you are not in an excursion, you can take a cab or a bus (be sure you buy the card before entering in the bus) from Vezneciler square.

best preserved mosaics in Istanbul. This old christian church, dating back to the 5th century, is a gem off the traditional tourist route. However, if you have seen Hagiya Sophia, and like the mosaics discovered there, you MUST visit this place, as it contains fully preserved mosaics with an unbelievably detailed execution, which makes it almost look like it's a painting.Unfortunately, when we visited the place, the main halls of the church were under renovation, which limited our experience to only two rooms, but which had almost 100% preserved mosaics on the ceiling and upper parts of the walls. Not too much in quantity, but truly awe inspiringI must commend my husband for finding the best approach to this place. Being away from most other attractions, getting here can be tricky. We chose to go to the Edirnekapi station (with metro/tram number T4, also displayed as metro/tram number 64) and with the help of a GPS application, we got to the church in barely any time, with mostly downhill walk. From the church we went (downhill again) to the ferry station Ayvansaray. From here we took the ferry (which works with your Istanbulcard) back to Eminönü.
Beautiful Church - shame it is partly closed. Absolutely stunning mosaics. Worth getting a guide as you learn so much more. Shame that the main naive of the church is currently closed for renovation.

skip it. Such a hassle to go there and to find it and for what???? a 5mn tour of old mosaiques most of them completely destroyed.The main part of the church isnt accesible to the public anyway and they charge you 15TL for that???? What a rip off!
Need an Audio guide.. Wonderful frescos and Mosaics. No information available so need an audio guide. Nave is closed. Nice café.

Excellent mosaics. Amazing mosaics. A great work of arts in itself regardless of what story it's told. Unfortunately a bit out of the way. Got scammed by taxi on the way back so must do your homework how to get there and back. Apparently taxi scam are common in Istanbul.

Best mosaics in Istanbul!. This place is a little difficult to find. We did it on foot with a map, but a taxi may be advisable, especially if you're coming from Sultanahmet. The church is certainly worth the trip, with stunning Byzantine mosaics and frescoes. These are much more extensive than the more famous ones at Aya Sofya.

An experience to cherish. Although a little out the way, the Chora Church, is well worth the extra effort. We travelled by tram from Sultanahmet - changed at Topkapi for Edinekapi- and the church was just over the road within the city walls.It is a gem. The frescoes are, in the main, extremely well preserved and tell a wonderful story. It is humbling being there in this small church with it's rich history and wonderful art. When we went there the nave of the church was closed for renovation work, but that nothwithstanding, visiting Chora was a fantastic experience.

Gorgeous. The Byzantine mosaics here are not to be missed! Even if I didn't love mosaics, the ones here are absolutely stunning! It was a bit crowded with large tour groups when we visited, but that didn't take away from the awe-inspiring mosaic tiles and brilliantly colored frescoes. The main dome and altar area were closed for restoration when we visited a couple weeks ago, but hopefully those will open soon (and most of the mosaics were elsewhere so we didn't miss much I don't think). Be sure to stop here even though it's out of the tourist center of the city.
Gorgeous mosaics. Well worth the taxi ride to visit this lovely church, with historic mosaics. There is also a good little bookshop on site and several restaurants nearby.

true history. Real pearl, will not leave anyone indifferent.Shame that the main part of the church is under restoration, the frescoes are really beautiful and amazing that after so many centuries so well preserved as the church itself from the outside.Definitely need to go back and look after the main part of the church restored.Do not miss it!

Hidden gem!. This church was one of the highlights of my visit to Istanbul last fall. It is a bit hard to find, on the western edge of the city, but you can easily take the ferry there and walk uphill through a quiet neighborhood. Once found it rewards you with spectacular mosaics - the best I have ever seen. Not only stunningly beautiful, they are intimate and full of life and humanity. It's a small church but full of enough detail that you could spend a lot of time here.

A must for any historian or art enthusiast. The most wonderful frescos and mosaics from before the Norman's came to Britain.There is a lovely café just outside to rest your weary feet. It is CLOSED WEDNESDAYS. No one told us that!!!Very tricky to get to. Got the metro and had to walk about half a mile through some rough areas.

Well worth a visit. This church is away from the main sites, near the old city wall, but is well worth the visit. You can get there by taxi, which is the expensive option. But we took the tram to the Laleli Universite stop (all tram tickets 3TL each - tokens from a machine by the stop) then walkedafew minutes to the bus station just behind the university and got a bus (7TL for a ticket for 2). The journey was easy and we did it the opposite way round to get back to our hotel. The stunning mosaics and wall paintings make this a must to visit.

A gem of a church. A little bit off the tourist track, this little gem of a church has some of the most stunning mosaics anywhere and is definitely a couple of hours. Be prepared for a stiff neck from gazing at the ceiling!

Really Lovely, Glad We Went, But Main Sanctuary Closed. First, BE AWARE, when we went on 23 March, the Sanctuary of the Chora Church was closed due to on-going restorations. The barriers looked pretty solid. So, if that would impact your plans, check that out. Using the Rick Steve's guide, we took the Tram then a Bus out to the Chora Church. Enjoyed the view of working day Istanbul. The Church is in a charming neighborhood. We also used our Museum Pass Cards, on their third and last day, so it was a low-cost trip for us. The Mosaics and Frescos were fabulous. Again, thanks to the Rick Steve's book, we could appreciate what we were looking at. The day we went, access was available to three long hallways. And it was all about the art. Had refreshments in the square in front of the Church afterwards. A lovely morning. BTW, the Church has the cleanest restrooms in Istanbul. Future visitors, please advise when the Chapel reopens. You will NOT see the beautiful dome photo above from the inside as of now.

Worth to visit. Gold Mosaics of the Kariye museum is unique with their crafted and well protected apparences... One of the highly protected church museums of the Istanbul and really worth to visit... Paintings and mosaics are highly advanced in their artistic quality.Also try to walk around the areas it is wonderfull not crowded and you see the real life of the people.

Just amazing mozaics. The walking from Topkapi-Ulanbati metro station is little bit tiresome, but then the mozaics and frescos in the Chora museum are breathtaking. The museum is partly on reconstruction, but anyway the mosaics were really unbelievable! Really worth to go and see it!

Worth to visit. Excellent mosaics and a beautiful frescoes in a not overtouristy part of Istanbul.Certainly worth the trip, Near the ancient Roman City walls, the ancient Chora church is a treasure house of early Christian iconography (much better than St Sofia). While there, visit the nearby monumental Roman city gate in the Roman walls, and explore the neighboring streets to get a feel for untouristed Istanbul.

Visit is a must!. Splendid! this is among few churches in the world that has the most illustration on Mary from her birth, education, the birth of Jesus till her death.. make sure you visit with a qualified tour guide for better explanation!
Extraordinary. Beautiful mosaics and frescos in a remarkable state of preservation. Worth the trip out there, cost about 20TL by taxi from old city area.

You don't have to be a Christian to appreciate this little church and museum. I had read about this church and its significance in the European history, so I made sure we visit it when we were in Istanbul in January 2012. We had to take a taxi to the church because it is located outside the ancient city wall of Istanbul, a little out of the way of the mainstay tourist district. But the special trip is totally worth it. I was a little confused when the taxi dropped us off at the gate with a sign that says Kariye Museum because I did not know that that was its name in Turkish. Only a small group of visitors was allowed to enter the church at each time slot. The minute I stepped inside I knew exactly why. It is such a beautiful little church that one can appeciate only with slow, measured steps. Why? Because your eyes will be glued to the ceilings and upper parts of the walls since the lower parts were completely destroyed a long time ago by the crusaders. Would we be as dazzled by the sight had the remaining parts of the interiors remained intact? One would never know. After visiting the church, we wandered through the neighborhood toward to ancient city wall. It was a lovely feeling because we enjoyed peering into doorways, admiring the different wall decorations, saying hello to fellow foreign travelers and talking to a group of young Turkish travellers. We finally came across a bird market that was being held inside the ancient city wall! Love it, love it, love it.Don't miss the Kariye Museum and its neighborhood when you are in Istanbul.

One of the wonders of the world. This is difficult to find but well worth it. The church used to be a mosque hence the addition of minarets. The interior walls were whitewashed and plastered during this period of its history.When the mosque reverted back to being a church the plaster was removed uncovering hidden murals and mosaics from the 13th century. They are simply breathtaking and and pretty comp-lete. Its one of those places where you just dont want to leave!!A must see attraction.

Not to be missed. The standard of workmanship was amazing, the images were hauntingly moving, the paintings were packed with meaning. Take the audio guide and take your time. Visit the Mihimad Mosque nearby for a contrast
Beautiful church. It's not that easy to get to, but it helps if you are on a tour that takes you there. This is a gorgeous church.

amazing mosaics and frescoes. located a little way out of the city, a visit here is essential. you will be amazed at the quality and preservation of the mosaic tile work and frescoes. almost every square inch of the church is covered with the most beautiful pictures from the byzantine period. you will leave with a sore neck from looking at the ceiling in wonder! the 15 Turkish lira admission fee is well worth paying!
Chora Musem. Small museum but worth a visit even if it was located a bit off the beaten track, the mosaics and frescos were breath taking.

Not worth the time and the price. Our hotel locates in Sultantamet District so it took us 40 minutes on the subway to visit the Chora Church. The main chamber of the church was under restoration so we were only allowed on the hallways. There was no sign indicating that before we purchased the tickets and the lady didn't inform us and charged us full price (15TL per person).Think thrice if you're lured by its TOP 10 placement on the DK Guide like me.
Awesome preservation. A very historic church that has great mosaics that are well preserved! If you have several days, worth a visit!

A must visit. This is a small museum/church a little further out of town so not that busy. It is simply amazing and probably the highlight of the trip - make sure you make the effort and get out there. We took the ferry out and came back on the bus. Both worth doing to give further insight into Istanbul life
Nice place!. I was very impressed with the mosaics work, i just expected for the architecture to be more impressive. Its is a very small church, far away from the Old City.
Disappointment!. Immensely disappointed as we made a special trip to see this but it was closed for restoration and we could not visit.

beautiful mosaics under restauration. The chora church (Kariye museum) displays beautiful 13th century mosaics in the first corridor and colourful frescos in its side chapel. We visited a few days ago and unfortunately the nave and the mosaics in it are off limits to visitors due to ongoing restauration works.The church is located a little distance away from the main touristic areas and may take some time to reach. Unless you are a real fan of byzantine art, it could be considered to not venture out there untill the restauration works are completed.Tip: we walked down the hill alongside the old city walls and took the golden horn ferry from Ayvansaray back to Eminonu and Sultanahmed
Beutiful Mosaics. Wll worth a visit. The mosaics are some of the best in Istanbul. The only downside is that part of the church is undergoing restoration and could not be visited

Mostly closed. This place is definitely off the beaten path but well worth a visit. It was pretty disappointing that quite a bit of it was closed for restoration because the things that you do see are really amazing. This is one of the places on the museum card so if you get one of those make sure to take advantage of it. It's in an interesting old neighbourhood and it seemed to me the "touristy" shopping was a bit cheaper here than the Sultanahmet area
mosaics. amazing mosaics from gold. You must visit that church. the icon of Jesus has the eyes on you everywhere you go. Try to walk in front of the icon and just watch His eyes!!!

Partially closed. Undoubtably the paintings and mosaics are beautiful. However you can currently only see part of the church as much of it is closed for renovation. It is a long way out of the main centre and a long walk from the station. However it does take you along the old city wall which was worth seeing. If you are pressed for time I would suggest giving this a miss.

Small Gem. Currently under long reno. Only 1/3 still open to visitors. Mosaics may be best in Istanbul but Ravenna in Italy has many, many more beautiful Byzantine mosaics. Enjoy the cats and the picturesque old everyday Istanbul neighbourhood. area. Have a haircut. I did.

Small but packs a powerful punch. If you love wall mosaics - you'll love this. It's part of the. Museum Card too. Small church now museum. Beautiful. Off the beaten track to get to but we'll worth it.

Another gem but..... This is an excellent Church to visit. Many unique mosaics. Only 'but' is that the Church is undergoing renovations as is much of the rest of Istanbul so much of the Church is not open to the public, at least for now.Is part of the museums covered by the 72h museum card.

Must visit. The mosaics are unbelievable.i am so glad that i had enough time to see that church.The saints and scenes from the bible are covering the walls and ceillings.One of the highly protected church museums of the Istanbul and really worth to visit.one of the highlights for my trip to İstanbul!i highly recomend to see this place.
interesting church. i like to watch the mozaics in the church. just one thing is not good . the transportation is a little hard to go there .

Unbelievable beauty. This church is hidden away in a small area of Istanbul, and it is worth every minute on the metro getting there. I liked especially the mosaics that date from the 4th C. which tell the life of the Blessed Virgin Mary. I couldn't believe the vitality of the colors of the frescos and the mosaics themselves. Some of them have been defaced, but that happened across Turkey hundreds of years ago. Anyone visiting Istanbul should see this amazing site, but arrive early, before the crowds. There is no flash photography allowed, and no public WC. I would not bring small children either.
Do not miss it!. We got there taking a city bus and a steep walk uphill at the end but it was well worth it! The mosaics are amazing!

Great mosaics but long travel for what you get. Half the museum was closed for renovation when we went. The mosaics were great but given that it takes about 2 times an hour from the Sultanamet to get back and fro with public transportation and that there is nothing else to see or do in this neighborhood we were not sure it justified the trip.

Neat but small. Was on my last day in Istanbul so decided to head out to this on the tram. Fairly easy to get from the tram.Not sure if some of it was closed or not but it was much smaller overall than I though it would be. The church and mosaics were really neat to see but even taking my time to look at a lot of things closely it was really only a 15-20 minute visit which made the 15TL entrance fee seem kind of steep. May have been worth it to get the audio guide but was budgeting my final liras for the trip.I probably wouldn't have gone had I realized it was gonna be so brief but it was still ok to see. If you're on the fence about it, pinching pennies or tight on time I feel like you could skip it and not feel like you missed out. However, if you have the Museum Pass or are sure you want to go then go, it was really interesting to look around but was just a little smallish for the price to me.
Kariye Museum. Beautiful Byzantine frescoes and mosaics in this museum! We took a taxi to get there as it was a fair distance from our hotel.
Exceptional experience. Incredible place, where one can see frescoes in their original .Simple and beautiful. Whole Bible is presented through the paintings.

Once the nave has reopened it'll be great to visit. The nave is closed for restoration work but it is still worth a visit if you like the mosaics and frescoes. audio-guides with lots of content are available for 15TL.

Amazing mosaics. The Christian mosaics in this Church are amazing....such fine detail and careful use of colour. It's outside the tourist areas but you don't really need a cab if you're happy to catch the metro, then tram, then a short walk. It was unfortunate when I visited that the central dome was closed due to restoration works.

Fine Frescos and Magnificent Mosaics. Those that were awed by the light and space but ever so slightly underwhelmed by the mosaics in the Aya Sophia should head out north west to the lesser known Kariye Museum. Housed in a former Byzantine church, it was converted (like all the others) into a mosque after the Ottoman invasion. It is hard to believe that the Ottomans would want to whitewash the place, as it really is a stunner: The beautiful, fragmenting mosaics and fading frescoes retain much of their detail despite years of neglect. Recent posts have told of the museum being closed, this is not true, only the nave is closed, and honestly all the best stuff is in the outer and inner narthexes. I also recommend wandering through Fatih, an area where few tourists venture, to the Fethiye Museum for a small, but interesting Byzantine delight.Getting there: you could take a taxi, but its unneccessary - bus from Eminounou is quick and cheap, details on this page http://www.choramuseum.com/transportation/

pity we couldn't see all. As there was a restauration going on we couldn't see all. But what we saw was impressive. The audiotour gave a good explanation.You can eat something by Pembe kiosk.You can reach this church by bus from Eminonu or by tram T1 and T4.

Most beautiful mosaics in the world (excepting maybe those in Jericho, Hisham Palace). Quite hard to find it, Chora Museum - Church is famous for its mosaics and frescos. You can reach by bus (sure, taxi is an option for 17 - 20 TL), a direct line with eminonu. For bus you need tickets (every station has them) - jetons are not working.By the Museum Pass for 85 TL (allowance to Chora Museum, Aghia Sophia, Topkapi, Dervhis Museum, Mosaic Museum) - separately is more expensive. Plus, you skip the lines, wich are quite big during the day. It is available for 72 hours.

Find this Place!. A bit hard to get to (it was 20 TL cab fare for us from sultanhamet), but worth every cent!The mosaics and frescos are better than those in the Hagia Sophia. We decided to walk back to the grand bazaar after leaving the church. It was awesome. Highly recommend walking back (about 3km). It is an awesome experience with interesting and beautiful (roman aqueduct from the 4th century!!) walk.

The museum was closed. The museum was closed due to restoration. only the entrance was open to public.Sooooo disappointed to travel so far and to have paid for the Instabul Museum Card and in the end nothing!!!

Don't miss it!. It's a little out of the way -- and not as well known as some of the other Istanbul attractions -- but well worth the taxi ride. The mosaics reflecting Byzantine Christian scenes, especially the life of Mary, are just breathtaking. The detail and vibrancy are amazing. The Church was being renovated and the main chapel closed when we were there, but it didn't matter as most of the mosaics are in the gallery areas outside the main sanctuary. While you're there take a short walk up to the walls that protected the city for a thousand years -- also well worth seeing and walking on.
Closed on Wednesdays. Chekc that the Chora Church is open - it's closed on Wednesdays and is partly under restoration. It's fabulous and worth the bus trip.

byzantine masterpiece. You will admire the art of colourful vivid frescos and the imposing environment inside the church. Also mark the way the sunlight enters through the windows and how gives life to the images.

Must visit!. Breathtaking gold mosaics and architecture.A tiny church with art that you just cant imagine!The mosaics are unbelievable.The saints and the scenes from the bible are covering the walls and the ceilings. it is little far from the old town but it is completely worth it to visit!if you are in İstanbul,you must visit this place!

Hidden jewel. We enjoyed this even tho' it's a bit of a way out. Be aware, however, that the main area is closed for refurbishment atm, so you won't see everything. The audio guide is useful but it can be a bit confusing locating what it is describing.

Beautiful and Touching Church. I belong to the Byzantine church and I must say that this visit to the last Church of the Byzantine empire was touching.I faced some difficulties to reach the place for it's far from the heart of the city and the signs were not very clear. Once you are there, though, you forget all the troubles you have been facing to reach it.The church is relatively small if you compare it to Hagia Sophia, but it's contents are very rich and breath-taking. The mosaics and beautiful frescoes will throw you in a spiritual state.You will feel the sadness in the eyes of the painted icons, you will feel they all knew it was the end of the Byzantine empire.The Chora museum is a must if you want to understand and experience the history of Constantinople/Istanbul, and it is a very enriching site for the Christian heritage.

Beautiful Mosaics. Although this site is isolated from other attraction sites, it is worthwhile to pay it a visit. The mosaic artworks are just amazing, and the interior beauty has no match even compared with Aya Sophia and Blue Mosque, etc. The only problem is the transportation. We come here by taking taxi, and takes the bus back to Taxim Square thanks to locals' help.
Beautiful. As with all sites, must read the history or go with a guide so you can understand the meaning of the artwork.
Beautiful Byzantine Church!. Amazing to see the history and the beautiful mosaics inside the church. Definitely worth walking around the outside as well....we missed this but wished we had done it.
Feel the history. The place is relatively very small to other attractions in Istanbul but the atmosphere of the building is quite unique. The mosaics are amazing!

Unexpected gem. It was really nondescript on the outside but inside the mosiac and the story it tells is amazing. Our guide Necip gave us a really interesting introduction to the story of Virgin Mary which was very different from the one I was brought up with attending an Anglican Church school !

Outstanding mosaics!. Still under renovation, the Chora church has some beautiful mosaics. It is situated in a particularly charming area of Istanbul with many old style wooden houses. This is well worth a visit, but in summer it can get very crowded with tour bus groups..go early or later in the afternoon. Lunch at the next door Asitane is a must for those interested in old style Ottoman cuisine.
Hidden away but worth it. Breathtaking gold mosaics and architecture.A tiny church with art that you just cant imagine! Its so beautiful

Wow! Don't miss this place. The mosaics here are the most beautiful we have seen, and every inch of the place tells a story. Our tour guide described it as "different pages of the Bible," which is accurate. We ended up here because another site on our tour was closed, and we are really glad to have seen it. It doesn't take log, and is well worth the time.

worth visiting. A very old byzantine churce with beautiful mosaics with rare depictions from the lifes of Jesus and Mary. Too bad the main church is under maintainance at the time of visit (most mosaics are in the pronaos, so you will see most of them). Not sure if it would be as interesting for anyone (i did spot some bored tourists in a group-it's not a very good intro to byzantine art I think). Not as crowded as other istanbul attractions. Entrance is 15TL (high for turkish standards) but it was worth it for me. Take your time there, and try to have a guide of some sort for matching an explanation for all images (my guidebook covered me)Not close to major transportation, I got a taxi for this one (and the cab driver got lost...)
A journey to the roots of Christianity... Visit and see! A must in Istanbul. All will be charmed with the paintings on the walls and hear the story they tell.
Best mosaics. A must for those who love Byzantine art.Exquisite mosaics with rare subjects like the life of Mary that have been magically preserved!
Fabulous mosaics .... Avoid the crowds and hordes of tourists to take in this historical building packed with lovely mosaics.

Whatever you do, don´t miss this gem. I am so glad we had time enough to see this church. The mosaics at the dome are incredibly beautiful. The saints and the scenes from the bible are covering the walls and the ceilings. it is a small church so if you have an extra 2 hour in Istanbul, dont miss it.
Fascinating, though a little of a chore to find. The mosaics are unbelievable. The museum was closed in January 2014, but still it was worth the trip for the Christus pantocrator alone.

Early chora visit no chore. Historic old church many of the mosaic figures have been at least partially recovered small quick and easy feel in a quaint part of Instanbul despite its museum status restrains much of an antique church feel as well interesting mosaic and painted topics

Golden mosaics of late christianty in Istanbul.... Gold Mosaics of the Kariye museum is unique with their crafted and well protected apparences... One of the highly protected church museums of the Istanbul and really worth to visit... Paintings and mosaics are highly advanced in their artistic quality. The enviroment of the church is also nice to walk and shop... Next to the Kariye Museum there is a small cafe and restaurant that serves all day for the visitors and enables u to breath in the old core of the city...
Low season closures. While the Roman sections were open, the main part was closed and there were no notices anywhere. You arrived and found out you could not see 80% of the place.

neck hurts from looking at the ceiling(in a good way). the mosaics and frescoes are amazing. it depicts the life of the Virgin Mary and the ordeals of the birth of Jesus and the Life of Jesus. the most complete mosaics i have ever seen. stunning in it detail and sheer goldeness. it has a different atmosphere than hagia sophia. i highly recommend seeing eventhough its a bit away from the other attractionstravelers tip: i recommend hiring a guide to help explain the story depicted in the mosaics and frescoes. also the nave is closed for renovation but not to worry all of its important parts are not in the nave
Beautiful. Much smaller than I expected. Would take an hour at most. Mosaics are impressive. A little far from City Centre. Change tram in Topkapi station and get out in "Edirnekapi"

Best frescoes & mosaics I have seen so far.... The church overall is amazing, but the frescoes & mosaics are the best I have seen so far. Colours are alive, figures are intact and all are very well-preserved. Definitely a visit if you are in town and have an hour to spare.

Wonderful for Mosaics, beautiful location but be aware of the taxis waiting outside. The mosaics are stunning. This is a very small museum and will take about 40 minutes to look around. The mosaics are in very good condition and well worth the visit. if the weather is lovely you may spend an hour or so in the outside cafe across the small road as this is a most relaxing place. The surroundding areas look very pretty indeed. If you choose to get a taxi back downtown beware..there are two or three taxis outside that wait for the unsuspecting tourist and offer a flat rate (no meter) and in our experience this is usually more than twice the metered fare. If your stuck then take it but if not..walk up the road and flag down a taxi that will charge less. Well worth the visit though!
Superb frescos. Like so much of Istanbul this site was under renovation during our visit but the part that we could access was truly amazing. Sistine Chapel eat your heart out.

Truly remarkable mosaics. Need to find a way to get there. Taxi works, but be aware that they can drive you around for extra pay. Know your route and approximate cost. Museum has unbelievable mosaics. A must see for art and history fans.
Awesome and rivals anything you might see in Rome. Extraordinary mosaics and history about Mary that you don't really get anywhere; one of the highlights for our trip to Istanbul.

one of the most beautiful places in the world. We have travelled a lot but this is certainly one of the highlights.This well preserved church offers us just a glimpse of the glory that was byzantine art...the whole byblical story, 14th century city life, the genealogy of Christ in the cupola, everything is just amazing...these colours so vivid after all these centuries...The church is well away from the tourist trail but certainly deserves a visit and the trip to get there can be a nice experience in itself.We did it as follows:in the morning we took the water taxi from Eminönü across the Golden Horn towards Eyup. Just watch for the 'Halic Iskelesi' (Golden Horn Pier). You can pay for the water bus with the Istanbulkart.Get off at the Ayvansaray station, then walk to the city walls (clearly visible) and keep following them.This is a rather poor neighbourhood. We did not feel threatened but I do not recommend t walk here at night.The route along the ancient walls of Theodosius is an attraction in itself. Just keep in mind that these fortifications were built in the 5th century and protected the city for ages.It still is not that easy to find the Chora church. We had to use the 'maps of Turkey' app on our smartphone and eventually we made it.We returned to the old town by taking a buss from nearby Edirnekapi.
Exquisite. Beautiful mosaics that have survived war and time. The Chora Church is well worth a trip beyond Istanbul's Old Town,

Take the time to visit. It is a beautiful structure and well worth the time. A short taxi ride from the historic section of town. Taxi hawks will be waiting outside for the return ride so give a local café some business and let them call you a cab.

It is amazing. The mosaics are wonderful. Just amazing how they did it... It is worth a visit and also try to walk around the ares it is wonderfull not crowded and you see the real life of the people.

The real deal. For those with a GENUINE interest in Byzantine mosaics and frescoes - as opposed to those who are simply looking for more pretty things to snap on their iPhones - this place is the real deal. The mosaics in Aya Sofia pale into insignificance compared to those in the Chora Church. Yes, part of the museum is currently closed for renovation (that happens in really old places - it isn't Disneyland folks) but don't let that put you off; I hope you will be overwhelmed by the glorious vibrancy of the artistic works created well over 1000 years ago. Oh, and a bonus, you won't need to queue for long if at all - your package tourist isn't likely to come here.Now, as to getting there. Catch a taxi if you will - but why not try it by bus? It takes longer but I like to think of the journey as part of the experience. Sorry, I can't remember the bus number but the Lonely Planet has it.

my favourite spot. Totally worth ....finding. The best Byzantium mosaics in Istanbul !!!!!!! It wasn't crowded the day we went. Oh yeh ..it was closed the first time we went - I think it was a Wednesday. You can check online when all the famous places around istsnbul are closed, they all seem to close at least one day a week. Yeh and don't take photos - why do people do that when they are told that it will wreck the fescos????
Overated. Unless you are majorly into mosaics, you will be done in about 15 minutes, not exactly worth the hassle of coming down especially if you stay across in the sultanahmet area

Satin fooled us! It was not the Holy Grail we were seeking!. Let me start by saying that by the time I was 10 years old I had visited many of the great churches of Europe, my parents were able to travel and take the family along. So we went to museums and churches in England, France, Italy (including the Vatican), Greece and much of Israel and the holy land. So maybe I expected more...Even though we were staying north of the Golden Horn at the Hilton ParkSA my wife and I were like ancient explorers in the New World as we traveled by cable car tram to get to Taksim and then the funicular to Kabatis. From there by road tram to Topkapi and then a metro rail train to Edirnekapi! We threw caution to the wind and risked our lives crossing several busy roads with taxis and buses determined to mow us down. Then, using my hand drawn map because the one I purchased assumed this church was past the edge of the rim of the planet, and my compass and daring navigational skills my wife and I found the chuch!Thanks be to God we proclaimed and knelt in prayer and tribute. We then paid the 30 TL for 2 tickets which we assumed was to pay for the quality frescoes and mosaics all the restoration. We entered and within 10 minutes discovered that this was not the Holy Grail we were seeking! Satin had fooled us and led us here and into the church without telling us that it was being renovated and only 2 hallways were open. We checked out the gift shop only discover they had little we wanted and many over priced and tacky items. Sadly, we left and realized we had wasted 30TL that could have been spent on items at the gift shop outside! I feel sory for anyone who paid a high taxi fare or wasted money on the audio guide! Don't waste your time, it is not the grail you seek!

Extremely beautiful. A church, turned into a mosque by invaders, later converted to a museum!! They have done an excellant job to preserve this monument. It is a bit out of the way for tourists to reach this monument on their own. There were no sign boards at the metro station to reach this monument. People on the road helped us with directions. But when we reached there it was really a feast to our eyes to see those paintings . They have done a great job to retrieve the wall paintings covered during the Islamic period. A must visit monument in Istanbul.

Crowded, Nave closed (Dec '13). Although we got to Chora by 09.30 (taxi), already a number of tour bus groups had arrived and crowded into the small space of the church (now museum). The mosaics and frescoes are indeed spectacular but the experience is reduced because of the large number of people in the small space. It should be noted that the nave of the church is closed for restoration, and we could not establish when it might reopen. As we travelled independently, we were able to walk a short way from the church to see the old city walls (spectacular size) and these made up for the crowds and closure at the church. We noted that the lines were none-existent when we returned from the walls at around 11.30am – maybe the tour buses all get there as the first stop of the day. Worth a visit, but best to try and avoid the lines with the earliest arrival you can make, or later in the day.If you have been to Ravenna (to which Chora is compared) than my overall impression is that Ravenna is more extensive – although again noisy and crowded, as Chora.

Simply extraordinary. My husband and I visited the Chora in December and were blown away by it! We took public transport out to it, via the metro and the tram...and after a brief walk discovered the very unassuming church nestled into the hillside.As we had visited other sites in the morning, we arrived in the middle of the peak American tourist rush, which was a bit of a pain, as we had to constantly move out of the way of herds of braying people who didn't seem to appreciate they were a) in a church and b) not the only people there. On the plus side, however, it did allow us to piggy back on their guides' information, but my recommendation would be to go early and avoid the noise - it must be hideous in the summer.The central area of the church was being renovated when we visited, but as the mosaics and frescoes tend to be in the chapels and passages around the central zone, this wasn't a problem. The colours and levels of preservation were extraordinary, and took my breath away.On the way back into town we walked back to take the tram as recommended by Lonely Planet - this was a MUCH longer route, but did allow us to see much more of Istanbul life, passing through a residential area - I'd suggest getting the metro/tram route sorted, as it's much closer.Definitely a must see - but go early in the day.

Spectacular mosaics. Beautiful small church with a large number of well preserved mosaics and frescoes. A little off the beaten Sultan ahmet track but well worth the trip out - even better to walk there, with many imortnat mosques to visit on the way.
St Saviour's Church. A hidden gem! Wonderful art work and mosaics from a by-gone age, truly revealing the character of Christ before Islamic times.

Great Museum, Confusing Audio. Pros:- Beautiful, small, quaint church- Brilliantly peserved frescosCons:- Out of the way. We took the public metro and tramway.- Confusing audio guide. There were many frescoes with no number so I found it hard matching the commentary to the fresco. Bit annoying as we made a huge effort to get to the museum- One part of the museum was closed for renovation.

unbelievable frescoes. This was my favorite attraction in Istanbul, and i loved them all. It was a little hard to find, involving a ferry ride and a long walk up a steep hill through some ancient neighborhoods, making it all the more wonderful when we finally located the church. i never knew ancient frescoes could still be glowing with such beauty and passion. on the way back, we took a bus to the University of Istanbul and walked through the campus on our way to Sultanahmet. Great fun and a good way to see the city.

worth the visit. The Chora church is a little bit far from the center but you have to visit it! I strongly believe that it is one of the most beautifull Byzantine churches!Mosaics and frescoes so beautifull!Don't have words to express my feelings!IThe church was originally known as the Church of the Holy Saviour Outside the Walls. It was a monastery and now is a museum.

Rich in history and beauty. This is only a bus ride away from the centre and then a short walk uphill. It is in a very poor, rundown and conservative area however, so best probably not to stand out (especially for women). The main section of the church is still closed off for the public, but what you can visit is a rewarding and enriching experience. There is much to look at, read and reflect on. The 'Chora museum' as it is called takes its name (chora) from its situation outside the centre (chora is Greek for country/countryside) of the medieval city of Constantinople. When asking for directions, the locals refer to it typically as Kariye mosque as a mosque was constructed adjacent to it.

Stunning and worth the trip alone. The mosaics here were absolutely stunning and well worth the trek up to Edirnekapi to see them. The building from the outside gives nothing of the splendour and majesty within. A must see for any trip to Istanbul.Ignore all the guidebooks who suggest that the best way to get to the Chora Church is via the metro (M1) from Topkapi/Ulubati having changed off the T1 at Yusufpasa over to Aksaray. Take the T1 to Topkapi then up a few stairs to the T4 to Edirnekapi. A quick look at a map and it is then less than 10 minutes away on foot. You also get to see some of Istanbul's old city wall as well.

Stunning,but being renovated. Stunning, but large part not open as being renovated. Worth the trip to this area. Mosaics beautiful, and nice to visit something of small scale after the big mosques etc.
A bit fa but don't miss it. Excellent mosaics and a beautiful frescoes in a not overtouristy part of Istanbul. From there you can walk down trough the streets of Balat.

A little far but is completely worth it. Kariye Museum is a church located a little far from other main Istanbul attractions.We took a taxi there and spend a good hour looking at the beautiful mosaics and attractions this church has. On our way back the taxis were over charging to take us back. Either you negotiate or do as we did and walk back. It was not a impossible walk.Actually it was very nice to see Istanbul on non-turistical areas and walk underneath the Aqueduct and see how the city changes as you get closer to main attractions.

history of istanbul. Here is written the history before 1453, it is a church that was then rebuilt to a mosque and then back to a church. In here there are many beautiful paintings. You can buy lots of beautiful books here about Istanbul.
Beautiful - but not all open to visit. Certainly worth the trip and some very impressive mosaics and frescoes, but note that the main part of the church is currently closed for restoration.

Partially closed for renovation. I was excited to see one of the ortodox churches, but when I got there it was partially closed for renovation. I think that they should lower the price of the entrance to the church if it is not open completely.

Simply Breath taking. The church is very beautiful. Words can not describe what I saw. The mosaics and frescos are indescribable. The fee was very reasonable. It is a little off of the regular tourist beat which is great. Plan to view art work on the ceiling and up high. Budget enough time. If you enjoy biblical history then you will enjoy seeing stories come to life via mosaics and frescos. Bathroom facilities are ancient. Be prepared for that. Take some water as it can be crowded. Budget plenty of time to simply enjoy the venue. The courtyard is nice and allows you an opportunity to take a short rest if you need one. This is an amazing experience to take advantage of.

Hard to find but worth it !. We knew it was hard to find but never that much ! If you are not going by taxi , Google it and trace the path from the nearest metro station as no one seems to know where it is located ! Do not ask for the Chora Church but ask for the nearby museum ! Somehow the Tourist Information does not seem interested in promoting this place ! Once you found it , you will find a very old church located in a nice environment ! When we were there in October , they were starting some renovation work on the outside but fortunatly the frescos where not hidden and we could admire them . We did not have a guide but a group came in with one 5 minutes after we got in so we could listen to some very interesting explanations for more than 40 minutes .  After the visit , there is a very nice cafe at the back of the church that seems to be very popular with the locals ! The mint tea and turkish coffee were excellent !

Magnificent attraction. You cannot visit Istanbul without visiting this magnificent attraction. Parts are under restoration at the moment, but notwithstanding it is still a must see. Once you have seen and observed its magnificence, it is only a short walk to parts of the ancient city wall.

Breathtaking. Somewhat off the beaten tourist path and limited public transport but definitely worth the effort to see the amazing mosaics and frescos. You end up with a neck ache for looking at the ceiling and there are so many with such intricate detail. There are long sequences of the life of the Virgin Mary and Jesus miracle acts. Herod and David mosaics showing their deeds etc.It is best to buy a museum card for TL85 if you are visiting several of the main attractions. Note whilst children under 12 are free, ticket and proof of id is required.It took us an hour to get back from Kariye to Hagga Sophia afterward in normal traffic: check with hotel best time for traffic. It should be possible to take the metro to Topkopi-ulubatli and then walk to the museum
Very beautiful. Half of the church was closed for renovation, but still, Stunning!Cannot be missed. The restaurant in front of it is decently priced.

Chora Icons. Near the ancient Roman City walls, the ancient Chora church is a treasure house of early Christian iconography (much better than St Sofia). While there, visit the nearby monumental Roman city gate in the Roman walls, and explore the neighboring streets to get a feel for untouristed Istanbul.

Not the first thing to see, but keep it in mind.. Near the ancient Roman City walls, the ancient Chora church is a treasure house of early Christian iconography (much better than St Sofia). While there, visit the nearby monumental Roman city gate in the Roman walls, and explore the neighboring streets to get a feel for untouristed Istanbul.

Beautifull church. The chora church is located outside the tourist area, near Erdirnekapi metrostation. To find it take tram T1 to station Topkapi, then switch to metro T4 to Erdinekapi. You have to walk downhill past the old city walls. Locals are helpfull if you ask for Kariye museum. The entrance price is 15 TL. When you are inside, it is recommended to buy the official guide in the store for 40 TL. It has great photos of the fresco's with helpfull texts. You can also use a guidebook like the lonely planet or the museum audio guide.

ISTANBUL DAIRY. DAY 2. PART 1. Our second day in Istanbul started with a visit to the Chora church. Chora means outside the city in Turkish. The place is a bit far 10-15 minutes without traffic. The taxi ride from the White House hotel cost us 30 lira. Good thing that cruise mates George and Bobbie shared the fare.A guide at our hotel told us to purchase a small book in order to understand the meaning of the mosaics on the ceiling of the church. The church is small but the ceilings have so many mosaics and frescos that are more fascinating than the ones found at the huge Ayasofya. Done in the 14th century, the frescos are well preserved even if the church was converted into a mosque when the Muslims took over.The mosaics and frescoes are a virtual storybook of the life of Jesus and Mary- from the nativity to the last judgment. Having said that, somebody needs to do a video documentary with commentary of this museum. Probably, like the video shown at the ayasofya. The area of the church is small and tourists would inevitably suffer from stiff necks from looking up while listening to your tour guide or consulting a guide book. This is not an easy task specially if there is a big tour group in the church.

Main part (naos) closed for renovations. A bit difficult to get there. It doesn't show on most tourist maps (it's in Edirnekapi far from any other tourist attractions). Easiest way is to go by bus since both the tram and metro stops are pretty far. No signs whatsoever on where it exactly is. Mostly have to ask locals for directions.Exonarthex, esonarthex and parecclesion are beautifully restored. Unfortunately the main part of the building (naos) is under reconstruction and closed to the public and most of all, nobody tells you anything about it until you get there.
Big part was closed. Unfortunately a big part was closed for renovation. But the mosaics we can see were great and worth the visit.
beautifull!. the fresco's are really impressive but the location is a bit out of the most popular places. Still it is worth a visit big time! We loved it there.

It's partially closed for renovation. It's beautiful, but 2/3 are closed for renovation. I will go back in a couple of years. The mosaics are incredibly beautiful and well preserved. It's a hidden treasure a bit outside of the center, but once renovated, definitely worth to visit.
The most amazing place in Istanbul!. The architecture was breathless! It was a beautiful experience and very magical. I would highly recommend this beautiful place when you are in Istanbul.

Stunning!. Amazing Byzantine-era mosaics & frescoes, among the most interesting in the world. Created around the same time as the 14th-century Renaissance painter Giotto. Definitely worth a special visit.

best byzantine mosaics. a hidden gem in istanbul, thanks to bitinya tours showing us the church and neighborhood. Theodore Metochites paid for extravagant mosaics and frescoes depicting the lives of Mary, Jesus and the saints in the 14th century.

Dazzling Mosaics in Small Church. Unless you take a cab, it is diffcicult to get here. We took two trams from the Old City. But we still had to carefully walk around a traffic circle and cross a very wide and busy street, then walk a bit downhill. It's a small church, very crowded. However, you are always looking up and craning your neck to do so. But there are some dazzling mosaics and nice frescoes too. Get the Rick Steve's book on Istanbul to help explain them. It will take 30 minutes or so to see everything. You are very close to the City Walls, but they are too steep with no rails so we did not climb them.

Beautiful Church/Museum. We were on a cruise and decided to go independently to the church. We got a taxi there and walked back to the ship which was an interesting experience!The church is byzantine and was turned into a museum by the Muslims. They covered the mosaics and painting with a thin layer of plaster which helped to preserve them. They were uncovered some years ago and are absolutely fabulous. Very bright colours and still in very good condition. Well worth a visit.

must see Mosaics and Frescos. The first time I visited Istanbul I missed out on seeing this beautiful Church due to time constraints. It is listed as one of the must see’s on any attraction list in Istanbul. Second time round in Istanbul I made sure that I made time to visit this beautiful Church.Kariye is the Turkish version of Chora, which was the Greek word for “countryside.” . The magnificent Chora Museum is an old Byzantine church, situated just inside the city walls at Edirnekapı and is known for its beautiful frescos and mosaics. I have to admit it is a bit off the routine tourist path. The feature of this amazing Church is the mosaics and frescoes. If you are history lover this is the place for you, so take time to appreciate and gaze at the beautiful mosaics and frescos. Pics are allowed remember NO flash .Audio guides are available at an additional charge just near the entrance. The area surrounding this Church is quaint and you may sit around for a while and have a cup of Chy/ Khave , people watch, observe or even explore the side streets. A few steps away you will see a small beautiful tomb, which you are allowed to enter ( please keep in mind local customs when entering)To get to Chora Museum Take bus #’s 28 or 36KE from Eminonu or bus # 87 from Taksim ( TIP – get the Istanbul kart – available at cafes and kiosks ) . A taxi ride from Taksim should cost between 10 and 15 YTL. ( in the same region if travelling from the Sultanahmet area)

Fabulous. It exceeded my expectation. Though currently undergoing renovation the audio guide still provided a great tour and I saw the most amazing frescos and a building that showcases rich history. I took the ferry then walked up the old wall and it was easy to find. Take a map and you will enjoy the time. Then I wandered on to find the tram back. It was a bit of a hike but well worth it and the outdoor restaurants at the complex offered good food and refreshment.

A bit out of the way, but beautiful mosaics. We took the 32A bus from Eminounu and mentioned where we wanted to go to the driver (they made a special stop for us tourists, maybe 100 ft from the real bus stop, so that we could just walk straight and not get lost getting there). The museum was very small (there was some renovation going on), but the parts we saw were gorgeous. The mosaic is really well preserved and so intricate. Also, if you plan on getting any Isnik tiles while in istanbul, get them at the vendors outside the Chora. There are 2, and the designs are similar (the same prlly) as the Grand bazaar, but the prices are much better (5-8 TL/tile item). Just time it well so you're not walking around the rest of the day with a bag of ceramic....
Wonderful little church. Extraordinary mosaics. Go with a guide to be able to understand the story associated with each picture.

Great - but too much renovation work going on!. Well this was worth a visit, but would've been better if the main hall wasn't closed due to renovation. What I could see, was indeed, amazing, but was also disappointed because we weren't allowed into the main hall. If you're planning to visit, maybe wait half a year or so, and maybe the renovation work will be complete by then! We walked here, after using the tram to get to the location, and it has some very steep roads to get here, so if you are travelling by public transport, be wary!

Chora Museum. We went with Insight Tours. It was my favorite. The docent is a professor at a local university. He added so much richness and understanding to the frescoes and mosaics we were looking at. We would have missed the significance of what we were looking at. The churches/mosques/museums in Istanbul are rich in the history of civilizations.
Don't miss this top attraction. We did not see the Chora Church in the list of many Top 10 attractions. It is a bit out of the way (take a taxi) but one of the best sites we found in Istanbul.

A Byzantine Jewel. The ancient Christian "Chora Church," which is known for rich interior Byzantine mosaics, was really something to see. Colorful mosaics just inside the door are in excellent condition. Each wall and the ceiling is adorned with hundreds of thousands of beautiful tiny tiles depicting stories from the Byzantine era. The colours are magnificent. Our English speaking tour guide, (Leyla Topal) knew the history of the "Chora Church" well and added so much more to our tour of "Chora Church" than if we didn't have a guide.

Go with a guide. Beautiful small church away from center city' our Viator guide Omar was great and especially knew this site very well' stunning mosaics' if you do get there on your ownthere are cafes at the door and sOme lovely Isnik type tiles with a few other shops as well'

Stunning mosaics. If you are a fan of mosaic work, especially early Christian mosaics, then you must see this small but impressive church. It is believed to be one of the first Christian churches as Christianity was outlawed until shortly before it was built. They restored it beautifully and it's just a delight to follow the story of Jesus, Mary and Joseph as they saw it so many centuries ago. One panel that impressed me showed the duality in Christ -- one side of his face is young and peaceful, the other older, stern. The god of love vs the god of judgement? It was striking.
A must see to appreciate. This is a beautifully persevered church and one that is a must see to appreciate the beautiful ceramic works and the architecture of it.

a treasure off the beaten track. Unbelievable! Every nook and cranny has a mosaic. The paintings on the walls depicted stories from Mary's life. There are too many to admire. Best option is to see the top ten from the guide. Worth every penny if you are an art lover. The views from the garden, overlooking the city are all also great. It's easy to get to. We took a cab going there, but came back by bus.

You do not really review this kind of place. Its small, but with blow your mind if you appreciate frescos and mosaics!. The richness of history and linkages with the Christian hertage are mind blowing, stay and stay, it will grow on you and you will be moved!
Under renovation. This site would be beautiful... but most of it is currently closed for restoration. So make sure it's open before you go.

ancient art and ancient food. The Chora Church is a lilltle gem of Byzantine frescoes still preserved at their original places. Some are almost intact. I very much recommend a visit there. And before or afterwars, I highly recommend a meal at Asitane Restaurant, where you will taste reconstituted food of ancient ottoman sultans.

More human scale than Hagia Sophia. If you like mosaics, then this church is for you.We had a private guide for the day and spent the afternoon slowly walking through this church and viewing the mosaics tha covered ceiling , walls etc.this church is not be be missed.

Don't miss this amazing church. Originally Church of the Holy Saviour Outside the Walls, then a mosque and now a museum, the Chora Church has the most amazing mosaics and fresco paintings, dating from the fourteenth century, which cover most of the interior. They tell the Christian story in vivid and beautiful detail. You need a guidebook to list the subjects depicted - the Lonely Planet guide has this on its last pages. The most powerful image is that of the Anastasis or Resurrection, a fresco in the side chapel, which brings Stanley Spencer to mind. Well worth the walk up. The Museum is included in the Museum card scheme: cost TL15. It is best to go at 9am or at lunchtime when the tour groups have gone to eat, otherwise it can be very crowded. The Pink Cafe opposite is good value, and afterwards you can walk along the Theodosian city walls and see the ruins of Constantine's palace.

A must see. Great mosaics. It was a Christian church transformed into a mosque.
Part of it was closed due to restoration work :(

Well Worth It...!. I have reservations when my significant other suggested walking to The Choral Church, through Istanbul streets and up on a hill mind you. But I admit it... I was wrong. This was well worth the effort (and sweat), of navigating the haphazard streets to find The Choral Church. It has an interesting and ancient history. The interior's mosaics are a bit breath-taking. There is also a small craft / souvenir stalls near by. Prices seem slightly higher (not by much) compared to the streets of Istanbul (excluding of course the Grand Bazaar which start much higher). The advantage of the Choral Church crafts are that they are far less pushy and seem accepting of people browsing.
Extremely interesting. Wonderful little church with incredible mosaics. You can couple a visit with a walk along the old City walls

Take a guide or guidebook with you to enhance visit. To get the most out of your visit, make sure you either have a guide or a good guidebook with you, to explain the stories being depicted in the various scenes depicted by the mosaics and frescos. This is a little gem of a museum,and is definitely worth straying a bit off the beaten path to visit.

Late Byzantine Gem Worth the Trip. If you have more than two days in Istanbul and like Byzantine art, the Chora church-museum (14th cent. AD) is a spectacular assembly of mosaics. It's a bit away from most other sights, so a taxi to/from is really needed. Well worth the effort.

Nice but very small. An old 15c. church, with some interesting frescos. It is built on the site of series of other churches, It is to the north in the Golden Horn and not too easy to find - even the locals were struggling. 15TL in and it is 4 largish rooms , the rest was under renovation. The frescos are not all complete but are quite attractive and interesting. Just about worth the effort of getting there and getting back

Small but perfectly formed. Nice to leave the city behind and see the walls on the journey to this small but intensely decorated church. The mosaics are brilliant - and the frescoes too. But it is small and will not take long to see.

It's a must even if you are not passionate about history of art. Some of the previous reviewers stated that it is not worth to go to the Chora church as the ticket prices are high and it is almost impossible to get there without a car. I dare to disagree- Chora church is exeptional example of byzantine mosaics. By the word exeptional I mean that nowhere in the world will you find 14th century mosaics of such outstanding quality and as completely preserved. Before getting there I strongly recommend to read some books or at least Wikipedia articles on byzantine art to fully apreciate this magnificent relic of lost and forgotten splendour.

Impressive mosaics. Very impressive and very well preserved. Similar to one of Ravenna, but not so stunning. I would suggest to go there by foot even if is quite long troll from Eminonu or Souleymane's mosque and enjoy a promenade in Balat distric, out of the classical tourist itineraries. Get a guide it is very interesting, since every mosaic is an episode of the life of Saints.

Amazing Church Museum. This is one of the most amazing church museums in the world! The mosaics and frescos are absolutely breath-taking. It can be a bit challenging to get to from other parts of Istanbul and the major attractions but it is well worth the time and effort. Chora is not nearly as busy nor as big as the Ayasofia but in its own way, equally impressive.

Stunning Mosaics. This small church is not in the Sultanahmet area and is not a site included in the Museum Pass but is definitely worth a visit. The Mosaics from the Byzantine Period depict the life of Christ and is simply stunning in its detail and execution. We visited the Chora Church immediately after our visit the Topkapi palace - it is in that general direction. The taxi cost about 20 TL. The return taxi back to our Hotel in the vicinity of the Blue Mosque was about 30 TL.After visiting the church you can relax at the restaurant outside with a cup of tea or coffee. The hot chocolate was really good!
Worth a visit. Quite far from Sultanahmet but if you want to see byzantine mosaics, than this is the place to visit.

One of the world’s greatest museums, Kariye.... A unique museum, that worths to visit in Istanbul, if you have time and enjoy mosaics and frescoes. That tiny but great museum with its glorious mosaics and frescoes is listed among the top 30 must-see museums in the World.
