The author of the book, “1,000 Places to See Before You Die”, Patricia Schultz ranks its alongside The Hermitage Museum in St. Petersburg, Van Gogh Museum in Amsterdam and others.I would recommend you to book a professional tour guide prior to your visit. Otherwise for sure you would miss at least half of the things there.PS: The photos are taken by my dear friend Dilek Basaran...
Great Little Museum. small museum but with beautiful Mosaics and helpful staff that give advice and help at all stages of the visit.Worth an hour or two in your trip to IST

Beautiful mosaics. We caught a tram and then walked for a few kms. Worth the hike. Stunning Byzantine mosaics. On return the three of us caught a cab back to the Blue Mosque for 30 Turkish Lira. Check the price with the cab driver first.
A gem. Beautiful mosiacs, especially since those in Hagia Sophia are partially blocked off. Avoid the crowds when the cruise ships dock. Plan to spend the better part of two hours.
indescribable. so glad we persisted in finding this small church on the outskirts of Istanbul our guide sadi it was worth a stop and that was an understatement indeed!!
Wonderful Mosaics. So many beautiful and expressive mosaics. Be sure you have a guide book for explanations,so you get the most out what you are seeing.

Worthwhile visiting.. Although a little out of the way, the Kariye Museum is well worth visiting for the excellent mosaics. Take the metro to the Edimekapi station and walk through the old western wall of the city. Follow signs to the right or ask someone for directions.
Religious pilgrimage. We visited this on our pilgrimage via the Greek Orthodox Church. This is incredible. Be sure to have a guide who can explain all of the mosaics and murals.
Wonderful mosaics. It's a fairly lengthy taxi ride from Sultanahmet, where we stayed, but absolutely worth it. The mosaics seemed, to me, to be even better than ones at Hagia Sofia.

Wonderful mosaics.. Wonderful mosaics and it's a not expensive attraction.It's a bit out of hand but it's definitely worthy to go there.We walked all the way from the Grand Bazaar, enjoying 2 major mosques, a University campus, and lots of not-touristic streets. It's not an easy walk (some streets to climb up and down), but it's extremely authentic (if you don't follow the main road).

Not as easily accessible but rich in history. We had to take a tram to the nearest station and then walk for a good 20 mins asking people around for the place. I must say it wasnt as close as i had thought (may be there was a shorter way and i didnt know of it) but when i did come there it was nice. The museum is less crowded than the attractions in the sultanahmet area, but still there was a steady group of tourists around. The place in itself is full of rich history and i would suggest using one of the audio explanations available of 5 TY to be used to understand the background of each image present there.

Nice location off the Sultanahmet. Beautiful church. I visited in the afternoon. The place had some crowd but not packed like Ayasofya. Highly recommend. If you traveling by yourself from Sultanahmet, take the TRAM to Aksaray then transfer the Metro at Aksaray, get off at Topkapi Ulubatli. After go up to the road and take the yellow mini bus (1.5 LT). Tell the driver you wanna get off at Kariye Musezi. At Topkapi Ulubatli make sure you ask the security which exit you should take as there are two.

Well Worth the Time. While a bit out-of-the way and difficult to find compared to the other major sites of Istanbul, Chora Church is very interesting. I very much suggest that you give yourself an extra hour or two to explore the neighborhood in the area!

Off the beaten track but worth seeing. This small church is off the beaten path (i.e. not near Sultanhamet) but is worth a visit. We took a bus & a taxi to get there from Ortakoy and it was nice to see other parts of the city. The church has small grounds and a few naves with Byzantine mosaics and frescos. I guess I was spoiled by having seen Hagia Sophia the day before, but Chora did not knock my socks off. It's nice and it's on the way if you want to visit Pierre Loti cafe, which we did. You can use the museum pass at Chora too.

Small but perfectly formed. A long way to go but very interesting when there. Probably best to get an audio guide unless you have a vast knowledge of Christianity and the history of the life of the Virgin Mary not found in the gospels.

Interesting, but take a guide. Very interesting museum - was once a church - the paintings on the walls were outstanding. We had booked tickets online which helped us avoid queues but our print outs were not clear/on good paper and the bar codes didn't work at the turnstiles. We were being forced to buy new tickets but they were kind enough to relent later although we did lose time. I had armed myself w a rick Stevens guide to guide us through the visit but in retrospect it would have been better to have a guide to explain us as it takes time for one person to read the stuff while u r inside then explain it to family etc. beautiful It

Peak of Byzantine Art. This small double church is the home of one of the most accomplished and iconographically rich cycles of mosaics of the lives of Jesus and Mary, a splendid example of Paleologan Renaissance are. Go by public transport or taxi, but go. A lovely cafe opposite the church serves decent and reasonably priced snacks and drinks under the trees. Be warned - once you go it having paid your 15T lira fee, you cannot leave the museum church and return and it does not provide toilet facilities! The only nuisance are the group visits led by polyglot guides who compete with each other for volume and enthusiasm level and manage to confuse even the most attentive visitor.

great museum experience in Chora Church. great museum experience in Chora Church: Christ the Pantocrator, The Nativity, the journey of the Magi, the flight into Egypt, the Second coming of Christ, the Resurrection and the account of the life of the Virgin Mary are some of the many mosaics and frescoes in Chora.

Dazzle, dazzle , dazzle. This church is a gem of mosaic and fresco painting, as well as being architecturally interesting. A must see.....and also walk the Wall which stood and protected Istanbul for 1000 years.

Very interesting. It's not in a city center, but this place is worth short taxi or bus ride. It has absolutely unique mosaics and frescos. Don't miss it if you are interested in history and art. One of my favourite places in Istanbul.

History there is nothing like it.. Learning about what people were life years ago given one an idea of where they wanted to be in the future, the history is so impressive the working on rebuliding and repairing.

Guide book essential. Unless you are well aquainted with the apocryphal story of the early life of the Virgin Mary many of the stunning mosaics will not make much sense to you. If you are then the interpretations guessed at by your fellow visitors will have you much amused. Equip yourself with a good guide book and marvel at the frescos and mosaics that still adorn this magnificent building.
Small church. Were there on our own, no guide, but again the guide book gave us as much information as we needed. Beautiful tiles and frescoes.
A short trek worth doing. Amazing frescos,mosaics and architecture. It has been wonderfully well restored . The guidebook is a good buy as a companion to the visit and momento.

Wonderful and moving. This glimpse into another side of Christian beliefs was amazing. The art is, of course, thrilling and the use of apocryphal stories was very interesting. We took a cab from the Galata Bridge and walked back through neighborhoods where "real people" live.
Well worth going to. The mosaics and frescos are beautiful. Don't bother with the audio guide- which was utterly uninformative.

Don't miss this!. A bit off the beaten path but an important and beautiful historic sight. It has outstanding 14th Century frescoes, possibly the best preserved frescoes in the world, and stunning mosaics made with the tiniest tiles imaginable. After your visit to the museum, walk next door to the wonderful Atisane restaurant.

Overpriced but amazing mosaics. I have heard great things about this place but never had chance to visit.It is a little interesting church with lovely frescos but too expensive (15 tl/person) . You only would need 20-25 min to see everything.Museum shop is also pricey and not much variety.

A hidden jewel with great mosaics. Take a taxi to Chora Church and admire all the wonderful mosaics. Audioguide recommendable as well as a good camera (no flash or tripod allowed, so you will have to work with high speeds up to 6.400 ASA)! A trip to Chora Church is really worth it. Very nice restaurant with large outdoor terrace serving excellent Pide (but no alcohol) right in front of the church.

Nice Mosaics. It is indeed a little out of the way. We had a hard time finding the bus line to get to this place, but when we got in the bus, it was easy to find the museum.I think for those who love mosaics and churches, it will be a delightful experience. For the rest of normal people, will be an expensive visit (15 lira) to visit a small place, where you can observe everything in less than 20 minutes. Don't get me wrong, the mosaics are really great, very impressive. But I don't qualify it as a "must see" like most of the people here.

Often overlooked gem with beautiful mosaics and frescos. You have to visit this small old church. It has better (and more) mosaics than Aya Sophia, and also has frescos from the same period. It's next to the old city walls, which are also worth a visit.

Outstanding former church with great mosaics. In some respects, a miniature Haggia Sophia, but even better in that there is no steep ramp to ascend to get a good view of the works, which are all close enough to enjoy details that are hard to see at the Haggia Sophia. Some splendid examples of late Byzantine art at its finest. Excellent audio tour enhances your experience. Take a taxi: very hilly area and several public transit rides are required to get close to this location,

Out of the way but 100% worth the effort!. Off the beated track of all the other tourist sights, but listed as "one of the 1000 places to visit before you die", so we took a taxi to this amazing church / museum. Exquisite delicate gold mosaics cover much of the ceilings and walls depicting various Christian scenes. If you have time it is well worth the visit & access is included in the Istanbul Museum card package.
Small treasure. Beautiful- frescos told story of Mary as related in Book of James, Some of the nicest frescos I have seen. Details are amazing.

Interesting experience but watch for crooked taxi drivers. Located off the tourist track in a residential neighbourhood. Interesting.WARNING - the taxis sitting at the front are mostly scammers. When I asked for my destination, they started with their usual lies of "traffic, traffic", so I walked away. Flagged down a taxi with meter, told him to take me to my hotel. Then I noticed he didn't restart the meter to zero. Another scam. So I told him "meter, sifir"- ie, put the meter on zero. Then he did, and we were fine. Watch out for taxi drivers picking you up near any tourist locale. Reasonable restaurant in front.
must visit. it is believed it has first signs of european renaissance.. it is a little bit far away from the old city but must visit..
Good, a little difficult to get there. Went by bus, interesting going through suburbs.Very old, and the mosaics amazing, well worth the visit.
Magnificent. The Chora Church offers an a inspirational view. It feels almost hidden away and it's quite a trek to get there but the walk there is a lovely way to explore.
A Beautiful Piece of History!. This little treasure is tucked away from the other main sights in Istanbul, but it is worth finding. The mosaics were amazing!

Fabulous frescos. This is a beautiful Byzantine church filled with impressive art works. It is dedicated to Mary and tells her life story in paintings. I am not a believer but was deeply moved by the beauty of this church. We walked up from the ferry and although it looked simple on the map we had, we managed to get lost in the winding streets. It was a very interesting walk but not the one we had intended. The locals did not speak English and Had we not stumbled on a couple of American hikers we may have never found it. Istanbul is not good on signage so nest be sure you know your route before you embark.

Incredible. I have seen a lot of churches in Europe, but was completely taken aback by this one. The frescoes and mosaics are amazing. While off the tourist path, this was definitely a side trip worth taking. I took the tram out to the Topkapi stop (not near the palace) and then switched to a light rail for a few stops. After that it was a 10 minute walk or so to the Chora Church. Do not let the journey intimidate you, it was easier than it sounds and totally worth it. You could also just take a cab.

Nice surprise. Located in the old town, close to the old wall (it is worth climbing up the few stairs for good views). It is not that well visible from afar, not like to the mosques. But when you find it, it is surrounded by nice restored wooden houses and the church museum has amazing mosaic inside. Well worth visiting.

Amazing mosaics. Amazing ancient church with great mosaics, frescoes and marble work. Not overly large, but the detail and craftsmanship of the mosaics is truly outstanding. It's part of the Istanbul Museum pass (I highly recommend getting this pass - saves both time in line at the Aya Sofia and Topkapi, but is a great value if you're going to most of the museums included anyway). A bit out of the way, but if you make the trip, it's worth sticking around for dinner next door at Asitane.

Chora chora chora!. A bit off the beaten track but worth the effort, particularly if you combine with a visit to Asitane restaurant. It has the most magnificent frescoes and mosaics. Recommend you arrange a taxi to take you back as it can be difficult to find a reliable one out of season.

Chora Church. This place is amazing and definitely worth the trip. The mosaics are beautiful. The church is located about 4 miles out from the city center by the old city defense wall (which, in itself, is worth walking), but you can easily get there on pubic transit. Public transit in Istanbul, like most of Europe, is inexpensive, clean, efficient, and easy to use. If you look at a map, you can take the street transit out to where it connects with the subway. You then take the subway to the station by the wall and the Chora Church is a reasonable walk from there.

Beautiful Works of Art. Unless you are on a group tour, finding this spot was a challenge. A city bus goes by an intersection 4-5 blocks away, but good luck figuring out when to get off the bus. With the help of a local, I did find my way here.The building is not large, but is covered with frescoes and tile mosaic. Some of these remain in good condition showing excellent details. Some of the mosaic have dropped many of their tiny tiles. One can still see many of these items at a close level, but please do not use a flash when capturing an image. Definitely worth the effort of finding this church.

Incredible mosaics, and nice neighbourhood. It's a bit far from the major sites, but it's worth it, and not only because it's got some very old and yet very preserved mosaics: the journey provides a nice break from Sultanahmet. You can get a bus from Eminonü (just ask around, we even found somebody who was going in the same direction and escorted us there) or a boat, from Eminonü too, and then walk along the ancient walls. The area around the church feels much more real than Sultanahmet, and it's nice to wander round.

Exceptionally Beautiful. My husband and I think that this church was the most beautiful site we saw in Istanbul. Though it is quite a bit smaller than the Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque and didn't have the "huge" awe factor, it certainly had so much beautiful art packed into its smaller structure.It is further away from the other major historic sites, but well worth the little trip. There are beautiful courtyards and parks around the area and places to have lunch or a quick bite to eat before heading back to the main parts of the city.Looking into the history and meanings of the art could be helpful as there are quite a few pieces working all in the same themes as one another (ie: geneology of Jesus, miracles of Jesus, temptations of Jesus, final Judgment, etc)

Amazing. You don't want to miss the brilliant and detailed mosaics in the Kariye Museum. I loved getting there by bus and seeing the non-tourist neighborhoods of Istanbul along the way. Not crowed and quite an impressive church.

Best site in Istanbul. This was the first historic site we visited, and what a wonderful introduction. Quite a trip to get to, but worth every minute. The mosaics are unlike anything we saw afterwards. Very highly recommended.
Amazing. You cannot go to Istanbul and not make the trip to this museum. Byzantine-era mosaics and frescoes glow like they were done yesterday. Absolutely astounding.
Chora Church. We really enjoyed the mosaics and paintings, as well the quiet beauty of the area around the church.
The Chora Church. Beautiful old mosaics tell the story of Mary, Joseph and Jesus. There is a mosaic that has the family tree for Jesus starting with Adam and Eve.
Most beautiful mosaics I've ever seen. If you visit Istanbul, you must see this place. The paintings and mosaics in this church can't be described in words - the beauty of it must be admired live.

The best place to see in Istanbul. Great location, close to the Theodosian wall.
The quality of the Christian art work inside is an inspiration! It is like stepping into a different world.
Be careful as it is closed in Wednesdays.
PERFECT MURALS. Outside the church, you see a common old place,but inside it, you will find perfect murals.Maybe the most amazing ones in Turkey.

Must see museum.. Kariye (Chora) Museum is a must-see in Istanbul. Mind-blowing mosaics.... Don't expect to spend too much time there though, it is a small museum (ex-mosque/church). It is not well advertised. Most locals will not have visited the museum. There is a tea house just next to it, it might be a good stop for a break, especially if the weather is nice and dry.

STUNNING. Off the beaten path, the mosaic work in this small church are nothing less than jaw dropping with a lot less strain on the eyes. The restaurant at the hotel next door delivers a great meal as well

Chora church. Well worth a visit. This is a fantastic example of Byzantine art with a brilliant guided tour from headphones which you can rent for 10TL. Entrance costs 15TL and with every penny. The Byzantine mosaics depict much of Jesus' life and that of Mary. Very interesting. It is a bit off the beaten track - cost 40TL from Eminonu by taxi but worth it.Visit the area of Balat close by which has lots of interesting Ottoman houses.

A bit of history. This is a beautiful church, though not a very big one and a bit off the usual tourist track in Istanbul. If you purchase a three day museum pass, the entrance fee to Chora is included.It's not difficult to find, one way for example is to take a bus from the Eminönü bus station (drivers should know which one) and if I remember it well it's a 15 minute ride. There are signs and should you miss each and every one of them you can always ask a local, since they get this question all the time. The mosaics are well preserved and definitely worth a visit. It's a great bit of Byzantine history!Don't use a guide or go on a tour unless you want more info on the spot, and even so I think you can get all the history and information online or find it in books and brochures before or after your visit. I enjoyed a visit on my own in a quiet atmosphere early in the morning. The churchyard is also worth a short stop, where you can sit down on a bench and enjoy a nice view towards the city while taking in the smell of the roses.
Off the beaten path. This beautifully decorated Byzantine church is away from the main sites but well worth the detour.combine with fantastic lunch at Asitane next door

Anne - a story in pictures. It you love mosaics and frescos this is a must church to see. And if you want the story of Anne - Mary's Mother of Jesus's mother then it is here. The story is ascribed to James the lesser and a lovely set of ceiling mosaics depicts it.

off the track. This church is off the track but shouldn't be missed.I wasn't planning to take my foreign boyfriend there but my Turkish friend made us go and I am glad he did. Please read about the church before you go.
A beautiful place to visit. An extraordinary example of Byzantine art. Beautifully restored and maintained and in an interesting area to explore when you're done.

Beautiful, unique church. The church is easy to miss as it is located down small alleys. Do ask for directions from tourist(mostly with cameras) as they had visited the church already. I felt the church was beautiful but preferred Hagia Sofia as there were more explanatory signs, art work and space. We spent not more than 30min at the church as church was rather small and was rather crowded. Do lookout for fethiye church not too far away for a similar experience of Chora.

Not to be missed. It's possible to take a taxi one way, tour the church at your leisure and then find a taxi waiting outside when you are finished. I purchased a ticket online, which allowed me to go straight to the gate. This saved me some aggravation, as the crowds were beginning to arrive. You will be in awe of the talent of the artists who represented the life of Christ on the walls and ceilings of this church. It's not to be missed.

Fantastic value of mosaics and frescoes. Fantastic value of mosaics and frescoes. The church is located a bit outside the center, but it is worth to take a taxi, for a reasonable price. The driver was waiting for us and the fee was absolutely acceptable.

Rare Byzantine Mosaics + Theodosian Walls. The Church is a bit out of the way but worth the trip to see the Byzantine mosaics on the walls and ceilings. It is then just a short walk to see a portion of the Theodosian Walls ... and you can even climb-up onto the wall if you're gutsy enough to negotiate about thirty feet of narrow and very steep steps.
Byzantine church. An great example of Byzantine art and great representation of the story of Jesus. The mosaics and frescoes are incredibly preserve considering the times and years in place

Mosaic out of this world. Could not imagine that this small church has this valuable mosaic , unbelievably beautiful and charm,
check the lovely small souvenir shop inside.

A WELL PRESERVED BYZANTINE GEM. This is a charming Byzantine church, converted to a mosque by the Ottomans, now a museum. It features some of the best, most elaborate mosaics from the era outside of the Hagia Sophia. The only problem as a tourist site is that unless you are on a tour, it is a bit out of the ways, farther out than the central attractions of the Old City. But if you have the time, it is well worth a visit.

Amazing...like stepping back in time!. Although off the beaten path, the architecture and artwork make this a can't miss site. The mosaics and frescos are impressive and well preserved. The audio guide is good!

Wonderful mosaics. Excellent frescoes and mosaics . Chora church is a must see place in Istanbul...The magnificent mosaics make your visit very worthy...you will be taken by the beauty & history of the place .

A Byzantine delight. The mosaics were stunning and well interpreted by an interesting commentary on the audio machines. The setting was peaceful away from the bustle of Istanbul. Near the old walls of the city and accessible by buses.
Don't miss. While this little church is not on the top of places to see, don't miss it. The mosaics are beautiful.

The story of Jesus's life in icons. The whole story of Jesus is on the walls and ceilings in the ante room of this old monastery. The adjoining chapel has beautiful icons/murals on the walls and ceilings.Allow at least 2 hrs to see it because it gets crowded.This one church/monastery that was not converted to a mosque nor have its murals plastered over.It is a must see.

Wonderful preservation. The mosaics are in very good condition, as are the frescoes. Although it is very crowded our tour guide did manage to be heard when explaining the significance of many of these art works. This was a Christian building of great importance.
Its a Long Way. This is a lovely Church and the Mosaics are amazing, but it is a very long taxi ride with no taxi stand nearby so you must pay the driver to wait for you while your tour the church.

Beautiful mosaics. Enjoyed this representation of ancient Christendom in a close-in Istanbul neighborhood. Reachable from the #32 bus from the bus station near the Spice Market. While a relatively small structure when compared to the larger mosques, it is definitely worth a stop. When we got through, there was a cab waiting so we rode back to the Spice Market for 12 Turkish lira. Good deal!

Art, architecture, history, religion. The location of the church is not easy to find but the trip is definitely worthwhile.I loved the architecture, i loved the art, i loved the aura. It's always a good idea to visit such historical places with a guide but in any case, try to read about the church before you come here. The mosaics are very impressive. The original church comes from the 5th century. The only disturbing thing could be the loud conversation of other groups:(So if you love the art, history, architecture or religion, you should see this place while you are in Istanbul.Nearby, there are two restaurants: one is right across the building and nice for drinking tea/coffee. The other one is Asitane Restaurant which offers Ottoman cuisine but a bit pricy. After a delightful historical visit, you might also want to have drinks or have lunch in one them.

A jewel by the city walls. I don't think there's any other place in the world where the beauty of Byzantine mosaic art and frecoes can be seen. Scenes from the Bible are displayed beautifully in tremendous detail. You don't have to be a Christian to admire this wonderful display of eternal art. Any trip to Istanbul without visiting Kariye will never be complete.
Worth while. Magnificient reconstruction of the mosaic technics on the walls Very interesting historical place away from the centre of sultanahmet.

Just go there. This is a unique blend of architecture and art. You can see a narrative of religious scenes in an astonishing mosaic technique within a great space. The affect of the pictures is very strong. The decorative use of marble is also of great beauty. It is a pity that there is no proper lighting design. On the contrary it seems like a local electrician has put whatever light bulbs were handy- even plain terrible economy ones- in a monument of such importance. This greatly alters the architectural sense of the space and in some cases makes it difficult to see the mosaics ('burnt' images, shadows due to uneveness of the mosaics, wrong way up shadows from architectural elements). At least, the room devoted to the mother is ok. This is a interesting example of a pack of wrong choices and alterations on how to present a great historical monument. You enter from the side door, while a shop is located in the originally main entrance of the monument and you diy the lights. Still, the monument is overwelming.

A must see in Istanbul. We went to the Kariye church/museum yesterday, historical Bible scenes depicted in incredible small pieces of tile, dating back to 1200's. Not that large of a church, but still took us a couple of hours to look at all the scenes depicted on walls and ceilings. We found it best to take a taxi to see it, agreed with taxi drivers both ways in advance to take us from downtown Istanbul to the church and back for 25TL ($12 .50) each way. To have taken the tramway, then bus (at 3 TL each person each form of transportation) and then walk a bit was not worth the time or money. After visiting the church, it is only a few minute walk to the old walls of the city and you can along top parts of the wall. Definitely one of the highlights and must sees in Istanbul.

Amazing little church. Went to Asitane for lunch. A little expensive but worth it for the amazing ottoman dishes. If adventurous, visit the local neighbourhoods and sample the freshly baked simits from the bakeries nearby!
out of the old city. it's out of the old city area. far from other "must see" places but you should make time for chora it's beautiful.

A beautiful old church. The Chora church is a small church tucked away in a residential area of Istanbul. It has a beautiful dome and has an air of sanctity which is hard to come by in the larger churches. It is definitely well worth a trip. Like a lot of churches in Istanbul it was converted to a mosque by the Ottomans and is now a museum.

Don't miss it!. This is one of great treasures of the world, perhaps the greatest collection of Byzantine art in the world. It is a little out of the way (about 20-30 minutes by taxi from Hagia Sophia) but you get to see the walls of the city on your way there. Go as soon as it opens because the tour buses start arriving and it is a small place. Don't miss this one!

Charming remnant of Byzantine history. Great mozaïques and paintings. A more palpable Byzantine relic than the Aya Sophia. Too bad the city walls and the Blachernae Palace are not in a great state nowadays. (The latter is being restored, without any idea when the restoration will be over.) But this makes for a worthwile visit to this region of the city anyway. There's definitely more to Istanbul than Sultanahmet (from a touristic viewpoint)!
a must do. This is so beautifull, if you don't do this when you visit Istanbul, then you shure are missing out on something extraordinary.
a must see. even when you're in istanbul for a short trip, this is worth a visit, mosaiques and paintings much better conserved than in aya sophia, and much less crowded
Outstanding!. So much to see in a small area. A must to see in Istanbul. Try to see it without tour groups as it gets very crowded.
Smaller than the Hagia Sophia but well worth a visit. Great mosaics , it's smaller than the Hagia Sophia (to say the least) but it is definitely worth checking out
Spectacular mosacis. Stunning Byzantine mosaics - one of the few areas where you can see some relics of Byzantine Constantinople.
The Chora Church. Originally a /btzabtube church, (St. Saviour in Chora) now a museum. Has excellent frescoes and mosaics, very well worth a visit

Byzantine Jewel. Beautiful Byzantine church that has been converted to a museum. The Kariye Museum is a bit out of the way but worth a cab ride to visit. You will also see the ancient Theodosian walls that once surrounded the city. We also visited the Faith Camii Mosque which was one of the most beautiful in Istanbul. Faith is a neighborhood of Istanbul that is not touristic and more conservative

Simply beautiful. The interior decoration in this church is overwhelmingly beautiful - our favourite biblical scene represented on the ceiling was of Mary learning to walk! We were staying in the Old Town and took a cab out to the church and it was well worth the trouble. The church is also set next to a lovely garden cafe that had quite a cosmopolitan vibe. The wifi wasn't working the day we were there (which would have enabled the iPhone tour to work) so I wished I had purchased the audio tour - it's worth asking before you enter if the wifi is working.

Outstanding Mosaics. A bit off the beaten path but worth the journey.The building itself is not near as large or as grand as Haghia Sophia, but the mosaics are fantastic. They are 10 times the quality and quantity of Haghia Sophia. It's amazing they have survived as long as they have. We spent about 50 minutes viewing all the mosaics.

One of the best Istanbul sights. We almost didn't go here as we felt it was a little bit far away! Luckily another traveller told us about it, and we decided to visit. Mosaics in the church are incredible - really awe inspiring to think how old they are and how well preserved they are. Added bonus - when you exit the church go straight up the street about 300m and you will come to the city walls. Climb up (if you dare!) for a great view over Istanbul.

You don't have to appreciate religion to appreciate this. It was a bit out of our way but my husband and I decided in hindsight that the 70 Lira it set us back (taxi there and back plus entry fees) was worth it!I'm not big on churches usually but the ceiling of the Chora Church is amazing as artwork. The mosaic work is just beautiful. We had our head up to the ceiling the entire time. If you love beautiful things this is an attraction you shouldn't miss.

Mosaics. I admit to being dissapointed after seeing it after seeing the review scores I did expect something else beside the mosaics. However there is nothing else to expect - It's a very old small church with truly good kept mosaics that I understand were covered in plaster after the fall of Constantinopol and thus very nicely preserved until they were revealed from under the plaster-. The mosaics are some of the most beautiful, but since I'm not a religious person and not a big fan of byzantine church art, for me it felt like it did not rise to the hype. On the other hand I do realize many people are religious and will feel much moved by the depictions and mosaics might be of much more interest to them.Thus the conclusion rests on which side are you. I've attached some shots of the mosaics I took to help you decide for yourself.

Hidden Treasure. This was our second visit to Istanbul and we missed out on this glorious church the first time around. the mosaics are fantastic. If you don't have a guide use the audio one. It throws a new light on the biblical stories we were told as kids

My personal favorite. Been there, done that, seen them all, but this was something extraordinarily special. A part of the tours on our "Voyages to Antiquity" trip with Smithsonian Journeys puts this (in my opinion) as the most intimate and memorable tour and number one on my list of favorites. This crumbling (but intact) structure dates from about 1100 B.C. as we see it today. Original construction is dated at 4th century B.C. The construction is a whole other category of discussion.The intimacy of this small church, the absolute beauty of the gold toned ultra-mini-small pieces of mosiacs depicting such fantastic pictures of what Mary's early life (think age 9) was like, and her father's process of picking Mary's husband-to-be. OMG, this was a fantastic experience. And then the Gospel according to James the Lesser (you won't find him in the present bible, he was edited out). So many exceptional expressions of life and possible happenings in so distant a part of history.And then, as in most of Turkey, the keys to the building were handed over to the Turks circa the 16th century, and the mosaics were plastered over (stop me if you've heard this one before) and then uncovered at a later point in history.It's a very heady, spiritual experience to gaze upon these mosaics and the story they tell. And the story told is moving, truly spiritual, and oh-so thought provoking. I will remember it forever.

Mosaics and Frescoes. It is surprising to see the Chora Church ranked higher than every other attraction in Istanbul. This is a good attraction for those who have a particular curiosity or interest in mosaics and frescoes that depict stories from the Bible. Otherwise, it is not worth the trip as the Church is small and there is little else of interest in the area. I was curious to visit based on TA rankings, but I feel it is not really worthwhile unless one has ample time in Istanbul or a very keen interest in Christian mosaics. The Church itself is pleasant and nice to see, but just didn't impress me as much as the other sights of Istanbul.

Interesting visit. This is an old church with interesting, relatively undamaged, frescoes showing excerpts from the life of Mary, mother of Jesus. It is useful to have a guide with you to explain these.
Intriguing and lovely. This small, ancient church and most of its frescoes were saved from the religous changes. The frescos were truely marvelous

Certainly Worth a Visit. Though somewhat out of the way, this small, and very old, church has some of the most amazing mosaics and frescos that you will ever see. Parts of the church date to the 5th century and it is enlightening to see something that old.
Must see church. Chora church is a must see place in Istanbul...The magnificent mosaics make your visit very worthy...you will be taken by the beauty & history of the place .....

Beautiful Gold Mosaics. The mosaics are still in really good condition, and worth a visit!
Plus it is not as crowded as the main attractions around the Ayya Sofya, makes a very pleasant leisurely afternoon trip.

breathtaking. I was amazed by all the frescos and the stories they told. I followed the guide in the Rick Steves book and learned a lot. Most, or all, frescos are above eye level so your neck may be a little sore afterwards.

Chora Church. Chora [Istanbul] is an ancient Byzantine Church.It is famous for it's frescoes and mosaics, which are of the bet preserved in the world.It is slightly off the beaten track, but so special it should not be missed at all!
Worth the climb. A bit out of the way but worth searching for. Excellent frescoes and mosaics. Pleasant cafes to enjoy afterwards.

One of the "must seens" in Istanbul. First of all , i should admit that it was not so easy to find the place. You have to change some vehicles if you're arriving with public transportation. Museum is not located in a bright neighborhood. So you may be suprised when you find a better place than expected. Mosaics, figures are not damaged . I guess, it will mean more for a christian . You have to take a audioguide from enterance as there is no explanation . If i would make a list for must seens in Istanbul , It will be in top ten. Not in top five.. There is so many things to see in Istanbul. Blue mosque, Hagia sophia, topkapi Palace, Istanbul Archelogy museum, Maiden tower etc...
Touristy but Beautiful. Touristy attraction but very beautiful. One of the must see Istanbul sights. Recommend going early before the crowds.

Wonderful mosaics. The muslims covered the mosaic of the Chora church in plaster and this allowed them to be kept essentially intact. The most beautiful mosaics seen in Turkey, almost as nice as those of Palermo, Italy.The Chora church is out of the way in Istanbul, but the visit is worth the taxi ride. One of the highlights of Istanbul.

Worth a visit. And go to the Ayubia Mosque area while you are there and it will be a real cultural trip. The frescas depicting the Life of Christ and its apostles are worth a trip and will save you a trip to Italy

Wow. Not the easiest place to get to or find but definitely a place you want to visit. I recommend you have a taxi take you. The former Christian Church which was also a Mosque was restored to it's original Christian Church state as much as possible. What beautiful mosaics and Frescos. This is the hidden gem of Istanbul.
Exquisite mosaics. Enjoyed the audio guide accompaniment . Was completely transfixed by the beauty of the mosaics, and annoyed by the very rude man in the shop.
Emotional place. Incredible history of the early Christian church with truly remarkable mosaics. Not the best of areas so consider going on a guided tour as we did.

Amazing. The mosaics are fabulous! It is amazing that they have remained in such a good state when they are about the Christ and The Virgin story in a Muslin country! Such an example other should follow.
Wonderful mosaics. Our tour guide gave a very descriptive overview of these intricate works of art that have survived for so long.

It's out of the way but when you get there, it's out of this world!. Really worth going out of your way for this one, especially if you like mosaics (we only grew to like them during our trip to Istanbul). We did this only because we had a bit of time to spare and we're so glad we did. We suggest making it one of your must-do's if you're on a sightseeing trip. Take some time to sit in the garden also, away from the hustle and bustle of Sultanahmet and the crowds all over the city.

Dropdead Gorgeous. A must see! The interior of the church was dropdead gorgeous. The mosaics of Jesus and Mary and their lives are massive and stunning. I couldn't stop staring at the walls and especially the ceilings. It was incredible inside. I am so glad our guide took us here.

Tricky but worth finding. This attraction is included in the Muze Pass. It is a little bit difficult to find it but i guess getting lost is part of the adventure! Kariye/Chora is small but full of history! It's also not very crowded which is nice. The only negative thing I have to say is that they sell Muze Pass for 80 lira, which is 8 lira more expensive than anywhere else in Istanbul.
Hidden Miracle. Very valuable pieces of art hidden in this place, away from the crowded part of the old town of Istanbul...
An interesting Byzantine church. There were beautiful mozaics and murals, and Özden of Turkland Travels explained what stories the mozaics illustrated.

Loved the art work. This places seems a little out of the way but it is well worth the visit. The art in this building is gorgeous. I loved all of it. You must enter with a great guide though to understand the history of these pieces. Either way this place is really a must!

A hidden gem. It may be a bit difficult to get to, but it is worth your every effort. When you go, watch people as they enter the church because they all more or less do the same thing: they step over the threshold, look ahead to the niche in the blank brick wall ahead of them, and then they glace to the space opening up on their right. And they gasp.They gasp because they're looking down a side chapel covered from floor to ceiling in frescoes where in the apse at the end, is one of the finest paintings in the world. The effect is heart-stopping.The building isn't very large, and it's divided into four separate spaces which makes it seems even smaller. The largest of these, the main church, is rather bare, but the other three, which serve as side chapels and entrance halls to the church, are covered with dazzling mosaics and brightly coloured frescoes drawn with exquisite sensitivity. The mosaics and frescoes are laid out to give the viewer a theological story, and I found it greatly increased my understanding and enjoyment to use a guide book that help me unravel what I was seeing. I saw a lot of other visitors were doing the same thing. Some were using the audio guides that you can rent for 10TL just outside the building. I didn't do this, so I can't comment on how good they are. Don't let this put you off, though, if this kind of reading up isn't for you, you can still enjoy the astonishing quality of the art, and feel the impact it has. In fact, a visit to Chora is a great help when it comes to understanding any of the other Byzantine churches in the city, especially Haghia Sophia. Come here first and it will be much easier to reconstruct how these others must have looked before the conquest.Some practical tips: there are toilets (on the way in). There are some nice, if expensive, places to stop for a bite or a drink in and around the delightful square outside, where you'll also find people selling icons, trinkets and other tourist ware.Getting here by public transport isn't very hard. Probably the easiest way is by tram (T1) to Topkapı (not Metro stop, not the palace!) and then the T4 three stop to Edirnekapı. When you get off, follow the city walls for about 100 yards, keeping them on your left and you will find the church down a side street on your right. If you need directions, ask people for "Kariye" and someone will point you where to go.
The cielling is beautiful. The church is very old one of the byzantine churhces . Must visit. Its more quiet during the afternoon.
You must see, wont regret it. you should definitly see and visit this marvellous chruch, if you have time after the visit, you can taste great Ottoman cuisene at Asitane Restuarant

Ok to a point. My first visit brought a mixed reaction from our group. The frescos and mosaics are well preserved and interesting but based on mythology rather than an accurate re-telling of the Biblical narrative.
Our guide gave the impression that fiction was fact. More Dan Brown than history.
Disappointing.

More than worth the 20TL cab ride. Small but impressive!!! Get the audio guide, this will be of great help when looking at the mosaics. Beautiful artwork sold by a local artist just outside the church .

Pretty and quiet church but a long hike. All the guide books and Trip Advisor rave about this church but its a real hike through winding streets and quite expensive for what you get. If you do go take the tram to Yusufpasa then the metro from Aksaray to Topkapi Ulubatli. From here it's a 20-30 minute walk along the old city walls to the church. Ladies be aware that you are walking through the more suburban areas of Istanbul and conservative clothing is advisable. The church itself is very pretty and some of the mosaics are spectacular but at 15TL each (the same price as the Topkapi Harem) it's a bit steep.

A quiet respite. Chora Church is a little off the beaten path but worth the trek. Most sites advise you to take a bus or cab. I ended up taking the T1 tram from Sultanahmet, transferred to the T4 tram and exited at the Edimekapi stop. After exiting the Metro you're by a highway, so I asked a few locals to help me with directions when Google maps failed. It was about another 10 minute walk. I am a female travelling alone and never felt unsafe. Souveniers here are also cheaper than in Sultanahmet.Once you arrive at the church and pay 15TL you will immediately be taken by it's smaller scale charm. It is not a hulking mosque but a rather quaint little brick church w/ breathtaking mosaics. Most of the other sites in Istanbul will be iznik tiles or frescoes. This is beautiful, lustrous, fine detailed mosaics. They are also extremely well-preserved for the most part especially on the ceilings, so take your time looking up and follow the biblical stories.

A must see byzantine church. Took the boat up the golden horn as suggested by the LP guide and walked along the walls to this gem of a church. The mosaics and frescos are outstanding, better even that the Hagia Sophia!
A unique monument. A unique place to visit in Istanbul Although very touristic it wasn't so crowded. One of h most well preserved Byzantine monuments that every Istanbul visitor must see.

A bit hard to find. Before you take the bus from Eminönü, check out the place on the map precisely. There are no clear signs from the bus stop, and since it is not at a tourist district, it may take a long time to find anyone speaking English and knowing the right direction.

Extraordinary - don't miss.. This was our second trip to Istanbul. The first time we stayed near the Topkapi Palace and saw all the sights in that area. Little did we know we were missing such a jem as this. It takes a little effort getting there; it's quite a bit out of the way, but it's certainly worth it. The murals/frescoes are truly awesome-scenes of Jesus' life seldom seen; brilliant colors; tremendous detail. If you have time, make the effort! It's worth it.

Great mosaics. Kariye Museum is unbelievably beautiful. It is very small and when you enter in it you don't expect too much. First you see some paintings on the walls which are good but not extraordinary. After the first part of the museum, you enter through a small door and you see a hall which is full of mosaics. I was in real shock when I saw these mosaics all that are in very good condition as if there hasn't been houndreds of years truly! mosaics are golden and shining with the day light.. I am a muslim and I didn't understand the stories but I think the stories are telling the miracles of Christ and may be they are very important for Christianity as they are some of the oldest mosaics of the Christian world. So you must go there, recommended!

most beautiful. The church is full of wonderful frescoes and mosaics telling stories of the life of Christ and the virgin Mary. It is beautiful in itself and, to a western visitor, a very welcome and familiar religious building.

Really worth a visit. This is such a lovely church - well worth a visit even though it is a little out of the way. Less crowded than other attractions - very peaceful and calm very different to other areas of Istanbul. Local cafe for coffee etc.
A hidden gem. We chose to take the ferry and walk rather than the bus but having found it we are so pleased we did. The mosaics and frescos are outstanding. The audio guide is definitely worthwhile

Not to be mixed. This lovely church has the best preserved frescoes and mosaics in Istanbul and is definitely worth the trip. You can take the metro to Edirnikapi and get there in a short walk. As a bonus you get to see a real neighborhood unlike those in the tourist area.
fabulous. This place was the place we had wanted to see the most. We were very satisfied. The mosaic was so fabulous.

Astonishing bible mosaics from Constatinople. Crowds of tours in July. Hard to see the wonderful mosaics, or to hear the guide, This is a unique experience, to be seen best out of peak vacation season

our favorite sight. Out of the way, but worth the effort. Since it is out of the way, there are no crowds. The mosaics are excellent in quality and well-preserved, almost on a par with those in Ravenna. Some very good frescoes as well.Take a taxi or book a guide. There are taxis available when you are ready to leave.

too many words. Everyone spoke us about this place. After walking on the hill for half an hour, the result was the discovery of a very nice church, but not so nice as we expected. Maybe we are Italian and so it's quite normal to find such a masterpiece, but we didn't find it exceptional.

" The Peace of the Past".. The Chora Church is often overlooked; perhaps because it is " off the beaten track " and is not as well known as many other well-known places to go to in Istanbul. If you have time; go. This is Constantinople and you feel it as soon as you step inside. The peace, quiet and depth of the past envelope you. You do not need a guide, just a guide book - which you will need - to ensure that you do not miss the incredible frescoes on the church walls. Imagination is hardly sufficient to understand the changes and upheavals that have taken place both within and outside these walls.....but it can keep you occupied for a long time before stepping outside into the teeming hoardes again.
The best place for me in Istambul.. This is An amazing churchil in Istambul! With Nice mosaics about Our Lady's life, which I have never seen in my life!

stunning gem of a Byzantine Church. Having traveled to Istanbul many times, I ventured off the usual tourist path to this small gem from the Byzantium period in Istanbul. It does not have the scale of Hagia Sophia, but, the frescoes and mosaics are in much better condition, more numerous and absolutely stunning. And the surrounding neighborhood still has many of the old wooden houses that once populated old Istanbul- not to be missed.

You won't be regretted. Absolutely amazing mosaics and different experience compared with other sights in Istanbul, though I am not a Christian. Highly recommend to get a audio guide to visit the museum. However it is a bit out of way (we caught a taxi from old town for under 20 lira), we enjoyed the tranquility of the location.

Our Favorite Place in Istanbul. The Chora Church is out of the way but is well worth the visit. It is much smaller than Aya Sophia, so the visit only takes about one hour. The mosaics were amazing. Make sure to purchase the audio tour, which will help you understand what the mosaics are depicting.

Amazing mosaics. It seems like this church has suddenly made it onto the "must do" list as there are no street signs in the surrounding area. Most of the crowds of foreign tourists seemed to be on coach tours. I had some difficulty finding it, from the tram stop, but it was worth the effort. The mosaics are quite wonderful and very sad to see the state of damage.

Very interesting find, not so many tourists. A small find packed with a lot of Christian meaning. The oldest Christian establishment that I've ever been to. Getting the audio book is a must; if they don't have your language make sure you have a book or something in advance.
amazing frescos. out of the way but definately a not miss. The frescos are terrific and the history is very interesting
Beautiful Church. The mosaics are wonderful. I love it as a Christian and my friend who is not a Christian is also very impressed too.
Very disappointing - better off going to aya sofia. Difficult to find. Not much to see. The fresco is nice but limited.Not value for money. I did not like the journey.

Mosaics to rival the best in the world. Lovely visit and actually not too difficult to get from taksim/ sultanahmet by public transport if you look it up. Not much to say other than see it for yourslef. Visited the restaurant asitane afterwards which is just near the entrance. Beautiful garden and white tablecloth service. Unfortunately had just eaten but had drinks and a dessert which was delicious and the prices although fairly expensive had a really interesting story.

Jewel Box of a church. Loved how old it was. Was mostly devoted to the Virgin Mary and had mosaics and frescos of her entire story, including the birth!There was a fabulous jewelry store just as you exit to the left, with a wonderful Turkish proprietor and she helped me pick some great pieces. Be forewarned, the prices are in Euro not Turkish Lire, so the stuff ended up being more expensive than I bargained for, but it is more costume then real and some super designs. Have already received may complements on my ring.
Good place to visit. I enjoyed the museum a lot. It was a bit of a walk to get there, but am glad we went. A lot to learn from their history

lovely Frescos. No wonder this is rated as one of the most beautiful churches in the world. This is situated at a 10 minute taxi ride from the old city and has some of the best Frescos i have ever seen.Not to be missed if one is in the old city.

Little Gem. The Chora Church is small but full of great frescos and mosaics. We went at the beginning of August with a public bus from the Galata bridge to the Church and were surprised how quiet it was. Eventhough it is a small place it was not crowded at all (not at all like Topkapi). Particularly the mosaics are great.
The genius of past days. A beautiful Christian church maintained and cared for by the Turks. The murals and mosaics are sensational

Amazing! A must in Istambul!. The mosaic panels were stunning, showing the aprocrif gospels. I definitely recommend using the audioguide to understand better the details of this rather small but very rich museum.
Good outing. The museum was a great visit and very well kept and maintained. A bit off the main tourist path, but we caught a tram and it was just a 5 minute walk from the Edirnekapi station.
Wonderful place. One of the best places in Istanbul, very beautiful and old. I liked it a lot - it's ancient and interesting place to visit. I definitely advise everyone to visit it.

The only way to understand the beauty of Hagia Sophia. This is a small treasure in Istanbul which shows you how the great cathedral of Saint Sophie must have looked. The mosaics and paintings are well preserved and it is a must see in town.

Nice complement to the big mosques. A relatively small church, but with some magnificent art. Quiet and spiritual. A nice counterpart to the huge mosques. Well worth a visit if you have a little extra time.

Awesome. The wonders of the church was really conveyed by the guide who was able to point out the various frescoes and the background history. The style and present condition enabled one to obtain a secular opinion of a spiritual world that does not seem to currently exist. it was very hot inside the church and the number of visitors made it difficult at times to have a long look at some of the paintings.This is another labour that is difficult to appreciate immediately, but reflection brings home the amount of effort necessary to have created the paintings.

Recommended. We took a taxi out here from Sultanamet and really enjoyed the experience. There is a very nice little village with a cafe in a great spot, a good quality paintings gallery (yes we bought something) and the old church is well worth seeing with excellent frescoes and mosaics.

Simply breathtaking interior!. Well-worth the effort to get to this tiny but beautiful Church. You can get a bus from the main port in Istanbul centre, outside the new mosque. When you get off the bus look for a sign pointing right (it may be a little before the bus stop so look around carefully), the turning should be before the city walls - if you pass under the city walls then you've gone too far!The decoration within this church is really outstandingly beautiful - even if you only have a limited time in Istanbul this is well worth a visit, perhaps even instead of Hagia Sophia, the decoration is certainly more spectacular.

Like a gem in a poor display box. This gem is ranked 1st with good reasons. It is an intimate attraction with well preserved beautiful mosaics. Rent the audio guide and follow the sequence mentioned by the audio guide (and not according to the number) to fully appreciate this place.The lighting of this place could be improved though. The lighting is too harsh and mounted on very prominent aluminum bars across. Like displaying a gem in a cracked glass box.
Chora is a must see in Istanbul. 12 century byzantine. Best preserved and extensive mosaics recounting life of Jesus and apocryphal life of Mary. It's like the whole new testament on the ceiling.

beautiful frescos and mosaics. This is a little away from the city center but was one of my 'must see' places during my trip, so booked a tour that included this stop, which was the highlight of the tour. It can be crowded even in January when I went, with groups of people on tours that study and restore frescos and mosaics. Was fun to listen in on their tour leader giving intricate details about restoration so is always good to keep a perked up ear for and have a listen. I do agree that the way that the lighting is set up with steel gridwork overhead does take away from the actual structure at times. There are areas that are lost from restoration due to earthquakes but interesting to see. Along with the mosaics and frescos, keep on eye out for the beautiful marble striations. There is also a gift shop and cafe on site. A great way to spend a couple of hours.

The most amazing mosaics ever!. The Chora Church is not located very close to other sites in Istanbul, but it is worth the effort to get there. The mosaics are several hundred years old and very well preserved. They are beautiful and tell an extensive story of Mary's life and the stories of Jesus. A terrific example of Byzantine are.

A tiny beautiful church. There are very beautiful fresco preserved relatively well in such a small place. Some details are very clear and vivid. If you have time it is definitely worth going. Taking a tram to go and a bus to be back to Eminonu was also an interesting way to feel the city.
Best Church in Istanbul. This church is small but the best one we visited. Have the headphones worth every penny you can spend a couple of hours going around. Don't hurry its amazing.

Wonderful, but for the lighting. Great job restoring this rare remaining example of Byzantine church mosaics in Istanbul. Unfortunately, the way the church has been set up as a museum is less than satisfying. The lighting and the equipment used for it is obtrusive, taking away the character of the ambiance, rather than adding to it.
Magical.. A truly magical and rather underrated place. I will probably be back very soon. I suddenly feel very lucky to live in İstanbul.

Sacrosanct -. This is a religious experience. I felt humbled to be able to witness the beauty and love that embodies this church. It touches your soul. Don't miss this. It only takes 20 minutes in a cab from the old district.

Very nice mosaics, well restored but crowded!. This church is worth to visit. It is a little bit hard to arrive here but you can take a taxi from the Sultanahmet side for 15 to 25 TL. The church is not very big. Also visit the shop next to the entrance which sells miniature paintings. Really nice!
BEAUTIFUL!. Wonderful Church with old Frescoes & Paintings, lovely setting from main hubub of the City. Pay admission but free to roam. Nice & relaxing

Must see Museum in Istanbul. If you are interested in Byzantine Christian history/churces, the Kariye Museum is a must see. The former church, then mosque has one of the most vivid and well perserved Byzantine mosaics in the world. The wall and ceiling paintings literally jump out at you. Unfortunately many of them were partially damaged when the church was converted to a mosque in the 15th century, but they have been able to uncover an impressive portion of the original mosaics and frescoes.The Kariye Museum is a little off the beaten track as it is out near the Theodosian walls so many people don't venture there when they visit Istanbul. It certainly is worth the cab or bus ride if you have the opportunity. The walls as well are worth seeing (they are just up the hill from the museum) and you can actually climb to the top and get a good view of Istanbul.

Under-whelming. It is true that the mosaics that have survived are beautiful and show a high level of technical refinement BUT as this is a small church and very few of the mosaics remain intact, there is not really a lot to see here. Added to the fact that Kariye is in an out of the way location, I wouldn't make visiting here a priority unless you have a specific interest or plenty of time. There are many more beautiful churches and mosques in this amazing city.

Intimate and packed with beautiful artwork. The frescos and mosaics at this tiny church are in excellent condition. I had the Lonely Planet Istanbul guidebook which gave a nice little explanation of the different artwork to see. My brother and I went late in the day on a weekday (about 1.5 hours before closing) and had the place almost to ourselves. Although the architecture isn't as breathtaking as Aya Sofya, the artwork makes Kariye Museum a must-see for lovers of mosaics or religious art.The area around the church is fun to explore as well, just a stone's throw from the city walls. To make a day of it you could follow the wall east a little ways, then make your way down to explore the neighborhood of Balat, followed by a walk along the Golden Horn back towards Taksim or Eminonu.

Mind Blowing. This was one of the favorite places we visited in Istanbul. We took a cab up from Sultanahmet (about 10Lira). The mosaics and frescos are so rich, so many. Fantastic! This is not to be missed, and its small enough that it feels easy to do and do well. Afterward, we lunched next door at Asitane, which was highly recommended and lovely. Then, a walk along the wall back to the ferry. It was a wonderful day.
Stunning frescoes. One of our favourite places as so old, and different. Also the frescoes had stories of before Christ was born, and an Orthordox church for many years.

Beautiful but tucked away. The mosaics in this church are exquisite, it's not a huge church, so in summer, it does wet quite crowded. You have to get a taxi there, as its a little out of the way but well worth the visit
Get the Audio Guide!. I rarely know what I'm looking at in these old churches, so I so appreciated the guide. The hardest thing is having to look up so much!

A must see. This small church is off the main mass tourism path but the frescoes and mosaics are exquisite. I would say far more impressive than those on view at Hagia Sophia, and because the church is smaller, closer to you. It is a short distance from the main tourist sites, about a 15TL cab ride.

Amazing!!!. This church just takes your breath away!!!
Get a taxi to this sight-- max 30 Turkish lira well worth the cost!!!

Hidden Gem!. Tucked away in a local neighbourhood, Kariye Museum is a hidden gem. We took the tram there, asked around and finally found this Museum. It was well worth the time and effort as the frescos were really beautiful. After our visit, we walked around the neighbourhood and had some snacks in a local bakery. The locals were friendly and even gave us some free sampling of their snacks. We really enjoyed the visit.

Very interesting.. I went there last month. Though it is very interesting along with the history it carries. However, this Church only has four rooms and that's it. So I guess you are better off with other sites.

Don't miss this site in Istanbul. Sure, the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sophia have the jaw-dropping magnitude and location location location, but this little church further afield in the Sultanahmet is easier to consider in perspective, and will quickly become a permanent memory of Istanbul.The draw is the mosaics, which are slowly being restored, and the frescoes. It is easy to imagine what the interior must have looked like in its original state, covered in tiniest of mosaic tiles, so carefully designed and laid. Curators have done a nice job of "partially completing" many of the mosaics so that you get a sense of the work involved. The easiest way to get to the Kariye is via taxi. It'll cost about 20 TL (8 Euros). For a tenth of that cost you can take a bus from the Eminonu ferry stop in town, and get off at Edirnekapi. We walked from the Blue Mosque, it took about an hour.Bonus: When you leave the church, wander the surrounding neighborhood -- there are plenty of the old-school Istanbul wooden houses, many restored and many abandoned. You can easily walk the residential neighborhoods downhill until you get to the water and then easily catch a bus or cab back, or just walk the boardwalk back to the Gallata. Makes the trip out there even that much more worthwhile.
Precious gem!!. Truly magnificent - a must see. A smaller but absolutely beautiful church with well preserved/restored mosaics.

overlooked gem. this usually overlooked church beside the western limits of the constantinople walls (near Edirne gate) is quite small compared to Aya Sophia and much more difficult to get to. in spite of this, the frescoes on the walls and ceiling are reasonably conserved and are one of the most beautiful you can see in the country. the architecture of the church itself is also impressive. just hope that you get there when there are no group tours so you can enjoy it better, i was not so lucky.

A gem!. Getting to the Kariye Museum requires making an effort, but it is well worth it!! This former church has the most amazing mosaics and frescoes from the 12th century -- they are beautifully preserved and will take your breath away. When in Istanbul, this is not to be missed.
Don't loose the chance to see it. for the churches lovers this Museum worth's every step. the frescoes are splendid. Out side you can have turkish cafe,

Hagia Sofia 2:). It is shame that Chora church is often missed when people come to Istanbul. It is perhaps even more wonderful than Hagia Sofia. Wonderful mosaics of Jesus etc. Doomsday part is great too.

A more intimate perspective on the Byzantine city. Smaller in scale and more recent than the monumental Hagia Sophia, what makes this hard to find is also what makes it more interesting and intimate. Still surrounded by a busy community, from the back lot one sees the imperial center crowning the hills in the distance, and can get more of a feeling what life was like for ordinary citizens living during the bulk of the Christian period. The story of the church's founding is itself an interesting glimpse into the workings of the Empire, while the intimate and moving mosaics are among the best examples of their kind. The light modifications made during its period as a mosque preserved, rather than destroyed the beauty of these richly decorated spaces. I've been drawn back to see them time and again and would not consider a trip to Istanbul complete without another visit.
Beautifully maintained mosaics.. It really is amazingly beautiful to see the various mosaic depicted scenes from the life of the Panagia (Virgin Maria) so wonderfully maintained.

Very historic, important but not very impressive.. My wife and I visited and felt we did not need to spend a whole lot of time here. We took a cab in the morning and as soon as we walked in, the church and displays were not very impressive because of their condition. The church, however, should be a must see because of its significance.

Amazing!. It is a must see if you're travelling to Istanbul!It is a bit tricky to get there by public transportation, but you can take a taxi from the city historical centre. It's not very expensive and I guarantee it will worth the money

Exquisite. This is a true gem! The mosaics and paintings are exquisite. It's best to take a taxi to the museum from Sultanahmet. Afterwards, I took an easy stroll downhill, along the old city walls to the Metro.

Eyüp and Chora, worth the quick trip.. Going up to the Pierre Lotfi cafe is fun and has a beautiful view overlooking Istanbul. Walk down through the cemetery and make sure to see the mosque. The mosaics at the historic Chora are gorgeous. There are also shops with fun jewelry near Chora.
Amazing place!. I have never seen better tiles in my life. You should definitely see this beautiful little church if you are in Istanbul and a history fan like me.
splendid. fantastic mosaics throughout. marvellous beautiful creations. The church can be a little hard to find so follow the crowds.The transport system in Istanbul is excellent so just get the bus.

stunning beauty. The Kariye Museum is in a peaceful setting about 20 minutes cab ride from the historic center of Isatanbul. Our visit was one of the highlights of our trip! The church is ancient and filled with beautiful and well-preserved mosaics. We spent about 90 minutes gazing, photographing, and marveling. The audio guide was also very good and worthwhile.

Fabulous mosaics. The mosaics in this church were really quite stunning. Their creators were able to put expressions on the faces of their subjects by just using coloured tiles. The gold coloured ones were spectacular. We managed to master the bus system to get there quite cheaply without a taxi fare. There is no cafe inside the museum complex and you can't leave and come back on the same ticket, but there is a good cafe in front of the church.
Gorgeous. This is worth the taxi ride to see the gorgeous mosaics. I would be helpful to buy a book or read in your travel book the history behind it and what the mosaics represent.

wonderful place. I was in Istanbul last year and visited Chora Museum. This is one of the wonderful places which I strongly recommend to see for everyone traveling to Istanbul. The mosaics and frescoes from the last period of the Byzantine painting (14th century) are beautiful.

Beautiful !. Take the time to go here.....you won't regret it. Beautiful...ethereal, and breathtaking. There was a guy posing as a security guy hassling a tourist...the museum guys immediately wrestled him down & the police were there within minutes.....Just made you feel so safe...........and most importantly...the mosaics are incredible
Don´t miss. Very small but very beautiful place. Its a must and I liked very much.It is located in a pacific place, with a good coffee nearby.

My favourite highlight in Istanbul!. This church was a one of the best surprises during my stay in Istanbul. Usually people go for the most popular historical sites – Haghia Sophia, Topkapi Palace and the Blue Mosque, and The Cora Church easily could be missed. It is included in the Museum Pass Istanbul for 72 hours which costs 72 TL with a single entry to 9 museums - Haghia Sophia, Topkapi Palace plus the Harem Apartments, Archaeological Museum, Mosaics Museum, Museum for the history of Science & Technology in Islam and Museum of Islam Arts. When using this card, bear in mind that The Cora Church is closed on Wednesdays.The church is a bit far from the main attractions but is still very reachable. To get to the church we took a taxi from Sultanahmet which cost 25TL and we asked the taxi driver for the price in advance so that we avoided some unpleasant surprises when it came time for payment. The journey was about 20 minutes and it was also an excellent way to see the walls that ringed old Constantinople. All images from the mosaics and frescoes are amazing and it is difficult to have a favourite here. They also are very unusual such as the one with the Virgin Mary with the little Christ in her tummy, or seeing Christ dragging Adam and Eve out of their tombs. Notice that all works are from almost exactly the same date as the work of Giotto in Italy, and as one of the guide books says, they have the same spirit of life and reality, so typical of the dawn of the Renaissance. The audio guide (10TL) was quite good. The artists of this church were storytellers; there are amazing stories to follow around and it is important to have an audio guide with you. To me personally, the story of the childhood of Virgin Mary as well as her parents, Anne and Joachim, is the most beautiful story here. The mosaics with the motives of The Virgin first seven steps as well as the Virgin caressed by her parents are fascinating: these images of the three of them as a family are superb and can hardly be seen in other churches’ walls.
Amazing mosaics. This small out of the way church has some of the most fabulous mosaics I've ever seen. Grab a book that explains the scenes in the mosaics, and be astounded.

History of Jesus. The story of Jesus told in mosaics is out of this world.Don't miss Asitane restaurant next door.it serves original ottoman dishes that are memorable, especially their stuffed quince.

Worth the Trip. My favorite historic site in the Istanbul area (which says a great deal). Magnificent, well-preserved frescoes, and a great audio tour. Definitely worth the cab ride from old Sultanahmet. I think we paid 20 lira for the ride - make sure you settle on the price up-front. Try to go around lunch time and enjoy excellent dining at Asitane next door - an historic experience in itself.

The best Byzantine mosaics in Istanbul. The Chora Church has the best Byzantine mosaics in Istanbul. A guide guide of Biblical stories would make the journey through the church even more meaningful. There is a great deal of early Christian history and theology depicted on the walls and overhead. The frescoes though are once again in need of some attention. The volume of tourists unfortunately is not always beneficial to such artwork. It is well worth the trek out towards Edirne Kapi to see this church. While you are out there if you have the time, go along the inside of the wall down towards the Golden Horn. It is worth the adventure.

If You Only Visit One Church. Simply the most magnificent mosaics and frescoes in a city full of amazing Byzantine art. Best way there and back is by taxi, and you can even choose a time for the taxi to come pick you up, as sometimes it's hard to find a return ride. There's also a lovely Ottoman restauarant next door, Asitane, so you can make it a half-day trip.

Do not miss! It IS easy to get to.. First thing...In my opinion, the distance from the touristy part of Istanbul and accessibility of the Chora Church is overrated. All you need to do is get used to the train/ metro system. We managed to go to this gem as part of our 3 and a half day stay in Istanbul. Second thing.... I don't think that you need to be an art lover to love this gem! The mosaic work, the restoration and the overall atmosphere humbles you.Third... get the museum passHow did we get there? 1. We took the tram from Karakoy to Topkapi (note: this is not the Topkapi palace, but the Topkapi neighborhood/ station, which is 6-7 stops after Sultanahmet/ Topkapi). 2. We then took the metro from Topkapi to Edirnekapi. This is the neighborhood where the Chora Church is located.3. After this it was a 10 minute walk along the walls to get to the Chora Church. Our "offline" map let us down...but a kind lady took us right to the lane that leads to the museum. Also remember, the locals know this as the Kariye Museum.Inside: The museum wasn't too crowded.. which turned out to be good for us. We bought the audio tour guide; again, very impressed with the content. The mosaics are beautifully maintained - keep in mind, the first construction happened during early 5th century. We spent around 2.5 hours there. The highlight for me was the series called "the life of Mary".Outside: There are a couple of restaurants outside the museum. We did not go to the highly rated Asitane, instead went to the open-air restaurant outside the exit of the museum (Pembe Kosk). There are the typical tourist traps...shops that sell "genuine Turkish souvenirs" (made in China) at ridiculous prices. There was a watercolor artist outside who had some lovely paintings (made by his father?). He brought down the price of the painting... but it being our last day in Istanbul, I decided not to buy...still regret it.

Well kept secret!. The church is hidden in some backstreets. Its a little tricky to find. I was fooled by the minaret and the crescent on its dome, not having known that it was converted to a mosque at one point in history.However, as with anywhere else in Istanbul, if you have a few words of Turkish, people are very friendly and helpful and always ready to direct you.The mosaics and frescoes are absolutely breath-taking. Their vividity and colour astonished me, as the church dates to the 6th century. The audio guide was very useful, it was great to have some background on the fabulous art we saw.There were lots of friendly stray cats stretched out in the summer sunshine in the church grounds who were very appreciative of a bit of fuss.We got to the church by taking a tram to Erdinekapi. If you need to change at Topkapi as we did, you will need to buy another token.A trip to Istanbul would be lacking without a visit here!

Worth the cab ride. This is just an amazing place for the best religious mosaics. It is a little off the beaten path if you are spending most of your time in the Sultanahmet and Bazaar districts as we did but it is a 15 minute 25-30 Turkish Lira cab ride from there to the western walls where Chora is. It can get a little crowded but still worth the trip. You will get a crick in your neck from looking up at the ceilings and walls and I took my binoculars which really helped bring some of the intricate figures to life. I was able to fit this in to a 3 day Istanbul itinerary. I will try to post a trip report explaining how we did all the major attractions including Chora.
