On the way back, we walked to the old city walls that feature so prominently in the siege and subsequent fall of Constantinople in 1453. A great feeling to be able to climb up the wall. Then we walked down from there for about 15-20 minutes to the Golden Horn Ferry pier and rode the 25 minute ferry back to Eminou which was a nice little bonus. Don't miss it if you like this type of historical, architectural, artsy stuff.
Chora church. Amazing! Learned so much about ancient history. Part of our tour. Credo tours are terrific and sites were w'll spaced.

Beyond Beautiful. The frescoes and mosaics are absolutely out of this world. I could have spent hours going over them all.... set aside a little extra time to really enjoy the craftsmanship and attention to detail.....Well worth the trip for anyone interested in ancient art and religious art.

Absolutely worth getting there. This is a small gem, a bit away from the historical center of Istanbul, but worth the trip. Especially the different styles in the different parts of this place are fascinating: from the austerity of mosque, over the mural paintings as you would find them in Cappadocia, till the golden and shiny mosaics.Some shops and cafe/restaurants on the small place in front of it.

Church we missed!!!!!. We walked for hours throughout the city to get to this Church only to find it closed on Wednesdays and we knew that a few days before but forgot. We did get to see the ouside gardens and a quick glance of the inside. This is well worth the visit - look it up on Google - it is not usually mentioned as Turkey Site to see but I believe it is probably one of the best. Make sure you take a taxi because it is hours of walking if you go the route outside the wall as we did. However, the district wherein we walked was most interesting - local life - no tourism whatsoever - also well worth doing if you are up to it.
Chora Church. Outstanding mosiacs. It shouldn't be missed; however, it was very difficult to find as it is away from other tourist attractions and the very few people spoke English in the area.

How come we haven't visited before?. We have been to Istanbul many times and also lived there many years ago, but only found this little treasure on our last visit.It is beautiful, the artwork is stunning and the history of the little church is fascinating. If you miss it you are missing a memorable experience. Also the walk there or back is through some interesting non tourist areas so you get a glimpse of day to day Istanbul!

A lesser known place of interest. We bought a 72 hour Istanbul Museum card. This was one of the listed sites to visit. We got contradictory advise on how to get there and probably the easiest is by taxi but where is the fun in taking the easiest option?! It is also confusing as the Church is known by a number of names including St Saviour Church. We caught a local bus from the bus station at Eminonu. You have to get off when you see the fortified city walls. Chora Church is signposted to the right from there. It is an amazing place - very different from the mosques and museums that we had already visited. Beautiful Byzantine mosaics and frescoes adorn the walls and colours are still vibrant despite their age. We got the impression that this little gem was a little 'off the beaten tourist track' and was therefore quieter than many of the other tourist sights. It is a little gem of a church worthy of the effort to get there. Photography is permitted without the use of flash. Stunning results can be obtained due to the close proximity of the pictures

The frescoes tell a stroy. The Chora Church was a substitute mosque when the Hagia Sofia was closed on the day we took a walking tour of Istanbul. What a lucky exchange! We had a wonderful guide who related the bible stories told through the frescoes. And the variations n the marble covering the walls was alone worth the visit. Couldn't stop taking pictures.

Little Gem. A lot of tourists miss it because it is out of the way, but combine it with the Theodosian Walls ( a good restored section a short walk up the hill) and you've got it. These are some of the best mosaics anywhere and it is absolutely beautiful. Don't go to Istanbul and miss this.

Overrated. It was a fine Byzantine church, but really not worth the effort to get out there. It certainly does not deserve to be the best ranked in Istanbul. Only takes about 30 minutes. If you do go, the pink pavilion across the way as good food/prices.

Hidden Jewel. This was a perfect last stop for us on a long day of sightseeing, with very few other visitors making it more peaceful and easier to observe all the wonderful mosaics, construction, and setting. There is an open-air restaurant next door which is also a good stop for lunch or refreshment.

World class Byzatine mosaics and frescoes. This church features in every handbook on Byzatine art as it is one of the most important monuments of the period. It was commissioned by Theodore Metochites, one of the top officials of the Byzatine Empire, and features some of the finest mosaics after Aghia Sophia. The fresco of Chirst's descent into the Underworld is easily the best surviving Byzatine painting. The best way to reach this church is by taxi. Other sights within walking distance include the Great Wall and Sinan's Mihrimah Mosque.

Please take time to visit!. Please make time in your trip to head out to this church. It's out of the way from the other main tourist attractions (we took a combination of buses/trolleys to get out there), but it's worth your time. It was originally constructed back in the 4th century and has some amazing frescoes on the interior that are very well preserved. It's not very large, but it is one of the best Byzantine churches I have seen. Because it is so far out of the way, it's not usually very crowded, so you have plenty of time to browse the mosaics. I would definitely bring a guide book as there aren't guided tours or brochures explaining what you're seeing.

Out of the way but definitely worth the trek. There's no easy way to get here. Your best bet is either via taxi or an organized tour. We walked from the Blue Mosque which allowed us to see many other sights included Suleyman Mosque, the Valens Aquaduct and the Great Wall. The nearest metro stop is close to a kilometre away. The church is quite compact but the mosaics are stunning. It's hard to believe they are in such great condition after all these years. Take your time to explore the church and rent an audio guide if you wish to get an in depth understanding of what is portrayed. One word of warning - as soon as you leave near the gift shop there's no returning so make sure you've done everything you wished to do. The Chora Museum is inclured in the 85 Lira museum pass. If you're going to Topaki Palace, Haiga Sofia and the archeology muesum then it makes sense to buy one.

WOW! Please go.. I was very impressed with the preservation of those mosaics and frescoes. The quantity and the quality of the work is well worth the travel. Not large but so impressive! Take the audio guides, it will explain all the details about the history that is expressed with the mosaics.

Went based on TripAdvisor, was not disappointed. After spending one day in Istanbul doing the main tourist things (Hagia Sofia, Sultan Ahmet, etc) I was back in the hotel browsing TripAdvisor to see what I missed. Kariye came up and I knew I needed to add it to my itinerary the next day! I grabbed a taxi from Taksim to Kariye and the driver knew exactly where to go, and cost me about 35 TL if I remember, it's a bit away from the main tourist area so I got a chance to see a bit more of the city as well. Tucked into a small residential neighborhood is the Church, overlooking more houses and a little city park from a hill. Surrounding the church is a tiny bit of tourism with some cafes and trinkets for sale, but nothing like the Sultanahmet old town of Istanbul of course. The church itself is rather small compared to Hagia Sofia, but the amount of artwork that is perfectly intact is amazing! Almost every single surface (walls, ceilings) has beautiful Christian artwork in an amazing state of preservation. Well worth the visit to take in all of the history and get away from the hustle and bustle of Sultanahmet and Taksim. I walked the surrounding streets a bit when I was done and took in all of the sights of this side of town, and was easily able to pick up another taxi once I made my way back to a main street.

Don't miss!. The Chora Church was originally constructed during the 4th Century AD. and has gone through many changes throughout its history. It is not a very large Byzantine Church, but the interior is magnificent. It contains beautiful mosaics and frescoes which have been restored. At the time I went, it was not very crowded so it was nice to take my time and take in the beauty of the church. Although it was a bit of a walk from the Sultanahmet area, seeing the neighborhoods, Roman aqueducts and other small churches along the way made the day an amazing experience.

MOSAICS ORTODOX CHURCH. All mosaics are quite well preserved. There is a huge number of them. The church is a little far from the city center so I recomend to visit it just if you are going to stay more than 3 days. You will need time to see the lively city. You can go there by tram from the city center (20 minutes) and then you have to walk about 15 minutos more. It´s easy because you can walk following the ancient wall towards the church. It is a little scary but it is safe.

Worth it if have time, but beware of taxi drivers. The mosaics are stunning and worth it if you have time to go out that way. Unfortunately, the easiest way to get there is by taxi and drivers know this. There are plenty of good taxi drivers, but enough bad ones who like to target these tourist area. We got this latter type the other day. I have been here long enough to know what to do, but want to let those who might not know be ready. As soon as you get in, check the meter. It should start at 2.95 and increase in small increments. If it jumps by more than 2TL, ask the driver to pull over immediately. Say "dur" which means stop if he pretends to not understand you. Do not let him negotiate or anything. If he keeps driving, roll down your window and start yelling "police." He will stop. Hand him a 5 (or nothing as we did) and walk away briskly.

Great but a distance from other sights. This is a small, beautiful and ornate church, however it is quite a distance away from the main Istanbul sights so if you're only in town for a few days, I'd probably give it a miss. We walked there, it took over 90mins from the Blue Mosque, so definitely take a cab.

A must see!. One of the most unique and important collection of Byzantine art, especially relating to Virgin Mary. It is some distance from the other attractions but well worth a trip. Note that your ticket allows only one entry. So do not leave museum until you are fully done. You won't be allowed back in as my husband found out when he went out to get some fresh air.

Not to be missed. Chora Church is a small Christian church near the old walls of Istanbul. It's a bit off the main sites (e.g. Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque) so visiting requires a special trip. The church is covered in two sets of frescos, one telling the story of Jesus and the other of his mother Mary. The frescoes are amazing and should not be missed.
don't miss. a gem of a church. one of the few left intact, now well restaured and turned into museum. take the bus to Draman (last stop) and after 100m you are there. a must for an avid traveller

try to go earlier in the day. we were running out of time and got there with half an hour to spare (by taxi i might add as it seemed confusing how to get there otherwise). It was definately worthwhile. Could have easily stayed there a lot longer however it was closing. If you want to admire and take some good photos and not study them in detail, i recommend about an hour to 1&1/2 hrs for this church. The mosaics are definately in better condition and more lushious in colouring as they haven't previously been covered over like at Ayasofya (even though Ayasofya is a must). Even my highly non religious husband could remember views of stories from the walls. Great detail/artist.
Not worth the hike.. Just like Ravenna. Too much hype about mosaics that haven't been well maintained. It's just not worth it, if your time is limited.

A must for mosaic lovers. If you love mosaics, and aren't mosaicked out after Aya Sofia and other old churches, this one is spectacular. But you should have a guide book, or a guide, to explain them. (They are mostly scenes from the life of Mary.) The best remaining ones are on the not-too-far-away ceiling

Difficult to get to but great!. We decided to go to the Chora church by public transport from sultanahmet area. I couldn't be bothered to get a taxi, as I heard so much about scams! Well, after getting an istanbul card. ( you can use one card for 2 people) then went to Eminou by tram. From there we walked to the bus station. ( walk under the bridge and walk for 2 minutes. Then we had to wait for either 28 or 90 bus. The buses have their stands but they were not well explained but luckily 28 arrived on time ( stop closest to the road). The stop for chora church is Edinerakapi? anyways you can see the sign for the church as you drive past, then it's the stop. You walk for another 5 minutes then ta da! The church has amazing mozaics. Outside is also quite nice, as the tiles are much cheaper than the centre ( it was 5 lira per tile!). It is also included in Istanbul museum card! Walking through the Fatih area after visiting was also cool, just like real Istanbul I walked through in Ankara!

Historic Wonder. A liitle challenge to find but worth the effort. A Fithe Century Christian Church with Thirteenth Century mosaics. Outsanding in a city of outstanding and beautiful buildings. A great little cate opposite to drink apple tea and reflect in what yiu have seen

Fascinating. We had a guide and the information about the mosaics and the tiles of the building was fascinating. The insider info provided by the guide probably is what made the tour so great. If we would have walked through on our own...we probably wouldn't have gotten much out of it. Love all the cats that take up residence in the area.
Beautiful mosaics. Beautiful mosaics worth the challenge to find the museum which is very close to the metro stop, bringing a street map would have been a good idea
Worth a visit!. Such an amazing church with it's Byzantine mosaics and the beautiful garden. The mosaics are stunning and beautiful restored.

A Must-See Jewel. The church is small and out of the way in a remote part of the city but don't let this put you off. The interior mosaics & frescoes are very, very special, quite beautiful. Well worth making a diversion for. If you then feel peckish, the excellent Asitane Restaurant next door will round off the trip.
Worth making a trek for. Best mosaics and Byzantine church paintings ever seen. The taxi ride was fuully justified by the magnificent sights.

Don't Miss this Museum!. Away from all the tourist sites this is worth the visit if you like art, architecture and history. Plan for at least half the day to explore the amazing mosaics, paintings and architecture. Be sure to get the audio guide as it will explain everything. The mosaics are unbelievable - far better than Hagia Sofia. There is a small book/gift shop inside. Grounds outside are nice too. There were several stands outside selling various touristy items which we ignored.We took the bus because the public transportation is excellent in Istanbul but you can get a taxi to take you as well.

Worth a visit. It has nothing much to offer. But what it has worth enough, and quite older than the other attractions. Not so crowded area, and have a good and relaxing caffe near by it. The inner working in the museum is rare and splendid
kariye a must see!. gorgeous small church with gold intact mosaics, including pregnant women! story of birth and childhood of Mary, among other amazing scenes

Beautiful Church wonderful mosaics. Don't miss Chora church. You have the most beautiful mosaics telling the history of Jesus family. In front of the church there is a nice square where you can have a coffe or drinks.
not many people and better than Sophia. Not many people, incredible tiles of Mary.... great history .... hiking the old wall is only 2 blocks away
a gem. an exquisite gem - very much worth the trip - takes only about 20 minutes to see the whole thing. very authentic, untouristy neighborhood. take the tram

The most spectacular pictorial mosaics I have ever seen.. I am not even Christian, and I found the 14th Century mosaics depicting the life of Jesus in this church to be spectacularly beautiful and inspirational. It is well worth the trouble to get there. Definitely get an audio guide. And go look at the Justinian Wall while you are in that part of town.

A must see in Istanbul if you like mosaics. This was probably the best art in Istanbul. The mosaics are exquisite.
Although you will probably need to take a taxi there, it's only about a 15 minute ride from the Galata Bridge and the round trip taxi fare by meter was only about 30 TL with tip. Probably more if you are starting and ending in Sultanahmet
beautiful. don't miss. it's not visited on lots of group tours but insist and find one or go yourself but never miss it.
For Art Lovers. I recommend this place to all Art Lovers and to those who like to explore the city and meet the less tourist neighborhoods.
Nice old Church. Was there last December with a group of friends. It is nice place to visit but difficult to find because there is no train or tram pass neer it.

Superb, if you like this sort of thing. I think this is the best attraction in Istanbul. It is a little bit out of the way, but not too difficult to find. However, it is what it is: an old building with mosaics and frescoes. If you like this sort of thing, like I do, then this is not to be missed. If this isn't your thing, then you might as well save yourself the hassle of getting there and skip it altogether

Worth the taxi ride to the Chora - beautiful church. Beautiful frescoes - bring a guide book that describes the paintings. You can also walk to the city walls, but to get the top you need to walk up what looks like a ladder built into the stone. We had to get back to meet some relatives, so didn't get a chance to climb to the top.Admission is part of the Istanbul Museum pass. Getting the pass allows you to skip the lines at Topkapi Palace and Aya Sofya. It also gives entry to the Mosaic Museum which was much better than I had expected.

Worth the trip. The Chora Church is not in the immediate tourist area, and as a result a lot of travellers miss it. We were lucky enough to be taken there by friends who live in the city, so we didn't have to worry about the logistics of getting there.The Church is set in a small garden, and you can rent an audio guide that provides the basic information about the history of the church and the beautiful mosaics and scenes depicted on the walls that have miraculously survived through the ages.Go if you have enough time, it's worth the trip.

Amazing if you like mosaics/frescos. Visited due to the high tripadvisor recommendations (and the Istanbul Museum Pass). Not disappointed. The church is small and a bit hard to find--but if you like ancient mosaics and frescoes, it is amazing. We actually spent nearly two hours there. Highly recommend the audio guide as I don't think I would appreciate the mosaics otherwise. The City walls are nearby so you can see them also during your visit. Cute neighborhood and you are far away from the busy tourist district so a bit more real Istanbul than other sights.

Beautiful mosaics. Chora church is an out of the way gem. The mosaics are well preserved and probably the best display of byzantine mosaics in Istanbul. You can get up close and touch them. We paid 15TL to get in, and didn't need a guide. The church is small, about 4 rooms and could be seen in half an hour or less. Also the turkish tiles out upon exiting we're some of the cheapest we found in Istanbul, I regret not buying them there.

Fantastic frescoes in a hidden church. It's a little far from Sultanahmet, where most of the attractions are clustered...but the frescoes at this church are better preserved than at the Hagia Sophia. Couple it with lunch at Asitane restaurant, and there's your perfect afternoon!
Scenic & ancient. Wonderful mosaics telling the Bible Story.. a bit of a trek to get there on public transport so take a taxi if you can!

Must Visit. if you are in istanbul you have to visit Chora Church!.it is little difficult to get there.But if you catch a taxi you can do that very easily!And it is complitly worth it to visit!it is a must see place!
Wonderful Mosaics. Wonderful mosaics of Jesus Christ and Virgin Mary life. It is not so big and is not dificult to arrive from tran.

Amazing!!! Would come back again. Although we need to catch a taxi to get to this museum, it is all worth it. The mosaics in the museum is amazing and some of the paintings in the wall is lovely. It is worth having a guide or buy the guide book so that it will provide you some more background about each scenary. Once the tour groups are gone, you will have the museum to yourself and you can take pictures (without flash) to your heart content.

Good example of Byzantine architecture. A more intimate, and obviously less grandiose example of Byzantine architecture in Istanbul (the crown jewel being the Hagia Sophia of course). Amid the impressive Ottoman artifacts, this one stands out as a good example of a more ancient Byzantine architecture. A cute little church, with some impressive mosaics & frescos, most of which are reasonably intact. Interesting to look up and spot the various biblical stories represented pictorially. It's a bit beyond old town, so you'll have to take a cab/tram depending on where you are.Recommended if you have extra time, and are interested in something different and older than the Ottoman period buildings.

What a lovely church...absolutely beautiful!. Very glad we visited the Chora Chruch. We went 'under our own steam' and found the frescos, mosaics and Icons stunning ..I would even say 'a must see' on any Istanbul visit

Stunning. A little hard to get to, but well worth it if, like myself, you love mosaics. The walls are covered with the most beautiful mosaics. Bring or buy a book, or get a guide so you aren't just looking at pictures blankly.

A gem of a church hidden away in the outer reaches of Istanbul. Rarely will you see a jewel of comparable beauty in Europe, a church dating from early Byzantine years modified with mosaics and frescos in the mid-fourteenth century to depict the geneology and life of Christ. Although converted to a mosque after the Muslim conquest in the fifteenth century, the concealment of imagery and idolatry by plastering over the mosaic decorations has meant that they are now revealed after restoration to their original form and colours. Each panel tells a story starting from the journey to Bethlehem, the presentation before King Herod and the nativity through to the temptations and, in the frescos, the last judgement. A panel above the entrance to the nave depicts the fourteenth century initiator of the remodelling, Metochites, presenting the restored church as an offering to Christ. A priceless reward for the effort to find and get to Edirnetkapi to see this gem.

Great mosaics from byzantine church. The mosaics and frescoes are beautiful and interesting, especially for Christians and those interested in early church history. I would recommend to go here before Hagia Sophia, to create an imagination about what it can have looked like there.
Hoped it would be better. I have heard about the mosaics from the Chora Church for many years, and maybe I got my hopes up, but I expected better. It is worth the trip, but don't expect too much
beautiful. beautiful frescos and mosaics. you shouldn't miss this if you're visiting istanbul. also find a good and cute guide with lots of info :)

Byzantine wonder. After seeking and viewing so many Christian artifacts/mosaics/frescos, etc. defaced and/or covered and recovered in other locales in Turkey, it was a relief to find a church (now turned museum) that shows religious art as it was. The audio tape is a bit hard to follow, and you may get a crook in your neck looking up, but the pictures on the ceiling are representative of Bible stories so that illiterate worshipers could see and understand the way that God had worked his will with His people. Also the surrounding merchants have souvenirs that are more easily accessible and are commensurate in price, quality and selection to the busier, more crowded venues like the Grand Pazar, etc. You can take a bus from downtown, but with traffic jams and construction, don't hesitate to call for a taxi as it will wend you up and up to the Kariye location. On the way down you may just see aquaducts from Roman times. Well worth the fare!

Tiny wonder of the Byzantine era!. This Church is an authentic jewel. If you appreciate history, architecture and art, you have to go there! Although it is far for most popular attractions (its name actually means: "Outside the walls"), I takes you a couple of minutes in a taxi cab. The collection of frescos and mosaics of the Byzantine era are the second surpassed only by Hagia Sophia, but, in fact, I like Chora´s better because of their density. An interesting fact is that scenes displayed in some frescos regarding Holy Mary's life are so old, that these scenes are in fact no longer in the Bible. Audio guide is very recommended so you can have a detailed explanation of every mosaic. The church is really small so you can spend fair time listening to each mosaic explanation. Do not miss the mosaic of Christ with Theodore Metochites (the church creator) presenting a model of his church, it's a nice rarity. CLOSED ON WEDNESDAY and MÜZE card is admitted, you can buy it there (http://www.muze.gov.tr/en) highly recommended if you have time to visit all attractions included.

Closed on Wednesdays, but worth a return visit. Somehow we managed to miss the fact that Chora was closed on Wednesdays and turned up only to be disappointed. We took a stroll down the hill through the neighborhood and had quite the exciting adventure, seeing a movie or Turkish soap opera being made. We returned a few days later and thought that this site was a highlight. The site is small, but fantastic. I highly recommend it.

Worth the trip. The Chora Church is fascinating, and well worth the trip outside the historic core of Istanbul. I took public transportation (most guidebooks have detailed instructions with tram lines and stop names), it was easy, and took about 30 minutes.

Out of the way gem. Its a bit tough to find, but once you do find it, the experience is completely worth it, We were lucky to be able to squeeze in a visit to this Church on our last day in Istanbul and the mad rush was completely worth it to see such an ancient monument preserved so well and the paintings and the frescoes were absolutely amazing. I highly recommend a visit.
Don't miss it...... The most beautiful frescoes and mosaics.....just awesome! Have your hotel write the address out in Turkish. Our taxi driver had trouble finding it.

A wonderful experience. The place is fascinating. Only comparable to mosaics in Ravenna (Italy). Try to get there as early as possible, to be able to move freely in the church's different rooms. Take binoculars or opera glasses with you to get a better look at the magnificent mosaics covering the walls. It's worth a visit. It is better if you can read some background material before getting there

If you like mosiacs. Of course we love the "major" sites like the Blue Mosque. But if you love mosaics, Ravenna (Italy), and intimate and accessible medieval churches, you will love the Chora Church. For those of a spiritual bent, it's an easy place to feel centuries of holiness. I am not religious, but was positively gripped by the beauty and pathos of this church and its mosaics.
a small church. This Kariye museum is so small. I mean it is nice but really small. True - the mosaic work is nice. It is definitely not the highlight of Istanbul.

Best church I have ever seen in my life. The Istanbul demonstrations did not affect our trip and I must say this church-museum is the best I have seed in my life. I cannot explain how beautiful the mosaics are.

Best sample of the Byzantine period. Best sample of the Byzantine period!! Amazing!!!You have to take taxi or bus to reach, but worth it 100%.There is a small market outsidewhere you can get crafts as in the Grand Bazaar with better prices.
old. if you like looking at a old mosque its good. Long way if your walking from the Blue Mosque area, not very well signed posted
Don't Miss Chora Church. Out near the city walls, but NOT to be missed. The frescos are one of the treasures of the Christendom. You can take the Tram #1 and transfer to light rail.
Stunning! Surpassed expectations. We were very impressed with the frescoes and mozaics as had no idea they would be so wonderful. A must for every visitor to Istanbul
Must See. Grab a cab from the Hagia Sophia, it's only 20TL. The Church is incredible. You can't miss the mosaics...I wish I'd gone twice.

A must see in Istanbul. Stunning church of the Holy Savior, mosaics are exceptional and will remind you of the roots of Christianity. We liked the church and the well preserved frescoes. Definitely a worthwhile visit.

A Bit Out of the Way But Mosaically Worth It!. We visited the Chora Church based on Rick Steves' advice in his Istanbul guide book and because we sort of had the luxury of a planned float day in our schedule. Be advised that this attraction is locally known as a Mosque (even though it is now a museum), and is indicated on Istanbul maps as Kariye Cami. Rick Steves' mass transit directions sounded rather diffcult and time-consuming, so we chose to take a taxi directly there, which was about the equivalent of $40 or $50 USD from the Galata area. The driver had no idea what the "Chora Church" was, but when we pointed to the name of "Kariye Cami" on the map he understood exactly where it was. The church is absuolutely the finest example of mosaics I have ever seen. The church is quite small, smaller than expected, but the entire inside of every wall and all the ceilings are covered with exquisite mosaics. I am not an expert by any means, but seeing these were really a spectacular experience for me and well worth the trip. An hour was all that was needed to see it all at a very lesiurley pace. There is not much at all in the way of restaurants or shopping outside a one-block perimeter, and it is quite out of the way, but if you appreciate mosaics, this is a must-see.
important. this is a very important historic site for christian belief&religion. also if you interest with byzantium history, you should visit this small but impressive museum..

Do not miss this church!. The Chora is away from the historical areas but definitely must be seen when visiting Istanbul. The church is filled with magnificent mosaics and frescos. The setting is just beautiful.

Do Not Miss This !. Saw the Topkapi Palace, Hagia Sophia, Basilica Cistern, Dolmabahçe Palace and the Blue Mosque? Don't think your sightseeing trip to major places in Istanbul is complete until you have seen the Chora Church. A visit here will also give short duration travellers an opportunity to see another part of modern Istanbul, which we miss out in the old city area.While Hagia Sophia is grand, this smaller church beats it in style when it comes to well preserved intricately made paintings. If not with a guide, an audio tour is highly recommended to understand the stories behind the frescoes. Keep aside 1.5 hours atleast to fully absorb the stunning artwork, the finest of Byzantine times, at the Chora Museum. Please note : Museum Pass is valid here. Another reason to not miss the Chora Church.

Hard to find by yourself, but worth it. We walked there from by the Blue Mosque - about 6 miles, and it was hard to find. Friendly people helped a lot. The site, though, is well preserved, and the information at hand is reasonable.

Mosaic Heaven. One thing is that you have to ask the taksi drivers for "Kariye" because they don't know Chora and getting there via public transit would've been rather challenging. Otherwise, the church was absolutely lovely. There was a nice garden on the grounds and clean W/C. The church itself was filled with incredible mosaics and frescos. And it's included on the 72 hr 72 TL Museum Pass!

Excellent mosaics...that will have your neck hurting!. This place was one of our favorite sites in Istanbul. We spent over 2 hours looking at all the mosaics both on the walls and ceilings. It must have taken years and years to create each; don't know how they did it! We then had lunch at the restaurant right outside the main door, then walked a few blocks to look at the ancient wall that surrounded Istanbul. Getting there by tram was very inexpensive. Overall, a trip to this church is a must see!
A Must See. This place has the most amazing work of art on the walls and roof, a must see in Istanbul. The mosaics are wonderful.

Not in the Historical area, but should be seen.. We took a cab to the Chora Church (20Lira going, 30Lira returning), but it could probably be reached by public transportation for less. It is well worth the travel time and money to see this 11th century Byzantine jewel. The church is small, but the mosaics and frescos of the life of Mary and Jesus are unique and very well preserved. It may be because when the church was turned into a mosque the art was plastered over. Now restored, the church is a museum.

Unique. There are probably fewer than a dozen churches in the eastern Mediterranean region where it's possible to see such an extensive and well preserved set of frescoes and mosaics--with the latter much more rare. The details are wonderful, such as the nest of fledgling birds in the mosaic of the annunciation to St. Anne. I wish we had brought a small pair of binoculars. Tour groups--even small ones--can create bottlenecks so be prepared to be patient and to change location accordingly. One surprise was that the little bookstore in the church offered not only good materials on this church but also the sort of high quality postcards of Hagia Sophia that I couldn't find at Hagia Sophia itself.

Mosaics!. First thing, beware of taxis to and from this site. Their goal in life is to rip off tourists. It happened to us.We used our Rick Steve's Istanbul Guidebook as an excellent guide through the church and explaining many of the scenes depicted by the mosaics.Give your neck a good stretch before entering this site. You will be craning your neck upwards with your mouth gaping open for the better part of an hour while studying and admiring the wonderfully perserved (in most cases) Christian mosaics. There is a mosaic shop that sells high quality beautiful mosaics right before you get to the church. Much more worth the money than what is offered in regular souvenir shops. There is also a cafe right outside the exit of the museum.
Gorgeous. We're not Christian, but you don't have to be to appreciate the gorgeous art on the walls of this church. Just exquisite.

Must be visited. This museum / historical church is located in Edirnekapi province of Istanbul. Actually it's not in the heart of historical area (Sultanahmet). It was built in 6.th century but was renovated in last 50 years. It'a typical Byzantine architecture. It's area is small but almost every wall is decorated with gorgeous mosaics. You have to pay a fee for the entrance (15 Turkish Lira = 8 $). As a result i highly recommend everyone to visit this museum / church who likes to see the Byzantine culture and wants to feel roots of Christianity in Istanbul

Kariye Museum (The Chora Byzantine Church). On June 7th, while staying in Istanbul, I took a walk across the old part of the city to visit the Byzantine Church of Chora. A beautiful walk it was. The church building is amazing, with all domes and halls still standing. Most halls still have the original religious imagery and tile work. One can see the influence Byzantine churches had on the architecture of Ottoman Mosques in Istanbul. The garden was quiet and filled for flowers, it felt like a place of meditation. The picture I took from inside-dome in the main hall of the church.

Stunning!. Pronounced "Core-Ah," this church of the Holy Savior is an unbelievable surviving structure from the Byzantine era. The church was re-built in 12th century. Yes, I said "re-built, as the original was built in early 5th century! In the 16th century it was converted into a mosque and the many fine mosaics and frescoes were PAINTED OVER! Today, they are uncovering the ancient artworks underneath, which are nothing short of stunning!

Magical, but a bit overrated. I really liked the church - the mosaics are simply splendid. I don't quite think this is at the same level of other monuments in Istanbul and it is somehow impractical to traverse the city to get there. Combine it with a lunch at the ottoman restaurant next door though and it is well worth it
Extraordinary early Christian church. Old and gorgeous mosaics, reminding us that many of the early roots of Christianity were in what is today Turkey.

worth the effort. take a taxi as it is a bit of a schlep and out of the way BUT it is a little gem with beautiful mosaics and frescos - much more on a human scale than some of the other bigger churches. You can get there when you take the Hop on Hop off bus but the Turks know it as Kariye Museum and nobody we tried to ask new what The Chora Church was! there is a very good restaurant ( dont know the name but well known for ottoman cuisine) near by and a cafe and souvenier shop under the trees. LOVELY VISIT.
Chora Church. wonderful. Tip: go in the late afternoon when the tourist buses have left; we walked down to the ferry dock and took a ferry back

Chora church. Historical Christian church. Small with well preserved frescos.
Local lunch at a nearby restaurant was good.

Just amazing. This place is wonderful. It's a Istanbul must !
You need to have some kind of interest for painting, mosaics or history in general unless you will do as a most of stupid tourist and take picture without even look where you are.

the Chora Church you have to see when you are in Istanbul. When you visit Istanbul you have to see the Chora Church/ museum. I thank the Turkish people making a museum from it. Beautiful history, See the old mosaic, The history of the Virgin Mary. It is all amazing. If you travel low budget; just take the tram to the stop nearby the old historic wall. Have a cheap drink and food at the mainstreet near the wall. See the restored old wooden houses near the church. After visiting; walk downstairs the streets to the water side. You will walk in the small streets where the Turkish people live.
Beautiful. Well worth the extra effort it takes to get there. Taxis are inexpensive in Istanbul so definitely a worthwhile visit.

Stunning. We nearly did not visit as it is a bit out of the way and we had to get a taxi but it is a MUST SEE. stunning mosaics of the life of Christ. In a city of so many beautiful paces this is one of the best Aparantly the restaurant next door is very good too.

Excellent but a bit of a challenge to get to. Do yourself a favor and take one of the many buses along the Fevzi Pasa Cd to the Mihrimah Sultan Mosque and then walk downhill a few blocks. We made the mistake of following Lonely Planet's advice to take the Golden Horn Ferry to Balat and then "walk along the city walls." Well, we never could find a direct route and it is quite a long and vertical walk from Balat (we ended up having to take a taxi, who tried to rip us off).

Relax inside..time tunnel. A very good preserved example of Byzantine art from 6th century,kariye museum's mosaics&ferescos were closed with wood after it was turned to a mosque.So,they were kept well and in 1948,it was arranged as a museum.When you are watching the details frescos,all of them tells you a story of thousand years so try to find a silent corner and relax there,you ll feel that you had a time travel.Entrance fee is 15 TL and it is closed on wednesday and easy to reach by a taxi from taksim square or any central loacation.There are also some stores and cafes around it if you like to buy some souvenirs or have some refreshment.

Beautiful frescoes are definitely worth the trip!. This church is definitely outside the main sightseeing area and we took the tram to get there. But it was worth the trip. The garden area had beautiful roses and the frescoes inside the church are amazing!!

Strictly average. We had the Museum pass and very amazed by the rave reviews on Tripadvisor.The museum is located in the Eyup area which isnt accessible by Tram or metro from where we stayed Gulhane/Sultanahmet and required bus travel which wasnt conducive with a baby stroller. So we took a taxi which worked out to be a great idea considering the relative comfort as well got dropped at the entrance.After all that effort the museum was much smaller and not as impressive as the reviews suggested, especially if one has been to the bigger museums like the Istanbul history museum. The whole round was over in less than 20 minutes.In hindsight perhaps we should have taken the audioguide or a tour guide and might have had a better experience but we didnt.The Area around was nice with some decent souvenir shops and Asitane (one of the highly rated restaurants in Istanbul). But since it was our last day in istanbul couldnt stay back for long.If you have time on your hand you could combine this with a trip to the rest of Eyup by also visiting the Eyup Mosque and the Pierre Loti viewpoint. else give it a pass and you wouldnt be missing much

A marvel in mosaic. Istanbul is a city of 15 million people, without the tourists, so depend on crowds wherever you go However, this church has crowd control, which allows for a good look before being told "to keep the line moving." The frescoes and mosaic depiction in the ceilings has been largely kept in tact and depict the assumption of Christ followed by his birth and resurrection. An interesting mosaic is of Joseph being explained to the supernatural event of a child born while he was away for six months. It depicts the reaction of many a baffled young man who needs explanation as to how this event could take place. The upshot is hand made mosaic tiles depicting these events.

Impressive. Beautiful mosaics and frescoes - so many of them it's worth getting a guidebook of some kind.
A little hard to get there so plan accordingly.

Worth the bus ride to get there. Fascinating and amazing mosaics which in part look as if they had been recently done although others are well worn. So pleased that restoration is being done. Signposted from main road where you get off the bus. People at Bus Station very helpful so was great to have a bit of an adventure.

Amazing Mosaics. Amazing mosaics! Thirteenth century Christian mosaics and frescoes are amazingly. One of the best mosaic museum with such small tiles.I have never seen mosaics like that, so much details in every mosaic picture not only in the workmanship but in their story telling as well.The location is a bit far away from the central area of old city Sultanahmet but it is quite accessible you can catch the bus from the central bus station by the Galata Bridge buses 38E, 37E and 32 get off at Edirnekapi and then bus stop are clearly labelled and walk down the hill from the bus stop and turn left at the bottom and then about 5 minutes walk to the museum.Buy a museum pass when you are in Istanbul for Kariye Museum as well as many other museums within a 72 hours period.

Byzantine unspoiled legacy. Chora Church was high on my list to see after Haghia Sophia and Little Aya Sophia - all early 1st century masterpieces. Chora needs to be seen with an understanding of the frescoes, mosaics and design of the church itself. Magnificent and so glad that this has been established and is supported as a museum of its own.

Some amazing mosaics. We went there by taxi (15TL) and afterwards walked to the ferry boat (about a half hour stroll downhill). It's only a small church but fascinating if you're into religious artwork of that period.

If beautiful now imagine before.... Not as crowded that Hagia Sophia and you have the frescoes and mosaics meters away!! Take your time and make the visit twice as you have different frescoes on every vision angle. I walked also towards the wall and climbed it, a very nice view of the Golden Horn.
Great Find. Lovely frescoes and the only church that tells the story of the Virgin Mary before the birth of Christ. Well worth going to visit.

Must see. A cab ride from the tourist center is a wonderful small church with fabulous mosaics and frescoes that go way back. i would definitely recommend it to anyone interested in early Christian religion. Go with a guide who can explain the meaning of the works of art.

Beautiful frescos. Be careful of the taxis coming back. They charged double over the trip to Chora Church. Lots of tour buses so I guess they thought they could charge more. We walked 1 block up to the main street and found one for 18 TL

A Must See Attraction. The Church of the Holy Saviour in Chora is considered to be one of the most beautiful surviving examples of a Byzantine church. It is hidden from the busy areas of Istanbul but ask any taxi driver and they know the place. Perhaps the beauty and the ambiance of the place made it one of the most exciting place to visit while in Istanbul. Dating back from 1077–1081, this church's mosaic arts makes you feel like visiting the sistine chapel, only that it is more serene because they tried to maintain the ancient looks of the building as well as the art.Entrance fee is LR15 and you can take as much photos as you like, provided you will not use your flash.
A jewel.. While small, this little church has perhaps the best Byzantine mosaics in Istanbul. Away from city center but worth the taxi ride.

Beautiful. Chora Church was a little bit out of the way from our hotel in Sultanahmet near the Hagia Sophia, but it was well worth the cab ride. There were beautiful mosaics in this church as well as beautiful architecture.

Fantastic. Almost didn't go, because out of the way. Glad we took the time. It is a must see/don't miss. Just beware of the taxi stand next to it. They want triple $10 price to take you back to center city. Two block walk to main street and hail taxi will save you $20.

Blast from the past. This museum/church is so old that you feel like you are in the past while you're inside it. The mosaics are incredible and well preserved! There are audio guides available in several languages, which I highly recommend using if you wish to make sense of all the mosaics. It's just the location is not very good, wish it was closer to the old city area.

The mosaics are worth the visit.. Remarkable to see the quality of rich colour and detail in these ancient mosaics which had been covered over when the church was converted to a mosque. they are still uncovering some of the mosaics but there's lots to see right now.

Amazing frescoes and mosaics. The 13th-century Christian mosaics and frescoes are amazingly expressive. I had never seen mosaics with such small tiles. The artisans were able to convey subtle emotions on the subjects faces. It's a little hard to find. You can take the ferry down the Golden Horn (Halic) and then walk up the hill, but it would be good to have planned your walking route in advance.

Beautiful Mosaics in a sweet little church. It took a short tram ride, and a very long bus ride (with confusion at the connection) to get out to this church - But the visit was well worth the time and trials to get out here. Also, the old city wall is nearby and a nice little walk to see it.

Stunning. A little tricky to find but absolutely worth it (and the locals we asked for directions were very helpful). I have never seen mosaics like it, so much detail not only in the workmanship but in their story-telling as well. The 2013 Istanbul Lonely Planet guide has a map of the interior of the church which was extremely helpful in explaining the different mosaics - I would hope that the church has a leaflet or similar which would give similar detail. Given that it is off the beaten (tourist) track, it was not busy when we visited. You can also enjoy a nice glass of apple tea or a pide in the cafe which overlooks the church.Buy a museum pass when you are in Istanbul - it gives you entry to Aya Sofya, Topkapi Palace & harem and Kariye Museum as well as many other museums within a 72 hour period, for a reduced price overall (and you beat the queues).

A little gem. If you have purchased the 72 hour museum pass ( worth doing, good value and you jump the queues) this is included. This one time church, one time mosque has some of the most beautiful Christian related mosaics which continue to be painstakingly restored. They are truly stunning. The church is small but it is well worth the visit. The location is a bit away from the central attraction area of old Istanbul but it is quite accessible - catch the bus from the central bus station by the Galata Bridge - buses 38E, 37E and 32 get off at Edirnekapi - bus stop are clearly labelled - walk down the steep hill from the bus stop and turn left at the bottom - you will see coaches parked so you'll know you're in the correct direction - about 5 minutes walk. Remember to get your bus ticket before you board the bus and part a two part ticket for the return journey, the return bus will cross the Golden Horn over one bridge before coming back to the bus station over the other. Bus station is situated at Eminonu.So absolutely no excuse for not visiting this little well hidden gem which so perfectly illustrates Istanbul's past.
Byzance. I liked anything: the museums, the people who receive us with kindness . Please, i have no time to say more
Fantastic mosaics from the late byzantine period. Get here early, the space is small, but well worth seeing. A pleasant plaza adjoins for tea, snack or lunch
Worth seeking out. Fabulous mosaics. Avoid the crowds and hordes of tourists to take in this historical building packed with lovely mosaics
Incredible mosaics.. Hard to find through windy streets but actually only short walk from metro connection to tram 1. Worth it for the preserved mosaics.
Very Beautiful. It was very nice combination of church and mosque in one building.You will just look around and could not believe your eyes that people did it with their hands.
amazing.... hard to find but once you get there you must take your time and see all of the tile work...it is stunning...
GO EARLY before the rest of the tourists. we had a great guide who amplified from what we would have seen but didn't realize the significance. So wonderful

Spectacular mosaics and frescoes. This is one of the great treasures of Istanbul. It can be easily reached from Sulanahmet by public transportation. Take the tram to Topkapi, the light rail to Edirnekapi, then a short walk. No need for an expensive cab or tour. The acoustic guide will make the visit more informative and you can linger with each image far longer than the tour groups would allow.
Best done with a guide or with audio. Byzantine frescoes and mosaics are outstanding. Much more enjoyable if you have a knowledgeable guide talking you through what you are seeing.

fantastic beyond words -. This should always be on everybody's. It is by the land walls of the city and in that manner you have two great places to visit. The Church was in service on May 29th 1453 when Mehmet II's army pierced the city walls using the largest canons of the era. Constantine XI died or disappeared nearby. If you are a lover of religious art this little church "of the country" or chora has to be visited.

Church of St. Saviour in Chora, Istanbul. This impressive church is also known as the Kariye Museum. It is a Byzantine church with extraordinary late 14th century Byzantine frescoes and mosaics, considered as among the most significant in the world. Many have considered the mosaics of the whole bible on its walls and ceilings the best in the world. This is truly a remarkable museum!

WONDERFUL MOSAICS. WONDERFUL MOSAICS BUT HARD TO GO THERE.
The area is a bit strange but the old church is located in the middle of a lovely garden where you can have a quiet break.
excellent. the paintings and murals are wonderful given how old there were and it is though that the the workman went from there to europe to be part of the renaissance

don't miss this. Its not just the church itself which is outstanding, so is the ferry journey up the Golden Horn and walk past Theodoseus's wall going too and from the place.
Chora Church allows one a glimpse into what all the ancient churches of Turkey once looked like. Forget the ruins - this is the real deal.

Worth the trip outside the city to see!. I thought this would be like any other Church, but to my surprise it was actually quite different to any other church i've visited before! The mosaics are just beautiful and the way they covered the internal domes were really nice. It only needs about 20 minutes there so a short "sight" to see, but the great thing is nearby are the old walls of the city so you get to enjoy 2 sights at the same time. I thought it was a nice change from all the Mosques in the centre of Istanbul and to see something so different, both on the inside and out. Was fun trying to find it, its not the most sign posted place to find! Thank you Offline Google Maps :)

Very moving. The Chora church (Kariye) is an easy cab or bus ride out from the center. It is near the old Byzantine walls. The ceilings are breathtaking. The facial expressions are astonishingly real.

Unbelievably beautiful. Small old church converted to a museum. Worth the 22 TL cab ride from Sultanahmet. Gorgeous tiles, floors, paintings on the walls. Everything you see is very old and very beautiful. If you respond to art you will love this church.

Dont' Miss. The Chora Church is a don't miss. If you are a little adventuresome, take the bus like we did, holding a map and asking the driver to tell us when to get off. Don't worry, the Turks are so friendly, with no language between us, someone showed us with hands waving and fingers pointing where to get off (in a nice way) .much better way to travel! It is several blocks from the bus stop..fun to walk through the small streets. We encountered a bride and groom walking with their party after the wedding. They stopped and poised for pictures!! The church is marvelous..not on some tours, but don't miss! Some of the best frescoes and mosaics in the world! A small church packed with art. It was crowded when we went, but thinned out. Take your time. But go! It is on the 72 hour Museum Pass which includes other attractions in the city.

Amazing mosaics. Absolutely beautiful church with amazing mosaics. We travelled there from our hotel by taxi which was quite inexpensive and I think worthwhile as there is a steep walk up to the museum. This place is an absolute gem!

The Chora Church is covered in great mosaics of Christian themes.. Chora is a very well preserved church covered with great Christian-themed mosaics. It's in a quiet neighborhood of Istanbul and not too far from the ancient fortified walls so you can walk along the walls and then visit the church. You can get there by the metro.

Very interesting. We took at taxi to get there as the hotel staff said it would take too long on public transport, and getting a bus back turned into a huge issue so we again got a cab! Really interesting, not so many tourists when we were there, but still crowded.

Old mosaics and fresques. They are some of the world's best mosaics, maybe the bigges area of high quality mosaics of their time existing. Their clearness tell us so much about those biblical stories - so do the fresques as well.

Patricia E (Professor from Australia) 'The Journey is as good as the destination.'. Walking through the narrow streets - children playing - laundry hanging out windows - one feels like you're actually in the real Istanbul. The church itself was great since there were far less tourists there but I especially enjoyed the journey.

A gem. It was astonishingly beautiful, and because it is small, it felt intimate and quiet, despite the crowds. It's a little out of the way, but well worth the visit. The freshness of the frescos is jawdropping.

A beautiful experience!. The Chora Church is also known as the Kariye Museum. Originally built in the 4th Century it has gone through many changes. The current building was built in the 11th Century. It has been used as a Church, a Mosque and a museum.
Although there is not much near the museum it was worth the trip for us.

stunning mosaics. wonderful mosaics, so colourful, part of Istanbul's Byzantine past, well worth a visit. Look especially at the depiction of Christ. His eyes seem to follow you wherever you are in the church. A pity about the metal support beams which block a clear view
Worth a visit. The frescoes are fabulous. While I wouldn't put the Chora Museum as a "must see" in Istanbul, time permitting, definitely add this to your list of sights to be seen.
Number One Attraction in Istanbul For a Reason. The beautiful frescoes will inspire! A lovely, albeit expensive, giftshop too. Make sure you visit the restaurant Asitane restaurant after!

Worth the Trip. Who would have thought you could say "bigger isn't necessarily better" when it comes to a lovely, small church. The many detailed mosaics portraying Jesus' life are amazing and beautiful. The exterior of the church reflects the 11th century. There is also a nice, leaf-shaded cafe just steps from the entrance overlooking the church.It's well worth the trip out of the tourist zone. We took the two trams to get here. On our return we jumped on Bus #87 on the busy avenue Fevsi Pasa. The bus stop is a short walk from the church. You can take the bus to the base of the Ataturk bridge which gets you close to a lot of sites. We took the bus to Fatih Park, where there are many restaurants famous for cooking lamb in underground pits (buryan).

Amazing, hard to get to but this is how you do it. There is a reason this is voted number one attraction on here - this place is just amazing, the mosaics are gorgeous. Get the audio guide it is reAlly worth the money and by far the best I have come across in Istanbul. The church is a bit far out, but if you know where you are going it is 40 minutes from the church to eminonu. Take T1 tram to Topkapi,change and go to Edirnekapi on T4. When you emerge from the station keep the mosque you can see on your right and head for the town you can see between the city wall and tower. Once inside the city walls take a left, I am not sure if it is the first but there is a Bridgestone shop on the corner and another shop with a green sign. Head down this small road and take the 2 nd or 3 rd right (there is a brown sign for Kariye Museum on the corner) go to the end of that street and turn left and you are there. Seriously don't miss this off your itinerary! There are other ways to get here but I believe this is the quickest.

Very beautiful mosaics. This church was one of the best churches which I saw in Istanbul. Very beautiful mosaics all around the walls and on the roof.You need a good guide to understand the meaning of those pictures, so, just hire a local guide and he will tell you an interesting story about those mosaics.

My favorite attraction in Istanbul. Absolutely breath taking mosaics in a well preserved church and former mosque. It is also a great opportunity to get out of the touristy parts of old town and catch your breath. Be sure to check out the old city wall while you are out here as well. Catching the ferry at Ayvansaray is a cheap and interesting way to get back to the spice market and Eminonu area by cruising down the Golden Horn. I believe it runs on the half hour.

A precious little church. This church is worth the taxi trek to it. With XII/XIII century frescoes visible from the byzantine days, there is an intimacy to it that brings one back to time when it was a functioning Christian church.

"...asymmetry, instability, unrest...". Kariye MuzesiThis 12C masterpiece, for all its irregularities, is among the most beautiful Byzantine churches in the world. The exterior of the church is utterly charming seen from the shady garden in the back of the church. This, and the 11thC Kapnikarea in Athens, are my two favorite Orthodox churches, both are small, intimate architectural spaces that seem to engage the visitor on a personal level. Reams have been written about the glory of the Byzantine art in the Chora, many experts believing that the frescoes and mosaics are perhaps the greatest extent examples of Byzantine art. The crowning masterpiece of the church is the fresco called the Anastasis, or Resurrection, depicting Christ raising up Adam and Eve from their tombs at the end of time. What intrigues me about the frescos and the mosaics, many depicting the life of Mary according to the apocryphal gospel of St. James, is what the Byzantinist, Otto Demus has called the “experimental” nature of the art in the Kariye—said to look forward to the masterpieces of the Renaissance, in particular, to the later development of mannerism; the figures are said to revel in “asymmetry, instability, and unrest” and in this sense they represent Byzantine art at its most experimental, creating a new mode of expression. Make sure to rent the excellent audio program to get a complete understanding of this marvelous church. It is no wonder that Trip Advisor contributors have ranked this the number one attraction in Istanbul and that is certainly saying something with the Aya Sofya and the Blue Mosque as rivals for one’s attention. Absolutely needs to be visited.
Don't miss this. You won't see frescoes and mosaics like this anywhere! It's a gem of church with worldclass Byzantine art.

exceptional. One of the most impressing byzantine monuments in Istanbul. The mosaics and frescoes are not only artistically of significantly great quality, they also depict the deep esoteric religious philosophy of the eastern Christianity. A must-visit in any case.

Most Admired Byzantine Masaic Is Here. I like this very classic church inside which the visitors all kept very guiet while viewing on the walls the beautiful mosaic of images of the characters in the Holy Catholic Bible.

Fascinating!. We did this church as part of a larger walking tour of Byzantine sites, and it was really remarkable. The mosaics are gorgeous and the church itself is very charming. It was a bit overrun with tourists, but I'd still recommend seeing it. I'd go super early next time to beat the crowds.

Amazing !. Just a short taxi ride and you're in a different world.the mosaics are stunning and the frescoes are equally beautiful. Our only complaint was that it was rather crowded,but that's Istanbul .truly a gem!

If you like mosaics, don't miss it!. This is a small church which has gorgeous mosaics and frescoes which are fascinating to study and photograph. Try to go on a weekday as late as possible in order to avoid crowded rooms. Well worth traveling to the out-of-the-way location.
Awesome Frescoes. Amazing frescoes depicting early Christianity. The audio tour is brilliant, indeed far superior to the Hagia Sophia tour.

Different site of Istanbul with normal not touristic life. We took the ferry from Eminou towards Golden Horn and then climbed up towards the Church. We walked through streets with normal houses full of people living their normal life. Didn't see a tourist until we reached the place. So nice :)

Beautiful, but take a taxi or a tour to get there. The mosaics are what everybody raves about, but the frescoes are just as lovely. There is also a charming rose garden around the back of the church. However, don't make our mistake and go with guidebook advice to take the Golden Horn ferry to Ayvansaray and walk up along the city walls. It's a long, difficult, and entirely uphill walk that's just grim and depressing in spots. Just take a taxi, a tour, or follow the directions provided by other reviewers to walk from the Edirnekapi tram stop.This is included in the three day Istanbul Museum Pass so if you have the time do try to go. The cafe across the street serves surprisingly decent food for a tourist trap -- the minced meat pide is nicely spicy and the lentil soup is excellent.

A Must See. The former Chora Church houses well preserved Byzantine mosaics and murals depicting the miracles of Christ, also the life of Mary, not evident in Roman Catholic churches.The ancestors of Mary, the Annunciation to St. Anne mother of Mary, birth of Mary, presentation of Mary to the Temple and her death are chronicled. Not as busy as for example, Hagia Sophia we were able to enjoy the amazing artwork.
Loved the mosaics here. There is a reason why this museum is the number one place to visit. It's a wonderful place and loaded with history. Take the time to walk there; you won't regret it.

Don't miss this church--great mosaics. Take the metro from the old city up to the Church. Wander the grounds and enjoy the beautiful views. When you enter the Church you will be rewarded with some of the most amazing mosaics. A real treat.

A real marvel!Don't miss it!. The place I liked best visiting Istanbul was Chora Church- there are so many mosaics well preserved! Just visit it and you will understand. After that, you must try the turkish coffe at the restaurant there- is very good.

Istanbul & History. I like each of historical buildings,I like hospitality of the people,bridges,bulevars,....shoops,sweets.Dislake only rush hours,you need hours to reach point B from point A but that is Isatnbul

Special place with historic mosaics and fresco work. It wasn't as hard to find this place as we thought it would be, and it was worth it to see the mosaics. Don't bother with those pesky (and sometimes shady) taxis. Just take the tram to Edirnekapi and then walk. I strongly recommend you go early in the day because the building is small and gets crowded and HOT inside by noon. We had to leave before we wanted to because of the heat. There is a lovely cafe just outside the church, great for a rest and a snack before heading off to other sites.

Great mosaics but not much else. This museum is off the beaten path and a long cab ride from the Old City. Wonderful mosaics, but in my opinion, it's not worth the trouble to get there. We followed a walking tour afterward, but the neighborhood was not particularly interesting. This was the only disappoint in our great visit to Istanbul.

away from the main section but stunning mosaics are worth it. This site has some of the most impressive church mosaics available in all Istanbul. It is not in the main Sultanhamet district near the Hagia Sofia, so if you are exploring on your own, it may be a bit out of your way, but it is well worth it. The church is a stop on many organized tours, so you can easily see it that way. The audio guide (or a private guide) will add significantly to the understanding of this site and its interesting history as well. There is a small restaurant with an outdoor garden immediately behind the church, so you can plan to take a meal or a short break there if needed.
Divine. Divinely inspired art of the highest quality. Whatever the triumphs of our current civilization we have not and probably cannot produce anything like this.

A Highlight of any Trip. This very well preserved Byzantine church would be a highlight of any trip you could take. It does not have the size, grandeur, or histroical importance of Hagia Sophia, but the Chora Church's mosaics are world class. This church takes you into the 11th century Byzanine world. The mosaics are a picture book of New Testament stories. You can imagine that the sermons delivered in this church concentrated on the lessons of these stories. The audio guide (10 lira) is very helpful in explaining the mosaics, the architecture, and history of the church.The church is small, as are the grounds, but the setting is still peaceful after all of these centuries and the build up of Istanbul. This used to be out in the country, but not anymore. There are some nicely shaded restaurants next to the church.It is easy to get to the church from the old part of Istanbul. But first remember that after all of these centuries, the church has picked up a number of names: The Chora Church, the Kariye Museum, the Church of St. Savior in Chora, the Church of Holy Savior in Chora, etc. Using the very convenient and inexpensive tram system:Take the T-1 tram from the Sultanahmet station west to the Topkapi station (this is not the Topkapi Palace). At the large Topkapi station, you will have to get on the T-4 tram going north. Get off at the third station, which is Edirnekapi (there is no transfer given so you will have to pay another fare). Once outside of the station, go east through the massive Istanbul walls by means of Fevzi Pasa Cad., which is a very busy street. Get onto the north side of the street and go three blocks to Seyh Eyup Sokagi and turn left onto Kalfaefendi Sk. This turns into Kariye Cd. The church is one block ahead.As I said, it is easy to reach the Chora Church. So how is it that my spouse and I got lost? Well, we are always confident that we know where we are going even if we are in a strange city on another continent. We never look at our map until we are sure we are lost. By the way, after you leave Edirnekapi station, if you find yourself in a gigantic cemetery, you went the wrong way.

Small but beautiful. It's another irony of the most complex, paradoxical city I've visited that the Muslims obliterated Christian art in this church by plastering over it--and thereby inadvertently preserved its glory. It was fun getting lost in the winding streets leading while walking through the neighborhoods leading back down to the Golden Horn.

Worth the trek. Was on the tourist trail and we thought it was a bit far out. We were so glad we made the effort. It is small and the tiles still visible are wonderful. We used trams to get there which was pretty straight forward and a small walk to arrive at the mosque (which is nearby) and church.

Beautiful mosaics, well worth a visit. The mosaics were extremely well preserved (where not totally missing, of course), brilliantly detailed and beautiful. Gets fewer tourists than other sites closer to Sultanahmet. Set in a nice neighborhood for seeing real Turkish life.

Marvelous history. It takes some effort to get to this site from central tourist areas of Istanbul but it is well worth it, this is a highlight of the City experience. The Church interiors have been exquisitely restored and the mosaics are most enjoyable. For the fullest appreciation of the scenes it is worth hiring the audio guide since the order and subject of the mosaics is not always clear. Look out for the legs of the leper, impressively covered with spots though his upper body is lost. Avoid the large tour groups that go through. Their guides can be very loud and enthusiastic. Our enjoyment was compromised somewhat by an over-enthusiastic Italian guide much impressed with the Virgin Mary, a clear argument for individual hearing systems. But this is a great site well worth visiting but do avoid being ripped off by your taxi driver, 20 TL should get you there from the city's heritage centre.

A bit out of the way but worth a visit!. It's a charming byzantine church with reasonably well preserved mosaics. We visited on a nice sunny afternoon and found no queue at the museum - even though we had a museum card so wouldn't have mattered if there were queues. It's a small church so can get crowded as soon as a group visits and we found that they came very regularly one after the other. But nevertheless - you can just focus on enjoying the feel and the mosaics and get out quickly. If you are in the area - don't miss out the city walls. There's a section which has been renovated and you can climb the stairs to get on top and enjoy really beautiful panoramic views!

Hard to find but worth the trip. A little hard to find but it is worth the trip. We took the bus from the pier area and walked a short distance and finally found the Chora church. All signs are for Kariye Museum so look for that not for the Chora church.

Not to be missed. The chora church is a small, beautifully museum with wonderful well preserved mosaics and frescos. The church dates to the 5th century although much of the current building is 11th century. It is just inside the city wall, probably 20 minutes from the centre of the old city.After visiting the museum we took a terrific walk through Balat to the waterfront. A great way to see the real Istanbul.
Great Museum. I love this place! I found the mosaics better and more beautiful than Saint Sophia.. My photos is wonderful.

The real Byzantine jewel. The Chora Church was what I was expecting to see when I visited the Hagia Sophia: exquisitely-detailed mosaics and exceptional frescoes from the early Christian era. Beautiful Byzantine art, easily accessible to the eye of the beholder in a small out-of-the way church near Justinian's city walls makes a great visit outside of Sultanahmet.The cafe just outside the exit is a nice place to stop for coffee or lunch.You can get there by bus, tram or taxi, but if you go by taxi, negotiate the fare in advance and pay with exact change. Don't fall prey to the sleight-of-hand trick practiced by my cab driver, who quickly pocketed my 50-lira note as he pulled out a 5-lira note and insisted that was all I had given him.

Interesting. I am not sure if it was our great guide, Hasan who brought this church to life or the fact that the mosaics are so spectacular. Most likely a combination. The story of Mary was carefully explained to us as it is depicted so well in the absolutely incredible mosaics on the roof of this small but special church. It is out of the main area where the other attractions are located but we thought it worth the trip.

getting there is half the fun. The mozaics are in excellent condition, it's a little gem. Taking the bus there is an interesting trip off the beaten tourist path and allows you to experience everyday Istanbul.
fantastic Mosaics. out of world mosaics,I have seen a lots os mosque or museums but I have not seen as beautiful mosaic as this museums....

Amazing mosaics!. If you like byzantine art you must go to the Chora Church. You can take the bus 36, 37 and 38 from Eminönü bus station and get down in Edirne Kap, we ask around for directions then to find the church but is not hard to get there. You can also walk around the old Constantinopla walls, they're very close to the church.

Well worth the effort. We visited the CHora Church museum on a day trip with a driver and a rented car which also included a trip to the Walls around Istanbul, a visit to the Aqueduct and a trip across the bridge linking Europe to Asia. Because we had a rented car, our driver knew where it was and we had an easy visit. The crowds were much smaller than at other attractions that we visited.The ticket to enter cost 15 Turkish Lyra and the headset rental was another 15 Lyra. The church is small, but the view of the mosaics and the restoration of the original works of art is well worth the trip.

Extremely well preserved. Great visit especially for orthodox christians.... The mosaic are amazing , very good rule for the big groups to use headphones as mandatory. Recommend for everyone to visit.

Great mosaics,a good locale,a good visit.. Although I am not a christian, and not really into the life of Jesus, this place was a great visit. Beautiful mosaics,haven't seen anything similar except for the mosaic museum in Gaziantep.

wonderful musaic paitings!. it was dificult to find it first and we've asked the address many times from the local people and walked through the rough alleys.but it really worthies!the church is not huge as Haghia sofia,but the paintings are breathtaking!all with tiny mosaics and covered with gold.there is also a nice cafe in the yard where you can rest after looking the roof for hours:)

A must see!. The crowds were not bad when we visited this gem! At least not as bad as at the Blue Mosque! We took the tram and then walked about 10 minutes. It's a bit of a hike, but not too bad. The signs are pretty easy to follow. The mosaics are amazing and our guide book spelled out the significance of the murals. We then wandered around a bit and climbed up on the walls surrounding the city for a fabulous view.
A real treasure!. Do not miss this treasure...some of the best Byzantine frescoes and mosaics we have ever seen! Accessible by bus!

Don't miss this exquisite church turned mosque turned museum. Beautiful church, finest frescoes and mosaics preserved anywhere! It is a cab ride away from Sultanahmet, where we stayed but worth the trip. Combine it with a lunch stop at Asitane, the restaurant next door which serves only food from recipes of the Ottoman Palaces. Amazing place.
Incredible Byzantine mosaics. Not on the tramway but so worth seeing, this small Byzantine church has the most amazing mosaics. Take a taxi and spend an hour here!
quite a schlep to get there..... took us a bit to get there... tram metro and then a walk...but the small understated church was quite lovely... a little hard to find...plan ahead
Amazing. If you liked Hagia Sophia mosaics, you MUST go to Kariye Museum. The history of Jesus and Maria told by mosaics in the charming interior of the building.
One of the top things to do In Istanbul.... When you hear Istanbul, you don't assume Kariye museum but it was one of our favorite places there. The pictures, the history, everything was fantastic

Go for the mosaics. If you are astounded by mosaics, then you will not want to miss this church. Built as a Greek church and later used as a mosque, it is much to the credit of the Muslims that they left these intact, as the representation of people or animals is forbidden by the Sunni Muslim as a distraction from prayer. Once you see these, you will understand their point.

Well worth the cab fare. A beautiful church well worth visiting. Amazing frescos and mosaics which were instantly recognisable. There were four of us and we took a cab there as it was raining but it was worth the effort. A stunning little gem although a bit crowded. .

Well worth the trip out. A visit to the lovely mosaics at this old Church fits in well with a visit to the Eyup Sultan Mosque, the old walls and other sites in the Western area. Go there by ferry - it's really easy.

Very nice but crowded. It's out of center, but defintely worth the trip. We took a taxi who got us there, there are also taxis waiting there to get you back. Paid 25TL from centre to there.Confirms other reviews, really nice mosaic, but very crowded. Use of tripod is forbidden (as in the other major locations in Istanbul), as well as flashing.
