A trek to some amazing frescos. This place does seem a bit out of the way, but it really isn't that bad - I walked there from Sultanahmet in around an hour and a half, walking slowly in the heat. The frescos really are striking - I think that as with so much of what you see in Istanbul, it's worth getting the audio guide, especially since the frescos are meant to be seen in an order that doesn't seem entirely logically laid out. Anyway, a lot of them are still in great shape, and wonderful to look at.The good news about the distance is that there aren't anywhere near as many tourists as you might expect. It's not exactly dead quiet, but it's not packed either. Just as well - it's a fairly small church.If your primary focus isn't really religious spots, I wouldn't try to pack this one into a short trip to the city, but if you have the time to spare, it's well worth a visit.

Absolutely beautiful, well worth the distance. Serene 14th century church. Lovely atmosphere and amazing mosaics. Less crowded than big sister, Aya Sofia, and personally preferred. Buzz on surrounding square. Suggest not walking the 6 miles from Sultanahmet, on whim, but taxi on way back only just over 10 lira.
Lovely murals and mosaics. Beautiful example ancient dedication to religious art. Lovingly restored and explained. And a stunning restaurant next door was an unexpected bonus!

Beautiful museum, easy to reach. We were a little put off going to this beautiful 12th century church, now a museum, with wonderful frescoes and mosaics, by posters who found it difficult to get there/expensive taxi etc. In fact it's quite easy to reach by tram. Take first tram to Topkapi, then change - no transfers given - need a second token, unless you have a transit pass, to second tram and get off at Edirnekapi. Church is a short walk from tram station. We had a beautiful lunch at the nearby restaurant Asitane, specializing in the traditional food of the Ottoman Empire. Shopped for inexpensive tiles at the shop just across from the restaurant.

Great mosaics, smaller crowds. Its bit difficult to get to if you are not on a tour. You could take a Taxi (TL 25 each way) or the bus or the tram and light rail. We took the tram and light rail, as described in Rick Steve's Istanbul book. The distance from the old town means smaller crowds and wait lines, so you can buy the ticket once you get there. Photography is allowed, but no flash please. Restaurant is across from the Church -- that's only where the only WC is (upstairs). When done with the church, have a look at the nearby old city wall and climb it at one of the access points for a great view all over the city,
Chora. Not in the main tourist area, but worth the detour to see the frescoes and mosaics as well as the lovely architecture and gardens.

Stunning, and worth the distance. A little way out of the centre, we caught a ferry then a taxi, but 100% worth the effort. Although on a much smaller scale than Aya Sofia, it is even more beautiful. Stunning mosaics.

Really worth the trip?. I am suprised that everyone below is saying that it's worth the trip, because personally I didn't think it was. I only had 72 hours in Istanbul and would have preferred to spend my time elsewhere. If you have more time perhaps, but it is quite annoying to get to. I was expecting more based on the reviews I read so I want to be honest here. Research the route and research what's there to truly assess if this is worth the trip. It was a nice place with great mosaics, but I could have skipped and not regretted it.

Unassuming and then Wow!. It's away from the main sites so a taxi ride. When you get there it looks like an old church.... But once you go in, it's breathtaking! Almost complete mosaics of the life of Jesus, made in the 14 th century, and covered up by panels rather than destroyed when taken over by the sultans.

Wow, a bit of a trek but worth it. This is a really interesting place. The church is actually very small (not more than 3000 ft2) but the art work is fascinating. It is included with the Instanbul Museum Pass.Watch for the hours though because we got there in the afternoon and the security guards were really pushy to enter the church because it was closing soon and we couldn't even stop for a minute or two to look at the lovely vista and garden at the rear of the church that you have to walk past to enter the church. That spoiled the trek somewhat but the church itself is really interesting.There is also a pretty good Ottoman-cuisine-inspired restaurant next door (quite pricey for Istanbul standards) so you can stay there until the museum closes and eat well afterward.
Wonderful frescoes. Small, frescoes amazing, this is a must-see but don't rush through the church. Take time to savor the experience.

The donor mural is worth the trip. Yes it's expensive and hard to get to but outside of Ravenna you wont see better art so close up. Watch the taxi drivers. Usual Istanbul scams. It may be best with one of the organized tours
Amazing. Its an amazing church tha has been converted to a mosque in the past. The has been very well restaured and it´s tiles covers the hole life of the Holy Mary.

No other place for orthodox church mosaics live that much!. A lot of mosaics survived the centuries, including the apocryphal ones.
The ad for audio guides with a mom in the headphone and kid, listening the speaker is misleading - one rented device can not play both ways simultaneously.

Chora church. We enjoyed our visit to this small church which has wonderful frescoes and is situated in a more residential area of town. We got there by taxi via the city walls which cost about 70 lira - you have been warned! Tell them to go via the main streets instead of the ring road! You could get a bus but it can get complicated if you don't speak Turkish. We walked back via ordinary neighbourhoods taking in another mosque/museum on the way.
great place. very far away by metro takea bus or taxi cheaper and easier ,a great place to see with windows tags to explain everything simply amazing frescoes

A bit hard to find but stunning interior.. We took two trams to get to this church and still had trouble finding it. After being pointed in the right direction by a local, we made our way into a cute little churchyard that wouldn't be out of place in any European city. However, the rather plain exterior belies the jewels within. Some of the best preserved mosaics and frescos of the world are here. I suggest reading about the church and mosaics first or buying the audio to see exactly how the mosaics fit together. I'm not religious but I can understand how the pictures must have awed the congregations almost 700 years ago especially when the lamplight hits the golden mosaic tiles. Be warned that because of the size of the church it can get crowded with tour groups and the ever present Istanbul cats. I really wasn't looking forward to seeing this church but it was my favorite attraction in Istanbul surpassing the Hagia Sofia. A must see IMHO.Be aware that in Turkey, this church is named Kayire Muse. The local man didn't know Chora Church until we showed him a picture.

Mosaics up close. These mosaics are closer than Hagia Sofia and the locale intimate. You can see some amazing art in a more intimate setting. It's a little further from most tourist spots, but a quick cab with no traffic. There's a great restaurant, Asitane, and some tourist shops nearby.
Mosaics. Brilliant mosaics - an unknown gem that we walked straight into and got too look around at leisure. Is really in the middle of nowhere

A stunner. Amazing ! Even this cynical atheist was amazed by the mosaics. I walked back down to Golden Horn along Theodossian walls and saw much of 'old' Istanbul. Intended to catch ferry but decided to walk back to Galata Bridge - quite a hike but cold beers on bridge made it worthwhile.

How have we never heard of the Chora Church before. Although I have visited many cathedrals, churches and mosques in many and various international locations, this church contained the most impressive construction features, religious paintings and mosaic presentations that I have had the privelege to witness. It was just brilliant.

mind blowing. This was hands-down our favourite church site in Istanbul. It does take a bit of effort to get there (99 bus, or ferry to Ayvansaray, or metro to edirnekapi) but its well worth the trip. The mosaics and frescoes are stunning - there are many more than at the Hagia Sophia and they are well-preserved. Don't forget to take some breaks for your neck! Almost everything is on the ceiling (or above door level) so your spine takes a beating. Worth the pain, though. Don't miss this site!

just too many people. I think this is the kind of place to visit out of season - because on a Saturday afternoon in April - there are just too many camera clicks per second to let you appreciate the calm and beauty this church/museum has too offer. It's just too small to take the numbers that pour through the 15 lira gate non-stop. As other contributors have said - the mosaics are stunning - although perhaps some of the restoration artwork around the mosaics looks a tad too bright to fit with the age of the original. I braved the crowd and got a stiff neck (a pair of binoculars or telephoto lens and a some way to support a cricked neck - would have helped) and went around the church several times in different directions - to really appreciate the details which are easy to miss under an arch or behind you first time around. But then I just couldn't take the snaps of the lenses - and the sheer amount of tourists alongside me. BTW - to get there - take an 87 bus from behind Taksim square - 20-30 mins depending on traffic. Get off near the end stop - where there is also a small road sigh saying Kariya Museum. If you walk some of the way back - the shopping centre in Edirnekapi - with lots of eateries and tea-eries - is worth checking out.

worth the trip. We went by taxi (say to driver "Kariyé Museum", if say Church or Chora they may not understand) although via Golden Horn ferry the access is possible with a little walk uphill eventually. Entrance fee is expensive (15TL each) but the church is well maintained and the mosaics full of gold and colors are charming. We skipped a full guided tour as we are not likely to spend too much time hearing who is who in the mosaics but we enjoyed the visit. It is a bit odd side from Istanbul modern center but not too far from Kapali Carsi and Suleimanye Cami.We are happy we went to see (I was never there before despite my frequent going to Turkey for the pasts 35 years) although it is not my favorite spot in Istanbul.

Favorite of the top religious sites. This beautiful little church is worth the effort to see. You have to walk uphill from the boat dock at Ayvansaray but the neighborhood is very quiet and pleasant. You just have to follow the Old Wall until you see signs to turn left for the Church of St. Savior. You will find the most beautifully preserved mosaics depicting the life of Christ. You realize the history of the place when you notice the faces of the stone saints were defaced by the Muslims. We found just one head untouched. There is a lovely garden behind the church for resting your eyes and feet. And, just across the alley is Asitane, a good restaurant with excellent service.

Stunning mosaics. Got lost walking there from Sultanahmet. Take the bus if you're short in time. The museum has some of the most beautiful mosaics I've seen. Very well preserved. My neck was a bit sore from staring up for over an hour. They really are wonderful. There's a nice cafe across from the museum for a break and the old city walls are very close by too.
Mosaics of rare beauty. The main attraction of the church is the mosaics. It is a bit out of the center, near the old walls and quite a journey but worth it if you like Byzantine mosaics

Pearl of Edirnekapi. Kariye muzesi(Chora church) is really as pearl of Edirnekapi.Location is very good for taking buses, generally its very easy to find this museum.As i was stayed at Tepebasi, i took bus what go from Taksim to Edirnekapi.Short walking by feet, and i could see this small church. Indoor it was wonderful, i was so impressed of these mosaics and frescoes.I will not write much, i add some photos, so you can see. My advice: come to Edirnekapi and look by yours own eyes!

fabulous, take a taxi as its a little out of town. It is very important to get information on all sites so you will hav e the History of each one.It tends to be crowded at times and the frescos are most beautiful on the ceiling so you will be looking up quite a bit.

why is this not in the must see in three days????. One of the view remaining Byzantine churches in the world and with some of the best preserved mosaics - and also frescoes which are contemporary with early renaissance works in Italy which show us just what might have happened if Constantinople would have been allowed to live a bit longer...Whilst not on the main tourist road an Sultanahmed it ties in nicely with a walk along the famous land walls which is a must although tiring for the keen historian

Mosaics and Tiles, Masterpieces. This is a small but exquisite mosque dating to the 6th century. Originally a church but converted to a mosque in 1511. Some think it is equal in beauty to the Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque with its masterful mosaics and tiles. Take your camera.
a must see. Beautiful church, with frescoes and mosaics. Worth visiting, even if a bit far from the historical center. I got the tram 1, then tran 4 and walked 600m, very doable.

tiles were amazing. like a little aya sophia beutıfull you should check next door restaurant asitane too.area of this former church then mosque and now museum is smell like history every where....
you should see other former churches in taxim area too.

Absolutely Stunning. It's out of the way, but I've never seen anything like it. I've been all over the place, all over Turkey, Italy, Europe in general and there is nothing in the 30 countries I've been to that is similar to the Kariye Museum. It's almost more worth while than the Hagia Sophia. Honestly, it's the most amazing place I've been. It doesn't matter if you're a Christian or not, the artwork alone is so incredibly fascinating that every person who is in Istanbul should see this. It's included on the Istanbul Museumkart, thank goodness, because I doubt I'd have gone if it wasn't. It's simply unimaginable unless you see it. Go. Now.

Amazing.. This is a little out of the way from most of the other major tourist attractions in Istanbul. An easy way to get here is to take a public bus from Eminonu to Edirnekapi (the old city walls) and there you'll see signs to Kariye Muzesi. The mosaics in this church are fabulous. They are utterly fantastic and blow everything in Hagia Sophia out of the water. I recommend getting the audioguide as it helps explain what biblical scenes are depicted in pictures and gives you a strategy for tackling the small but dense church. Most of the mosaics and frescos are wonderfully well-preserved and really give you a sense of just how important this building was to the benefactor who commissioned it. Also, after you're done, you can easily walk to the city walls and climb them for free, giving you some great views.

Fabulous sight, uncontrolled tour groups. I visited the church in late afternoon on a weekday in early April. The mosiacs were stunning, and the church an absoloute treasure. That said, the church has relatively small floorspace, and we were absolutely overwhelmed with tour groups who packed literally every square foot of the place. One tour guide rudely shoved me aside to shout nonesense to his group. I am marginal on recommending the site, unless you can somehow be assured of a realistic experience. This will become worse as the season progresses.
great place. Wonderful mosaics work, A little off the central sightseeing track, but well worth the extra effort to find. Stunning mosiacs in a wonderfully atmospheric part of the city.

kariyie ! wonderfull. I visited this museum with advice. simpler and cheaper to get tickets. interior design is great to see a very old church visited a very well preserved.'d hoped lot of great art, I hope you will again get a chance to roam unequivocally

Amazing fresques...it might change the beginning of ages. One of the Most interesting side of the historical Istanbul. Museum, houses, silent and peaceful pink cafe. Also you can rest at the full flowered park under the museum.

A must see. You must see and go through the history of Christianity. The mosaics are very well kept - most of the pictures are clearly seen. It is a small museum, but the stories are nice and long so takes at least an hour to visit. I suggest to take a guide or at least the head phones. Without these it will be a pity to just look at the mosaics, without listening to the stories. The mosaics tell the story of Christianity starting from Mary's wedding to Jesus's miracles. Parking is a huge problem.
A must. A little off the central sightseeing track, but well worth the extra effort to find. Stunning mosiacs in a wonderfully atmospheric part of the city.
Fabulous Byzantine mosaics. Spectacular mosaics; a must-see. And if your budget allows, have lunch at the Asatane Restaurant right next door.
MUST SEE. It is astonishingly beautiful with amazing frescos and mosaics.This is the other place to see after HAGIA SOFIA. It is well worth the effort.

absolutely the must place in Istanbul. this Chora Church is a nice contract to "Top Istanbul attractions" of huge scale. I will not write about mosaics and fresco - you can check all information at any guidebook.come to see this place, it has its atmosphere, human scale, you can easily imagine people praying there, on top of all - nice views outside, close to ancient city wall - so you can stop over to take a picture, and it is a nice reason to escape over crowded tourist places and see where from come all traditions of Russian Icons, St. Marco cathedral mosaics, etc if I'm not completely mistaken.

Truly wonderful. We almost didn’t go to the church as it seemed a little more awkward to get to than other sights, but it was certainly worth the effort. The church, now a museum, is small but it is even more beautiful than we expected. Actually it was easy to reach by public transport. Take line 1 to Topkapi (the station, not the palace) and change to line 4. The church is a short walk from Edirnekapi station.

Perfectly conserved Byzantine mosaics with rare scenes. This beautiful museum today gives us the opportunity to look at the difference between western and oriental art of Cristian iconography and it has the most amazing and very well conserved examples of so many rare and few apocryphal bible scenes of St.John in today's Istanbul coming from the old Constantinople ! Around the museum there is a nice cafe spot and tiles and artisanal shops plus Asitane hotel (which was an old Istanbul house restored as an hotel)which has a very good and classy restaurant with traditional and fusion Ottoman dishes.You should also have plenty of time for this museum not only visit only the museum but also to visit sorroundings like LAnd walls of Theodosius or Blakhernea palace even Mihrimah mosque which was build by great architect Sinan !
Closed on Wednesday. Remember Chora is closed on Wednesday. Unfortunately I planned a visit in the wrong day therefore I can not write a review

Astounding - you must see this. Yes, it's a little bit further away from the other tourist sites but wow the mosaics are unbelievable. Absolutely stunning. Possibly the best in the world for a building of this age. Don't miss it.

Unmissable - a highlight!. This small church must be on your itinerary if you have any interest in the history of Istanbul/Constantinople and its architecture.We spent a good two hours marvelling at the exquisite frescos and mosaics. They are truly breathtaking, as all the guidebooks say.It is difficult to say more, really. Amazing, beautiful and absolutely essential for any visit to the city.Like others, we followed the Lonely Planet recommendation taking the ferry to Ayvansary and walking up the hill for about 30 minutes to the Kariye Museum. If you follow the roads just INSIDE the impressive city walls, it would be difficult to miss the turning to the church (now a museum).Highly recommended!

Truly amazing. Take a taxi ( maybe 15 tl) to this place, a bit difficult to find. Very small mosque with incredible mosaics, the workmanship is unreal. A step back in time...if you're into this stuff, you won't be shortchanged...

Magnificent mosaics and frescoes. This ancient church is rightly celebrated for its mosaics and frescoes. Although a little off the beaten path, it is worth the trip. The entrance fee is insignificant for what is displayed. At one time it was out in the country, as its full name suggests, It is now a museum. It is truly a paradise for art lovers.

Peaceful small church. Away from main tourist sites, a fascinating church with intersting Biblical frescoes and all the better for being on a smaller scale. Personally preferred to some of bigger better known sites

Interesting mosaics. We took the ferry to Ayvansary and walked up the hill for about 30 minutes to the Kariye Museum. The museum isn't terribly easy to find - bring a good map if you do this, and be prepared to ask people along the way for directions! Make sure you stay within the historic city walls. It is a good walk through these streets, which are in a non-tourist area. The mosaics are interesting - get the guidebook - it has excellent photos. If you have seen the mosaics in Ravenna, Italy these are in a similar vein, but in a smaller church. These mosaics are beautifully executed, and are worth seeing. We walked back down to the ferry, which was somehow even more challenging than the walk up! You might want to take a taxi one way.
Impressive and of excess beauty. By visiting The Chora Church is like going a trip back to Byzantium, a church that provokes intense sentiments by its beauty

Worth the long trip. This church appears in almost every "must visit" list of Istanbul sites, and for a good reason: the building is beautiful, especially when looking at it from the internal garden, and the interior of the church presents wonderfully preserved frescos, some dating back to the 14th century. It is located in the western side of Istanbul, in a lovely, traditional neighborhood, pretty and peaceful, and offers a unique glance at the christian past of Istanbul. Last but not least, next door you'll find Asitane restaurant, which offers a delightful culinary experience.

Chora the Cathedral of Byzantium. Just before Islamic Turkish Conquest of Constantinople, The Chora Churh was the main cathedral of Constaninople. Therefore, you should not miss if you are interested in history and art-history.
worth the trip. a little off the beaten track. tons of frescos, mosaics in a smallish church in an older neighborhood. Close to old city walls that are worth clambering over.

An amazing survival. This is a bit off the beaten track, but well worth seeking out. It is near the Edirnekapi Metro station (caution: the area is safe, but go with care). The Church contains over 100 mosaics and frescoes showing biblical (and apocryphal) images dating from the 14th century. It is stunning. The Church was converted into a mosque in 1511 and the art work was only rediscovered in 1860 with restoration from the 1950s. The standard of restoration is excellent, although some images are badly damaged, but this does not distract from their sheer beauty. The site rightly deserves its place in the top 10 to see in Istanbul. There are a couple of eating places around the small square outside the church.
Must see. Even better than Aya Sofya. Mozaics and shape of church are more close to initial Vizantian style, and there are not so many tourists.

Fascinating. We travelled to the Museum by bus and found it relatively easy to get to. The mosaics and murals were outstanding. It is well worth making the trip away from the usual tourist routes to see it.

Unbelievable mosaics. Make certain to find to make it to the Chora. We took a 20 minute boat ride from Eminou to Avansaray and walked up the hill to the church. The church mosaics were absolutely breathtaking and were the highlight of our 5 day visit to Istanbul. You can also take a number of buses from Eminou but we found it much more enjoyable and easy taking the boat up the Golden Horn. The boats leave once an hour from Eminou. Nice restaurant right outside the church also for a nice lunch.
a dream in the past. i can't decide what i liked most: Aya Sophia or Chora....two masterpieces, don't miss these places..wonderful mosaics, Chora is not so crowded as Aya Sophia,but a jewel..

Little Wonder in the Outskirts of Istanbul. This is one of the best examples of Byzantine Architecture designed with beautiful mosaics inside which are still intact. I found my way to this place using the google maps, which comes in handy. As i entered the building i laid my eyes on one of the most beautiful mosaics i have ever seen. It describes the life of Jesus and Mary, which depicts christian faith of Turks during the Byzantine times. It is well worth the visit!

Beautiful church. We took the ferry up the Golden Horn and walked along the old city walls to the church - a fascinating walk. The church itself was marvelous: the frescoes and mosaics are more than worth the trouble of going there.

Like Ephesus it's somewhat disappointing. Best preserved doesn't mean perfectly preserved. Come only if you have extra time it kill. Only half the mosaics are still intact, although a few are so well done, they have facial expression qualities that look like oil paintings. Some mosaic tiles are so small, you'll have a hard time photographing them even with a macro lens.

if you love Byzantine mosaics.... make sure you go to this museum! The mosaics are incredible and are well worth the taxi ride or boat ride. Taxi from the Hippodrome was $15 USD one way - expensive! - but worth it. Take the boat to that area and back for a reasonable fee. I was at the Chora when a lot of tour groups were, so perhaps go later in the day, after the groups have moved on to something else.

Wonderful mosaics, beautifully maintained. We made the trip to Chora Church as a result of it being ranked so highly on TripAdvisor, and I have to say it was worth it (especially as we combined it with checking out the Theodosian Walls).It may be a bit out of the way, but popularity of this small site is clearly growing. While we were there several large coach groups arrived, which made it difficult to get in. We opted to get some food in one of the nearby tourist-centred cafes while we waited for them to pass through the building before heading in ourselves. The church is small but beautiful, and its interior is incredibly intact. Though it was busy inside, we were able to spend some time absorbing the well-lit and well-preserved detail. In terms of travel, it’s not that difficult to get to by public bus (and much cheaper than taxis each way!) According to the tourist information office, from Eminonu bus terminal, you can get the 28, 31E, 36KE, 37E or the 38E to 'Kariye'. If you keep an eye out, you can’t miss the old city walls and the mosque that’s part of them. Get off and follow the brown tourist signs down a few side streets to the Museum.You get free entry with the Istanbul Museum Pass which also gives you entrance to a number of places including Topkapi Palace, the Hagia Sofia, the Archaeology Museum, and a few others for 72 TL for 72 hours. The pass can be bought from any of these places’ ticket booths, and gives you ‘fast track’ entry to bypass the queues at the gates.
really worth the taxi ride. The mosaics are wonderful. The church itself is really beautiful. Make sure you get an audio guide, it is essential!
Fascinating. This church is small, and out of the way compared to other main sights, however I thought it was well worth going to. The mosaics are fascinating and well preserved.
if in area - stop by. old church interesting art work, can do as part of tour to Loti Hill and Yedukuli Fortress (kids will like Fortress).

Cool church with incredible mosaics. A bit challenging to get to by tram. The locals call this Camii Sokak and will have no idea what Chora Church is. To get there by public transport, take the tram to Topkapi stop (not the palace) and switch to the other tram there and get off at Edirnekapi. Face the old city wall, head left, cross the highway behind the wall onto Fezipa Street and look for the sign for "Camii Sokak" or "Kariye Muzesi" which will point left. Go down that road and you'll eventually find it. It's not well marked. While the museum and mosaics are great, don't miss the opportunity to climb up on to the 1500-year old city wall for some neat views. The part of the wall nearest the church has some very steep steps up to the top. There is no handrail and it is definitely not for acrophobics.

Marvellous Mosaics. Chora Church is definitely worth the slight trek out into the western suburbs of Istanbul. The small, unassuming church does not look much from the outside but once you enter, you realise that this is truly a special place. Almost every inch of the interior is covered by beautiful medieval mosaics, and you cannot help but gape at them. Being a small building, it can feel a little crowded if you arrive at the same time as several groups. Despite this, it is an absolute must-see and it was my favourite attraction after Hagia Sophia. The only guide book is a fairly weighty tome so I would advise bringing your own guide book or using the audio guide as there is no information available inside the church. We did not eat at the restaurant next door as it was quite pricey and instead ate at a friendly local bakery - two pieces of tasty Turkish bread for 3 TL - can't say fairer than that!

Mosaic Heaven. This place has such a high concentration of beautiful mosaic art it's almost overwhelming. It's not a big place,but the mosaics are so well-preserved. So historical and beautiful. And you MUST eat at the restaurant next door - best meal you can get in all of Istanbul. LOVED it.
excelente option. It was a little bit difficult to get there but once you are at the place it is absolutely wonderful: it is a must go

Mosaics not to be missed. The best mosaics in Istanbul. You can reach this church independently by public transport - 90B bus which can be picked up at the stances at Beyazit. Quite a number of parties visit so it can be busy.
Meh.. Very small church with some vaguely interesting, though typically grim christian mosaics. Some cute shops in the area, especially for art.

Wonderful.. Please make the effort to visit this church, you will not be disappointed. We were four, two lapsed Catholics & two not practicing Muslims, and we all were delighted by the little church with its frescoes, and the mosaics. Pay the extra for the audio guide, it's worth it, but don't feel obliged to follow the recommended sequence, instead move away from the tour groups, find an empty space, look around you, imagine those who have worshipped there in the past. We took a taxi, 20 TL each way, for the four of us, good value.

An incredible display of mosaics and frescos!. Today we visited the Kariye Museum and it was amazing. The beautiful mosaics and detailed frescos were a sight to behold. The entire display also details the life of Christ. This is one museum you shouldn't miss in Istanbul.
Lovely frescoes and mosaics. It is quite a way outside city centre, with no other tourist sights nearby, and can get very busy. However still worth seeing for the fantastic frescoes and mosaics.

The best Orthodox Church in the world. It is absolutely the best Orthodox church I've ever seen. It is not that I do not like other churches I've seen in Greece, Russia, Israel, and elsewhere. But this one clearly plays in a completely different league, the same as San Francesco in Arezzo, San Marco in Venice, cathedrals of Siena or Pisa. Both the XI-XII mosaics, and the XIV frescoes are stunningly beautiful (and much better preserved, than those of Aghia Sophia, for instance). An absolute must for any visitor to Istambul, terribly much more important than any mosque, any palace, or Aghia Sophia itself, for that matter. There, you see Greek Byzantine art in its prime, absolutely au pair with the Italian Rinascimento.

Excellent church. I went to that church even but far from istanbul Center but to reach it very easy as only one bus from bus station , the church amazing place from the 5 century really old and made of mosaic which really amazing also church nice and big with nice garden to sit and many caffe there and nice shops , it is worth it to see even sone walls ruined by the time
Etheral. This church "In the Fields" was not plastered over by the Ottoman's. The mosaics are inspiring. Rent the headset so you know what you are viewing.

Serendipity Traveler Highlight in Istanbul. The Chora Church aka The Kariye Museum is small, exquisite and well worth finding. I recommend purchasing the audio as the information is rich and the historical dialogue meaningful.The mosaics here are breathtaking and the sense of sacred very much present. Take your time,and then next door visit Asitane for lovely ottoman cuisine.

A tranquil, sacred space. The mosaics are exquisitely beautiful, and there is something utterly timeless and sacred about this place, no matter what your beliefs. I found it to be a quiet and inspring oasis, one of my favorite pauses in Istanbul.

Breathtaking Mosaics. Kariye stands in a hill, very close to the Land Walls of Theodosius, quite far away from what we could consider the main tourist area (Sultanahmet).But don't let this discourage you, for taking a hike to this old byzantinian church is something you won't regret.In it you'll find one of the finest collections of byzantinian mosaics narrating the life of Christ and the Virgin Mary, still in great shape. A must!

Amazing!. Well worth the trip to visit this church. It's a bit out of the way and in an area that offers nothing else to see but the mosaics and frescoes are incredible. Because its out of the way there are few lineups so it can be a quick trip. Highly recommend.

Great Mosaics. A "don't miss" site on your Istanbul itinerary. Wonderful little chuch with a great deal of history and art to behold. Try the little eatery on the hill behind the church. And time your visit so that you are not trapped in traffic getting back to the city.

my favorite site in Istanbul. I thought this site was much more rewarding to visit than the Hagia Sofia, which disappointed me. The mosaic work in this church is incredibly well-preserved and there are explanations of every one, which I didn't find elsewhere. Also, it's in a charming neighborhood with one of the city's highest-rated restaurants right across the street. I actually walked there, about 4 miles from my hotel, along the ancient city wall - great walk. The garden surrounding the church is also lovely. Give yourself plenty of time to enjoy this church, especially if you are a fan of Byzantine Empire history.
Woow. Absolute fantastic mosiacs. If you are a Christian or just love art. It is a must to visit. A bus trip from the city centre only costs 7 lira or £2 return.

well worth a visit. Visited today, we went on the metro and walked along the Byzantine walls on the way.The church is a little out of the way but it was still busy with quite a few tour groups. If you are lucky you could maybe listen in to a guide but we paid for an audio guide which was very informative and explained all the history as well as the mosaics. It is a beautiful and interesting place to visit.

Amazingly beautiful. Truly beautiful...or at least what's left from it. My heart was breaking at the view of the gorgeous remaining frescoes knowing that there were much more but they have been totally destroyed during the time the church was converted into a mosque. Same like Aya Sophia!The area is very poor and dodgy and tough to reach by anything but local busses from Eminomu - took n.90 and it was ok except from the fact that he bumped into something on the way and pretended that nothing happened. Make sure to buy a return ticket if you plan to hop on a bus on the way back - we didn't have one (impossible to find a kiosk) and one can't get them in the bus. The driver took us and brought us to a stop near Galata bridge with some sweets and crap kiosk where he indicated that we can buy tickets. When they told us we couldn't get any there, he became suddenly super rude and started screaming at us (we had offered him immediately to buy tickets from him), grabbed the money he was previously refusing (pocketing it obviously) and left!

GO! A not to miss site.. OK, we took a cab from our hotel in Sultanahmet and it was about 20TL, we arrived around 9:30am (it opens at 9am) it was PACKED inside. We had tickets I had bought online, but there was no ticket line. The Church is very small, so it doesn't take many people to create a crowd. Once again I wish we had a guide to tell us more, but the size made eavesdropping easier. The mosaics and frescoes were stunning.

Worth a detour. This church is decorated with exceptionally beautiful and well preserved Byzantine mosaics inside. It's not within walking distance of the other major sites in Istanbul, however, it's a short cab ride to get there and the taxi driver will either wait for you or there are some cabs usually parked outside the church so you won't be stranded.

Amazing mosaics transport you into the byzantine past of the city. One of the rare byzantine churches converted to mosques where the byzantine mosaics were not destroyed and are amazingly preserved. Located about 30 minutes walk uphill through a picturesque part of the city that provides a completely different "small-town" scenery.

Definite Must see. This is a gorgeous example of Byzantine Architecture. while it is a bit out of the way, a definite must see in Istanbul. Note that the easiest way to get to this location is by cab (about 15 TL each way). Nearby are the old city walls.

Beautiful frescos and mosaics. This former church is a bit out of the city centre but is worth the effort. The beautiful frescos and mosaics were in positions that were easy to photograph (no flash though). I had a Turkish coffee at the cafe behind the church afterward.

Unparalleled Byzantine mosaics. Truly a once in a lifetime opportunity. Entering the Kariye is like being transported back to the 14th century. The mosaics are remarkably well preserved, and really give an insight into how Christians worshipped around the time that the frescoes and mosaics were installed in the early 14th century. The original church on the site dates from the 5th century, and over the centuries upgrades and post-earthquake repairs resulted in the church you see today. Very much worth an hour and a half to two-hours of gawking at the gorgeous art lining the walls.

Wonderful ancient church in authentic neighbourhood. Beautiful frescos and mosaics (they are really as good as the guidebooks write). Use a chance to walk around the conservative neighborhood of Fatih to experience another side of Istanbul.
Skip It!. It wasn't much of a museum. It was out of the tourist area and not easy to find. The mosaics were not very interesting.
Finest Byzantine mosaics. It is worth visiting one of the few Christian Churches in Istambul. The surroundings are also very nice to walk around. Mosaics and frescoes are very well preserved.

Authentic and beautiful. The Chora Church is worth the visit. Where the Hagia Sophia is huge and restored (and on-going) the Chora shows the original artwork in an intimate atmosphere. Public transportation by Metro train to Edirnekapi, to the other side of the city wall, follow signs on the left.
Very interesting, hard to find. The mosaics here are wonderful and worth the journey out to see them. But check your route there and back, it is not that well signposted from the ferry nor the metro.

Very small in size. Conservation of mosaic is excellent. located in an existing residential neighborhood in harmony.. The Ticket to see Kariye Museum (15 Turkish Lire) is over-priced in comparison to what you pay to see the Hagia Sophia (25 Turkish Lire) or the Topkapi Palace, which offer a multitude of architectural and other physical objects.

Absolute Gem. This is utterly amazing. No book can bring to life the beauty of this mosaics and the atmosphere of this little church. Because it is not near many other attractions in Istanbul, we considered missing it, but I am so glad we managed to see it. If you have a guide to teach you the stories behind the mosaics, you will get even more out of it.

It's not close to anything, but I am happy I went out there.. The church is very well preserved and worth the taxi cab to get there. It is also very close (about three blocks away) to the Wall of the city and you can walk around there for nice photos. This was part of the museum pass.It is a small church, but the mosaics are superb.

Little Gem. Chora is an out of the way gem and a must for anyone with or without religious interests. The amazing mosaics that are over 1,000 years old were breathtaking. Worth the taxi ride to this part of town. Suggest tying it in with a day you go to Pierre Lotti since the church is out of the way a bit.

Beautiful and serene Church Museum. We heard that this church was hard to get to, so we saw it with a guide on a half-day tour. This church is a contrast to the crowded historic sites near Sultan Ahmet. With less people you get the chance to study the detailed and well preserved mosaics with scenes from the bible - some convey a world view or religious views unlike what you see in religious art otherwise. Other are traditional (mother and child, the last supper). The surroundings were beautiful and quiet. The sparsely decorated main chamber, lit by natural light from glass windows, made a strong impression in all its simplicity. The Chora Church was well worth a visit.

Byzanntine masterpieces. This church is dated 11th and 14th centuries. Most impressive are the imterior mosaics and fresco decorations depicting the lives of Jesus and Virgin Mary take a taxi 20 lire or 3 lire by bus from beyazit bus no86 terminal ask bus driver chora church Edirnekspi stop then follow road signs.
Astonishing !!!. Perfect ...!!! You need at least 2 hours to get seeing this small church, and preferaably have a guide with you, or buy a guide....otherwise you will miss half of the interest.....

Amazing. Chora church would interest anyone with a an inclination for culture, art or history. This place has a magic of its own; it is tucked away from the crowds, its size is less impressive than that of most reknown monuments but the frescoes, the light and the mosaics are unbelievable.
Stunning. A definate must see. Easy to get to by tram and a short walk from sultanahmet. The mosaics were breathtaking and an audio guide is available.
Worth to See. If you are near Sultan Ahmet at least you should stop by and do not forget to have a Turkish cofee or Nargile in the cafe next to it.

worth the trip. This have been one of the most beautiful masterpieces i have seen anywhere. It is quite simple to get to the church by tram. We were unsure where to go exactly once we got off but it really was not difficult. My only regret is that i did not read very much on the history before visiting the church. Highly recommend!
Mosaic. Nothing to dislike, the most fantasically well preserved mosaics & a small but pleasant shop for postcards etc
Beautiful Church. An amazing beautiful Church. The art is simply stunning!A little way off from other sites but easily accessible via tram and worth it.

Stunning. Beautiful mosaics and frescoes. You can travel by tram without difficulty, but you will need to ask locals for directions once you get out of the station. But they know where you want too go before asking! We got there for 10am, probably best to go early to avoid crowds, as it is small.

A beautiful small church with world famous mosaics. The church is out of the way in the northwest, but it is easily accessible by bus #87 from Taksim square (or down the hill from Istiklal pedestrian zone to a bus stop on Refik Saydam Street). Remember that buses do not take cash, you will need a transit pass (your hotel probably sells them).Take along the Rick Steves guide to Istanbul. He explains all the major scenes portrayed in the mosaics. Expect busloads of tour groups, and enjoy the quiet times between them. Beautiful!
Very small and crowded. But,very interesting for the history,worth a visit.You have to struggle with a lot of visitors(Difficult to access and park by car)
Don't miss this.. Church was build over 1,500 years ago. Beautiful Mosaics, the one's that are still intake. Amazing place.

Interesting and worth the trip. I took a taxi from the Sultanahmet area, but you could take pubilc transportation and if up to it, could walk - at least one of the ways. The gardens are quite peaceful - or at least they were when I was there, off season. You can look online to find out more about the church, its history and the frescoes so I won't go into that here. Be sure to walk around the neighborhood - it's nice to be out of the touristy area!

A definite must-see. Chora Church is absolutely stunning. It is very easy to get zapped back in time and imagine how beautiful it must have been when it was first built. It's very small so even if you have a packed day, saving an hour and a half to two hours (getting there and back included) would be sufficient. No Istanbul itinerary is complete without a visit to this place.Getting there: It costs about 15-20 TL to taxi from Sirkeci area to Chora Church, and I recommend walking over to the Constantinople wall afterwards. That area is a little run-down, however, so you may want to catch a taxi back to the Old City when you are through (we walked the stretch of the wall all the way to the tram station to take it to Taxism, and had our guard up the whole time because we felt unsafe).

off the beaten track. Decided to find this place on our own and had a little difficulty explaining to the taxi driver 'where' to go--but we found it! It is located in a quiet part of town along a hillside. The Byzantine art that remains after all this time is outstanding--well preserved mosaic and murals--the architecture so strong!! I enjoyed meandering around the interior rooms and the outside gardens were plentiful with quiet places of respite. English was pretty much non-existent but hailing a cab to return to the bustling city was quite easy when using the good old fashion hand language and exchange of smiles... as much as there is to see in Istanbul/Turkey, I'm very glad we made a quick stop here---even the ride to and from was part of the adventure!!!

Pleased to have made the effort.. This visit was well worth the short bus ride to the edge of the old city. Buses go from the Galata Bridge in front of the Spice Market, look out for the sports pitch below road level on the right and get off at the next stop just before the section of defensive city walls. The church is on the side that the bus stops and signposted.We chose this above the archaeology museum (too much to see in one visit) for the third day of our 72 hour museum pass on the basis that one museum a day is enough for us. We were not disappointed. The mosaics are very well preserved and, for northern Europeans, are a great opportunity to see so many works of the Byzantine era. The museum is far less crowded than the tourist 'honey pots' in Sultanahmet. It's easy enough to do a self guided visit with a well detailed book such as the Rick Steve's guide book as explanatory leaflets with the entrance ticket are not provided in Istanbul's museums. But even if, like us, you are not into the religious significance of the panels they can be appreciated as art.There are shops, cafes and a nice park close to the museum to pass a pleasant hour on top of the time to visit and the city walls are worth a closer look a few hundred metres further away.
Amazing Mosaics. A real must-see place with well-preserved Byzantine art.Excellent tourist kiosks outside it where u can buy colourful and traditional souvenirs.

Destination Venue - Don't Miss this Awesome site. The Chora is one of the TOP "must see" venues in Istanbul. It is one of the venues offered on the MUZE PASS - http://muze.gov.tr/museum_pass - and, while it will take a little effort (try T4) to get there, you will be richly rewarded for the effort - especially if you combine the Chora with a visit to Asitane Restaurant next door. Most everything to be seen in the Chora is 'overhead' so bring your distance glasses. This is a small venue so time your visit accordingly. I visited in late Sept and it was not overwhelmingly crowded - particularly between tour groups. Spend some time here - it is comparable to the Hagia Sophia. The Asitane Restaurant is a good landmark for directions. The Chora is just outside the City Walls and a walk in the area is a great way to check out the walls - and you could walk down to the Golden Horn and take bus back to Eminönü and the T1 and the ferries.

Breathtaking Byzantine art. The best example of a Byzantine frescoed church in the world. Completely awe inspiring and very moving - a humbling experience. Try to get there before the coach parties (generally before 11am) and hear the silence. Not to be missed.
Beautiful church - well worth the visit. The mosaics in this former church shouldn't be missed. If you get a chance go with a guide so they talk you through each of the different areas.
amazing. I think its one of the most amazing place to go in Istanbul...its so old...oldest mosaic icons are in whole church...it is so beautiful... i highly recommend to go there...

If you like Mosaics. Slightly out of the centre but only a 20TL taxi ride from Sultanhamet and well worth it. Excellent mosaics in such a small church, the addition of a minaret gives a flavour of the past.
nice. if you dindt get the chance to see Aya Sophia. This church is a small sample of the same situation that passed this church through the Ottoman empire
Kariye Museum. A unique example of a Byzantine Church before the Crusaders ransacked and devastated Constantinople during the fourth crusade.

Gorgeous ...... Brilliant master piece of Christianity early period in Istanbul...There are very important mosaics.........Why? Some of them have the first time expressed some of Bible stories in some absolutely new art direction......it was very , very NEW in early Christianity...... Also, the mosaic with Patrons is in very good condition...what is very rare...

Well worth the trip, but take a taxi!. This small unassuming church contains beautiful restored Byzantine mosaics and is well worth the difficult trip out here.
However it is painful to get here by Tram and by bus is difficult if you have not researched the route and impossible if you do not have one of the smart cards.
I'd recommend you take a taxi!

Understated and FABULOUS. This really is a must-see, in my opinion. Lovely gold (very antiquated) Christian mosaics amidst crumbling plaster and brick. Love, love, love.
Fun side note: it is located right next to "Asitane" (for my fellow Anthony Bourdain fans)....

Beware taxi rank. We went to visit this beautiful church and were thrilled with the intricate mosaics. It is well worth a visit and the journey to it gives an opportunity to look at the ancient city walls.Beware of the taxi rank outside the church. It appears to be run by an individual who takes an introduction fee which the driver presumaly will have to recoup.After taking a circuitous route back to town, our taxi driver relieved us of a 50 TL note while 'assisting' my husband in finding the correct fare. We only discovered this after he was long gone so a taxi fare inbound cost us 25TL and 80TL for the return journey.
gorgeous. Very interesting place! Must-see especially for Christian people. Beautiful mosaics and unusual atmosphere.

A top 10 attraction. Not too hard to find from the tram stop if you know which direction to go, although crossing the busy roadways is an interestig experience. 15TL admission. Closed Wednesdays. As been said, fantastic mosaics, but a waste of time and money if you do not know what you are seeing. So, either have a good guidebook that describes the history and stories in the mosaics, or pay 10TL for the audio tour. I did the audio tour and found it dull and barely worth the money (10TL). Bring your own headphones or you end up holding it up to your ear! Spend an hour, two hours tops.
Magnificient. This church far from the centre is worth to visit because it has very nice mosaics which are well preserved.
amazing mosaics. It's worth finding this church by tram and metro. It may be hidden away, but the Byzantine mosaics are incredible

Mosaics of gold. My catholic husband was enamored by this Christian church featuring over twenty beautiful mosaics covering Jesus's life. Smaller and more intimate than the mosques, but beautiful architecture with plenty of domes, marble, perched on a hill with views of the city below. We walked here twice, very strenuous climb up cobblestone streets. Taxi or bus would be recommended to save your strength, although the ferry service up the Golden Horn was enjoyable, It required some serious walking.

Incredible and amazing!. To appreciate it, you have to go there in the least stressfull way. It takes out the fun and excitement if you are tired getting there or upset about the taxi fare! The other blogger have it right, take the tram and get off at Topkapi, then transfer to T4 line and get off at Edirnakapi. Then its a short walk from there. Take the main road vs along the wall. The mosaic details on the Chora was incredible! In my opinion, It was much better than Michelangelo's frescoes on the ceiling of the Sistine Chapel. A must to see!

Well worthwhile. My wife and I toured the Church of Chora in May, 2012, while on an organized tour through Istanbul. We had no interest in visiting the bazaar, which was the organized activity for the morning, and elected to visit the Chora Church instead. I cannot imagine why the Chora Church is not included in every organized tour's itinerary. Perhaps the relative inaccessibility of the church precludes efficient transportation, but my wife and I regard our visit to the Chora Church as a highlight of our visit to Istanbul. The Chora Church is simply stunning. For a relatively small fee one can rent earphones through which one can listen to commentary on the mosaics. The commentary was useful, and I believe that those who did not spend their careers in the study of art would find the commentary well worth the small additional expenditure. Although one could in principle breeze through the church in short order, I recommend that the visitor allot an entire morning or afternoon to this experience. If my wife and I should be fortunate enough to visit Istanbul once more, we would surely allot an entire day to this lovely little museum.

You should not miss this. This church is amazing. Follow some kind of guide book so you will understand what all the scenes are. You'll be able to guess about half of them. We took the Metro M1 to the Topkapi stop (not the palace, the road) then walk along the city walls and Topkapi street. There is a safe path to walk on. Once you turn right and go through the city walls follow the signs for Kariye Museum. It's in the middle of the neighborhood so hard to see. Just go.

Worth the effort. Although out of the main tourist centre of Sultanhamet, this is extraordinary and worth the effort. For anyone interested in religious or art history, it's unmissable. The immediate locality retains some old-style character and restaurants and souvenir shops.While in the area, also inspect the remains of the old city walls.We got there via the T1 and T3 tram routes, then walked back via the Golden Horn shore (only to be done if you are fit, although there are ferries).

Hidden masterpiece!. I must say, it wasn't easy trying to get there on your own with the train but we managed in the end. It's kept hidden in a residential area so not very easy to find like other attractions. This church is simply magnificent with all the pretty tiled ceilings, get a good guidebook to enjoy your visit by knowing the history behind the building.

Hidden gem. Amazing, seems to be off the mass tourist radar. Located in a tad run down area near the wall. Took the the T1 to Topkapi, then the T4 to Edirnekapı. Walked along the wall for a bit, and then through the neighbourhood. Got slighly lost but locals happy to help put with directions. Last entry at 4:30,but open till 5. Although shop closes earlier than this...4.40ish...
Beautiful mosaics. This museum a former church has beautiful mosaics on the ceilings. Look up on the ceilings of gold mosaics of Jesus.
A hidden pearl. I've seen a lot of historic places. The Kariye Museum is one of the most fascinating places I've ever seen. It's really worth your time.

Small treasure. First a racy long taxi trip. Then a really intimate church with beautiful mosaics and paintings. It would have been a good idea to hire a guide to get more understanding about the pictures.

Not difficult to get to. Can't add anything about how good this is to see. Can add that it's easy to get to. T1 tram to Topkapi than leave station walk over to the T4 tram and its a few stops to Edimekapi. Then walk diagonally across the roundabout (beware local drivers!) and down behind the walls taking first or second right. 5 minutes from tram. On the way you can scale the walls up to the tower overlooking the roundabout - one very steep set of stairs carved into wall though - very careful on way down particularly.I have the Rough guide issued May 2012 and the T4 tram is not mentioned in the Chora bit and is not on the tram map at all!

Best thing in Istanbul. This small church is pretty much worth the trip to Istanbul on its own. Stunningly beautiful Byzantine mosaics, many of them in excellent condition. Hugely better than the few in Haghia Sophia. The entrance fee is nothing for such an experienceTrue it isn't a two minute walk from Sultanhamet but is easily and cheaply reached by tram. Change at Topkapi and get out at Erdine. You then have to cross a roundabout and go down behind the land walls and down a sidestreet; about four or five minutes walk. There are plenty of buses back into town from the nearby main road. No need for a taxi and a lot more interesting.
A pleasant experience. If you have the time, it is interesting and is in a neat area away from the tourist stuff. It may take longer to get there than the church visit itself though!
Byzantine gem. This 11th-century church, now a museum,was noted for its remarkable byzantine mosaics and frescoes(1315-1321)

A must see for any Art or Religious Historian. For anyone interested in Church history this Museum (Church) is a 'must see'. Some of the walls have images that have a non-Gospel spin to them. Also the quality of the figurative representation is extraordinary when compared to the devotional painting being done in Europe at that time.

A little far away but a good place. We went there from Bosphorus strait. We asked someone how far Kariye museum was and they said it was 15 minute walk so we started walking. 45 minutes later we asked another person and she said it is far to walk!!!! At that point I was DONE since It was cold and my hands were frozen. We took a cab from there. Not to mentioned got conned by a guy on the side walk who forced naggex us to polish my shoes and my sons and wanted 25 TL for each. We finally gsve him 10. If we had known he far it was we could've paid 25 TL and taken a cab. :). The muse was a good experience. Take the audio guide you will need it or use the quick scan app. They have it all over the muse.
Stunning. Worth the trip if you are interested in mosaics and frescoes.A little far out, but a taxi fro, Sutanahmet can be had for 15 TL, but expect to pay 25 TL on the return.Stunning.
Gem often ignored. A little far from Sultanahmet. Took a taxi which was expensive. We enjoyed the interior paintings about stories from the Bible. They need restoration badly.

A Christian Relic in Istanbul. We were debating whether to go or not to this Church but our hotel manager said that it is beautiful and beside it is a very good restaurant, Asitane which he recommended highly for Persian food. What a treat this Church was with its frescoes and mosaics especially the one of the Assumption of Mary. This is one of the best museums I have every visited.

Kariye Museum. wasted trip. got off to a bad start as our taxi driver scammed us (set the fare before hand!!!!) relatively high entrance fee for what it is. The frescoes and mosaics have not been looked after over the years and most are quite worn (hence entrance fee should be lower), although several beautiful pieces remain. Not for everyone. May be worth a visit if you are in the area already or have an interest already.

Chora Church is a must see hidden gem. So pleased we decided to take the trip out to this small museum! From the outside its hard to imagine the treasures hidden on the walls and roofs of this old Byzantine Church! Amazing mosaics and frescoes amongst the most beautiful we've ever seen! Well worth the taxi trip out!
Lovely excursion.. If you are into historic mosaics and frescos, this is the place for you. The history is amazing, and they offer comprehensive audio guides.

Chora and Byzantine Art. This is a beautiful museum showing some iconic byzantine art. Well worth a visit. Take the tram to Topkapi and walk along the old city wall to make this a complete experience.
Fantastic icons. Beautiful icons in an old church away from the central tourist area with a good view down over the city. Well worth a visit.

Beautiful frescoes and mosaics. We were staying in the old quarter but took a taxi. There are many delicate and realistic depictions, which match the quality of those in Hagia Sofia. The colours on the walls and vaulted ceilings are well preserved and the mosaics are set off with gold. They are truly beautiful and easy to see because the church is quite small.

Sublime mosaics, among the best on the planet.. It can be tricky to find the church if you follow the directions in Lonely Planet, but persevere. The mosaics are truly sublime and worth every befuddled wrong turn it will take you to get there. We walked from Eyup mosque. It is a long walk, but worth it if you stay along the Horn and then follow the old walls up the hill. Get better directions than these! But go!

Tranquility in an urban area.. This church contains some incredible mosaics and frescos. This is well documented. The expensive restaurant next door offers a stunning menu. For those looking for a quick inexpensive snack the cafe on the west side provides this with some very good typical dishes.The whole quiet ambience of the this museum at the bottom of a steep hill is an absolute must.

Mosaics as beautiful as Hagia Sophia's. The church is not as large or grand but the mosaics are just as, if not more impressive than Hagia Sophia's. This site is not right near the central historic area but its not far. It is a short cab ride away.

Impressive! A must-see in Istambul.. The interior is covered with amazing mosaics and frescoes. They are truly impressive. In my opinion one of the most beautiful Byzantine monuments! I have heard that not many people go there when in Istanbul. If you have to choose, pick Kariye Muzesi(Chora Museum) and Ayasofya (Hagia Sophia) and leave the Blue Mosque behind.

Beautiful mosaics. This is definitely worth a trip outside the touristy old city district. The mosaics lining the church walls and ceilings are gorgeous and unlike those you'll see in most other places. Beautiful park below the church to take pictures too.
a place a lot of people miss. I loved the restoration of a Byzantine church and the fact that it gives you some idea of what Constantinople was like

Over rated. For the price (15 liras) the church is really small and there is little to no information inside. If you haven't been to eastern Europe and seen Christian Orthodox style churches then I would recommend this place, since that is the style of the paintings inside Kariye. But since I was there before coming to Istanbul and visiting Kariye nothing inside surprised me.

Kariye Museum and Asitane Restaurant - Do not miss. I visited the museum and then ate at Asitane. I used the tram to get there and once I found the sign for the museum, it was an easy walk from the station.The museum is run by the same entity as Hagia Sophia and the mosaics are much easier to see because the space isn't as dark. The tile work is really high quality. Books are available at a kiosk. As other reviewers have said, if you like mosaics, this is a do not miss sight.Asitane is one of those restaurants that are more expensive, but really worth the effort to dine at. The food is based on traditional Ottoman recipes. Everything was excellent and the staff was very accomodating even though I didn't have a reservation.

One of the best palces to visit in Istanbul!. This church is definitely out of the way to get to but the trek is definitely worth it. The Chora Church was one of the most beautiful locations we visited during our stay in Istanbul. As a Christian, I was truly impacted by the tremendous ancient frescos and mosaics that still survive in the church.

Chora--my favorite place in Istanbul. Of all the majestic places in Istanbul, I could have just sat on the floor and spent hours marveling at the mosaics and frescos at The Chora Church. Breathtaking is not a good enough word to describe the magnificent and moving Byzantine artwork in this small, perfect, architectural gem.I seriously fell in love with this place. It is precious.
Do not miss. Even if it is not in the center of Istanbul you should not miss the incredible art in this church. Afterwards if you can stop at the Asitane restaurant, terrific food.
Stunning site. Beautiful frescos and mosaics, full of history and artistic brilliance. Anyone interested in Byzantine history and the history of world art should spend some quality time here.

a little out of the way, but worth it. The frescoes were incredible but unfortunately, there is no direct mass transit connections--we took a cab and then walked back through a most interesting section of town past the aqueduct The church itself is a gem and though it was small and you could see all of it in less than 30 mnutes, the quality of the surviving frescoes made it worth it
Incredible. Awesome place, super small but beautiful non-the-less. When we were leaving, like 40 tourists entered so it could be frustrating if you don't like populated areas.
A delight. This is not to be missed, the mosaics are beautiful and not many tourists in sight. Good cafe opposite

do not miss this. Not easy to find but essential to any Istanbul visit. A 12th century church with painterly frescoes and Byzantine mosaics that suggest art history development earlier than Giotto and the Italians. Powerful, moody faces and best news of all, you can get very close to them. Take a taxi from the Eminonu bus park--it could be as much as 20TL; pay attention to how you got there. After your visit, we walked down the hill and bumped into the commerical strip in the town of Balat. Walked through that, and then headed for the waterfront thinking we would take a Golden Horn ferry back. Not simple to do because, the Golden Horn ferry only stops on the south side @ Ayvansaray which is not that close to Balat. Catch a public bus to Eminonu from any stop along the busy waterfront cadd. We were there in wet, cold January; perhaps in the summer, it would be pleasant to walk these distances.
Best Mosaics. You must go this museum. It's a wonderful visual depiction,of the live of Mary. The best example of the mastery of the artists of the Byzantine Renaissance.

Far but worth it. Lovely place, the mosaics are stunning. Little remote and hard to get to. Had to take a taxi. The first taxi Charged me 21 TL, for the return trip identical distance the taxi demanded 30

Excellent hidden church. This is very impressive ancient church. It's situated not in th center but it's worth to visit. We've liked it a lot and I can say that I was impressed by it's mozaik very much. It became my biggest impression in Istanbul.
Go with a Guide. Guides have THE best info on this place. I don't want to spoil it, but here's a hint: not your basic Nativity Scene

Do Not Miss. We almost skipped this site as it is far from the city/tourist center of Istanbul. However, this is one of my favorite churches in all of europe. The church is very small in size but has unbelievably gorgeous decoration in the form of frescos and mosaic. The church is situated in a residential area. There are several other interesting sites in the area however area surrounding the church can be a little awkward for the beginner/intermediate traveler. We did a walking tour which was quickly aborted as I did not feel as though we should be entering these communities.
Amazing!. A bit of a hike but short taxi ride to the most amazing mosaics. Good audio guide and near Istanbul's old city walls.

Incredible frescoes. Worth the effort to get to as the church has some of the most beautiful frescoes I have ever seen. Do read a good guide book about them as it is very helpful to understand what the pictures are about.
A must see. The stories of mother Mary told on the walls of this Church are amazing and in great condition. The walls are covered. Much better with a knowledgable guide.

Great mosaics, very small. This Byzantine church is worth a visit, but don't expect to spend more than an hour. Like the Hagia Sofia the mosaics were plastered over and then removed, so they are in excellent condition. The church presents the story of the life of the virgin Mary, according to the Greek Orthodox tradition (so some scenes may be surprising to those familiar with Catholic doctrine) in lovely detail. However, there is no context given unless you buy a guide, which is suggested if you don't come with one.
Great discovery. A friend told us we could not miss it, and she was right! Excellent frescoes and mosaics, and a very beautiful setting. A MUST
Amazing!. Probably the most impressive visit of our stay in Istanbul. You don't wanna miss this byzantine gem!
Greatest mosaics. This is a gem of a church. It has beautifully preserved mosaics that dipict many scenes of the Bible. One of the best finds in Istanbul.

A beautiful view into the Byzantine past. If you visit only one old building in Istanbul, make it this one. It is a little out of the way, but well worth it for an opportunity to see the remains of the mosaics which the Byzantine era is noted for. It is affordable, and far less crowded than some other attractions (although admittedly we were there on a Saturday afternoon in December).It is a very beautiful place and you get as much time as you like to look at the art, most of which is in quite good condition because it was roughly plastered over rather than destroyed as it was in so many churches. The lighting was a bit dim, which made it difficult to take pictures since you couldn't use a flash, but presumably this is required to protect the paint. It was still well enough lit that you could view most of it.However, most of the best examples are well above eye level, so you need to crane your neck to see them. I found myself wishing there was a scaffolding to allow me to get closer to the ceiling work, because details were lost by distance. I suppose I would have been equally happy with a few benches or cushions which would allow me to lie down to contemplate the works.It is a bit light on the details of the specific pieces or the history of the era in which it was built, but if you've taken the time to do some basic research before visiting you won't feel that more plaques are needed.Most of the walls are not protected, although there are guards to prevent people from touching them. If you visit with small children you will probably be actively engaged in keeping them from touching things and they probably won't find the experience very interesting.

Beautiful. This was fairly small. It is so ancient. It is full of mosaics and truly stunning. The various Mother Mary and Jesus Christ paintings are gorgeous and really give the sense of true art and reverance.
Excellent. This showed the old Christian Era and how the structure changed religious from Catholic Church to Mosque and like othere went back/forth. The mosiacs were great.

Beautiful. If you are interested in Byzantine art, you must go. Make sure you get the audio guide to know what you are looking at. It's a wonderful visual depiction,of the live of Mary. The best example of the mastery of the artists of the Byzantine Renaissance. It took me a minute to find, but once you get kind of close there are signs leading you to the church. From the outside, like the Aya Sofya, it is not too spectacular, but don't let that deter you. Go in and see it for yourself, you won't be sorry.

Worth a trip out of the center.. A good companion visit to the Hagia Sophia. It's a little tricky to find, but worth the effort.Try Asitaine Restaurant right next door for a gorgeous meal. Also check out the city walls and climb to the top for a crazy view of the city.

A must. if you go to Istanbul YOU MUST visit this place. It's really incredible. I fell in love. It is a bit outside the usual touristic route (we took a taxi - 10 lira). But after visit the beautiful mosaics, you can walk back to Eminonu and you will pass through the most interesting part of Istanbul.. Fatih (Fener and Balat). REally inspiring.

A very old church and very quaint. We loved this old church. It is now a museum, and well worth visiting. It is ornate with paintings of Jesus, the apostles, and Mother Mary. Not nearly as large as later cathedrals, it has a more personal, spiritual atmosphere somehow. If you are into historical buildings it is well worth seeing.
Kariye Museum. Wonderful ancient drawings on the walls and ceilings. A must while you are in Istanbul. Put it on your short list.

Beautiful. Go early to avoid crowds. We got lost taking public transit, so I would recommend a cab. Kinda out of the way, but go to Asitane next door to make it an afternoon and wander around to see a less touristy side of Istanbul.The mosaics and murals were gorgeous here. Highly recommended. You can get pretty close, but please adhere the rules and NO FLASH.
Relics preserved. this church is a little out of town, it will reward you with well preserved art, featuring catholic icons.

Early christian frescos and mosaics. Wonderful early church converted to mosque then museum. A bit on the outskirts of Istanbul but worth the effort. Amazingly well preserved early frescos and mosaics. A bonus is to see the nearby Byzantine walls from 4th century.

Go - if you have time after the other sights - but it is a bit of a hassle to get to.. Tell the taxi to go to Asitane- nice restaurant next door. church is smaller scale but frescos and mosaics are impressive- pay particular attention to the marble - it is amazing - pieced into patterns and were impressive as well.

The place is off from the tourist center, but is a must to go.. It took us 1 hour to walk there from the city center (Sultanahmet area), but we did not regret it a single minute.It is a 11th century Byzantine church. It looks small compared to Hagia Sophia, but it is no less beautiful.During Ottoman period, it wonderful mosaic works were not destroyed, as happened to many other churches, but just covered with plaster. After restoration in 20th century, most of the mosaics become visible. Even some frescoes survived!Now Chora Church is the best example of Byzantine Christian mosaic.

Just have to do it once.. Watching Kariye Museum in History Channel on TV and being there in person are two different experience. Even though we took a bus a little out to see this Musesum, it's worth the journey. Just have to do it once.

Breathtaking Mosaics. Ya, I know - you've seen enough churches and monuments. This one is out of the way and how different can it be. You don't need to be there long but the mosaics are in amazing condition with vivid colors and superb craftsmanship.

Hagia Sophia's little sister. The Chora Church is a little bit off the tourist tracks, but definitively worth a visit. The earlier you come, the more intimate the church/mosque will be for you. Gold, gold, gold galore!

Interesting stories and probably best to busy with a guide. We truly enjoyed out visit to the church/museum. The Christian arts are best preserved/recovered here compared to other places in Istanbul (including St Sophia). There are lots of biblical stories shown through out the mosaics here which made the visit rather interesting. Given the number of stories there are and all the mosaics, I would recommend going here with a knowledgable guide. We went with Backpackers Travel tour and had an excellent experience. Alternatively, there are audio guides available on site.

lost on narrow streets. Reaching the church was time and nerves consuming. we got lost several times in a traditional turkish neighborhood where nobody seemed to know about this church. we got there and we paid a 15 lira entrance fee to see a small old building not very well preserved. do something else with the time...
Off the beaten teack. The Chora Church is away from the city center. However, it is worth a visit. The frescoes on the walsl and ceilings are beautiful.
Fascinating and elaborate. We went as part of a tour of the area - quite interesting, especially the earlier history of the place and its predecessor.

Absolute gem. This gorgeous gem of a church is absolutely worth the visit. A stunning example of a Byzantine church, the mosaics will leave you breathless. Featuring both the life of Mary and Jesus, they are surprisingly human and warm. Even if you are sick of religious sites, you'll want to see this one!

No lines and easy to get to on public transpitation. We took the blue line to Topkapi Stop (not yhe palace stop about 8 later) then hopped on the yellow line getting off on yhe third stop. Crossed the crazy highways then headed down the hill and to the left. What a beautiful museum. The mosaics are facinating. A must see! Wont take too long so you can squeeze it in easily.

Impressive. Mosaics are outstanding. The walk from the centre of town to the church was worth the effort through interesting parts of town. Disliked the number of people who ignored the request not to use flash. Liked the courteous way they were dealt with. Gift shop not dominant, good. Reasonably well lighted thus not requiring flash esp with digital cameras.

Beautiful Byzantine Mosaics. Leave the hustle and bustle of the historic district and visit this small Church / museum and also walk around the neighborhood. The Church is about 4 miles from the historic center, an easy cab ride. The mosaics are on the walls and ceilings and depict various events in the lives of Jesus and Mary and other Christian figures.
