The current church dates to around 1100; it was built after an earthquake; in the 16th century it was converted to a mosque and all the frescoes and mosaics were painted over. Luckily in the 1940's the frescoes were discovered and restored.

Worth a Detour!!. The mosaics are fabulous. We took a taxi because of time limits and you need to take taxi, tram or boat as mentioned in other reviews. There are some small restaurants across from the museum and an interesting mosque nearby (follow the minerets).

My favorite tourist sight in Istanbul. There are so many amazing sights in Istanbul but I was awe-struck by the beauty and history embodied in The Chora Church. The tile work is incredibly beautiful and is in superb condition.
A Must!. Loved this little gem. Worth getting out of Historic District. Taxi is the way to go as the church is tucked away.

Spectacular frescoes and mosaics. If using public transportation, don't plan on walking from the red metro station. Too far along an uphill twist and turn route. I ended up getting a ride from a local. On return, I used the bus, which stopped on the main street close-by. This is a much better way of getting there. Ask any local around for directions. Admission 15 lira. Walking into the church will cause you to say "Oh, Wow." The place isn't that big so you can see it in a relatively short period. Beware, school groups and tour groups. I could hardly get from one place to another when they were in same room. But, the art was absolutely worth it. Gift shop. If you found my review helpful, please click on "yes." Thanks.
Amazing. Not very popular but very important in the christian history. The audio guide was very helpful. The location is 30-35 minutes by taxi from the city centre as 'chora' means outside city.

Chora - fantastic mosaics. A little off the beaten path. At hotel staff suggestion took ferry up the Golden Horn and then wandered uphill. I do mean wandered. No signs or markers. Just kept asking people and walked up hill. Was actually part of the fun. Church is beautiful. Had heard it was a highlight from others and we agree. Would very highly recommend going to see it. Take a taxi if you are short on time or don't want the adventure.
byzantine wonder. This church is amazing. It is one of the oldest relics of Byzantine Christianity. The mosaics are beautiful, but if helps if you are with someone who can translate the writing.

A quiet little gem. The Chora Church was a little far from where I was staying but conveniently located 10 minutes away from a metro station (thanks Tripadvisor!). Totally worth the time and effort to get there, an audioguide or a guidebook is definitely recommended to fully appreciate the history and the meaning behind the murals.
Bizantine art. Include this visit on your regular tour, here you can see some of the most relevant bizantine paintings in the area.
Icons galore. This is one of the most significant sites for Byzantine art in the world. Dine next door at Asitane, one of Istanbul's finest restaurants.

Well worth the effort in getting there!. Absolutely stunning and extremely well-preserved mosaics and frescos some ways out of the centre of Istanbul, well worth the effort in getting there (though be prepared to be ripped off by the taxi drivers who prey on tourists who emerge from the church with an expression of "gee, that was womderful but how on earth do we get back to our hotel from here!").

MUST See. As lovely as the hagia Sophis but not as well advertised. Truly a marvel and the mosiac panels depicting teh life of Joseph and Mary are wonderful. Get a guided tour and learn the history of the Christian faith and the beginnings of the church.
Hard to find but well worth it. Okay - took a while to find this church even with the tripadvisor app. But well worth it. This church is on the smaller side but well worth the effort.

An unknown jewell. The Chora Church, now a museum closed on Wednesday, is probably the most unnoticed monument of Istambul, but it deserves a visit, perhaps the first day of your trip, even before seeing Agya Sophia. It´s not only the magnificient and breathtaking mosaics and fine frescoes of the Byzantine period,but the atmosphere of the little chapel that offers you more than the outside shows. The backyard and the old quarter surronding the church are really worth visiting too. You can eat here cheaper. I recommend you to visit this church with a guide. Otherwise you could miss some important information about this chef d´oeuvre. If you can spare two hours you must see it.

The best byzantine mosaics. It is the only place where you can see the best preserved byzantine mosaics in Istanbul ans Turkey. You can see so many mosaic about the life of Virgin Mary, that is really amazing!!!
Magnificent. The number and quality of frescos and mosaics in this small church are simply amazing. Visitors to Istanbul should not miss this gem.

Beautiful. Didn't visis the church this time but hope to next time. The fresco's, mozaiek and gold are amazing. Impressed me the most the first time I visited IStanbul. Tip: Go early, it has become more busy every year

well out of the way... but well worth it.. Not something you want to miss while you're in Istanbul.
The church is small, but it's covered in beautiful mosaics. Probably one of the top 5 sights in istanbul.
Only church that has remained a church-incredible with its age!. To visit something that is so old and intact gives one chills. Beautiful and only wish the walls could talk!

Visiting the chuch. It really is very beautiful. To better appreciate the mosaics pick up a flyer (which they keep hidden in a black box to encourage you to buy a book/guide!). The box has to be opened for the mutli-language guides. This box is on the wall on the left side of the exit door as you are heading out of the church. It is worth reading it explains how the mosaics are actually the life story of Mary from birth to death and explains the story of each mosaic picture which made them even more amazing!

Historical.. A must see in Istanbul!. You should not miss this place when you are in Istanbul. You need to know the Turkish name of the place (Kariye) coz no one knows about "Chora Church" and we really had a difficult time finding. We needed to ride a cab but not even cab drivers know that it's Chora Church. Entering the place, ,you get an amazing feeling seeing the mosaics & frescoes. Definitely a place to put in the bucket list! I am so happy we went here and got to see all the mosaics.

STUNNING. The Chora Church is just stunning. The mosaics from the 10th century are still in good condition. The church is a must to see for all denominations, as it reflects exactly as to what is spoken in the bible. Please go and see this historic church, it is worth the entry fee and the time to go. Do some research before you go, as it will help alot. EXCELLENT

Worth the trip. We took the tram and subway out and then walked 15 minutes along the old City walls, not easy but we found it. Its very small and crowded with tour groups, but take your time and look at the frescoes. As someone brought up Catholic it was fun to try to put the images to the Bible stories. Eaves drop on the tours to help learn what the frescoes are about.As with all of Turkey don't expect to be given any free pamphlet to explain what you are seeing. We didn't do it here but found elsewhere it is worth getting the audio guides.

Amazing!. Take a taxi from the Four Seasons Sultanahmed Hotel just outside the Topkapi Palace. Fare should be 15TL. Avoid taxis at the palace gate. We tried to take a bus from the Grand Bizarre but could find the stop or any help. Visit this beautiful church the relax with a cup of salep in the cafe'.

hidden gem. This was a gem we uncovered thanks to the friendly owner of Hotellino Istanbul, and I am so grateful for his recommendation too. The Chora Church is not in the usual touristy area so is slightly out of the way but well worth a visit. Despite being quite compact, the Church packs a multitude of gorgeous frescoes.You definitely need to do the audio tour to fully appreciate the stories that the frescoes tell.

Outstanding mosaics from Byzantium period. Beautifully presented (although a bit difficult to find) with fabulous mosaics.Strange to see representations from the bible - familiar yet ancient scenes. Wonderful experience - used to be outside the city walls. Locals call it Kariye Mosque - be sure to ask taxi driver for that rather than Chora otherwise you will get nowhere.

pictorial tour. peaceful and very ancient church with frescoes which are still intact despite part being turned into mosque, lovely old part of Istanbul and has its own rabbits in grounds....with turkish restaurant outside of church...popular although out of the way
Well worth the visit.. We love mosaics and we're glad we visited this wonderful museum. It is not walkable, but worth a cab ride. Not as crowded as most of the other sites.
Simply stunning. Slightly out the the centre of the tourist area but a must see, jump in a cab - the beauty of the byzantine mosiacs is just amazing you would not leave disappointed.

Must-see attractiobn. This beautiful church is a a real gem. It is a short bus ride from the Galata Bridge station on #36 bus. (buy your ticket at the booth before boarding). The bus passes under the aquaduct, too so have your camera ready.The 900 year old mosaics and frescoes are stunning --- actually maintained rather than destroyed because this remained a christian church rather than being converted to a mosque. Cost was about the same as most attractions 25tl. TIP: If you have a smart phone, don't rent the audio tour --- use the QR codes to get great details. (better than the audio tour)The grounds are peaceful, and if you time it, you can avoid crowds so you can really appreciate the interior. Nice little outdoor restaurant across the street for a coffee after your visit, and of course shops.. Afterward, we walked back --- visiting local shops and a great farmers market.
Wonderful mosaics. Teşhis is one of the oldest Chuches in Istanbul with excellent mosaics, exceeding those in St. Sofia. The black and gold mosaics are especiallt exceptional. Mustafa visin.

Fairly expensive but great mosaics. This church is far from the other sites and you will need to take a taxi or a bus. We definitely got charged over that what we should have for the taxi, so make sure to establish a price before you get in. The buses would have worked fine though. We ended up walking half way home and taking the bus the rest of the way. Beautiful mosaics though and well preserved.

breathtaking mosiacs and frescos. The museum was easily reached by tram and then light rail where you got an excellent view of the old city walls. The museum had wonderfully restored walls and ceilings. Make sure that you have a tour or at least a guidebook when you go from room to room.

Great Things Come in Small Packages!. The Chora Church (Church of the Holy Saviour Outside the Walls) is a very small church that dates from the 11th century. As with so many buildings in Istanbul, this one has also served as a mosque. Miraculously, the incredibly beautiful mosaics have, for the most part, survived. This is easily the most stunning building in all of Istanbul and the mosaics are absolutely breath-taking. Plan to spend time here; the longer you look at the mosaics, the more you come to appreciate them. The church is located quite a distance from most of the other attractions in the Sultanahmet area but it is well worth the bus or taxi ride. Highly recommended as one of the most beautiful sites in Istanbul!
Mosaics. This is a real gem with amazing mosaics and frescos. The setting is a bit off beaten track but easy to access by public bus. Enjoy the outer courtyard as well.
Very old frescoes. The first inspirations to reneissance art in the middle of Europe.A small place but takes minimum your 40 minutes to visit.

Place worth visiting. The only place in Istanbul that wall mosaics and frescoes from the Byzantine era were not demolished. Gives very beautiful and real feeling what the atmosphere was like to a person entering the religious space. To myself, the feeling of strong-colored figures against undulating surface of golden mosaics, was like the time and figures floated in front of me. Sort of timeless experience and well worth a visit.
A real jewel. This is an absolutely marvellous place. Fantastic frescos and fabulous mosaics. This site should be on every visitors itinerary.

Stunning mosiacs worthy of a visit. This sight is just on the outside of town. Where we stayed we had walked to all of the sights in the old town, however this is a quick (~15min) and cheap (10-20TL) taxi ride from the old town. You can take the bus to get there, but the taxi is much easier. There were no lines, and the crowds were negligibe (only two tour groups came through while we visited). However the mosiacs and frescos were stunning and we were very glad to have made the extra trip to see this church.
Ancient mosaics. A short taxi ride to one of the most stunning relics of the art of mosaics. a must see within Istanbul. Pre book tickets to save time.

Don't miss it.. This little church is a gem. The mosaics and frescoes are beautiful. The site itself is a little out of the way and IMO the taxis are run by a cartel, it was the only time in Istanbul were they weren't using the meter, and we negotiated before we got in. The area is a bit dodgey. But don't let that put you off, we were there first thing in the morning and it was fine.

Glorious. Fairly small church with the most amazing fresco's and mosaics. It's well worth buying the guide book before you look around as it points out the various bible stories depicted. Also a nice little cafe opposite for an apple tea when you have finished your tour.

Our favorite. Really unique experience to see mosaics and frescos almost perfectly intact. Spring for the audioguide, it's worthwhile. A little far from downtown, but we coupled this trip with dinner at Asitane, which was just amazing. Recommend mid-afternoon visit so you can roll right into dinner afterwards. Also, nearby, parts of the old city walls.

A lesson in Christianity. The mosaics depict the story of Christ and the Virgin Mary. It's a small but very important church. Of interst is the hall where the altar facing Mecca is between the mosaics of Jesus Christ and the Blessed Mother.

out of the way but stunning. I didn't get to Chora until my second trip to Istanbul and I'm so glad I did. Compared to Hagia Sofia and the Blue Mosque, this place is tiny, but the mosaics are absolutely breathtaking. Take the time to get a guide book or bring your kindle to walk through the significance of each mosaic... there are symbols and icons galore that are fun to read about. Also of note... you will get dizzy and your neck will hurt from look straight up and trying to follow the circular story arc of the mosaic. I had to go outside for some fresh air every now again to stop spinning.

The top-rated attraction in Istanbul for a reason. I visited this church my last day in Turkey and was glad I did. Many of the ceilings and walls are covered with breathtaking mosaics and frescos from the 13th century. My wife and I had seen some fine Christian frescoes in the Goreme Open Air Museum, but the Chora Church takes this art to a much higher level.
Well Worth the Trip. A small church - but well worth the trip to see. The mosaics are beautiful and inspiring, steeped in history. Truly remarkable, one of my favorite sites we saw!

Second after Hagia Sophia. It has marvelous mosaics like a cartoon story of Orthodox bible is in color on its inner walls... Altough its a bit off the route from the old town center it is definitely worth to go there. You might also like to go to the restaurant Asitane right near Kariye Museum as they use old Ottoman recipes, like eating out in an Ottoman restaurant of 300 years ago...!

Interesting and historical church. Again this place requires homework or a good guide. We had a good guide. Other wise it is so crowded that it would be nearly impossible to appreciate if you had to read a guidebook while looking at all the mosaics and frescoes.

lovely experience. Loved the neighbourhood. The church is beautiful and the tile work exquisite. Sad that the main dome has had all of its tiles removed. The restaurant across the lane served some nice snacks. Would definitely return.
Church in the fields!. A delightful district, the mosaics in the building are extraordinary. Who says the renaissance began in Florence.
Mozaics. Wonderful small Church off the beaten tract but the frescos are to die for. considering the age they are in good repair and for such a small space just give a glimpse of what must have been

unmissable. we nearly didnt go here because it was a bit harder to get to!!!. Got a taxi from Sultanahmet and managed to get a bus back. The mosaics are amazing and would have to be the best we saw in Turkey
Beautiful, beautiful. Such a gem, in a quiet suburban area, hidden away from the main sights of Istanbul. The mosaics are just incredible.
Mosaic heaven. The on,y rival I've seen is in Ravenna. Stunning mosaics and frescos. A must-see for Byzantine or art lovers. Right next to the walls for a quick jaunt to see the view.
jewels. the frescoes and mosaics of the Chora are matchless in the city and stand with those of Sicily, Venice and Ravenna
The best preserved mural icons. Amazingly preserved mural fresco icons on the walls of this Byzantine monastery! The details are superb both from a historical perspective and from a religious one.
Must see!. So many people don't visit here, but it is a wonderful little church with amazing was mosaics. It's a bit out of the way from most of the other sites, but we loved it!
A jewel of Byzantine Art. Well preserved mosaics and frescoes with stories of Mary and fromt the Book of Revelation: a real 'Biblia Pauperum!

Wonderful mosaics and frescoes. The Chora Church is a bit of a distance from the main tourist sights of Istanbul. Because of shortage of time we took a taxi to and from. It was well worth the effort to see the outstanding mosaics and frescoes.
Go here.. Yes, it is far off the beaten path but well worth the visit. Visually stunning. Pair this with a walk along the city walls and lunch at Asitane and you will not be disappointed.

Go early, but don't miss this. It took several tries for me to make it to Kariye. First it was closed and then it was too late in the day. I ended up going first thing in the morning, and that was perfect. Only two tour groups had ventured out for the opening at 9 AM, so I had ample time without the crowds to view these magnificent treasures. If you a well versed in the scriptures, you can easily understand most of what is pictured in the mosaics and frescoes, but if you are not familiar with Christian Gospels, then a guide book wil be supremely helpful. One hint, buy your post cards across the way...they are cheaper and bigger than inside the museum.
Beautiful mosaics. Although out of the way location-wise, it is well worth the trek to see this museum. Some of the most gorgeous mosaics we have ever seen in such an ancient site.

Spiritual Place. This is on the must see list for Istanbul. The mosaics and frescos are just wonderful. It is a little out from the Historic centre but easily assessable. There is a restaurant and good facilities here.
not as easy to get to. If you are staying in the Sultanahmet area this can be a little more difficult to get to but it is very interesting. Worth making the effort to see

Stunning. This church is a MUST SEE when you visit Istanbul. The mosaics and wall paintings are totally stunning.A short bus, tram or taxi ride from the centre of Istanbul, this church, now a museum , cannot fail to stun the senses. Also,close by are some of Istanbul's ancient city walls which are definitely worth seeing. There are several cafes and two small supermarkets near the church too if you want to stay for something to eat while you're in the area.

Interesting but disappointing. It was a real struggle to get to and from the Kariye Museum..an expensive cab ride (twice) from the Blue Mosque area..and the first time we arrived late in the day it had closed (contrary to guidebook posted hours); the art is interesting, obviously treasured and looked after, but difficult to view, and quite crowded. Nice to have seen but not worth the effort, particularly if you are short on time.
beautiful ancient mosaics. we loved this site and spent a long time viewing the fantastic mosaics well worth a visit nothing like it except ravenna.

Small yet beautiful!. 1. Time and Fee: 9AM-5PM closed Wednesday. Fee: 15TL, but we use our Museum pass. Kids: free.2. Review: The church itself is small yet beautiful. It's walls and ceilings decorated with magnificent mosaics and frescoes of Christ. Its just amazing!3. How to get there: IMHO, TAXI is the best transportation to get there, but BEWARE of TAXI SCAM always ask to use taximeter,and make sure the meter is working properly, we almost get scam 3 times!! dont take taxi from near hagia sophia/ blue mosque, the 1st taxi driver around that touristy area would charged us 40-50TL. Fortunately, I know it should be no more than 20TL from sultanahmet area to this church.So, we leaved him and took tram to sirkeci station and find the 2nd taxi driver, he ask for 25TL, we leaved him. Then we found an honest taxi driver, he ask for 20TL but we ask him to use the taximeter then he said ok, turn out it only cost us 14TL. On the way back, we took taxi that standby near Chora church,when we ask to use taximeter, he said yes, but this taxi driver is the worst, he manipulated the meter, from 2.70TL to 4TL then jump to 12TL and turn back to 6TL, but then suddenly become 15TL?!?! when we ask him what happen with his meter, he begin to yell to us, then drop us in the middle of nowhere. We were shocked!! Grab another taxi,luckily this last one is an honest man.

A Little Surprise. Getting to the church is a bit of a haul by public transportation, but I really wanted to see it and a bit of the Theodosius city walls. The couple of rooms and hallways contain some magnificent frescoes and mosaics - I just wanted prepared for how small it was.

A church tucked away outside the city.. Turkey is like one big museum and every nook and corner has a story hence if you have time since it's quite far away from the major tourist areas and/or a BIG history buff or christian then visit. Chora Church is considered to be one of the most beautiful surviving examples of a Byzantine church, honestly i didnt appreciate it as much because of the lack of the above points i just mentioned and only went because i had covered pretty much everything else.

nnarcin. This small Byzantian church is very nice with her iconas as well as building and, location. I visited Kariye Museum for several times and, it was always attracting...Only, take care of cheating sellers...
a must. The Chora Church is out of the way and not on public transport, so a taxi is needed to get there. The murals and the building itself are very well kept, and a must see.

Small but attractive. Situated in a quiet square, this beautiful old church in its own well-kept gardens has well-preserved tesserae and murals. You only need 30 minutes here, and then you can rest up with a snack at the cafe opposite

Not to be missed. Really worth a visit. We got to it by walking the wall from a tram stop....quite an expedition and well worth it for a real view of Istanbul. This church is a gem for its mosaics and frescoes as well as its location. We returned in the evening for a meal aat the hotel next to the church..wow!

Exquisite little Byzantine church with delicate and beautiful mosaics.. Church and immediate setting was interesting, if a little touristy. Difficult to find with poor directions in Lonely Planet guide.
An exquisite Byzantine church. Superb frescoes and gorgeous mosaics. It's located near the Theodosian walls - you'll likely need a taxi to get there. Some of the best mosaics in Istanbul.

The Mosaics are very significant. This church (built 1100's) has the first historical depiction of Christ. All subsequent depictions are derivative. This makes seeing this church very important. The other mosaics are also very historically significant. A must see.
Full of history and legends. Its a part of history. It is associated by numerous miracles and "miracles" or in other words full of legends (depends on point of view). Its worth to sight seeing.
The most impressive byzantine church. One of the most best preserved byzantine churches in Istanbul. Amazing mozaics, shows the spendor of byzantine art.
Chora Church. Not to be missed the most wonderful mosaics and fresco paintings......exceptional and well worth the visit, slightly out of the other popular sites but not to be missed
worth the walk. Absolutely stunning mosaics and architecture. Quite a sense of travelling back in time to meet early Christianity.

A must see.. The mosaics are amazing. The history of this Church and mosaics are one to know about. Finding the Church is a little tricky and the Church is small, but the mosaics tell the powerful story of Mary and Jesus in a way no other Church has.
unique building with many features. a must see ! all the iconas, frescos very well protected, they say all about the storied in the Bible

Spectacular mosaics. The Chora is one of the less-visited destinations in Istanbul. Unless you are with a tour, it is a little off the beaten track. But it is easy to get to by public transportation and well-worth the trip. The Byzantine mosaics are mind-blowing. There is a great Ottoman restaurant next door, The Atisane.

Stunning mosaics. Another taxi trip here but well worth the effort. The church is a beautiful building from the outside but the mosaics inside are stunning. I really can't imagine what it would have been like when it was intact, but what there is left is certainly impressive enough. There is a small entrance charge and plenty of nearby cafe's to sit in after your visit!I'm afraid the description on my pictures are rubbish as I have no idea what anything is - I didn't take a guidebook with me.

Great place to visit.. Wonderful place to visit. Beautiful mosaics and frescoes. A little out of the way so not many of the visitors from the huge cruise ships visited this wonderful small museum. Well worth the trip when you get there if you are interested in history or art!
Must see. Small jewell from late byzantin times. One of the most amazing places to see in Istanbul. I would rather skip topkapi than this church.

Christianity and the byzantine era. A little off the beaten tourist track, this little 5th century chapel is definitely worth the effort of finding in the Edirnekapı neighborhood. A cab may well be the easiest way here, and I recommend you get the cab to wait for you as it is about 15 minutes from the Grand Bazaar. Allow around 30 - 45 minutes here for your walk around.The outside is unimposing, but as soon as you enter the chapel you are confronted with some of the most beautiful, intricate and intact byzantine work remaining in the world. The biblical characters and stories from your Sunday school lessons will come to life in mosaic, gold and muted fresco's.Sometime in the 16th century, during the Ottoman era, the church became a mosque and in 1948 it was commissioned as a museum. It is easy to become absorbed in capturing the artistry with your camera, but take a moment to sit in silent reflection and let the centuries of prayer and meditation feed your soul.There is a cafe here, however I did not stop, so cannot make a recommendation. It did seem popular.Enjoy.
Fantastic and unique early mosaics. Most amazing mosaics of the life of Christ. Very busy and out of the city centre but worth the effort.

Outstanding Mosaics and Paintings. We walked up the hill from a City Windows tour bus stop (St. Georges Church). It's a bit of a hike, but worth the hassle. There are incredible mosaics depicting the lives of Christ and Mary, and paintings of events after the Crucifixion. Next time I'd probably take a taxi, but the walk through old neighborhoods of Istanbul to reach the museum is interesting. Stop and have a glass of tea with the locals.

done in under 30 mins. small church, some beautiful and impressive mosaics and clearly with a lot of history... we had lunch first at Asitane (next door) which is a little expensive but very tasty... the shopping directly around the church for Ceramics (hand made in the south of turkey) was worthwhile... if you do all three of those - it's a worthwhile trip...

One of the highlights of our trip!. The easiest way to get to this Church is by taxi which is not expensive (although we were ripped off by our taxi driver so getting to the Church cost double what getting back from it did!). The Church itself is amazing - the mosaics are brilliant and even standing just a short distance back from them you would swear you were looking at a painted surface rather than one made up of thousands of little tiles. The Church is small but we were lucky and managed to visit at a time when it wasn't so busy - just as we left a huge tour group was arriving so we were very happy to have had the time and space to view this treasure comfortably.
Bueatiful paintings and work. Bueatiful paintings and work, raly morning visits are even better because of the number of tourists.
well worth your time. I love mosaics and am glad I went. It is not walkable, but worth a cab ride. Not as crowded as most of the other sites.

a must to see. incredible murals. murals (paint and tiles) which cover the walls and ceilings tell the story of the bible. Rooms are relatively small and can be very crowded. Market area just outside the church.

MUST SEE. A fantastic place to see and experience. What history! Stunning mosaics. We took the tram from the Blue Mosque, transferred to Edienne, and it was a short walk from there. The locals easily give directions

What a surprise. Our Turkish friend told us we must not miss the mosaics and frescos int Chora. And he was right. One of the most significant churches anywhere in the world. Well worth as visit to Istanbul just to see this.

Must visit. Exceptional byzantine monument. Must visit for sure when you go to Istanbul.
Unique beauty mosaics , in exceptional condition
The Chora Church. The Chora Church has unique and well preserved mosaiques. Worth visiting and seeing for all the admirers of byzantine history.
Wonderful mosaics and frescoes. A real treasure. The fact that the mosaics and frescoes have survived 1500 years is amazing. You can take a taxi from the old city for about 20 Turkish lira.

Breathtaking. The Chora Church is often included on the list of "greatest hits" for Istanbul. As it is not that easy to access, I find that many visitors choose another place and time. I urge you not to miss this extrarordinary place, world class by any standard. The mosaics and paintings of scenes from the life of Christ are beautifully conserved and easily viewable from within the supportive architecture of the building. I was particularly interested in how scenes, and the structures within the scenes, conformed to the arcs and arches of the domes and their supports. Take advantage of the audio tour; it is comprehensive, very interesting, and very quiet alternative to the babble of many guides in several languages at once. If you can find a corner, or an hour early or late beyond the crowds, it is a contemplative opportunity unique to Istanbul and elsewhere. The adjacent cafe is restful and an adjacent restaurant is reported to be excellent.

Mosaics!. We heard that the Hagia Sophia does not reflect the art of the Byzantine church and that Chora church is remarkable in this regard. It's true. Chora is a wee bit out of the way, but well worth the visit. Go with a guide or rent the audio phone. It's well worth your time and trouble.
Unforgettable Mosaics. A little difficult to get to, but well worth it for the beautiful, Pre-Renaissance mosaics, so humanistic for their time!
Lovely mosaics. Lovely mosaics. Worth it just for that. A very Christian place if that is important to you. A very short trip from city centre.

Stunning. Take a good guidebook such as "Strolling through Istanbul". It was easy to get a bus from Beyazit. This has to be one of the treasures of the world. So much of interest packed into the glorious mosaics. My personal favourite was the one of Mary's first steps with her mother's gown and the cypress tree blowing in the wind in the same direction as the baby's tottering steps. Busy, but you could spend hours here.

Do not miss this church!. This is a bit off of the tourist circuit, and so might be missed. Make a point of getting there. The mosaics are unbelievable and the audio guide is well worth the price. Very special
Amazing frescoes and mosaics. This Church is a must see in Istanbul - it has the most beautiful christian mosaics and is wonderfully serene and peaceful.
worth a visit. excellent tour guide here - worth visiting and very interesting - go earlier in the day with less people around.
Outstanding. Worth the trip to the north of the touristic area. Much less tourists group at lunch time. One of the most beautiful mosaic church we've ever seen.
Amazing, alone worth the trip. Among the the most outstanding mosaics in the world. The building, incredibly well preserved, takes the visitor back to 15 centuries ago

Gorgeous church. This church is absolutely beautiful and well worth seeking out. Only thing is we found it almost impossible to get to by public transport - never mind, we got to experience Turkish friendliness and Turkish taxi driving in our endeavours to visit the Chora church!!

One of the best sites. Although a bit away from the major historic sites, this is a gem. Originally an Orthodox Church built outside the city walls (chora) it was magnificently decorated with mosaics representing the life of Christ. Most have been at least partly restored. Before you go read the background. These are the mosaics you need to see. Tiny church so easily visible. Few people seem to go except Monday since other museums are closed. The early Byzantine architecture and the use of marble to create decorative patterns instead of sculpture is intriguing. Some frescos but they seem to require serious restoration and are from a newer period. One of the top restaurants in town, Asatane, is next door but be sure to make a reservation. There is also a small hotel that looked inviting but I make no recommendation. Across the street is the usual cafe for kabobs and fresh juice. We shared the mixed platter and it was large and tasty. Watch for unscrupulous taxi drivers even with a meter we had a cost issue.

Absolutely Do Not miss!. It takes a 15 minute taxi ride (not very expensive) to get there from the Hagia Sophia/Blue Mosque area, so you might be tempted not to bother. But that would be a big mistake. This church has the most amazing frescoes and mosaics in perhaps the world, and certainly is a highlight of any visit to Istanbul. The audio guide does an excellent job of explaining each panel and guiding you through in the sequence of the Bible stories (which is not the same sequence as you would tend to follow taking yourself from room to room).

Very Worthwhile stop.. Our guide, Ram found an alternate entrance for me that
made it easier. He explained the murals thoroughly to us. Loved it.
Art Treasure. The range of the mosaics and frescoes. The crowds could be quite large and it was somewhat confusing as to what route to take.
worth visiting. This is a gem of a preserved church, beautiful frescoes and mosiacs. Worth the travel out to the city walls to see it.

Beautiful space and a welcome break from super-crowded spaces.. Maybe it was just the time of day/week/year that I visited but it was wonderfully peaceful and I found the exterior of the building and the grounds just as beautiful as the insides. I did not do the audio tour but a native helped explained a little bit of the history to us. Loved learning about the updates the churches go through switching religions. Bonus: really classy, though tiny, gift shop as well!
Amazing mosaics. This church is not on the traditional beaten path of old town tourist sites and takes a little effort to get to. Do go as it is well worth it. The mosaics are beautiful.
the best in Istanbul. just amazing... a nice surprise, took lots of pictures in and outside in the lower park. I got there on a Ferry from Iminonu and I walked up the hill 20 minutes.

Amazing. this church is amazing the mosaics are beatifull, take the audioguide, the explanation is very complete, but sometimes you have to hear it twice and look around to understand what are they taking about. If you are a couple take earphones with you and you can use only one audioguide.

An historic must see. The best mosaics bar none, historic art. Requires taxi from most places but worth it. Many travel guides suggest a walk along the Theodosian walls, and other Byzantine sites as well as less traveled neighborhoods; this is also well worth the effort.
A gem. This church was an unexpected delight. It is filled with crisp mosaics in vivid colours. A real sense of history.

Gobsmacking. We were told about the Chora Church and how wonderful it was but none of it prepared us for the beauty of the mosaics. Absolutely gorgeous and because the church is little one can see all the artwork up close. It is somewhat far from most other sites but we visited it on the day we used the Hop on Hop off tour bus which made it easier. Go and see it and allow enough time to wait for big tour groups to go through if necessary.
beautiful old mosaics. Difficult to get to except by cab. Mosaics were covered up so they are colorful and fresh looking. Wonderful garden restaurant.
Spectacular Byzantine church. A lovely church with amazing 14th century mosaics and frescoes, well worth a journey. If you have the time, walk down the hill to the Pammakaristos Church too.

You must visit it!. Don't think twice if you are a big fan of frescoes, mosaics and icons (like me). Just go. Chora Museum is full of Byzantine art (it is second only to Hagia Sophia) and history. It is hard to get there by public transport but possible - I did it. Just take the tram until Topkapi Gate or Edirnekapi Gate Station and walk. You will see the City Walls (also worth a visit).

A must when visiting Istanbul.. This little Church has an abundance of beautiful mosaics and is a 5 star attraction. Unfortunately there were 3 large tour groups there at the same time which detracted slightly from the enjoyment. I have amazing pictures on my picture blog which you will enjoy. http:/hennopsrover.blogspot.com. I hope this brings the church alive for you.

Nice monuments. Another great historical monuments of Istanbul City. The location is not that bad, and there are public transportation you can use to go to This place from Eminonu Bus Station.The church itself is most famous for its frescoes covered on the inner parts of the church.

Chora Church. Difficult to find. Need to take several trams of buses to get there. Very small, but great icons. It is not promoted by the tourist places and limited information is available. Best to take a taxi or take a bus from the university of Istambul or from Taskin Square.
Interesting but not arresting. Good examples of wall/ceiling paintings and mosaics. The church is near the city walls which are also interesting, but the surrounding neighbourhood has few amenities.
Beautiful old church!. The frescoes covering the walls and ceilings are stunning! Good to have a tour guide to explain the stories behind them.

Great for Church History buffs, and others. The main attraction are the ancient Christian mosaics that continue to be in good condition. Extensive collection and I thought well worth the trip. This area is off the beaten path, though and somewhat had to get to.

beautiful museum. Used to be a byzantin church but now it is turned into a museum, very well kept!!! It's so fortunate that the mosaics and frescos were not ruined when the Byzantine empire fell and the church was converted into a mosque but they were just covered up so now they are revealed! It's a bit off the usual turist path, near the Edirnekapi walls but there is also a small square right outside with some shops and cafes so it's really pleasant and worth visiting!

Byzantine art in its original location. For people who enjoy religious art this is a must see. Slightly out of the main drag, so a taxi will be needed, but well worth the trip. The mosaics and Frescos depicting the life of Mary and Jesus are outstanding

Very old detailed mosaics. If you have not been to Italy to see mosaics there, these are great and very comparable. Nice to have someone available to rub your neck afterwards as you will be looking up a lot. It was very crowded when we arrived as a couple buses had just arrived. We stayed long enough for them to clear out and it was a much more enjoyable experience. Aspe has been cleaned out of all evidence of being a church so that was the only disappointing part.

Byzantine mosaics in the suburbs of Istanbul. Chora church (museum) is worth the bit of a trip it takes to get out to the western suburbs of Istanbul. However, check into the ferry schedule (Goldern Horn Ferry) as we couldn't get one the (Sunday) we tried - and had to talk the #37 or 38 bus (from the same Eminonu terminal) up to near the church.Once there (and after eating at the excellent Asitane, right next door) we got to walk around the well preserved church. The mosaics are beautiful and really comprise the main reason to visit. Do try to get down there if you have an extra few hours in Istanbul.

Small but gorgeous. Not in the center but easy to get to by cab. Can be busy with tours but well worth it. The mosaics and frescoes are breathtaking. The neighborhood is charming. Be sure to climb up on the city walls nearby for a great view and eat at Asitane, a real treat.

Unique inheritance. The best preserved mosaics! Don't miss the opportunity to admire this unique inheritance. Pay attention to the colours, as only in Chora Church and Pammakarists Church the white colour is used as a "wallpaper".
Don't miss Chora Church. Well worth the effort.. Don't miss Chora Church. Well worth the effort. One of the very few places in Istanbul where you can catch a glimpse of Byzantium.

Unbelievably beautiful. The Chora or Keriya Museum certainly lives up to its reputation and the frescoes are just so beautiful and considering their age, most are in very good condition.The audio is very good although at times, I found it a little difficult to locate which fresco they were talking about. The frescoes are well lit and I was lucky to go when it wasn't to busy so could take the photos I wanted and stand and admire the wonderful artwork. Even if you are not religious, you would have to admire the artwork and appreciate the beauty.After taking a tram to Topkapi and then a taxi (20TL from the tram station) we decided to walk up to the main street and take the bus back. Really enjoyed the ride which takes you to the University (close to the Grand Bazaar).

What a gem. There are at least two aspects of this church that will absolutely blow your mind, but you really need a guide or an audio guide or a good guide book. First of all the frescos and mosaics are of the highest artistic quality. Secondly, if you have never heard te story of Mary's life than you will learn a bit. Thirdly, the restoration of the art work was clearly painstaking and thorough. Not too be missed.

Pleasant Surprise. While relatively unknown, this church has some of the best remaining examples of Byzantine church art in the world. However, because of its setting and relative anonymity, it's easy to visit without the hassle of long lines and masses of people. Another interesting aspect of this church is that it's in the most conservative part of Istanbul and it's not unusual to see women in this area walking in full chador and bearded men in baggy pants. All in all, definitely worth a look, especially if you're interested in Istanbul's Byzantine past.

An expensive visit. I don't know much about Byzantine art, and maybe if I did I would have been more amazed by what were, in fact, some very nice mosaics, but it was an expensive visit, between the taxi rides, admission fee, renting the audio guide, etc. Also, once we exited (almost by accident), we could not get back in to easily return the audio guides, or use the toilets! The place had the feel of a tourist trap, although I am sure it is much more than that. The crowds of tourists, being led by their guides, in what is a fairly cramped space, did not help either. Not sorry I went, but did not think this was the #2 attraction in Istanbul!!
Completely worthwhile. Although we had to travel by taxi to get there, it was completely worth the trip. Many stories from the Bible were displayed as colorful mosaics in stunning detail.

Not to be missed !!. What a pleasant surprise. The Chora Church is 15-20 minutes out of downtown Istambul. On the ruins of Constantinople is this beautiful church with amazing bizanthine frescoes and mosaics showing scenes from the most relevant moments of the life of Christ.
Second to none in its own art by its own merits.
Not to be missed !!
overcrowded. The church itself is beautiful but there were too many other people also wanting to see the mosaics! Our fault for not going when it opened.

Beautiful Byzantine mosaics!. Kariye Museum is off the beaten path in Istanbul and requires taking the Metro and walking a bit or catching a cab (easy to do in Istanbul). But what a worthwhile experience! Beautiful and educational, this small church has mosaics that are stunning. Take a tour or buy a guide book, as you will learn so much!

Masterpiece of Byzantine art. Amazing frescoes and mosaics. A bit off the beaten path, but it's well worth the traveling outside town. To go back to Sultanahmet you can bargain a taxi for no more than 15 lt. They will ask you for 20lt.
Highly recommended.

Small, but stunning mosaics you should not miss!. This church shows the extent of Orthodox Christian creativity, creating mosaics in the ceilings and walls of Biblical scenes that appear dazzling and new even though centuries old. You need both super-wide lens and telephoto to capture both the splendor and the detail of this marvelous church.

Escape from the tour groups. What a delight. I never would have sought out this small church if it weren't rated so highly on TA. Had just come from Topkapi Palace totally overrun by tour groups and found this a uncrowded calm environment. The mosaics were absolutely stunning. I might have paid 30 euro each way for the taxi which may be high, as you can't easily take the tram. But it was worth it and was my favorite place I saw.

Chora church. We were visiting the balat area ,where we found out it has the kariye church ,unfortunatley it was wednesday,and the kariye church is closed on wednesdays,so check the website before u go,we went to balat (where the chora church is) by bus,u can go to eminonu and catch the balat bus (bus number 99 at stand 9 ) and drop off at the balat stop,u can ask the locals for the karyie museum and its an uphill 25 min slow walking from the bus station,keep asking untill u get there,
Definitely go. A bit out of town but definitely worth it beautiful mosaics and paintings. For a bit of adventure take the local bus.

Amazing. It is so unbelievable that we can see such old pieces of art. Church is in the middle of neighbourhood with small houses. Small but making very big impression. Mosaics are magnificent. Ticket => 15tl.
Beautiful mosaics. Interesting little church. Our guide was able to pick out the important parts of the mosaics and relate them to the bible.
A special little museum. Fantastic mosaics, a little out of the main stream area but if mosaics interest you then it is worth the effort.
A Jewel. The church is a considerable distance from the other sites and can be missed by independent travelers. Don't let this happen to you as it is a marvel of Byzantine construction.

wonderful. the mosaics were wonderful , it was just so interesting to visit the church which had over 100 mosaics in very good condition and was changed to a mosque in 1511. Make sure you look up at the exterior before going in
Beautiful mosaics!. Small but full of magnificent mosaics telling religious stories. It has a rich history of many different religious affiliations, and has lovely architecture.

Fantastic Mosaics. This church is awe inspiring by its historical developments and amazing mosaics and frescos. It is not very large and can get very airless when there are quite a few people visiting. Having to crane your neck backwards for a long period of time can cause some difficulties, but you can't do it any other way. It's well worth visiting as part of a cultural tour of Istanbul.
Fantastic Frescoes. The frescoes were beautiful and we recommend getting an audio guide to help you be better informed about the frescoes. We found it very interesting and intriguing

A top-10 European historical site. The beauty of 'Chora' is its intimacy; much more approachable than the other mega 'must-sees'. The mosaics are simply outstanding; wonderful shades of colour and light; evocative expressions; great insights into the difference between Catholic and Orthodox. Options to ponder the difference between the Word and the dogma.At 5 TL audio-guide is a bargain and chock full of information. Don't bother with public transport; it is just too complicated. Check that the taximeter is on and it will be 15 TL from Sirkeçi station (Sultanahmet) - outside rush hours. Do not accept a fixed price offer; you will be fleeced. Get your ticket on-line.I rank this one of the two mega must-sees along with Hagia Sofia.
Early Christian Church. A little hard to find. Very nice frescos in the historic church. Worth a visit if you have a second day in Istanbul

Out of the way but worth the trip. It's a bit out of the way if you are staying in the Sultanahmet or Taksim part of Istanbul. But the moscaics and frescoes are top notch and worth the extra time required to visit. I learned alot about how frescoes are done. More importantly, the frescoes in the newer part of this church are some of the earliest examples of perspective and 3-dimensionality in paintings; it may be argued that the renassiance in art started in Constantinople and was carried to other parts of Europe. I would put this on the short list of must sees, right after Hagia Sophia and the Topkapi palace

Well worth the travel. Excellently preserved frescoes very evocative of the Byzantine era This took us outside the main tourist area and gave us the chance to explore another historic part of Istanbul..
Amazing mosaics. The church at Chora is well worth the visit. The spectacular mosaics were simply beautiful. Try and visit early in the day as it gets busy.

This was a surprise. Hadn't known about this church, the mosaics are utterly wonderful and the space is more intimate than Hagia Sophia. The pictures focus on the life of Mary and the early Saints, they will take your breath away for their beauty.
Out of the way, but worth it. Beautiful mosaics in a rather small Byzantine-era church. The scale of the place makes it easier to appreciate the mosaics which depict the life of Christ.

Absolutely stunning. It is quite far from the centre, but there is a bus going there and then a short walk is needed. If you believe the mosaics in Hagia Sophia are fabulous, believe or not, you have seen nothing. You just have to see those in Chora. The church itself does not look very impressive bit just get inside.

Well worth the effort to visit. This was the second time we had visited the church. It's a little jewel in the crown of Istanbul. The early Christian frescoes and mosaics are so beautiful and still in a very good state of preservation. If you visit on your own it's well worth taking the time to go in between tour groups - then it is quieter, more atmospheric and definitely more enjoyable!

Worth a visit. The mosaics are too beautiful not to visit the Chora Church. I can't believe there is gift shop in one of the corners of the church, right above all the art! There are not a lot of food options around the church so eat before. Also, cabs back to the city are easy to find.

Worth a taxi ride from the Sultanahmet area. Beautiful mosaics, marbles and frescoes. We used Rick Steeves Istanbul Guide which was very descriptive. You will see the city walls on the way to the church, There is a nice shady cafe across the street where we had a lovely apple tea.

Intense. I would have liked more time to guide myself around the stunning mosaics in this church, but I was with a group and had limited time. It gets quite busy as well, which makes it awkward to see some walls and ceilings clearly. Worth the effort getting there.

A bit of a trek but worth the effort. A beautiful and very old church out by the city walls that is worth the visit. Easy enough to get to on the tram then about a 10 min walk. Fantastic mosaics and a nice change of architecture from all of the Turkish Ottoman sites in the centre of town.

Beautiful. I always love old buildings! It was neat to stand there & think of how it was built so long ago.
Very nostalgic so worth a visit.

Colorful display of the life of Christ. A guided tour through the church at an easy pace, amazing factual information about the elevated role of Mary, the mother of Jesus, whose position was almost equated with the divinity.

Spirit of Constantinople. A "must see" if you go to Istanbul: this christian church is a museum nowadays and has the most beautiful paintings and mozaïcs you can imagine. The famous 'Christ' (Aya Sofia) is also here on the walls, as well as scenes from the old and the new testament. You'll find guides in different languages and you can use QR codes at the entrance if you have a smart phone. Have a look at the ancient walls when passing the street with the wooden houses!

I missed it :). Unfortunately saw it only from the outside. Stupid stupid! Read your guides and remember the closing days since not everything is closed on the same day. I thought it was closed on Monday. It was closed on Wednesday - my last day there. There is a very nice park with a great view of the outside just bellow the Church with a good enough cafe.
A jewel in Constantinople. The vivid colors of the frescoes and the mosaics along with the opus sectiles are beyind imagination....A living example of the Byzantine art of the Palaiologian period.
Wonderful mosaics and frescos.. This is a must see on any Istanbul trip. It is a little out of town but is included in many tours. Include the city walls on your tour.

The Chora Church. One of the oldest churches in the world. Although quite small, its architecture is most interesting. The paintings, which are centuries old, depicting the life of Jesus and other religious figures are outstanding.

Unmissable. This should be your #1 unmissable Istanbul site if you are interested in ancient churches and mosaics. No website or printed picture can begin to do justice to the incredible effect when you walk in and see panel after panel of glittering art.
byzantine excellence. a church that everyone must see when visiting Istanbul. The very well kept mosaics and fresco's give an idea of the high standards of culture in Byzantine times.

Attractive. I do not like museums but this museum is very attractive and i think it is one of the best attraction place in istabul, i recommend if you have enough time take a look at here but if you have not enough time it is not priority

The best Byzantine mosaics in the world. A bit out of the way, and off the well-beaten tourist path is a beautiful small church, set just inside the Theodosian walls, with some of the best Byzantine mosaics in the world. In addition to the mosaics and frescoes, a great place adjacent to the church serves wonderful mezze for lunch or dinner. The combination makes for a splendid morning with lunch, or late afternoon with dinner. Accessible either by public transit (tram and metro), with a bit of a walk, or by taxi.

Extras. We love this little museum with rich history and art. It is the best among the place I visited in Istanbul with Christian arts. The extra bonus is afterward, we walked to the walls nearby. We were able to climb up to the wall, to enjoy the breeze and the grand harbor view. Right next to the museum there is a wonderful Ottoman style restaurant. The food is a little pricy but good. We had an appetizer with four different assortments of cheese or beans. Each one was pounded with fresh local herbs. It is best of its class. These extras made the trip even more memorable.

Beautiful former church with incredible mosaics, a hidden gem. We got there easily by public transport. The benefit of this was that we saw the ancient city walls and also got a taste of some 'ordinary' parts of the city. But take care when crossing the roads!As always, it seems, in Turkey, there was little information provided to explain the full significance of what we were viewing.

Easy to get to with the new tram. Beautiful mosaics - lovely little church.Caught tram from Sultanahmet to Topkapi (tram stop - not the palace!) then changed trams taking the new one from Topkapi to Edirnekopi - then walked for 5 mins to Kariye Cami (Chora Church).Had lunch at Asitane - made a booking prior to going thru the church. Fabulous lunch
beautiful. It's well worth the visit. The mosaics were impressive. Gives you a feel for the lost Byzantine world.

A Unique Church. Since we had a walking tour of Istanbul on Monday and Hagia Sophia is closed on Mondays, we were taken instead to Chora Church. It is a out of the ordinary CHURCH,, beautiful mosaics and frescoes. The feelings that you experience being there can't be described
The Mosaics make it worth it!. Hard to find but worth it. Hiked here from Beyoglu and got lost on side streets. Very much worth it as once there, mosaics were spectacular.

A Precious Gem of Byzantine Frescos, Mosaics - Not to Be Missed!. I have seen many beautiful sights across the world ... Yet this small church filled with outstanding frescos and mosaics is a very special place that I return to again and again. Originally built in the country (ie Chora), this church is off the beaten path (and often not on basic tourist itineraries). However, if you are an art lover it is very much worth the effort!
Well worth the trip. The mosiacs in this little church are beautiful - more impressive and informative than the Hagia Sophia. A little gem!!!
Chora Church. I liked the different styles of the church depending which room you were in and the mosiac's were beautiful, however it is quite far from the center of town.
Incredible Mosaics. This beautiful little church has astonishing mosaics. Well worth the taxi ride. The audioguide is a worthwhile investment.

worth heading off to. The mosaics are quite well preserved and fascinating - maybe not as stunning as those in Ravenna or Torcello, but very, very good and a chance to see what Byzantine churches were like in contrast to all the later mosques.

A unique experience. Fascinating and beautiful. Try to find a time when it is not busy as it is quiet and can be rather haunting. We generally return for a second visit. Located close to the hippodrome and close to many small restaurants.

Quiet and interesting. Taken there as part of a small tour. No line to get tickets, and was relatively quiet there. Seemed to me a small version of Hagia Sophia. Calm and peaceful location. A painter had a small stand outside selling his work and could not resist buying a painting!
Beautiful mosaics!. Intimate place and great mosaic story on Mary. Lovely restaurant right next door. A little off the beaten path but well worth the detour.

Small and interesting. It is in a location that is not that easy to get to by public transport. The church has some beautiful mosaics which are worth seeing. We did this as part of a small group tour and you need to be there early to enjoy the experience before the large tour groups come through.

a little hard to get to, but great!. This church was a little hard to get to but it was really great! Wonderful art, interesting church. Not much around it, but much better preserved than in a number of other churches we saw. If you go to to the Kariye Museum also go to the Asitane Restaurant right near by (in the basement of the Kariye Hotel). We had a lovely lunch outside.

Worth the travel time!. Kariye Museum is worth getting out of Sultanahmet to see. You'll have to find a way there as it is a bit off the beaten path, but it is such a gorgeous church. The frescoes are beautiful and well preserved. Lots of history in this church.

absolutely perfect. It was absolutely beautiful and a must visit! I would highly recommend hiring a guide for the day to cover all the sights.
Another must!. Just like with the Hagia Sophia review, I recommend buying these tickets online in a bundle. So worth it! lots of time saved in lines!
Incredible mozaics. We had no idea what this museum was like, we chose an excursion that included the Cisterns and this was part of the tour. We were blown away. Magnificent mozaics.

Amazing Mosaics. A bit out from the other tourist areas, but definitely worth getting there. It's also worth having someone to point out what each picture is about, since there are so many you could miss some neat points.

A unique place of Byzantine culture off the beaten path.. The mosaics are exquisite in the small, wonderful church away from all the main sites. Well worth the trip. Spend some time exploring the city walls while you're here and have some kebaps at develi.
Absolutely Stunning. Worth going - 100%. The frescos are still intact and a joy to see. Te whole place is so serene and peaceful.

Mosaics. The museum is situated somewhat outside the main Istanbul tourist routes but definately worth the visit. Please don't take the advice of a well known travel book to get there because the ferry mentioned has been cancelled due to work on the bridges. The art work is fantastic and it is worth while having a camera to take photographs - truely memorable. Tour groups visit the museum so it may be wise to get there early.
great church. it is like little Hagia Sophia, made around the same times and it also has the most beautiful mozaics you can ever see, deffenetly worth visiting.
do not miss. fabulous ancient frescoes and mosaics worth the trip if you have more than a day or two in Istanbul,even though it is away from the center of town.

a real must. so many tourist forget this, which is the real jem in instanbul. go there. spend lots of time looking at mosaics and enjoy the neighbourood. last time i was there while looking the mosaics on the roof i crashed against the queen of spain, who was doing the same.....
Gorgeous Christian Artwork. This is really well preserved and well worth the visit. Great mosiacs, etc. One of the best preserved churches around.
Very unique. Wonderful mosaics and frescoes. Very old. A MUST in Istanbul. You'll love it! Not in Summer when it is HOT

Mindblowing. I absolutely loved the Kariye museum, what a wonderful gem. To think that all those frescoes and mosaics were forgotten for so many hundreds of years and only found again in the 40s, is just mindblowing. Please make sure you give yourself at least half a day for this to make sure you get a chance to see all the pictures. There are so many people that you may have to go around several times.

It's a gem!. If you were thinking about going here or not like I did, then you shouldn't think twice about visiting this place just because it's a bit further than Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque and other places in Sultanahmet. It's worth visiting! I was amazed by how beautiful this place is. I went here by a bus and rented an audio guide. I took time and listen to the audio guide and amazed by all the mosaic and the stories behind it. If you go here by yourself without a guide and don't want to go by bus, you can reach this place by a taxi. It's also easy to catch one when you come back. Taxi to Sultanahmet shouldn't cost more than 15 liras.

A Window Into Ancient Byzantium. This is one of the places where ancient Byzantine church art is most to be admired. The frescoes and mosaics are wonderfully preserved and give a tantalizing flash of what ancient Constantinople must have been like.

Picturesque setting and a nice sight to see!. This church is set on a hill overlooking Istanbul. Pretty mosaics almost throughout the church. Very nice atmosphere inside and out. Nicely restored and preserved. Definitely worth visiting.

A jewel in Istanbul. It is not the most touristic place in the city, but I think it is a must to see. The history, the design, the paintings and the architecture is unique and beautiful. It helps the person understand the history of the city before the Ottoman Empire.

St Savior in Chora. This is a must see. It is a pectacular church that was preserved throughout the religious shifts in Turkey. It is well-restored and on a beautiful site in a lovely garden with a different view of Istanbul.

A Byzantine Jewel. This is one of My favourite historic places in Istanbul. It's not exactly in the main touristic area, but not far, and really worth it. The Byzantine mosaics at incredible. You can go there after visiting Eyup in your way back to Sulthanamet or Taksim areas.

Holy moly mosaics!!. Wow, if you can spare the time to go all the way out to Chora Church (it is about a 40 minute trip, requiring two trains), you'll see some of the best mosaics and frescos. Just be careful -- it's closed on Wednesdays and our guide book didn't tell us that. :-( There's not much else in the area, though I did see good reviews for the restaurant right outside the museum. Still, even considering our first, ill-fated Wednesday trip, we're so glad we went back. If you appreciate art at all, you can't miss the Chora Church.

Don't Miss !!. This is an amazing place. It is one of the most beautiful examples of Byzantine Church. Taking an audio guide is highly recommended. It presents all the mosaics in a sequence which forms the events of lives of Joseph, Mary and Jesus. This is much smaller than the Hagia Sophia but more beautiful frescoes and mosaics inside make up for it. This definitely deserves a piece of your time in Istanbul.

Wonderful mosaics. This little church is a bit of the beaten track with nothing much around it, but after Hagia Sophia Museum it is the next best site. The church is full of beautiful mosaics and frescoes some of the best in the world.

A masterpiece to visit in Istanbul. The Church of the Holy Saviour in Chora, a masterpiece to visit in Istanbul. The church is situated in Istanbul, in the Edirnekapı neighborhood, which lies in the western part of the municipality (belediye) of Fatih. The interior of the building is covered with fine mosaics and frescoes.

I was expecting a much bigger place. For some reason every time I've seen pictures of Chora I though, it was a huge church, and it's not. That was a little bit of a disappointment. However, I loved the place, the frescoes/mosaics are so beautiful, I don't have words to describe them other than I gasped when I looked up and saw them. The #90 bus at the Eminonu bus terminal takes you there. It's the last stop in the bus (about 20 minutes). Then you walk for about 10 minutes, part of which is a climb (for about 2 or 3 blocks)
Very Nice Church. The Chora Church was one of the places I wanted to visit for its cultural significance. It is an amazing building with an interesting history.

Not easy to get to, but worth the journey!. This amazing little church is tucked away in a neighborhood that isn't that easy to get to. We were fortunate to find the bus that went this way and a helpful driver who signaled to us when to get off the bus. Once you arrive, you'll be wowed by the intricate mosaics which laid covered up for hundreds of years. It's like stepping back in time. Don't miss it.
Historical and amazing mosaics. The only problem is that it is very far and it is not comfortable to reach from Sultanmhet, but I ensure that you can't miss it.
little hagia sophia. it is almost the same style of haGIA SOPHIA. taksi will charge 20 tl from sultanahmet. i got overcharged. just be carefull.

beautiful mosaics. we are staying at the oldcity. so it is abit complicated to go there with public transportation taxi cost around 20 tl. to taking a taxi easiest way. and if you around 4-5 days you must go this museum, because it has beautiful mosaics..

well worth the distance. located in a residential area not near the old historical sites, this church has the most beautiful mosaics in Istanbul. Small church but you will take time there just marveling at the well-preserved mosaocs telling the story of Christ. Very moving!
Truly Amazing. This Church has the most incredible mosaics and is a true marvel with lovely coffee shops opposite and an incredible Ottoman restaurant next door

interesting. interesting mosaics but entrance fee of 15 lire-approx 8 euros too high
spent about 15 minutes in here

A Must!. Visiting the Chora Museum is an absolute must! This former church and mosque is now a museum housing the finest and most well preserved examples of Byzantine mosaics and paintings in Istanbul. Because the building is so small, everything can be seen in a short amount of time, but I couldn’t bring myself to leave right away— I walked around over and over again to savor the experience for as long as possible.

Ancient frscoes and mosaics. This 11th Century church contains priceless frescoes and mosaics depicting the life, death, and resurrection of Jesus. Out of the way from most Istanbul attractions (except for the city wall, which is nearby), it is well worth a visit.
Wonderful Church. This is a must see in Istanbul. The mosaics are phenomenal, the frescoes are amazing too, and the price is right!
Chora Church very moving. Frescos are unequal anywhere. Fantastic audio tour for only 5 euros. Well worth visit even if not religious.
Definitely worth a visit. Well worth the time to find this place, take a taxi as its easier - it is a small church with amazing frescoes and mosaics.

A Special Jewel. I visited the Kariye Museum twice while in Istanbul. It is truly a jewel because of the beautiful mosaics. Do spend longer than the usually recommended hour as there is so much to see. The audio guide is a must.

A highlight of our trip!. The mosaics and frescoes of this church/mosque are not to be missed. Elegant depictions of biblical stories. You will take several trips around this building before you leave!

Interesting Christian mosaics. Interesting bizantine church, that was later transformed into a mosque. Pay special attention to the beautiful mosaics from the 11th century. I recommend having a coffee or a chai, and smoking a nahguile in the nice place behind the church. The church is quite distant from Sultanahmet and the 15TL charged seem a bit heavy in comparison to other museums, but it is still worth it.

A long way from Sulanhammet. This was a long way from where we were staying, and on a hot day felt like quite an effort to get there - so I was hoping to be 'wow-ed' by it! Unfortunately it left me underwhelmed!
Liked this a lot. Very cool little church tucked away in residential neighborhood. Stunning mosaics and murals. Esp. good if you are keen on Christian history.

Don't miss this church. Only in Ravenna are there such a quantity and quality of romanesque mosiacs. Inside a rather drab Byzantine structure, in a residential neighborhood (but a 10 dollar taxi ride from Sultanhemet - at most) you will discover a true miracle in art preservation. Do not miss this.

A real jewel!. This church/museum is not listed with much emphasis in some guidebooks. Wow! Breathtakingly beautiful! The ancient mosaics are abundant and so, so beautiful. This church/museum is a jewel box. One of my favorite sites in Istanbul.
Don't miss it. An important church for the Othodox world. In very good condition with its freco's still intact. has to be seen.

Worth the Schlep. There are ways to get to this beautiful, if small, museum via public transport. But no one local will be able to explain how to do so, and the guidebooks telling you to take such-and-such bus don't tell you where to get the bus. But it is definitely worth it! And when you are done seeing the beautiful mosaics here, go right next door to the Asitane Restaurant for dishes that were eaten by the Ottoman Sultans at the height of their power.

Stunningly beautiful mosaics and intriguing frescoes!. The Chora church is an eye-opener! Even the well-traveled have sometng to see and learn here. The charming frescoes of the Harrowing of Hell and archangels are really unforgettable. The mosaics glitter richly, three-dimensionally along the ribs of the dome! Here's the important part: if you are cool with public transport, just take the T1 to Topkapi tram stop, then the T4 to the Edirnekapi stop. From there, follow signs to Asitane restaurant ( next door to the Chora). Easy!
Love the history and painting. The paintings/mosaics were restored quite well. The story of the the birth of Christ and told from a different perspective.
Hard to get to. My husband and took a tram, walked to the metro, the walked a lot moremto visit this church. It was filled with wonderful frescoes.

Discover Hidden Treasures of Istanbul. Everyone knows that Chora Museum is a real gem that not to be missed a visit while in Istanbul. Every year thousands visiting this museum don't seem to be aware of what other treasures there to be discovered within proximity.The Chora Museum was located within 5 minutes easy walking distance from the Theodosian Walls which were built in the reign of the emperor Theodosius II. They begin from the Sea of Marmara and extend to the gate of Kerkoporta. The latter is located between the gate of Adrianople and the palace of Constantine Porphyrogenitos. From the palace on, the walls continue down the 6th Hill, without a moat or outer wall inclusion, to adjoin with the sea at the Golden Horn. The walls and the towers, which are incorporated-in at every 55 meter intervals, are known to be one of the last greatest fortifications of antiquity. Today they seem to be resisting time most of its long stretch. The palace of Constantine Porphyrogenitos is at a short distance from the gate of Adrianople (present day Edirne kapi), that is the gate through which the young sultan Mehmet II made his entry to the city. From the top of the walls adjoining the palace you will have a striking view of the entire Golden Horn and after that that of the Topkapi palace and Hagia Sophia and beyond the Asia. As you continue exploring, and keeping the walls on your left, you pass through an interesting neighborhood where a close community, mostly gypsy families, live in poorly built little dwellings attached to or by the walls. The path will lead you down and pass by the gate of Kaligaria (Egrikapi) where the last Roman emperor Constantine XI Palaeologus Dragases was seen for the last time desperately fighting to save his empire. Further along down the walk path you come to the ruins of the Blachernae Palace, once a magnificent palace built by the Emperor Alexios I Komnenos. After him his grandson of Alexios, Manuel II had the imperial court transferred here.Blachernae Palace unfortunately witnessed the savage sacking on Constantinople by the crusaders of 1204. Nearby, attached to the walls is the famous Anames dungeons named after Michael Anemas. This section of the walls and towers stand rather imposing. At this point you may wish to have a break there you will find the Anames café, an ideal place to enjoy your tea viewing the hill of Pierre Loti at the far end of the Golden Horn.Further down the hill in a nice garden setting stands the church of Saint Mary of Blachernae, the imperial church, commonly known for its holy spring. This is one church where the congregations are held on Fridays instead of Sundays ever since the siege of the city by the Avar Turks in 626.This completes your tour of the hidden treasures of Istanbul located in proximity of Chora Museum.

A treasury of mosaic paintings. When we first visited Kariye Cami'i in 1995, there were only a handful of people there and the few staff around were academics, i believe. This time around, the church is one of the top attractions in Istanbul considering the number of tourists buses that were outside the church. The church was packed! But the huge crowd was bearable, the problem was a guard. I accidentally stepped out of the church and I was of course not allowed to get back in. I tried to ask him a question (I got a little confused and could not remember where exactly the entrance was which was on the garden side. Apparently, he really did not know any English and he just kept on shouting at me to stay out. I told him I was only asking him a question, but he even ordered me to "SIT" while pointing to the nearby steps. He was very rude and arrogant. One would hope that with the amount of money they are raking in from the countless number of tourists that come continuously the whole day, they would be able to utilize people who can speak a little English and who would be a bit helpful, rather than plain arrogant. I tried to go back to the man entrance and tried to get permission to be allowed in. I still had my ticket and it had just been over an hour and a half since I got in the first time, but the guy manning the gate would not let me back in either. All I wanted to do was to take some pictures of the garden. I simply don't understand what the big deal was all about. What harm could I possibly do the second time around? So I guess my warning would be, don't step out of the door unless you are really, really ready to leave - because there is no prayer in heaven that would allow you to get back in again.But of course, the mosaics are out of this world. One never tires of looking at them. This is my 4th time in Kariye and one can never get tired of those paintings. It is a real treasure and I hope the paintings will be preserved forever.

Beautifully preserved mosiacs. Our family visited late in the late just prior to closing and it was a good time to go. The church is small and can not accomodate large crowds inside. It is worth the visit, however, if you have the time due to the beauty of the mosiacs which are wonderfully preserved.

Great Mosaics & Frescoes. The church is a little bit away from the main tourist areas but easily reached by bus from Eminonu. It is an old Christian church with great frescoes and even better mosaics that were truly stunning. It is not very large and it was a bit of a trial fighting our way through the crowds inside but well worth it. I rate it above the Aya Sofia.
Wonderful Mosiacs/Church. Worth the difficulty in finding/getting to this wonderful historic site, I suggest a Taxi. I loved the fact that the splendid artworks & Mosaics are so close.

Byzantine Mosaics’.
