This church in one of the hills , the access is not very good to go walking – it is better to take a taxi and ask the driver to wait for you ( difficult to get one out of there and they try to charge more).The Byzantine Mosaics are really beautiful , a lot of piece in this place.Istanbul is a Museum itself – amazing city.

hidden but.... Kariye museum is a bit outside the usual turistic circuits but I am sure that distance must not become an excuse to avoid a visit.This experience is really fantastic, mosaics, atmosphere...

As good as it gets. Kariye Museum is quite difficult to get to by Metro as requires a taxi ride as well. Best to get a taxi the whole way.The Museum is just beautiful and definitely worth the trip.There is a wonderful restaurant beside it with Ottoman food.
Jaw dropping expereince. The most amazing mosaics and frescoes in the world. Make every effort to visit this church. It looks like nothing on the outside but the inside is breathtaking.
to visit absolutely. Wonderful place, in a characteristic street of Istanbul. It deserves a visit. Spectacular mosaics in a small Bizantin church. An unexpected place close to the Golden Horn.
worth the taxi trip. small but fascinating chrch especially if you have been to cappadocia too as it's an obvious descendant

couldnt get in. we searched for chora church for hours walking all around the kariye area and ayvansaray, however when we got there it was closed because they close on wednesdays :( however the surrounding area is just amazing, a getaway from the busy lifestyle of central istanbul

Go the extra mile. A spur of the moment decision, my visit to Chora church actually exposed me to the true Turkish life. Situated away from the main Istanbul city, I took the tram, the metro, the underground metro and walked to and from this Church. Good hearted Turks went out of their way, to lead us to the nearest metro station. They spoke Turkish; we spoke English. But has full blown conversations for hours. The Chora church is near to the Golden Horn and was built at the outskirts of the famous city of Constantinople. When I reached the church early morning, I was among the few tourists who actually made this one of their stops. The ambience was beautiful, silent, with the gentle wind blowing into my hair. I sat on the benches outside and observed people for around 30 mins. before I actually went into the church. It is a small church with all the characteristics of Byzantine architechure. The key attraction here are the fresco paintings that have survived time, nature and history. There are quite a few controversial frescos as well. There is a mosaic of Church on the Throne, the Resurrection Christ pulling Adam and Eve out of their tombs, the 2nd coming of Christ and many many other stories depicted on the walls and domes of this church.This church was once used to help sheild fighters against the Ottoman onslaught. This was also converted into a mosque in under the Muslim Ottoman reign. They covered the beautiful mosaic art and frescos under walls of plaster to keep people from seeing symbolic imageries. Now the Church of Chora is a museum standing tall, beautiful and proud against the test of time. Try and visit this unique masterpiece. You will enjoy it.

Breathtaking. This small former church/mosque out by the remains of the old Constantinople City Walls eclipsed the Hagia Sophia with its frescos and mosaics. Christ's miracles shown in the mosaics were especially intriguing as was the vision of the universe as a shell in the Last Judgment frescos. The neighborhood is not touristy, but the outdoor restaurant in the square did provide an adequate meal with local people surrounding us. All in all, the best art we saw in Istanbul.

The crown jewel. Everybody writes books about 101 things to be done but they forget to mention this museum.It is the onl competetor to Ravenna mosaics in the world and from some points,even better.It can be easily put on the top of the list as the highlight of Istanbul.If you miss it,you may regret.

artistic.... Although I am not a christian but this place was good to be at..clean surroundings.. nice garden outside...nice views.. the pictures inside are not too faded.. worth looking at...overall a very good experience.. but the location this place is a little off..compared to all other attractions of the city..

My favorite church or mosque in istanbul. I would recommend this church highly. All of the art on the walls tell a story and is ancient. Chora has heart. It's also perched on a hill with a lovely view, and you can sit on the benches under the trees and feel the breeze. Highly recommend.
A hidden gem. The frescos,paintings and mosaics are amazing. Make sure you visit this place. It is slightly off the beaten track but well worth a visit.

Fascinating. Amazing to think they were hidden for so many years behind plaster but goes to show how special they are when they weren't destroyed. Looking up following the story around the walls and remembering the stories from the bible (I'm not v religious but it's amazing what you retain from childhood..) is quite hazardous - as everybody else is doing the same thing - I managed to bump into the same poor woman twice. It defies belief that the colours can still look so fresh. Well worth a visit, we got a taxi out there as it's a bit out of the central drag - check out the bridal area on route - I have never seen so many colourful wedding dresses!

very old church. It is an amazing feeling to be in this structure knowing just how long it has been around. Get a tourguide. It is worth the moderate preice. The guide will explain the chronology of the wall and ceiling mossaics and paintings. Very interesting!
A walk in the most distant past. It just feels really good to be in a place that is this old and historic.Get a tour guide,it's worth the money (which is not much...)

A bit far away. It s an amazing church with a very special atmosphere. History is written all over it but it too far away from the main attractions. If you are a couple days in Istanbul I recommend you to see 2 of the other ''big'' attractions instead of just this one.
Beautiful experience. The frescos, the paintings, the fellow travellers, all made the experience wonderful

Lovely little church once you find it.. Comming from a new part of the world Istanbul was the first truly old city I had visited. Take the walk from Sultanahamet. We came across a street market that had the best local food and was interesting walking through the suburbs. The beauty of the mosaics was just unbelievable. You have to go.

A must-see in Istanbul. After you've seen the Blue Mosque and Hagia Sofia this should be your next stop. A small church compared to the two former ones but very rich in its past, the mosaics, frescoes, truly remarkable.
Mini Ayia Sophia. If you likemosaics, these are simply wonderful, and rival those of the Ayia Sophia.
Worth the walk. Beautiful murals but a long hot walk from the ferry
Another must see!. To appreciate this city's rich history, you need to make sure this is on your list.
A place that someone must visit. Excellent restoration and a building that stands after so many centuries. They say that with the frescoes they can save the christianic history.

Don't waste your time if tight for time.. It's a long road for a small old church with a few remnants of byzantine mosaics - I've probably seen too many mosaics. If you have time, it's ok to visit as you get to go through some "real" areas of Istanbul and get to see the old wall just 100m away. Climbing the wall, was more interesting - no safety at all (I truly was thrilled by the climb).

Great artwork in a quiet corner of Istanbul.. The Kariye Museum is a bit of the beaten track but well worth the trek. It has beautiful mosaics and frescos, one set of mosaics covers the story of Mary from birth - not usually found in Byzantine art. It's closed on Wednesday, so beware.
Wonderful!. Another little gem, marvelous frescoes, interesting structure, a pretty little garden setting.

Do not miss!. Off the beaten track but worth the effort to get there. Beautiful frescoes in a lovely old Byzantine church. Not as well-known as Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi, etc., which are all musts for any visit to Istanbul, but this is a little gem.
great art work. "amazing" , "astonishing.. great art work. we did not have enough time since we were with kids but it was more than words..

Stunning. We caught a taxi to see this beautiful Church, it was worth going to see, with so many beautiful mosaics. We walked around the area, climbed the old city wall and then walked to the river and caught a ferry back to Galata.
A Christian Church in Istanbul. Beautiful Frescos and right near our hotel. Worth the extra effort to visit this church.
Amazing Mosaics. A Byzantine masterwork. A bit outside the center, but worth the trip.
Best Bizantine Mosaics. A bit far from the main historic area but 100% worth the trip
The Mosaics put Hagia Sophia to Shame. Absolutely amazing mosaics in this tiny little church just outside the city walls. Worth the trip and relax in the cafe just outside the door.

Beautiful mosaics, not difficult to travel to. Some people have said this is quite difficult to travel to but it's not really from Sultanahmet. Take the T1 to Topkapi and change onto T4 and get off at Edimekapi. From here it's probably best to ask for directions.
The mosaics are beautiful and try and go in the morning to avoid any tour groups.

Worth the stop!. We took a long, but worthwhile, stroll from the nearest ferry stop, following the old city wall through a very colorful and non-tourist neighborhood. Views along winding narrow streets, glimpses of the old walls, historic homes - some well-kept, others abandoned. The Chora was so beautiful, and worth the walk which made the church all the more special. It's small, tucked into a neighborhood, and another stop that is easy to do if you have limited time. The frescoes and mosaics are preserved and reasonably protected.
Wonderful mosaics. This 11th cent. church contains wonderful mosaics and is well worth visiting although off the main tourist area

Incredible mosaics but bring a stepladder. This Byzantine Church has remarkable mosaics and frescoes. It is a bit out of the way but worth a $10 taksi ride from where we stayed in Sultanachmet (or less if you take the tram and a taksi). Unfortunately these are all up on the ceiling or high up on the walls so it isn't easy to see them. It's an old small church so it doesn't require a major investment of time.
Noise and bustle. Be prepared for many groups of tourists all led by their own tour guides speaking at the tops of their voices

Late Byzantine Painting and Mosaics at their best. The Blue Guide will taken you through the iconography of this great church, one of the most important centers of Christian Art in the World. The Resurrection, or the Harrowing of Hell to Western Christians, is, as claimed, one of the greatest of all paintings. You can visit this church by taking the Gate of Horn Water Ferry and walking up hill from the stop nearest the Church. As with everything in Istanbul, make the visit alone with a well-written printed guide. Always take your time to read and look with care.

Chora Church. This church is located near the City wall in the Western area of the historic district. Take a few minutes to see the well preserved wall. There is little to see in the church, only frescoes. There are no other exhibits or anything explaining the history of the church or artwork besides a few paragraphs on the visitor pamphlet. Still, this is worthwhile, and I recommend walking here to see the mosques and aqueduct on the way.

Hard to find but worth every penny.. This church is very difficult to find when taking public transport as there are no signposts and it is out of the main centre a bit but once you find it the search is worth it.On the walls and roof are mosaics and murals dating back to the Byzantine era in excellent repair. There are no flash photographs allowed but there is plenty of light to take good quality photos.
Kariye Museum. A bit off the usual track but well worth the cab ride to get there. It's a gem!

nice frescos in a bad district. a beautiful old church and museum, the only downside is the tourist traps outside the church and the slums beyond that. if you want to see some real istanbul life walk from the church due west for about 20 minutes...
A unique church. The mosaics are really fantastic . Although it was very difficult to find the Chora church i feel very satisfied i have visited it. A place must be seen!!!

You have to want to get there, but when you do. While the church seems out of the way from the main sights, you cannot pass up the opportunity to go there. This is iconographic world history art 101. Don't worry if you don't recognize all of the art, you will never forget it. If you want to walk the walls afterwards, do so, they are great! After you make it to the the water, get a cab. I didn't . . .

Well preserved mosaics; worth the visit. This attraction was recommended to us by several of the travelers we met around Turkey. The mosaics are absolutely gorgeous and very well preserved. Take the time to go there.
Don't Miss This Church. If you are interested in art, this church has great mosaics and frescoes. Most of the interior is in good condition. Well worth the trek.

Chora Church is worth the trip. A taxi is the easiest way to get to the West suburbs, but taking the tram from Sultanahmet was more interesting and pretty fast. The mosaics are glorious, even if you don't try to follow the story they tell. But there are low-pressure guides, really nice and very informative. Chora is small and uncrowded (until a tour bus hits). It's also next to Asitane, an upscale restaurant with ancient recipes, which we liked well enough for lunch, but which would be even better for dinner.
thorough, story-filled art. Like it better than Aya Sofia as art had more complex tales to relate and included more dogma and Apocryphal stories

Even if you think you don't like mosaics, go. An atmosphere of respect for the Byzantine past, permeates this elegant building. It's many rooms contain, wall paintings, mosaics, but mostly beautiful tall spaces, set in a garden in a wonderful old neighborhood of wooden houses on hilly streets.
Magic!. Magic atmosphere ,less crowded.amazing restaurant at side and confortabile cafe just in front. Bizantine mosaics and frescos of rare beauty in a less caotic area of Istambul
Wow!. Amazing mosaics which tell the story of the Virgin Mary, Jesus and other biblical stories. Bought to life by our wonderful guide.
Beautiful. This is a little gem situated a short way from the centre of Istanbul and well worth a visit.
epitome of Byzanine mosaic art. A visit to this church was a highlight of our stay in Instanbul. The well-preserved mosaics are moving in their artistic and spiritual splendor.

A tranquil escape from the city bustle. A very spiritual building very sensitively restored. Learned a lot about Christ's life as depicted in the frescoes and mosaics. The local guides are extremely knowledgeable and without one we would have missed most of the meaning. The restaurant next door Asitane was exceptional in every way - have lunch there. It is worth exploring the market 200 yards away behind the city wall
A gem away from it all. Its 15 TL to get into this church but worth the money. this is a museum now but so beautiful and set up high on the hill with great views of Istanbul. Very tranquil setting.

Best example of mosaics in a Christian Church in Turkey. If you have any appreciation for art or architecture the Chora Church is a must. The mosaics which depict the life of Jesus and Mary are incredible. I will add some non flash photos I took but they really don't do the church justice. It is one of the few museums that vandals haven't ruined the mosaics or frescoes with graffiti. Well worth the 15 TL entrance fee. Take the time to see every section of the church and then enjoy a cold drink at the restaurant behind the church. Getting there was a little challenging but follow these directions and you will get there easily enough. At Eminonu (opposite the ferries) you will find the bus station. Find bus number 32 or 38 or any other bus that goes to Edirnekapi. You will need an Istanbulcarte to catch the bus (it's 2.75 TL each way when you swipe your card. Simply purchase one from the newsagent type booths scattered all over Istanbul . You can use the Istanbulcarte on the tram too .. cheaper than buying the tokens). When you get off at Edirnekapi walk back the way you came for about 40 metres and a street on the left takes you to the Chora Church (Kariye Museum). It will be signed but look back when you get to the street mentioned because the sign is facing the other way and not the way you are walking. On returning get any bus that says Eminonu to get back to the bus station. Sounds complicated but it's not and 5.50 TL return is cheaper than getting a taxi (approx 50 TL). Enjoy.

Byzantine mosaics. A little out of main tourist area but definitely worth a visit. Spectacular mosaics and frescos. We took a tram and was a little tricky to find after leaving the station. A taxi might be easier.
MOSAICS. Best preserved mosaics of Byzantine era at İstanbul,takes 15 mins to visit which is shorter than your expedition to the museum,skip it if you are not not nearby and try Google instead...

Hard to find but interesting. There is no public transportation so taxi will be the right way to get there. If you have enough time in istanbul you should visit. Also Asitane restaurant is right next door so make a reservation and should eat there...

HIDDEN JEWEL. This church (a museum today) is extremely hard to find. Be prepared to do a lot of asking after you step off public transportation. It is worth all your efforts because inside are some of the most precious and best preserved frescoes and Byzantine mosaics. If you must know their meaning take a guide, but if you can just delight in art work and colors enjoy!
Beautiful mosaics. Worth the trip out to take a look at the beautiful mosaics.
Do not miss this site in Istanbul. Best mosaics in Istanbul - off the tourist track, but worth the trek or taxi ride. I visit here each time I come to Istanbul (3 and counting....)

Nice to see but not a MUST. Reading on-line review I thought this was a MUST see in Istanbul, but it wasn't. it was nice and had a nice historical value but was not as expected. It was on the other side of the city from our hotel so we had to take a cab to go there and it wasn't familiar with the locals as when we first asked about it they had to ask number of people to know what we were talking about. It was a few rooms museum and not much to see. If you love ancient mosaics and architecture maybe it is a Must but if you don't you would not miss much if you don't go.

Ignore at your peril. Yes this church is away from all the other sites and is not exactly easy to get to on public transport but if you don't go you are missing out on a great treasure. To have such a number of frescoes and mosaics under a single roof must be unique. Do not miss out

Small, out of the way, some beautiful frescos. This church stays true to its Turkish name (which means 'outside of the city walls') - it is a little out of the way. We purchased the audio guide (5TL), which was interesting, but a little waffly at times. The remaining mosaics and the building's history certainly are interesting, and the surrounding suburb is tranquil in comparison to the mayhem in the centre of Istanbul. However, there are many more beautiful and scenic buildings in Istanbul that I would see before making my way to the Chora Church.We were also incredibly cheated by a taxi driver on the way home. He was short, incredibly friendly, spoke good english, and called himself 'Mr Marvellous'. He offered to take us to Pierre Loti's house, bought us a drink, and then stole several hundred lira from my mother. We have had such a beautiful experience in Turkey, and the people have been so incredibly friendly, but this experience was punishment for having let our guard down too much.
Worth a visit. Loved the mosaics and architecture. Liked the natural light.
ancient mosaics. the fact that the mosaics are still in pretty good condition
Unbelievable old mosaics; don't miss it.. While somewhat off the beaten path, this is a place to see and wonder at. The mosaics are so beautiful and moving. Don't miss a visit.
nice. beautiful but full of people, as hagia sophia is better to go early in the morning
Small gem. Mosaics of Hagia Sofia to the 10th power. Out of the way location, take a cab & walk in area afterward to get a feel of "normal" life in the city.
Excellent mosaic. This late Byzantium church is a great example of the decorations of the orthodox churches in that period.

Byzantine mosaics and celestial beauty. One of the best preserved examples of Byzantine art in the world. Stunning. Bring your camera, not your flash and enjoy a jar dropping slice of Byzantium. A beautiful little church.
Worth the trip.. I really enjoyed the mosaics here. It is a bit out of the way, so take a cab but try not to do it at rush hour (the cab will charge you more). Great kitties in the grounds too!

Amazing. The artistry of the mosaics was stunning. I was surprised to see real emotion on some of the faces, so different from other icons I have seen. The inclusion of animals and everyday life in some of the scenes was intriguing. I will long remember the color and detail I saw there.
Exquisite mosaics. Although further out of the historic district, one should take the time to visit this former church to see the unique and exquisite mosaics.

mosaics in excellent condition. If you are going alone this is not an easy place to find - we became very lost. However once there, well worth the search. The mosaics are in the finest condition, given their age - stunning. The gardens around the church are very peaceful and pretty

Another beauty. This church has more of it's Byzantine Christian artwork intact than
Hagia Sophia. The murals and mosaics are really stunning.
It's a bit of a drive to get there. Took a cab - about 25 E from my hotel.
A little gem. Exceptional mosaics and frescoes in a small space, so easy to look at.
Outstanding!. Out of the way, but incredible mosaics and frescoes. Take a cab and imagine what the Hagia Sophia must have looked like!

Unique sight on outskirts of city..... A beautiful church near to the old city walls. This Church can be reached by the Tramway. Take the T1 line to Topkapi then take T4 to Edirnekapi. Exit the station and cross the road. Follow the signs to Kariye Museum. This transport option is not given in either the Lonely Planet or DK Guides as I don't think the tramway was extended to this location at the point of the books being written.Well worth the visit, but beware that the team can get very busy and crowded at peak times.

Lesser known gem of Byzantine art. More beautiful frescoes and mosaics would be impossible to fit onto the interior of this small but perfectly formed church/museum. Essential viewing for anyone with the slightest interest in Byzantine art.

Feeling cross culture. worth to get all the way to find this museum, nice and gigantic building with beautiful architecture. A but crowded but still great. "no flash" was the sentence i get on the first click on some items internal that cross my eye. Thus, must explore it!
Worth all the way. Not far form the tourist center, a mere 20 liras by taxi from Sultanhamet, this little charming museum, once Christian Church is a jewel for those who like mosaic work

The Kariye Museum-Saint Saviour of Chora Church. It is a little gem. Beautiful little church, remaining part of a Byzantine Monastery. It is perfect architecturally with wonderful frescoes and mosaics. Make sure you get an audio-guide. It is only 5TL and it is very detailed and informative. The little square in front of the church is a very pleasant and peaceful place. You don't want to leave. I would visit this church a second time, you cannot see it enough times.
Pilgrimage 2012. We arrived when it was rather full and had difficulty hearing our guide. Was better when the crowd subsided.

Beautiful!. Wonderful architecture and historical importance. You really need to have a guide or the automatic guide to get the full details. I would imagine it gets very crowded in peak season but well worth a visit. If you venture off from Chora you can find the city walls close by and, if you are fit find the steep stairs because the views are amazing. Make sure you know how to turn off your flash for this one - camera flashes are not allowed. Payment is in turkish lira only not euros.
hidden teasure. a little difficult to find but worth the effort. A beautiful setting for lunch after visiting the church

A bit out of the way. Went to Choro on the public bus from the station down near Emonunu. It was real easy and the friendly and helpful citizens of Istanbul who were also riding the bus made sure that we got off at the right stop.
This has to be my favourite. Just stunning, a beautiful place with the most amazing mosaicsI have seen. Well worth the trip further afield to a lovely setting on the hill.
Not to be missed. Fantastic examples of Byzantine mosaics, frescoes and marble work. A little hard to find and get to, but well worth the effort. I rank it in the top 5 things to see in Istanbul.
Worth the hassle. Hard to find, even once you get off the correct bus. But the mosaics are beautiful

Worth the trip. Quite an amazing oid church (converted to a mosque during the Ottoman reign) with an interesting history and very well preserved frescos and mosaics which tell the stories and history of the Byzantine religion. While a ways outside the old city, it is well with the trip. I would recommend a guide as there are many stories in the frescos and mosaics that will enhance your experience. While not a very large church, Imthough this was certainly one of the top 5 sites to visit in Istanbuhl.
Excellent. Well worth finding this gem. Incredible mosaics. Take T1 to Topkapi station then T4 to Erdinburnu. Walk 5 mins towards city Walls
Must see. Mosaics are amazing. This church is an art history jewel that should not be missed. Smaller and less well knowm, but more impressive than hagia sophia.
Magnificent place. Just go and visit it! I was stoned by its beauty and calming atmosphere... Historical and artistic value is "invaluable".

A must.. The Chora is out of the way a little, and many put it off for this reason. But you have to go. It is the most magnificent of the many magnificent things I saw in Istanbul, astonishing project of recovery all the more poignant for the great gaps and losses revealed in every room. Churches that were painted over as mosques and then later stripped back and recovered form a central part of the complex history of this region, and there are beautiful examples in Macedonia, Bulgaria and elsewhere. This one is spectacular and not to be missed. Pick a time when tours do not go. They can be avoided. And, unlike say the Boyana church in Sofia, they allow photography here, so you can get stunning photos to take home.

Don't miss it. Because this is not close to tram lines or other sites it often gets missed on itineraries but it really should be on your must do list if you have more than a couple of days in Istanbul

Not essential to see by itself. This is a small church about 20 minutes by taxi from Sultanahmet.There is not a lot to see in that the mosaics are relatively small in area and it can get quite crowded.We felt that it was not worth the trip by itself but we combined it with Rick Steves' self-guided tour of the city walls which departs from here and that made the trip quite worthwhile overall.

Out of the beaten track, and we love it for that. It's still touristy with plenty of souvenir shops around a small square, but less crowded than the other sites in Sultanahmet area. And no giant tourist buses that unload hoardes of herds. The terrace cafe is perfect for snacks and tea. We had lunch at "Asitane", and their famous stuffed melon did not disappoint. Wine list seems a bit overinflated but they did not mind that we only wanted water.

Beauty spoilt by too many tour parties. Undoubtedly this is a magnificent place with stunning mosaics. However when we visited in late May it was completely ruined by tour parties with guides who shouted against each other and completely ruined the experience for everyone. think carefully with everything else you ca see in Istanbul if it is worth the time and effort to go here. It was also the only time we were overcharged by a taxi driver so beware!

contrast to all the mosques. This church had original mosaics and mural paintings. Where as the islam culture does not allow human portraits, it is very special to see these old decorations were not (all) destroyed, but saved under plaster while the church was used as a mosque. What we still can see today is of a very good quality and tells the bible stories vivedly.

worth the trip. This was one of the more amazing things we saw in Istanbul. The mosaics were incredible--such vivid colors and images. If you love to visit old churches, this is a must see, but even if that is not usually up your alley, this is worth the trip. It is just an incredible site--breathtaking, really. We enjoyed the ride out on the tram--it was a chance to see some neighborhoods outside of the touristy areas, and gave a sense of the real Istanbul. We actually walked back, first along the old city wall, and then through the neighborhoods along the Golden Horn. This was fun, but a little strenuous for some. Just take the tram there and back--it's an easy ride.
Great little gem. if you are interested in medieval church architecture. Fantastic mosaics. A bit out of the way, but you can stop by taxi on the way to the airport if pressed for time.

beautiful mosaic!. it is a little bit hard to find, but well worth the trip. The byzantine mosaic are so well preserved it is amazing! definitely get the audio guide, so that you can know what story each mosaic is telling.
A little out of the way but worth the trip. Beautiful frescos and mosaics. Take the tram and then walk back to the golden horn region via the old wall.

Excellent mosaics; very crowded, remote. Definitely worthwhile, but a little hard to get to with public transportation, and crowded because it is so small. A good section of the original city wall is nearby, and you can climb on top for great views of the city.
Wow!. A quiet little church with amazing mosaics and frescos.
A bit of a let down. Visit it only if you are into byzantine monuments was not that very attractive but if you want to some mosaic walls well worth it
Gorgeous site. Do not miss.. This is one of the most amazing sites and we highly recommend seeing this wonderful art.
Do not miss! My personal favorite.. The mosaics in this gorgeous church are mind boggling. This is one place where the Christian artifacts are still in such excellent condition.
don't miss. i liked that the paintings were 200 years in frond of their era.. don't miss it.read before you go or take a guide
Mosaics are amazing. A little out of the way but worth the taxi ride. From Sultanhamet it should cost around TL15. The mosaics really need to be seen, they are amazing
You feel the history. You just feel the history once you walk into this place

"Outside of the City..". The city walls of the old empire capital were built around the 5th century, it is said that the Chora Church (chapel) existed prior to the city walls going up & was outside of those first walls. In Turkish the word "Kariye" is derived from the Greek word "Chora" meaning outside the city...And if you're staying in the old city/Sultanahmet sections or across the water, it is a bit of a trip to this once outer limit of the city walls. Cabs & buses run to the area, don't quote me but I think the cab ride from Topkapi area was around 40 Turkish lira. There is a modest entrance fee (again set by the Turkish museum system), but well worth it if you are into the architechture of the 6th century, and later Byzantine art forms. The church was converted into a mosque in the early 1500's, when in 1945 it was converted to a museum. It was through that period that most of the beautiful frescoes & mosiacs in the Byzantine style were discovered & restored. These are some of the finest examples of this art form you will find. There are restrictions on flash photography, but I found there was ample natural lighting, especially for digital photos. It can get cramped inside, especially if there are several tour groups there at once...patience may be a virtue during your visit. There is a Turkish government shop there with a wide range of interesting & affordable items, reference books, guides, etc. There areseveral small eateries within walking distance, but I have not been to them. If memory serves me right, the museum is closed on Wednesdays. A nice side trip on way back to where ever you are staying, would be a stop at the Spice Market area. This area offers a very wide range of unique shopping experiences, great visual & olfactory input, and a great range of eateries, bakeries & street food.
Gem away from the usual tour sites. Definitely recommend spending the time to come here. We used Rick Steve's guide which explained a lot of the beautiful mosaics and frescoes.

Perfection!. The Chora church is an amazing sample of the Byzantine art. Build in the outskirts of the old city of Istanbul it was not totally destroyed but the Turks. Inside the church someone can see perfect examples of Byzantine mosaics ans frescos. It is the most well preserved church in Istanbul. Not to be missed!!!
Shockingly beautiful. One on my favorite sights in Istanbul. A bit out of the way, but easily accessible by bus. And well worth it! Do NOT miss!
Wonderful mosaics. A French friend suggested we visit the Chora Church, just for the mosaics. He was right.

Not too far. The Chora Church should be on your list. It'll cost about 20 lira from Old Town to get there by taxi, though the driver might quote you 30 or 40 if there's no meter in the taxi. Go ahead and haggle a bit. 20 lira is fair (though 15 lira is actually about right).It's really a surprising find. Pull up an online summary of the frescos and mosaics before you go. (I just emailed them to myself and read them as I went around the church). Not much else to do around there so you can plan to see the church and get back to old town in two hours.
Quaint and Off the Beaten Path. Terrific mosaics and one of the better examples of Byzantine art remaining in the city.
great scenery. it is the royal churches of the great Byzantine epoch
amazing... If you have more than 5 days do not forget to go Chora Church. It has the best mosaics
unknown information. There were frescoes of the Blessed Mother's parents and pictured information about the life of Jesus that I was not aware
magnificent. Beautiful bulding inside - so many visitors but didn't feel at all crowded. Highly recommended
Great place but poor information. Excellent mosaics and very beatiful old church. You should bring your own documentation because they don't have anything besides the audioguide.

Worth the visit!. Beautiful historic Church with amazing icons. It is well worth a cab ride to this site. There is an affordable restaurant located across from the Church and a more expensive one nearby as well. There are no other restaurants in the area--we learned that after searching for one and walking a few miles so it is best that you eat at the kabob place near the Church if you are hungry. The Church is so full of history and beautiful art.
beautiful very unusual mosaics. good explnations. very interesting, easy to find, nice location, nice restaurant in the garden
Serene. Beautiful mosaics! Wonderful little area behind the church to eat and wander.

u learn they christian history and beliefs here.... far from city centre, but its worth being there, but do not forget to take the audio guide else you will not enjoy the place, better to go for audio guide then the human guide :)
Okay, if you have the time. This is a beautiful Byzantine church, but it takes longer to get there than to experience.
Small but Very Beautiful Church. Chora Church has very beautiful frescos and mosaics in a compact space. This is a wonderful place to visit in conjunction with a walk along the Theodosian Walls.
A gem. This Byzantine church with its restored mosaics and frescoes is a bus ride from the center of the Old City near the city walls in the north and well worth a visit.

Not on Wednesdays. It wasn't as spectacular as I expected from what I'd read and heard, but it was interesting if you like Byzantine church art. Warning: it is closed Wednesdays, unlike everything else in Istanbul.If you walk a couple of blocks uphill, you can climb the steps to the top of the old city wall. From there you can see everywhere, but it can be scary if it is windy.

Lovely Mosaics - a bit overcrowded. For those it is off the beaten track - it really isn't - when we went it was FULL of tour groups. It's very small and the entry fee is steep considering. Get it on the Museum Pass.

Peaceful. In an predominant islamic world it is nice to see a christian church, built in the Bizantine period, so well restaured and mentained. It is a museum. Despite some mosaics are deteriorated here and there, it shows the interest of Turkish authorities for preserving all historic values.

Awesome place, a bit out of the way. If you want to experience real istanbul go here. The venue is awesome but a bit out of the way. It's real nice inside and not as crowded as the other venues in Sultanamet. After go outside and into the main street. Walk around and you will experience real Istanbul, with local people, english is a struggle but they will help none the less. Go into the shops and eat and buy for a great local experience.

A Gem worth a visit. Located just inside the ancient walls of Istanbul this tiny church with well preserved Byzantine archecture in the Edirnekapi District 4 miles outside of the Suntamet district. The word Chora comes from "uncultivated fields" or "a virgin" so this church is dedicated to the Virgin Mary. Its very crowded and small so go early or late to enjoy it without the crowds

Must See. Visiting the Chora church was our favourite day in Istanbul. Not only was it different enough from all the other religious sites to be worth a trip on its own, but it forced us out of the comfort of the regular tourist locations. We caught a tram from Sireci and then two trains to get there which was easy enough (with a bit of help from the ever friendly locals). Then after a sincerely admiring visit of the church (complete with audio guide which was good) we wended our way down to the Golden Horn getting pleasantly lost in the alleyways en route and sustaining our energy levels by arbitrary stops in patisseries with delectable home-made dishes. Lucky it's downhill to the river because we could have rolled if need be. Then instead of looking for a ferry boat we walked back to Eminonou along the river front and again were the only tourists in sight most of the time. It took about 2 hours of very slow walking to get back. Don't miss this opportunity to see the non-touristy side of Istanbul.

Lovely mosaics and frescoes - well worth a visit. This is well worth a visit - and while a little way from Sultanahmet is easily accessible by taxi. The mosaics and frescoes tell stories from the life of Jesus and of Mary. The walls and ceilings are covered with these colourful, detailed pictures. it is useful to have a little booklet (or something similar) with all the pictures and their location so you can follow the thread of the stories more easily. The only potential downside of a visit is a sore neck from gazing up at the paintings! That is a small concern really - given what there is to see....

Extraordinary mosaics. This was just about the last site we visited in our ten days in Istanbul, but it was among the most rewarding. The mosaics and frescoes are amazing. Getting to it takes initiative - we took a ferry up the Golden Horn then a taxi (10 TL) from Ayraskoy (sp.?). We caught the bus back, but more by good luck. Like most such sites in Turkey it is poorly managed. There is an English brochure, but to get it you have to ask a security officer, who dispenses it surreptitiously from a locked box on the wall. Why? Presumably to encourage you to purchase the audio guide? But do see this extraordinary survival!
Off the tourist trail but worth a visit. A small Byzantine church with many detailed mosaics. It's in a residential area, but easy enough to find even by public transport and a short walk.

An Independent Visit to an Interesting Church and Neighborhood. The church is, as just about every reviewer has said, very interesting and well worth a visit. Getting there and walking around the neighborhood is part of the fun - if you like to do things independently. At the Sultanahmet tram stop, take the T1 in the direction opposite to going to the ferry piers. Have 2 tokens for each person taking the trip - one when you board the T1 and another when you transfer to the T4. Get off at the Topkapi tram stop (not to be mistaken with Topkapi Palace). Transfer to the T4 tram - you're getting on at the terminus for T4 so there is only one direction to go. Get off at the third stop (Edirnekapi). From the tram stop you can walk to Khora Church. There are signs but they are not always clearly visible. When in doubt all you need to do is ask people on the street. Remember to ask for "Kariye" not "Khora". People are very helpful. After visiting this gorgeous church, walk around the neighborhood to get a feel for the lives of ordinary Turks. If you feel you are getting lost, ask people again for directions. You can either retrace your way back using the tram or, if you are really adventurous in the neighborhoods like us, you can find your way to a pier on the Golden Horn where you can take the inexpensive ferry back to the historical center.

A must see whe in Istanbul. This church is difficult to get to but well worth the effort. The mosaics and frescos are outstanding. Take the tram and train and then get a taxi for the last couple of kilometers. We got ripped off by a taxi driver who was waiting outside the chuch when we left - be aware that even if a price is agreed its not always adhered to. We gave the original amount only and the driver wasn't happy but be aware this does happen. For such a major attraction this was a disappointing end to the visit.
Stunning frescoes. Stunning frescoes and mosaics. Not overwhelmed by crowds, so there is a chance to see everything.

A lovely Byzantine Church in an interesting, non touristy neighborhood in Istanbul. This should be on the must see list for anyone interested in history and in viewing Iconic mosaics. These mosaics are as lovely as the ones in the Aya Sophia but are more accessible as the site is smaller and there are no crowds. There is a nice small rose garden around the site. Take the ferry to get here as you get a nice view of the city from the water. You can then taxi or bus back to the Galata bridge. Walk around the neighborhood as well, to get a true flavor of a real working city neighborhood. The waterfront park area is a nice respite from a very busy city, particularly on a hot day!
historical. The mosaics in this former church turned mosque are exquisite and well worth the time it takes to get there.

Do not miss these mosaics. Our guide toured the church's ancient mosaics with us, making sure we understood the biblical stories being portrayed. The mosaics are in wonderful condition and are well worth going to see. Then have lunch outdoors at the beautiful Asitane Restaurant nearby.
little hagia sophia. it is almost the same idea of hagia sophia. it is worth to see it.
Byzantian. Atmospher is marvellous, well protected mosaics, part of old Istanbul, i like it very much. Please go and see.
Wonderful paintings. Wonderful Biblical paintings on the walls and ceiling.

A MUST SEE Site. An incredible display of frescoes and mosaics in a thoroughly charming church. It takes a little bit to get there, but it is more than worth the effort. Just don't go on a Wednesday; it's closed.

Magnificent display of Byzantium architecture. The Chora Monastery is an absolute must for experiencing Byzantine architecture and well preserved mosaics and frescoes. It is referred to as the Chora Complex or Kariye Museum. The church itself is the most important Byzantine monument after Hagia Sophia. The whole building is in great condition and inside the mosaics and frescoes is still vivid. Coming from Sultanahmet you can take the tram and get off at Topkapi station and change trams to Edirne Kapi. When you get to the station you will see part of the old city wall with a gate through which you pass and then turn left and you will see the signs to Kariye Museum. From the station it is about a 500 meter walk. The entrance was 15 Turkish Lire but it is really worth the money.Outside the museum is little shops and a restaurant.

Amazing. This church is a must to see, after all the Mosques this stands out as the best wall and ceiling art, both mosaics and paintings. Give it time do not just walk through if you are interested in early art this is the place to be

Out of this world. You need more than an hour to really give this wonderful place any justice. The wall paintings are just breathtaking. Read about it before you go it makes sense when you look at the walls and ceilings.

a wonderful site. chora is like an art history book almost come to life. stunning. as it is out in edirnikape in fatih next to the city gates it is not as heavily visited as the other sights are in sultanahmet. while you are there be sure to climb around on the old city wall nearby - great views!
a gem. off the beaten path but well worth a visit. Outstanding mosaics, beautiful atmosphere.
very far but amazing. One of the most amazing buildings I've ever seen! Make it a must for your trip!
Mosiacs that take your breath away. As beautiful as they are now, they must have been breath-taking when they were new.

far to get to. Was not as convenient to get to as some of the other sites, but is a good choice if you want to see a very old Christian church that was later turned into a mosque and is not having the Christian mosaics detailing the life of Jesus, etc,
Pick your day. I am not in a position to review this but a tip for travellers. Don't go on Wednesdays as it is closed
Make the effort to find it. This lovely little church with its amazing mosaics and frescos is well away from the usual tourist areas, and rather hard to find, but it is definitely worth it.

An Istanbul Must!. This little church is a bit out of the way from the old city, but remains an absolute must. The entire place is filled with the most amazing frescoes and mosaics.FYI, from the old town area, we took the tram to the Suleymaniye Camii (Suleyman the Magnificent mosque) and then a cab from there only cost 10 TL for 3 people. If you do this, be sure to remember that it is the Kariye Muzesi. Locals dont know what the "Chora Church" is. The ride back to the main port/spice market area was a little more (20 TL) but well worth it.I cant recommend this place enough if you have the time in Istanbul to get away from the main tourist attractions and see the little ones that you will forever be talking about.

Small, but memorable. The mosaics in this former church turned mosque are exquisite and well worth the time it takes to get there. We walked through the neighborhood and loved seeing the local people in their daily lives.
excellent chuch. not maintained. strange because we paide the entrance tickets

A small church with the most complete Mosiacs in Istanbul. It was small, out of the way and the mosiacs were just wonderful, it was amazing to find it had been preserved so well. Not to be missed Bus 37 & 38 from bus station Galata Bridge get you there, 5 t.l. return. Bus drivers helpful and tell you where to get off and where to go.

lovely mosaics. A bit tricky to get to (we took a bus, but it's not obvious where to get off or what to do after you do) but worth seeing if you have the time. The mosaics are quite astonishing and largely well preserved. The audio guide gives detailed descriptions of what you are seeing. There is a smart restaurant next door but that was fully booked: we had good kebabs and fruit juices at the place directly opposite.
impressive. Easy to view; beautifully preserved; historically important....and impressive
Well worth a visit.. This a is a wonderful church with the most wonderful mosaics and paintings. A real must. Quite hard to get to.

memorable. I am so glad we made the effort to find this wonderful church. My husband treated me to a wonderful lunch at Asitane afterwards...just close to the church wonderful food and not that expensive.
Chora Church.. Wonderful mosaics and frescos. It is quite small and was very crowded until a tour party left!

The Chora Museum is a Must See!!! aka Kariye Muzesi. The Chora was a wonderful place to visit. It is a relatively small Byzantine Church compared to others in Istanbul, It is also a little out of the way but take a taxi or a day tour to get there, it will be worth it. The frescoes are beautiful, but the mosaics were unbelievable! I could have looked at them for hours. I do mosaics as a hobby and I tried to imagine the workman hours and skill that went into this church and It boggles the mind.The section featuring the life of The Virgin Mary and her parents was especially of interest as I had not seen anything like this before.I will visit it again when I am in Istanbul preferable in low season when I can really enjoy. I found taking pictures was an effort as there were so many people, tour groups, so I bought the postcard booklet with all the frescoes and the Mosaics and just enjoyed myself in the moment, rather than struggle to take mediocre pictures.
rude staff. used to be a church, so people must show more respect.
Breathtakingly beautiful. The frescoes and the mosaics are mere beauty. It makes you wondering about the high quality of ancient arts.
out of the way but worth the effort. Wonderfully preserved mosaics of byzantine style, rent the audio guide as it really provides in depth information about the content
very good. A bit off the beaten track but well worth a visit. The mosaics and fresco painting are wonderful.I would recommend you to see.

fabulous mosaics. it may be small compared to the other sites (aya sofya, blue mosque...), but it's well worth the short bus ride to edirnekapi. the mosaics are absolutely beautiful. this makes my top 5 list for istanbul.
Worth a trip. Another important site for Orthodox Christians - must see and read about it before you go
worth the cab fare. We loved this site and please don't be put off by the distance from other tourist sites
Kariye museum. lovely mosaics. go early before it gets too crowded and stroll along the old walls nearby too.

Mosaic to protect. I have to say that the mosaics in this church are one of the most beautiful i've seen, even more beautiful than Ayasofia. If you have time try to get to Chora it might be far from the tourist area but worth the hassle!
Wow. Unbelievably well preserved! The staff was friendly and helpful! I wished they had the lower section open to the public.

Beautiful. If you are going to be in the Sultanhamet area for more than one day I recommend buying a Museum pass, 72 Turkish Lira, with it you get into, Hagia Sophia, Kariye Museum, Topkapi Palace, the Archaeological Museum, and the Museum of Islamic Culture. And you can skip past the ticket lines for all of those places with the pass!

Not to be missed. This incredible gem might be overlooked as it's a bit out of the way, but well worth taking the time to seek it out. It's the best bang for your buck based on square footage - the mosaics are phenominal, and the frescos are amazing also. WOW.

Astounding glory. I had been to Istanbul several times but never visited this church. It has magnificent Mediaeval mosaic depictions of the life of Christ all over the inside of its walls . Some damage, admittedly, but by far more impressive than the ones in the Aya Sofia. I was blown away. I will go back and revisit this.
Amazing mosaics. Easy to view; beautifully preserved; historically important

a place not to miss. the place is of great historical and religious value but i didn't like that the maintenance is very bad.
the roof is nearly falling apart and the mosaics are missing pieces!

Very interesting !!. Although the Chora Church (its Greek name ) or the Kariye Museum (in Turkish) is not a very promiment museum , it is very interesting, with wonderful mosaics in a very interesting neighbourhood if you walk about a little. Definately worth visiting it, but you should have a guide to pinpoint the little details that make the difference !!!

Rather far, but really worth it to see. Don't be afraid of wasting the time on the way to this place, yes, you need around 1-1,5 hour to get there by metro&walk(if you do that by yourself) but the beauty of this small church will give you enough inspiration to continue the trip.On the way you can see the real life of Istanbul with it's narrow streets and interesting people.

Stunningly beautiful. Somewhere that really has to be seen to be believed. It pays to have some knowledge of the history Somewhere that really has to be seen to be believed. An understanding of the history of the church and Christianity would be helpful and I would recommend the audio guide. Not to be missed.

Sad but stunning vestiges of a glorious past. Everywhere you go in Istanbul, former byzantine churches have been converted into mosques under Ottoman rule. Usually all anthropomorphic decoration has been erased, but Chora remains a church and has retained many of its original and fabulous mosaics. One can only imagine the wealth of art and culture that has been wantonly destroyed everywhere else! An absolute must-see.

Well worth the visit. The actual name is Kariye museum of Saint Saviour in ChoraThe church dates from the 11th century and here you will see some of the finest Byzantine mosaics and frescoesThe journey to reach this site is about a 30 minute tram trip followed by a 10 minute walk along the old city walls
A hidden gem.. This was my favorite site in Istanbul. It is a taxi ride away from the center...but well worth it. The mosaics are exquisite.

Chora Church. This is a little out of the way so you will need to take a cab to get there but once inside it is very beautiful. We did not take the audio guide but I wish we did as there are many interesting mosaics on the walls and celinings.
Beatifull. An unexpect silence of prayer.Incridible habit of washing head, foot.....different

This little jewel depicts, in mosaics, the life of Mary.. This is a small museum, a former church and mosque. It is one of my favorite museums in Istanbul. So often, the history of Mary, mother of Jesus, is neglected in study and art.
Bit of an effort to get there. Worth a visit if you are into ancient church history especially to see the mosaics but there are similiar mosiacs in the Hagia Sophia museum.

Amazing mosaics inside this little church. Looking not much from the outside and in a neighbourhood distant from the centre although just within the old city walls, I was amazed by the mosaics inside this church, brought alive by the historical knowledge of our guide Faruk from Argeus travel.
Find it. It's not that easy to find, so take a taxi or prepare to walk from Ayvansaray ferry stop.

Worth the side trip. It's a bit out of the way, but it's absolutely magical. The mosaics are so well preserved. I would say that it's a must-visit on a two- to three-day trip to Istanbul. It's very moving for a Christian.

Incredible frecoes and mosaics - not to be missed. This church is near the Roman city walls and is easily accessed from the Sultanamet area by tram (one change). The interior of the church has incredible mosaics and frescoes. It would be helpful to have a plan in each area of the church on a board to aid identification of the different scenes depicted.

amazing space, great neighborhood. We took the metro and only got vaguely lost, but signs lead you up the winding streets. You could spend hours with your neck straight back, following the life of the virgin, the bible stories and the mosaic trim work which was like tapestry. It's an amazing piece of Byzantine art, not to be missed. Read up about it before hand if you can, as it's a little hard to figure out on your feet.  And if you time it right, there's a lovely cafe behind it for a hot chocolate, tea or lunch.
Must see!. Its a small church/mosque/muzeum full of marveilous mosaics near Edirnekapi. A bit further but worth a visit. Sitting in a small garden of church in afternoon is amazing.

A Hidden Treasure. This involves a trip out of the centre of Istanbul by bus or Metro but well worth it. More than 40 excellent mosaics showing the life story of Mary. You will need at least 2 hours here to study the mosaics - ask for the leaflet in English, giving detailed explanation.
Beautiful frescos. It is very good that these masterpieces are remain and we can see it at this time.

Closed for resoration until July 2012. In a recent visit to Istanbul we intended visiting this museum, but were advised by a local travel agent that it was closed for restoration purposes until July 2012.If it is on your "visit" list and you intend visiting most of the important museums you will save a lot of money and queuing time by purchasing a 24 or 72 hour museum card which will give you entry into the major museums

Take the ferry there. This church is a gem with stunning mosaics. It is out of the way but we were assisted by local people in the neighborhood who kindly walked us there. There is a lovely but expensive tea garden next door. Tea was twice the price but the location made it worth it.
Expensive - but worth it. Fantastic Byzantine mosaics. Out of the way, but worth the trip
Interesting. The mosaicaics are extraordinary, the peacefull feeling that you get, the thought of the past, everything is so interesting.
The best Byzantine Mosaics, Istanbul. A real gem and should be on every Istanbul must see list.
Worth the effort. A bit off the beaten track but well worth a visit. The mosaics and fresco painting are wonderful.
stunning!. very comfortable athmosphere and stunning mosaics that prove that Istanbul's architecture is one of the most amazing ones in the world, especially with this religious site!
Feast of Byzantine mosaics. Probably best pre Ronesaince building of the history of art

Perfect little gem. Hidden away from the main attractions of Istnbul this is a perfect little byzantine church with beautifully preserved frescoes. The surrounding area of Fener is worth a wander too - we got lost several times and were guided back on track by a succession of elderly gents and young lads, all with perfect good humour and courtesy despite the lack of shared language. Wonderful afternoon.
Beautiful small church. The frescos still tell amazing Biblical stories, still visible since it was built in 1000 AD.

Don't miss it. It's not in the center but you should go there. Wonderfull historic site. On your way there you can see parts of the city. nice restaurantes near the site, expensive ones and sheap ones. just go there and see it!

Don´t miss visiting fantastic frescoes.. Despite being a little distant, a visit is worthwhile, for the frescoes are fantastic. As the church is small, arrange a visit for lunch at Asitane which is next door and has a beautiful experience of the former kitchen of Turkey.

Fabulous Mosaics. Chora's mosaics are spectacular. The walls and ceilings of the inner and outer narthexes are covered with some of the greatest mosaic work ever done. We've been to Ravenna twice to see 5th and 6th century mosaics at the churches there, created when Ravenna was the capital of the Western Roman Empire. Chora's are probably of equal quality, although the style is 600-700 years newer. Chora is certainly worth the trip. It's about a four mile drive from Sultanahmet. For those going there I would also recommend taking a short walk to the old city walls. They are about 1500 years old and definitely worth seeing.
Unexpected beauty and detail. Huge crowds, but worth the trek up and down the small streets.
Off the beaten path. One of our favorite sites in Istanbul. Not as crowded as the more popular sites, making it easier to enjoy your visit.

Out of the way but worth seeing. This attraction is very different from other sites we visited in Istanbul and a lot of people skip. I am very glad we were able to see the church's beautiful mosiacs and frescoes and would go back on a subsequent visit to Istanbul.
A Little Gem. A bit out of the way to get to but well worth it. Lovely cafe opposite for a spot of lunch.
Mosaics are the BEST. Don't miss this place, it is really cool even though it is off the beaten path.
Mosaics are AWESOME. this place is off the beaten trail but worth it. Check out the nice coffee shop in front of the church. THIS IS A MUST SEE
Simply Great.. Simply Great. Is one of the best sites I have ever seen. It's a little bit far from the old city but I highly recommend it. Very nice mosaics
Frescoes and Mosaics!. Amazing frescoes and mosaics in this small out of the way church that is definitely worth a visit.

WOW. Don't miss this absolute GEM. The paintings are wonderfully preserved, beautifully done, and truly sublime. Its small but packs a big punch, worth the ride to get there. We missed out on the restaurant next door but heard it was wonderful.
Great Mosaics. I loved this place...I had heard about it, and found it fascinating!

Don't miss this church. The mosaics were spectular. Spend the time and money to get a taxi and visit this wonderful church. There is a great restaurant next door Asitane which we didn't visit but would recommend it.
For Mosaic lovers. What a lovely church / history. It's a quiet place, and a bit out of the way, but you will be glad you went.
A truly "wow" experience. This was on my list of places to visit for aaaages! I was so impressed with this museum. It is well worth a visit - just as impressive and magical as the bigger Aya Sophia.

Fabulous Byzantine Mosaics. The museum is a bit hard to find, out in the suburbs also confusion in tourism info about the name: St Saviour Church in Chora/Kariye Museum = same thing but not always clear. Found it in the end and it was fabulous.
Great mosaics and frescos.. The illustrated bible stories covering walls and ceilings are beautiful and illuminating in all senses of the word. Go with a guide to get the most from the visit.
Absolutely Amazing. Very beautiful and well maintained building. Excellent value for money.

amazing byzantine mosaics. If you can do only two sites in istanbul, make this you number two. it is a hike to go there but well worth the effort. Get the audio guide and spend time to enjoy the garden and look at the structure from the outside. On the return, most taxis will gouge you so walk up the hill to the main road and you will also be able to see the Ottomon walls.
A bit esoteric. You need to go there by taxi. It is a good visit for Art History people

A jewel. Beautiful and not nearly so crowded as Hagia Sophia. We saw this attraction as part of a "Christian Istanbul" tour offered by Tutku Tours, also highly recommended. We usually use cruise ship tours. Never again in Istanbul. We'll use Tutku exclusively from now on.
All about Mosaics. Out of the way, but well worth the visit to see the best preserved mosaics in istanbul.

Unbelievable mosaics. The Khora Church is well worth the effort as it is about 30 minutes from the Old City. The Byzantine mosaics are outstanding and depict many and different scenes from Mary's life.
Visit if you have time. A little out of the way. Great frescos a nice museum to visit if you have extra time in Istanbul

Wonderful Mosaics. Although this church is much smaller than the mosques in the old section, the mosaics are worth the trip. The Chora church is a bit of a challenge to get to but it also gives you a different view of the city. If you go on Saturday, walk uphill a few blocks to the Pigeon Market. Lots of Turkish men selling all kinds of pigeons! Next to the Chora church is a wonderful restaurant, the Asitane, which serves food from recipes from the 1400, 1500 and 1600's.
Wouldn't go again!. Not friendly, food poor, lamb kebab tasted more like five day old mutton.

A must in your greek Istanbul day. Recently restored, now it shines fully. If you are patient with the groups, you could finally visit it on your own. The book shop has a couple of interesting books about the churches in Istanbul and Turkey not so easy to find out there.

The Old Old Quarter. Endure the crowds for the splendid mosaics and charming scale of the old Greek church. Find your way back to Eminonu through the old neighborhoods of Balat and Fener. Far in decay for the most part, but still evocative of a Greek and Jewish Istanbul now nearly gone. Good bakeries!

Best bizantine mosaics in Istanbul. Despite being quite fa of the center, don't miss this joy. And after the visit don't fear to descent by walking to the Golden Horn to finish your greek morrning in Istanbul and visit the greek Patriachiate and the Pammakaistos Church

Worth the trip out. The mosaics are unparalleled -- it was much more interesting than I had expected. I would suggest either hiring a guide or referencing Rick Steve's guide when you go to get the most out of the trip and understand what you are looking at.

Amazing mosaics. If you feel kind of sad that many of the murals and mosaics in the Hagia Sophia were destroyed go here to lift your spirits. The church itself is small and it takes a little more effort to get there but is worth it. The mosaics are fantastic! You can get there by tram/train with one change from Sultanhamet then there are signs pointing you to the site after exiting the train.

turkey. this church was dedicated to the life of mary and depicts her whole life on the ceilings of the entrance inside its really something the mozaic tiles are less then a third of an inch its really wonderful to see
Historic Byzantine Church. Stunning mosaics and frescoes, also good views of this quieter area of the city
The best "Byzantine"mosaic museum. Except on wednesdays it is a must for a tourist in IStanbul !

Fantastic Ancient Orthodox Mosaics. The Church is not on the itinerary of every tour and is off the beaten track but it is well worth the effort to see it.The mosaics and wall paintings were covered over when the church became a mosque.Once the Turkish Government decided to make the building a national museum experts were able to remove plaster and covering and once again expose the mosaics.As the church is comparatively small you can get very close to the mosaics and get a really good look at how they were made and then step back and take in their beauty. Other people have covered their history etc so I won't repeat but I will say- If you are in Istanbul don't miss them.

Pain to get to, but wonderful mosaics. Got a bad deal from a Taxi in getting there, but the Mosaics are really quite wonderful. Coming back there is a bus stop just down the road. Once exiting the church go left. Head until you hit the main road. You'll see the bus stop there which will take you back into the heart of Istanbul where you have many transportation options for where you are going next.

Great tile work. The tile work inside the church is fantastic. It's too bad it's far from the city but it's worth going. The church is not very big so it won't take you more than 30 minutes to see it all but don't underestimate it and browse it too fast. Take a good look at the detail. It's too bad there's so much tile work missing. I'd had love to see it in it's prime days!I think this and Hagia Irene are the only churches not converted to Mosques.
Beautiful mosaics!. Despite od small, it's a very beautifull old church, one of the oldest know christian churches with great mosaics from Bizantine times.

Extraordinary Mosiacs and Frescoes. This early church dates from around 11th century, although they did extensive work inside in the early part of the 1300's. The Mosaics and frescoes are breathtakingly beautiful. I have visited many early churches in Italy, however, this placed surpassed my expectations .Please be sure that you arrive early, and bring along a small pair binoculars so you can to see the details of delicate and splendid artworks. I arrived when the museum first opened and had free movement for about an hour. Then the hordes of tourists arrived pushing their way thru the museum; snapping tiny digital cameras at everything without thought, but missing the experience of the beauty and wonder of this former church.Easy to get to from Eminonu main bus station. Nice gift shop, and outside many places to have a drink and a little bite to eat.
A little out of the way but worth it. Beautiful mosaics. There is a lovely park just below the church. Nice place to have tea and hang out with the locals.
Kariye frescoes and mosaics. Wonderfully preserved/restored. We did this on own and took a taxi to get there. We had to walk up to the main road to find a ride back to our next destination.

really impressive church. really impressive church with its 14th century mosaics and frescoes with scenes from the Bible. Photos were allowed inside --- must be taken without a flash --- they have security which monitors tourists)!
Don't miss this slightly out of the way treasure. These mosaics are truly amazing. Easy to reach by tram.
Stunning. Although it's a little distance from the main attractions in Sultanahmet, Chora Church is amazing. Well worth the trip, since you can also check out the ancient walls of the city there too.

Beautiful Mosaics. This mosaics in The Chora Church are well worth a visit. We had private guide who explained them to us; one could also get audiotours before entering the church. Definitely worth a visit.

Worth the visit. I was a bit worried to reach the place based in some comments that it is deep in the suburbs but actually I just needed 20 minutes from Pera area out of the rush hour by taxi and around 15 liras.The mosaics and the architecture are terrific, and the whole atmosphere of just a such old church was remarkable. Coming back there was a taxi in the entrance asking me for an expensive ride to return to downtown. Just skip it, walk a bit to a main avenue and you will find regular taxis very easily.Don't miss this it if you visit Istanbul.
Small, but nice. We did this on an extra free afternoon, but could have been missed.
The Chora. mostly liked the frescoes which are well protected. This one is taking you back to history.
Senses, soul and love. I liked all about Chora Church: the paintings especially.

Our Favorite Istanbul Site. This was our favorite place of the historic sites in Istanbul. It is small but the mosaics inside are wonderful. It does not take long to go through it so we had our taxi driver just wait for us. It took about 30 minutes to see the whole thing plus look around the small gift shop. There is a nice cafe just outside the exit for a cup of Turkish tea if like.

Mind blowing. This museum has the most incredibly beautiful mosaics and frescoes. It is a little way out of the city but well worth the visit. I had been impressed by the frescoes in Haghia Sophia but I believe these are more impressive. There are so many of them and in very good condition. A must on any tourist's agenda in Istanbul.

Beautiful hidden gem. A bit out of the way but well worth a visit - you can walk from the centre of town (about an hour) and see lots on the way and get a taxi back - lots waiting to pick up tourists.

Fun Field Trip. This little gem is a must-see for anyone seriously interested in the art and history of Byzantium. Produced during the "Byzantine Renaissance" after Michael Paleologus reclaimed Byanztium from the Crusaders, it has spectacular, highly-detailed mosaics from the life of Christ. After seeing the church, stroll up the hill and walk a bit along the Theodosian Walls.
Don,t Miss. Although tucked away from other major attractions we are so glad that we visited the Kariye the mosaics are amazing.
let down. after reading all the wonderful reviews for this church I was very much looking forward to going there. It was ok. only spent about 10 minutes there and was able to see everything.
Worth going. I loved the atmosphere, the icons are marvellous, the whole place is great for making pictures. And also very close by there is a superb restaurant of Ottoman Cusine

Beautiful mosaics!. These mosaics did take my breath away! If you like (at least a little bit) "art&history" places, you will enjoy the visit. It takes some time to reach the place (tram+metro+a bit of walking), but, as a "bonus" you can see a part of old city wall and a less touristic part of town as well.Advise: learn a bit about the history of this church before the visit (audioguide mostly explains the meaning of the mosaics).

Great change from the mosques. This church is a bit out of the way but we decided to do it anyway upon the recommendation of a friend in Turkey. Negotiate a flat rate (we were staying in Sultanahmet) with a taxi driver to get you there and I guarantee you it will be cheaper (20TYL flat rate/31 with meter.) We were told this by our friend but decided to try both ways. Not smart!The church itself was 15 TYL entrance fee and was small but had some amazing mosaics. I would highly recommend this church as there weren't many mosaics at the other places we went. There were a few over-priced shops around outside of the place and grabbing a taxi back was as easy as pie.

What a gem!. This little church on the far side of the city from Sultanhamet has fabulous mosaics in an ancient setting. And while, completely worthwhile on its own, its location near a large section of the city wall affords an opportunity to kill two birds with one stone. Cab there and back to avoid a long walk or take a good map and hike across the city seeing real neighborhoods, byzantine aquaducts and more.

Moni tis Horas-Monastery of the Nation. Among the oldest churches in the city.
The best mosaics ever showing Christ and Apostles.
A museum now .A must visit,really must

My favorite small church in Istanbul. This former monastery is small for the price (15 TL, the same as the Topkapi Harem) but worth it for the Byzantine mosaics and wall paintings. There are only about 4 unfurnished rooms to view; my visit lasted about 30-45 minutes but the mosaics are lovely. It can be reached by taxi or if you are using the Istanbul transit system, a 10-15 minute bus ride to Edirnekap - several go there and the driver of mine told me in sign language how to get to the museum - it's an easy short walk towards the Bosporus.
Don't miss it.. A bit out of the way, but a must see. Such unbelievable beauty in the frescos and mosaics. Book a tour if you must, but please don't miss it.

Worth the trip. This church has some lovely restored mosaics and it's located in a residential neighborhood, so it's worth the trip to see another part of the city. There is a nice cafe directly across the street and Asitane restaurant is right next door, so makes a nice lunch after the tour.

Best Byzantine mosaics in Istanbul. When you finish the classical tour of Istanbul ( Hagia Sophia, Blue Mosque, Topkapi Palace and Bazaar), if you have a second day, go for a Bosphorus cruise and in the afternoon visit this church to see the best Byzantine mosaics and compare with frescoes of Giotto in Padova-Italy. You will see the difference. You can end up the day with a turkish coffee toward sunset at Cafe Pierre Loti (end of Golden Horn)

Well worth a visit. Very interesting - with beautiful mosaics. Was a bit of an effort to find. On our last afternoon we found a taxi driver who spoke perfect English - For 80TL we mopped up the sights we had not seen, and he took us back to our hotel. Well worth it.

Byzantine Art at its Very Best. Although out of the centre of the city - take a taxi, it is miles from the nearest public trasport - this is an absolute gem. The frescoes will take your breath away and are reviewed as probably the finest examples of Byzantine art in the world.

One of the best example of Byzantine Art. One of the best preserved church from the Byzantine period. Most of the frescos are covered by plaster during the Ottoman period. It was not well known church till 1975. After the renovation of the district, The Chora Church gained importance and nowadays it is an important attraction place of the tourists. Most of the pictures and frescos are taken from the Biblical stories. It must see place in Istanbul
Mosaics. Great mosaics in a tiny church in a quiet part of Istanbul. good cafe nearby.

Breathtaking frescoes and mosaics. One of the top 5 interesting places to visit in Istanbul. Byzantine church with a-m-a-z-i-n-g frescoes and mosaics some well preserved! Visit the place early in the morning, so that there are less people in the church. This way you will enjoy the mystic atmosphere. Don't leave Istanbul without having seen it!
Beautiful.. Compared to the other buildings you visit, this church is small, but the art work is beautiful. The preservation of the murals and art is amazing.

Beautiful and historic. Well worth going to see. Somewhat complicated to get to by bus, but a taxi can get you there. Be sure to get the fare settled in advance, especially on the way back! The church itself is lovely, with ancient murals and frescos on the walls, and a sweet little garden area surrounding it.

Amazing mosaics and paintings. There are so many pictures to see.
All byzantine icons from before the Ottoman conquest

amazing area. when you will go to this place .
you feel history and
