fantastic

A pearl. It's not the easiest place to reach, but it's worth the walk through Fatih neighborhood. Its mosaics are just wonderful and well preserved/restored, and the place has an authentic flavour. The surrounding area is a bit run down but safe. I found this place really inspiring. Try not to miss it during your stay in Istanbul, even though you might have to get things organized on your own. You could also take a walk in the neighborhood and see a less touristic side of the city.

An Amazing Must See in Istanbul. Though situated a little bit away from usual touristic sites of the city, Kariye Museum is definitely a must see in Istanbul: once you step in, you are carried away from the present and you are really amazed of the environment thanks to beautiful mosaics and frescoes dating back from the 10th and 11th century. This place which is a museum today, used to be a church first, then was converted into a mosque during Ottoman Empire days and since the establishment of Turkish Republic, serves as a museum. There are a total of 90 mosaics and frescoes inside, on the walls and in the ceilings. Each of them signifies and symbolises important messages. Without knowing those meanings, touring the museum will be a mere contemplation of art work and that will be too limited. Therefore, I recommend you go there with a knowledgeable guide or make the tour with audio guides available at the entrance. The museum shop, though small, offers not only souvenirs but also good books about Istanbul and history and arts. Beware: once you enter the museum, you can use your electronic ticket again for the same place only after 3 hours: as at the exit, there is a cafe, many visitors would like to take a break there and continue but this 3 hours limit create a problem for them. Next to this museum, there is also one of the best Ottoman restaurants of the highest quality (Asitane), so, you can combine a lunch or dinner for after the visit as well.
good. we came to know the histrory of istanbul , how the old kings and fought for there freedom
Amazing mosaics. A little tricky to find this amazing church from the metro, but well worth the trip. Such amazing mosaics! Beautiful exterior, too.

St. Savior in Chora. A must-see location in any visit to Istanbul. We went with Ozden Basak of Turkland Travel, who explained the amazing mosaics and frescoes. Also, next to a great Ottoman restaurant, Asitane.
Mosaics everywhere. The presevation is something. Quite a site to see.

2 trains and a little walk. Getting here on your own and be a bit of an effort but well worth it. The uncovered mosaics are gorgeous. It is far enough out from the main touristy areas that it may not be quite as crowded. It is an easy stroll but having a guidebook to help appreciate all there is to see would be suggested

small old church. In the past, this church probably was beautiful. However, at the present time, some of the mozaiks are already broken and lost.. though the ceiling is still beautiful. Not many things that can be told from this church. Personally, you can go here if you have more time. But you can save it for other site if you have only limited time

Beautiful mosaics. Worth seeing but beware of of taxi drivers. The church ia far from old city sites & we had to haggle with a taxi driver who ripped us off in the end. Make sure the meter is on or have your hotel arrange transportation.
Chora Church. Took taxi there, enjoyed the shopping across the road better than any other shopping area, quiet and friendly shop owners

The Crown Jewel of Byzantine Istanbul. This place is definitely Constantinople, not Istanbul! While Sultanahmet offers a lovely picture of the glory days of the Ottoman Empire, this museum hearkens back to Istanbul's heritage as the capital of the Byzantine empire. The mosaics here are inspirational, you don't have to be Orthodox to appreciate them. It's out of the way but that adds to the allure of it. There are no pushy peddlers and tour guides operating here. Price is reasonable (15 TL I think, maybe 20). It takes about an hour to see the church if you are concentrating on each mosaic and the architecture. It's out of the way for the main attractions, and we got ripped off by the cab to see it, but this is the place to come to encounter Byzantine Constantinople.

Famous Byzantine mosaics. The Kariye Museum holds some of the finest Byzantine mosaics to be found in Istanbul, many of which are complete or nearly so and will be familiar to anyone who has looked over a book on Byzantine history. The Kariye is a bit outside the main tourist districts around Sultanahmet but can be easily reached by taxi (the surrounding neighborhoods are run down, so taking a taxi would ensure the quickest route to the destination). The museum space itself is rather small and there are number of vendors offering books and postcards in place of a museum gift shop.

Great mosaics and lovely old church. Hard to find by public transport so probably best getting a taxi (cheap). Many original mosaics and murals. One of the best I've seen. Non-flash photography allowed. Small shop. Cafe opposite exit is good. Good views from entrance which is round the back. We walked up the side of the cafe and came on the walls. Turning left we followed the walls to the main road and turned left into town taking a bus to the Grand Bizarre (1 Turkish Lira).

Out of the way but worth it. It was a bit out of the way, but provided a beautiful example of relatively well preserved Byzantine mosaics and frescos. It also gave me a glimpse of a more "regular" suburban neighborhood.

Amazing mosaics. You go to Aya Sofya for architecture, but Chora Church for frescoes and mosaics. They are incredible and it's worth paying an extra 5TL for the audioguide that explains each image. It's easy to get to by public transport - a number of buses leave Eminonu and go past it, just ask the driver to let you off at 'kariye muzesi'.
So beautiful church. the scale of chora church is astounding and the history is incredible, it really is a must see..

My Favorite chuch,you can see hell and heaven in frescos:). It is one of the best chuches of Turkey,the others are Tokali in Goreme, Sumela Monastery in Trabzon, Ahtamara Church in Van. But in terms of mozaics,Kariye of Khora is the best one. It is less visited than other sights in Istanbul,but beacuse of teh location. If you are not a tourist,but a traveller, it is must see. You dont need to be a Christian to explore life of Virgin mary and Christ,beacuse it is full of with best examples of Byzantine mozaic and fresco art. Especailly the last judgament,hell and heaven is scenes are unique in elegancy. It is not hard go there,all you need to have taxi,or u can find a bus to Edirne Kapı from Eminönü,where the fishmen and Egyptian Bazaar located and ask where to stop to driver. If u love walking you can also go there by walking from Laleli,or Beyazit,and pass through Şehzadebaşı where sehzade mosque is located,then just follow the main road going straight to Fatih or Edirne kapı direction too. Many people doesnt know Khora museum which is Named Kariye in Local language. so pls ask them to go Fatih mosque and from there you can ask Kariye museum.

Difficult to get to, but worth the trip. Chora, or "The Church of the Holy Saviour" was originally built outside the city walls, by Constantine the Great. Now it is just inside the newer walls. We went by tram, and then walked for about half an hour. It was OK as the weather was fine, but the best thing is taking a taxi from wherever you´re staying to avoid all the hassle.The Church was built in the early 14th century, but was converted into a mosque in the 16th century. The art work was forgotten until 1860, when it was rediscovered in a bad shape. Restoration work did not begin until after the Second World War. The church is now a museum with slightly faded, but beautiful, Byzantine mosaics dealing with the life of Christ, and frescoes with scenes from the Old Testament. Majestic!Afterwards you have a chance to try typical Ottoman cuisine in restaurant Asitane - if you dare! Consult the Trip Advisor comments first.
Chora. Two tram journeys from the centre, but worth the trip

Have to see!!!. This was an off the beaten path, but well worth the trip. Not only do you get to see the most amazing mosaics around, you see a very intact city wall that runs around the ancient city of Constantinople.

Chora - Some of best mosaics in world. The Chora Church is outside the central historic area so it is worth taking a cab, tram or tour to get there. But by all means, don't miss it. Since the Virgin Mary is even more important in the Eastern Orthodox tradition than in Western Christianity, many of the mosaics of the church tell the story of her life and that of Jesus. It's astonishingly beautiful, yet little known among those who visit Istanbul.

Beautiful Byzantine mosaics. The Church at Chora (Kariye in Turkish) is off the beaten path, but well worth the trip. It is about a 20 minute/20 turkish lira drive from Taksim Square. Our taxi driver out there tried to charge us 25 TL but we referred to the meter (that had 17 before he turned it off) and we gave him 20. The first taxi we asked for the ride back wanted to charge us 30 so we didn't go with him and simply walked a couple of blocks to the busy street, where we easily found a taxi that went to Taksim for 20. Anyway...The church has beautiful mosaics of Christ's life and ministry, and also of Mary's life. The detail is amazing and many of them shine with gold and other brilliant colors. They are close, so you can really see them well. No flashes are allowed, but it is light enough that you can take pictures without a flash. There is a side room with impressive life-sized frescoes as well, and most are very well-preserved. Very much worth the taxi ride (despite some negotiation required).

Amazing!. We have had problems getting to the Chora Church--a couple of times taxi drivers dropped us off far from the church. Best to get a cab through the hotel. It is worth seeing. Exquisite mosaics that are very complete of the Virgin Mary and her life. A lovely, lovely church at the top of hill. Very pleasant outside as well. Even in the summer it is not over run with tourists.

Amazing!. This was one of my favorite places in Istanbul! The mosaics are fantastic -- very good for flash-less photo opps! It's a bit of a journey to get there, but it's worth it. Also, the gardens are nice (full of cats!) and the man at the gift counter was very helpful and friendly. Definitely go here!
One of the best mosaic museums in the world.. mosaics dated to the 14th century..stories of them like a novel..dont visit without a guide..

simple breathtaking. When visiting turkey, istanbul, dont forget to visit this place. Its beathes history and amazing architectural paintings. Its peaceful and the ground near it is filled with roses. Something you can enjoy with your family and truly if you are a history fanatic, then this is the place.
dont miss this place. must see this church museum. Mosaics and frescoes are very attractive. you shouldn't miss this place ;)
Worth a side trip. This is a bit off the beaten path, but has some incredibly well-preserved Christian frescoes.

Probably worth a visit, if only for the views of the city walls on the way there. Takes a while to travel to via public transport and there's not much else out there. The mosaics and frescoes were nice to see but the spectacular views of the city walls from Edirnekapi tram station were by far the highlight.

Go and see if for yourself. I'm a very ignorant catholic. Well this is probably one of the places where i can get most detailed information and all the interesting story on everything. The mozaic is wonderful too though i am more amaze with the comprehensive story telling in the picture while you are listening to the audio. Worth the trip. Absolutely a must see. The mosaics are in excellent conditionRecommended by the hotel otherwise we would have missed it.
A Must. This was our favourite place to visit in Istanbul, a little further out than other attractions but buses are easy and in fact we walked back. The audio guide is a must. Enjoy
Don't miss this one. The mosaic tiles are exquisite. There is something beautiful and haunting about the Chora Church. It was one of my favorite places in Istanbul

Guide Guney Presents. For Art lovers and religious foodstepers.It is a vivacious experiment walking through the small Inner and outer Gallery and ransack your knowledge or whats left of the life of jesus and mary.Anyone who wants to imagine how the apocalypse ends in the judgement day should face the northern wall of the paraekkleision.

Remote church worth a look. When we finally got to it, we liked the church with its Byzantine frescoes very much. However, it is difficult to get to the church on public transportation and I suggest that travelers take a taxi from a tram stop rather than trying to walk to it from the closest metro station. A bus might also be an option if you are familiar with the Istanbul bus system.

love it. Absolutely fabulous, wonderful, is not generally seen as eccentric (although the sites are concentrated in Istanbul in general). The exceptional quality of this site offsets the need to take a taxi to get there (and either pay the pending time of the visit, or to risk a long wait there another cab free to return).
GORGEOUS MOSAICS & FRESCOES. Wonderful church; out of the way, so not as crowded as other Istanbul attractions.

Mosaics!. This byzantine church(not as old as Hagia Sophia) has very well preserved mosaics. It is not a big church, with a beautiful garden, a little difficult to find it.From tramT1 Sultanahmet go to Topkapi station,change to tramT4(upstairs) and descend Edimekapi,then on foot.

Worth The Taxi Ride. I've never seen some of the images on the frescos in other places, so it was quite interesting. I'm really glad I went.
We found it necessary to negotiate the price of the taxi - it seemed taxi drivers would start with a price twice what we ended up paying after walking away from them.

Breath-taking mosaics. We took a cab from Sultanahmet to the Chora Church, and were not disappointed. The mosaics in this church are like no others; ornate, reasonably well-preserved, and massive. Additionally, the old walls of Istanbul run close to the church; it is possible to climb these walls and get an amazing view of the city. After seeing the church and the walls, we walked back to Sultanahmet through the Western districts of Istanbul, where we also saw Faith Mosque and the old Roman aqueduct. It was quite the afternoon!
Not much to see there. It is out of the way and not much to do around. The mosaics were nice but there wasn't that much to appreciate.

Beautiful frescos. The Chora Church, next to the Hagia Sophia is another must visit. The frescoes are wonderful. What is sad is the vandalism that took place in the past. The Turkish government now seems more willing and able to protect its ancient churches-- good thing.

The best Chuch of Turkey. It is a very small church from outside,and dont have an attractive decoration,but inside is like a magic: you can see almost all about life of Virgin Mary,and Christ. Moreover, if you are not an Ortodox,you can explore the amazing world of Ortodox icons,mozaics and Frescos. It is open all the seasons,and a good escape from other toursiic attractions whicxh are full of toursits in Istanbul. no need to vait in the long queques like Topkapı or Hagia sophie. But it would be beneficial to read about the scenes of Gospel apocryfical and Luka,Yuhanna,Matta,Marcos. If you dont like reading,you can find a guide who can read the scenes to you and you can also discuss about them:) I especially liked the Paraclesion,beacuse there was a detailed scenerey pf Paradise,hell and the last judgament day. It really deserves to be visited. Also the museum is very close to other attractions like Blacherna Palace and Holy spring of Blacherna. Give yourself a day to explore the museum,and the area. You can also see the step brother of Christ in the mozaics:)

A gem. This is a must though it is off the beaten tourist path and therefore often neglected. A Byzantine Church that contains some of the most wonderful wall paintings and mosaics I have seen, which makes you wonder what Byzantium must have looked like in its glory days with hundreds of churches like this. Best to take a taxi which are incredibly cheap compared to Central Europe as the church is quite a distance from the touristic centre.
Little gem of a museum with excellent Biblical depictions. The church has some of the best examples of mosaic and paintings illustrating passages of Jesus' life.
good place. It,s very good place you can visit to discover the turkish culture
jeweled walls. Gorgeous mosaics and frescos. See it before it disintegrates.

Gorgeous. The walk there through Fatih and then back, was as memorable as the church and it was as the title says, gorgeous. We had learned some Turkish before going and we took a big exciting risk in walking from Chora back to the Grand Bazaar. With directions from a nice adam we found another historic church museum: Fethiye Müzesi. Then, we wandered out as school was letting out. The kids all tried their english on us as the showed us a panoramic view of Istanbul and Phanar Greek Orthodox College. We then wandered the neighborhood around Phanar Greek Orthodox College as we wandered back toward the grand bazaar. This neighborhood is the. real. deal. the best. it's quite far from the rest of monuments, but it really deserves a visit. incredible!
Beautiful artwork. Absolutely beautiful church full of frescoes and mosaics.

A hidden gem!. This little-known church is maybe what impressed us the most in our visit to Istanbul. Its mosaics are simply amazing. It's a bit off the beaten path but it's quite easy to locate and very well worth a visitThere are buses that will take you there from Eminönü (31E, 37E, 38E or 36KE) or 87 from Taksim, get off at Edirnekapı after the sunken stadium you'll see on your right. You have a well-indicated 5-minute walk afterwards.
Worth the minor hassle of getting to this outoftheway place.. Excellent mosaics. Well restored and presented. Worth the minor hassle of getting to this outoftheway place.
beautiful. gorgeous mosaics and frescoes. it's just way outside the main areas of the city (in the middle of the residential area), you really have to go out of your way to see it
mosaic at its best. Small place in wonderful part of Istanbul. Christian mosaic in islam surroundings. Must see!
Fantastic mosaics. I could not believe how great the mosaics were. I spent hours in there and took many pictures. Very impressive.

great place. we came here on the last day of our istanbul trip (six days). It is hard to get so we take a taxi there. Istanbul taxi is very good and cheap. we are family of four so it make a lot of sense. this place is not that big, but what a place to visit. we rent the audio guide which you should get. All amazing mosaics are great to look at and listening the story. it was great to see our kids enjoy this too.

Interesting history of Christianity. It was very interesting to see the depiction of the life of Mary including her life as a young child through the teen years. We have never seen much about her early life. The tiles were beautiful.

One of the most beautiful monument in the world. Magic from outside and inside, this is truly one of the most beautiful monument in the world, with amazing mosaics. And it's remarkable how this church from XI century is so well preserved.
Definitely a must see.

Best mosaics in the city.... This small size church has the best icons in the city not only about Jesus but also Virgin Mary's life. Backgrounds, decorations of teh mosaics are remarable and their colors are just striking...

Mosaics are amazing. You can walk through Chora Chuch in less than 30 minutes but everywhere you turn there are beautiful mosaics. The Church is difficult to find if traveling on your own and not through a tour group.
Byzantine Art Jewel. Wonderful mosaics, one of the best exemples of his kind around the World.
Jewel. Wonderful mosaics, one of the best exemples of his kind around the World.
Unique in the world. The mosaique preserved here is not to be seen somewhere else. You must dee to understand the beauty of it.

beautiful mosaics, resturant next door amazing. I highly recommend making a trip to the chora church. The church is not very big, but the mosaics were very beautiful. I think it costs 15 TL a person. We came here on our 4th day in Istanbul as we already explored everything in the historical and european part of istanbul. It was difficult to get to, but it was worth it because of the things nearby. Right next to the chora church is a restaurant called Asitane, which was one of the best restaurants we ate at in Istanbul. We came here for a late lunch after our visit to the church. They specialize in ancient ottoman cuisine. They researched the recipes of the topkapi palace and then serve them on their menu, they include dates from which originate (ex: 1500s). The atomosphere was beautiful. Unfortunately we came on a monday, and apparently there is traditional turkish music played from thursday to sunday. ~ 110 TL for 2 with 2 appetizers, 2 mains, and 2 turkish coffees.Another thing to visit is the walls of istanbul a short walk from the church. You can climb stairs to get to the top of the wall and see the view.Another thing to visit is a hill nearby, recommended by our hotel, where you can take the cable car up and see a nice view of istanbul. Unfortunately we came on a cloudy day so it was not as beautiful as it could be. Information on how to get around: We took ferry from Eminou to Eyüp where the hill is located (~ 30 min, 2 TL, unfortunately only once an hr). Then we walked to cable car and took it up to the hill (2 TL), but is definitely walkable. Enjoyed the view. It was suggested to get a turkish coffee and enjoy the view but we came at the same time as a tour bus and it was very crowded so we didn't. We walked down through the cemetery, which was interesting in itself. From there we took a taxi to Chora church (~ 7 TL). We visited the church (~15 TL). Then had a late lunch at Asitane. We then walked to the city walls, and walked up to see the view. We walked along the wall until we got to the Ayvansaray ferry dock (it was kind of a run down neighborhood so I suggest to stay on main streets) and took the ferry back to Eminou.

DON'T MISS THIS MUSEUM. The building was built in the late 11th century, but has gone through many renovations and repairs during the following centuries. Almost all of the interior decoration—the exquisite frescos, the famous mosaics and the less renowned but equally striking mural paintings—dates from about 1320.The mosaics and frescos are considered some of the best in the world. The first mosaics you’ll see are dedicated to Jesus and Mary. Then you’ll visit two small domes of the inner narthex which focus on Jesus’ ancestors (all the way back to Adam). Then the next series of mosaics outlines Mary's life, and another, Jesus's early years. The final series concentrates on Jesus' ministry.Then there is the Parecclesion which is a side chapel holding the famous frescos, which focus on the death and resurrection of Christ. Don’t forget to look up and all around the room, including the doors you just came through.For four centuries after the Ottoman conquest of Istanbul it served as a mosque (Kariye Camii), and all of the Christian artwork was covered due to the prohibition of images in Islam. The frescos were covered by dirt, paint, and plaster for centuries until the former glory of Chora Church was entirely forgotten. The building was rediscovered in the mid-19th century and restored by the Turkish government.The building facing the Kariye Museum was once the Kariye Muhallebicisi or Pudding Shop, an old Istanbul institution. It now serves a variety of refreshments and is a delightful way to wait for the rest of your party to finish their tour of The Chora Church.Also, there is a small but nicely appointed gift shop just before exiting the museum. They have nicely priced items that will catch you eye.Although this isn’t as popular of a tourist attraction as Hagia Sophia, Basilica Cistern, Topkapi Palace, or the Blue Mosque, it really is a delightful gem and shouldn’t be missed.CLOSED WEDNESDAY.

Most of the tile mosaics are in excellent shape, and there are many, many more than what you can see at Hagia Sophia. If you are not into appreciating church history and faith through beautiful mosaics, this is not the place for you. The structure itself, other than its age, is not impressive architecturally. But oh those mosaics! It can get crowded - not that many people come here, but since it is small, when tour groups arrive, it can be crowded. Just move to a room where the crowds are not, or step outside for a few minutes.

Interesting location and place. We took a taxi here from our hotel. While it is a "museum", you are really seeing the church itself and the mosaics inside. It is not all that big...about an hour will do it max. The mosaics are worth the trip. Very beautiful!But what we liked as well was walking around this area. It is residential with the old city walls along the edge. You can follow the walls down the hill back to the city. An interesting walk with lots of local activity. Very good for phototgraphy.

Wonderful Mosaiques!. Karyie Museum - Chora Church is perhaps a little off the beaten paths but this totally worths the visit. The mosaiques are magnificient. We decided to visit on our own. See instructions below to reach the Church.From Sultanhammet, take T1 tram line head to "Aksaray" then walk for about 400m. to Metro M1 Aksaray station. Take metro line head to Havalimani (Airport) stop at Topkapi-Ulubatli (when coming from Aksaray) stay on same side and take first street on your left getting out of Metro "Kaleboyu Caddesi". You will see the walls on your right hand side. Walk for about 1km and at big cross you will see sign for Kariye Museum (turn left),
Outstanding Byzantine mosaics. It is an incredible Church with well preserved mosaics that depict many Biblical passages.

A must see, for the frescos alone.. Would advise going early in the day, as the area around the church, is not very nice. We took the tram as far as it could go and walked the rest of the way. In that way we got to see the old city walls. They were worth a look, fristly as still standing since before 1453, secondly you get to see the various lines of defense old cities had, for real!! The church is hard to find, and in the end a lovely old man showed us the way. Would advise reading up on the church beforehand, or buying a guide as there is no information whatsoever about the frescos. It took my breath away, and this is after most of the frescos were destroyed when changed into a mosque. it is not as magestic,or as awesome as the hagia sophie, but as it is small, and more frescos have been perserved, it is more moving. We walked back to the city centre, briskly, as two women, even in the afternoon, we felt could not linger. Along the way, there are very 'interesting' bridal shops, and one passes where Constintine the Emperor was buried.

Meaningful attraction - read about it before you go or.... ...arrange for a private tour from someone who is knowledgeable as to this site's particulars. The mosaics are amazing! This site was well worth the effort of getting there, even on a scorching hot July day. If time allows, explore the neighborhood in which it is set, which is also very interesting. We used Rick Steve's walking tour which provided excellent information about the Chora Church itself as well as the neighborhood. The Church is beautiful, while not of the same huge magnificence as the Hagia Sophia; its relative smallness and obscurity provides a peaceful addition to your Istanbul experience. Before we entered the complex, we had lunch at the conveniently located restaurant, eating outside where we could have the the Byzantium architecture for our view. We are so glad we made the time to include this in the list of 'must sees.'

Fascinating historic church! Breathtaking mosaics!. This church is amazing! The mosaic portrayals of biblical stories are beautiful works of art! The history is interesting, once made into a mosque, altered to offer a point at which to face Mecca, later made into a museum. See this after seeing the Hagia Sophia and Blue Mosque for further historical context...

Great to visit the church in conjunction with the old Constantinople city walls. Go to this church so you can envision what Hagia Sofia must have looked like! A bit pricey, but I think it was worth the 10TL or so to see the magnificent mosaics. It doesn't take long to visit this little beauty, so suggest you couple it with the old city walls and perhaps Yedikule fortress. In detail:First, take public transit to Edirnekapı station-- Chora Church is about a 10 minute walk through an 'authentic' part of Istanbul, really really fun to see. On your way to the church, you'll walk right past the old city walls. We took the time to climb up one of them to a tower (it's all just open!) and had some great views of the city. After you do Chora Church, take a cab to Yedikule to the south (about 10 minutes, 12TL). The ride is all along the old walls, quite fun!

Amazing mosaics and frescoes, it is a must-see in Istanbul!. The Chora Church or Kariye Camii is an antique church founded in the 4th century, which was richly decorated with mosaics and frescoes in the 14th century. The mosaics and frescoes in Chora are the most beautiful example of late bizantine art. After the otoman invarion, in 1511, Chora was converted into a mosque and all decoration was covered with plaster. In 1945 it was converted in a musem, and a full restoration was completed in 1959 by the American Bizantine Institute, when all decoration was uncovered.It is a good idea to get there by cab/taxi. We went by bus and had a hard time to find it by feet, and the neighborhood is not that nice.

Backpackers Travel Agency Istanbul. We were in Istanbul and the Backpackers were the best. They offer great tours with very good guides. We enjoyed our tours a lot. Would recommend that agency! They were great and very friendly!

Chora Church: Mosaics & Frescoes at its finest.. The Chora Church or Kariye Muzesi is considered as one of the best example of a byzantine church. It boasts one of the best and well preserved mosaics an frescoes in its interiors. These mosaics and frescoes depicts the life of Christ from childhood to adulthood to crucifixion and beyond, so watch carefully and I just hope you follow the sequence. If you are interested to know the stories of each phase of the fresco, you might want to get a licensed tour guide in the area.It's impressive so take a day out of the usual tourist path and go to there. People say it's out of the way or transport is complicated, but those were in theory, in reality it's easy. Been to Istanbul several times and I always miss this place so one day I decided to check the location on google map, and I figured there must be a way to go there by tram -- not bus.I was staying near Beyazid tram station (2nd stop from Sultanahmet, so if you're in Sultanahmet, it's the same tram) so I took the tram the one going to Zeytinburnu, get off at the 8th station called Topkapi (10th from Sultanahmet), then from Topkappi tram station walk up to the gound level and few steps - you will see it immediately, take the Metro that goes to Mescid-e-Selam and get off at the 3rd station called Edirnekapi. Get out and walk your way to the wall and you'll see what looks like an entrance between walls which is actually a highway/road, just beside one of the wall to your left is a small stairs and go up there and on the first street on your right walk your way down until the end and youll find the Chora Church on your left. Don't worry, all people in that area knows the place, I asked the old man selling bottled water near the walls of Constantine, and there's also a sign. Entry Fee = TL15.

Beautiful mosaics and paintings. Must see!. The Chora Church is a definite must see on a trip to Istanbul. It is out of the way and will likely end up costing a bit when you add up the entrance fee plus taxi fares but it is worth it. We used the Rick Steves' guide to go through the church and it was great. The guide takes you through in a particular order which basically tells the story of the Gospels. Most of the paintings are very well preserved. Photos are hard to take since you can't use a flash so take the time to look at the artwork and enjoy it. Right by the church are some remains of the old city walls. You can climb us to the top for a nice view of the city. If you are lucky, you will coordinate your climg to the top with the call to prayer. It is really neat to hear all the nearby mosques calling at the same time. We payed 15TL each way from Eminonu for a taxi. You could probably walk it though it is a bit far. The Rick Steves guide has a walk that starts from the church but we decided to skip this one.

Beautiful Church, Hard to Find. This was one of the stops on a day long walk. The church is beautiful, but hard to find. I got lost once (or maybe twice) walking the area. Worth the trip if you have an extra day, but wouldnt make my "top of" list.

You have to visit this church.... As a previous traveller said, it is far away, but it sure worths a visit! This church has amazing mosaics (some of them are unique...). You can see Holy Mary as pregnant, Jesus miracles and scenes of Jesus life and many many more...Believe me it is a church you should visit !!

It might be out of the way, but don't miss this. The narthex and side chapel of the former Church of St Saviour in Chora contain extraordinary and beautiful 14th-century mosaics and frescos, far excelling those encountered by the crowds at Aya Sofia. It's very well worth the trek out from the centre to see this. We took the tram to Eminonu, and then caught a bus - the experience is rather chaotic, but all the more fun for that. Allow an hour, or a little more, for the visit, and make sure you equip yourself with a decent guidebook with a key to the iconographic scheme. The Lonely Planet guide is good here (and elsewhere), or for something seriously in-depth, John Freely's 'Strolling in Istanbul' is encyclopaedic. We combined our visit with a meal at Asitane, just next door, and a visit to the land walls and nearby mosques.

Meh.. Are you really into Byzantine frescos? Then you'll love this place. Otherwise, you'll wonder why you traveled out here to drop 15 TL (really? I spent 3TL to get into Didyma...) on a small museum/church surrounded by wildly overpriced restaurants and scarf sellers. This is NOT one of the top attractions of Istanbul, unless you are a Byzantine fresco scholar. It seems like a big attraction for the cruise/tour coach crowd.What IS worthwhile is the walls of Constantinople which are just a few hundred yards uphill of the church. But if you arent going to see the walls, dont make a special trip.

A Byzantine jewel. I'm surprised by some of the lukewarm reviews of this stunning little church. These are some of the best preserved Byzantine frescos in the world and they are fantastic! Small and easy to take in, the only drawback is that its a ways out (Chora meant coutnry - so it was country church out of town. ). The area that it is located in has seen a huge influx of people from the east, so many of the residents are conservative Muslims. We wandered off into the neighborhoods and had some very unpleasant attention (especially my wife, who while modestly dressed wasn't "covered up". You can catch a cab here

A historic gem. Out of the way, but worth it if part of your tour or take a cab. We saw this gem, and though restored from the 12th century, the mosaics here depict the Byzantine glory of past. They may not be as glorious as Ravenna, as one reviewer pointed out, which is where Theodorus ruled Goth from with Byzantine support, before Justinian, but Metochites' creation here is one of the very few gems left, and we must understand that though our guide pointed out that the mosaic quality is not as high as Aya Sofia, it is because it was covered in plaster when converted into a mosque. It now stands beautifully restored, domes in varying numbers of arches, in a unique quincunx church layout. If you are tired of all the mosques, this one reminds you of Istanbul's rich past. Combine this trip with the city walls, and it is so worth it.

A Byzantine treasure thats well worth a vist. Once you get there ( get a good guide book & map ) you will be amazed at the scale of beautyfull mosaics & fescoes that can be seen.The church dates from the 11th century but the present mosaics were designed between 1315-25 when the chuch was remodelled. "in Chora" means " in the country" which implies when the church was first built it was orginally in the country before the city began develop past the old city walls.Mosaics dazzle all around you the beauty is amazing and in great detail & excellent preservation. Although no flash photography is allowed, you can still get some great photos even though its a little dark in places.This has to be the treasure of Istanbul even Haghia Sophia does not have this many mosaics still in situ.Enjoy the vist i certainly did, all for 15 turkish lira ( Sept 2010).

Late Byzantine masterpiece. This church has many more Christian frescos and mosaics than are left in the Hagia Sophia. There are still a few of the earliest frescos left. A beautiful setting, but also rather crowded.

number 3? really?. I had not intended to write a review of this site but when I saw it was rated number 3 in Istanbul (and the top rated ones surprised me too!) I thought I'd throw in my opinion. Other sites in Istanbul are more interesting, more representative of the city and more bang for the buck IMO. But as a discalimer, I have seen alot of mosiacs that were more impressive - such as Ravenna, in Venice and in Rome. If you are in Istanbul for a short time, like two or three days, I would not include this. Actually the "getting there" was more entertainment than the sight - we went by public bus - we were possibly the only non-residents on the bus - very little english spoken but everyone seemed to know where we wanted to go and helped us get off at the correct stop. On the return trip there was a young woman on the bus who wanted to practice her english with us - she invited us to her home! but we figured it was really her cousin's rug shop so we declined.

My Istanbul Highlight. Just impressive.. I understand why some people didn't like this church. It was out of the way....but I think that was part of the beauty of this little gem. If it were located in Sultanhamet, it would've been flooded with crowds! Also, people complain about not knowing what to see and that there were no descriptions. I suggest that before going there to have at least a travel book (I have the Rick Steves Istanbul Guide, which walked me through every mosaic and fresco in the church). Anyway, I took public transport to get here (very easy). The church has several sections, and each area has several mosaics depicting scenes from the life of Christ. Now, I'm not at all religious, but seeing stories from the Bible over head in finely constructed mosaics was nothing short of breathtaking. My book walked me through every scene and it made me appreciate the place even more. There was a section near the entrance that has some impeccably done frescoes from centuries ago. This church is a must-see, and on my next visit to Istanbul, I'm definitely going back here again!

a bit disappointing. It 's a long way to get there with public transport and quite hard to find (2 trams from Sultanahmet and then still a long walk). The mosaïcs were nice, but there was no explanation at all. 15TL was quite expensive for such a small museum. There are more beautiful things to see and do in Istanbul.

surprisingly amazing. it is a beautiful church turned museum at the far west of the city. the best way is to get the tram there and then get a taxi, costed us 7LTR to get there, it is uphill so the taxi is worth it. the mosaic is beautiful and not like any biblical story you usually see in any european church. it is small, and it will only last you 30-60 mins, but it is worth the trip. By the way, the next door got a really good ottoman restaurant. not the cheapest, but make a huge change to all the kebabs you will eat in the old city.

A must visit in Istanbul. If you are only going to spend 15 minutes, don't go. You wouldn't just spend 15 minutes in the Cistine Chaple or the Duomo in Florence, their art and beauty command respect. So too does the Chora. The mosaics and artwork from the last great flurishing of Byzantine church art are stunning. Yes, the church is on the small side, but it makes the artwork all the more accessible. Spend the time with a good guide book or better yet hire a guide to walk you through the biblical scenes depicted. Indeed, I would argue that only in viewing the art of the Chora can you begin to have some idea of just dazzling the Aya Sophia or St. Irene's or St. Surgious and Baccus would have been in their full glory. It is also at the Chora that you can begin to understand the artistic roots that ultimately helped to transformed art during the renaissance. The Chora is a special place, well worth the time and effort to see and understand not only the art that exists there, but how it has been conserved. Additionally, the neighborhood is close (very walkable) to the Tekfur Saraiy -- the remains of part of the Byzantine palace complex of the Blacharnea as well as the impressive Byzantine land walls. Truely one of the most impressive and moving monuments in a city full of impressive monuments.

Astoundingly wonderful. Absolutely worth the effort of Tram, Metro and 2 mile walk....I have never seen such beautiful pictorial mosaics. Chora was absolutely wonderful BUT I went on my own and there were no guides there, and all I had was my guide book for information.When I was there an Art tour arrived and I was so envious of their art historian. I cannot recommend Chora highly enough - but would advise going on a tour.

Beautiful mosaics but quite out of the way and not for everyone.. I sprained my ankle the day before and wanted to rest it, so I took a taxi to Kariye Museum (I paid 50TL from Sultanahmet and back). The mosaics of Jesus Christ and Mother Mary were particularly beautiful and fascinating. However, the church is small in size and you only need about 15 - 20 minutes to view the mosaics. My verdict is, a definite "do" if you're nearby or have seen all the other popular attractions but a "don't" if you haven't seen the main sights, are pressed for time or are not really into mosaics/art!
So sentimental place. I went there twice and really recomend. So emotional church with special mosaics that explains important events of the Holy bible.

Beautiful mosaics. It was smaller than I.... Beautiful mosaics. It was smaller than I expected and a trek to getto as we were directed to the wrong church which was near the bus stop. However it was worth it. Plan a visit for the late afternoon then round off the day with dinner at Asitane restaurant next to the church where you can try fine Ottoman cuisine.

DEVINE!!!!. This was one of the many places recommended to us by our hotel manager in Istanbul. Part museum, part church if you like Byzantine art there is no better place in than the Chora Church. We had already visited the ST Sophia but this church has it beat hands down in terms of mosaics and frescoes. If you plan visiting however I'd recommend taking a guide, guide book so you know what you're looking at.

Not a "must see" for everyone. If you like religous art then this is worth a visit- the mosaics are beautiful, but I have to admit I was fairly disappointed. I certainly wouldn't say it was a definite must see for a visit to Istanbul. To be honest I can't understand why it's so highly recommended. In essence it was a lovely old stone church (smaller than I was expecting) with mosaics depicting stories from the life of Jesus. It's now a museum so didn't really have much of an "atmosphere" for me. Also, it was quite complicated to get to and admission was 15 TL.
Stunning. As many others have said in their reviews, this museum/church has some of the most wonderful Byzantine mosaics in the world. It's a must see.

unbelievably beautiful. The transportation to this Church/Museum is a bit tricky, but no matter what you do, no matter how much time you have in Istanbul, you MUST visit it. In size, the building is not comparable to Saint Sophie, but the mosaics in Chora will fascinate you more than what Saint Sophie will. Arriving on a budget: From Taksim Square, there is a bus which will pass by the Museum. The best is to ask the staff at the square which bus line it is. Ask for "Kariye Muzesi" and the bus driver will also know where to drop you off. After you get off, it is a 10-15 min walk --> follow the signs.After visit, hop on a taxi and go to EYUP, from where you can take a lift to Pierre Loti cafe overseeing the Golden Horn. At this cafe, a tea + simit + creamy cheese is a feast...

Outstanding Byzantine Art. This small 11th century church in the Fener neighborhood is *the* place to go to if you want to see outstanding Byzantine art. It's worth the time it takes to get there to see the art. The mosaics in the narthex are especially dramatic. If you don't know anything about Christianity, or are rusty on the Bible, either make sure you have a good guidebook which tells you what you are seeing (Lonely Planet Istanbul is especially good for this), or buy a book at the little souvenir stand near the entry of the church. I bought the one called "Hagia Sophia and Chora," and it was very useful. Again, this is an absolute must-see in Istanbul. It's worth the time it takes to get there.

Breathtaking. Pictures can never do Mosaics justice. You have to see it to understand how intricately this former church was decorated. The ride to Chora Church from the Sultanahmet area is best done in a cab. I did Rick Steves' Chora Church Tour combines with the Byzantine Walls and it was quite an experience. HIGHLY RECOMMENDED!!!

A must visit attraction. One of the highlights of my Istanbul stay. The church is a bit out of the way, but it is worth the visit. The church itself is fairly small but is packed with interesting things to see. If you are not religious, I would recommend a good guidebook or a tour so you understand what you are seeing.

Heaven for Byzantine art lovers. The church of Our Saviour in Chora is a gem: the mosaics are wonderful, as works of later Byzantine art, besides being theologically interesting (bring a good guide book: the Blue Guide has several pages on this church alone). The same goes for the frescoes: part of the church has frescoes, no mosaics. The fresco of Christ and the Harrowing of Hell is an all-time masterpiece by an anonymous genius. I was dumbfounded in front of it. You have to be something of a Byzantine art afficionado, or know something about it at least. But then it is VERY rewarding. There is nothing as good as this in Greece.

breathtaking mosaics. T.he architecture is impressive outside but the mosaics inside are just breathtaking. The 10turkish lira guidebook is very helpful because it gives a plan to follow as the mosaics are not in an obvious biblical order. The cats in the garden are more numerous than anywhere else.A taxi is a good idea because its a bit difficult to find. If you get a taxi back make sure that the meter is on. It's the only place where a high fixed price was offered to me first.

Lovely, but a little out of the way. The church is quite lovely, with a sweet but small garden, and several cafes across the street, but otherwise hidden and surrounded by working class apartment buildings. It's like a little spot of beauty hidden away. Of course the mosaics are wonderful, although not all of them are restored. The main area is empty and haunting, and if you can get in there when there isn't a tour, and you can experience the space alone, it's pretty amazing. When I was there, there were 4 large tour groups there, which really overwhelmed the space. I waited until it thinned out and then really had a chance to look around. It is not large, but it is worth seeing. The mosaics show scenes from the life of Mary, and it would probably be very interesting to read about the specific scenes before you visit there.

If you love mosaics - go here. If you love mosaics go here .... and if you don't, you might give it a miss.I feel I might be a bit out of step with the other rave reviews in this section, but the location away from the other sites, and the relative cost ,15TL, (10US$) leads me to believe that if you have limited time or budget, there are other things in Istanbul more worth seeing.The mosaics are excellent and tell stories of the life of the Virgin and the infancy of Christ, anyone who goes specifically to see the mosaics will not be disappointed. The mosaics here are better than those in Ayasofya.The building itself is not achitecturally beautiful and is tucked away on a side street. I went on bus 28 and found it difficult to locate without asking directions and a reasonable amount of walking. If you were visiting as part of a tour then you might feel more positive about the experience.

Breathtaking Byzantine Mosics. A gem of a place to visit, the Chora Church is jam-packed with gorgeous mosaics of which some are very unusual. One of the transcepts is entirely devoted to the Virgin Mary with unusual scenes of her life. While there are amazing mosaics in the Hagia Sophia, the Chora Church is very small and intimate. From its simple exterior, one would never guess the treasures inside. I highly recommend it.

beautiful frescos and mosaics. Hagia Sophia will wet your appetite for mosaics, but Kariye will satisfy your hunger. How's that for a cheesy description? Seriously, this is a fabulous church and reminded me of walking into Florentine churches and being blown away by the frescoes.

The mosaics are incredible!. It was well worth a long cab ride to go to the Chora Church. The mosaics are a must see if you go to Istanbul. The detail and the colors cannot be described. I'm not in to churches but I am so glad I went to see this one. the building is now a museum and each mosaic is better than the one before. Wow!

Amazing, intelligent, informative guide and beautiful places. I had a wonderful time on the tour and our guide, Abdurrahman Yaramis from Backpackers Travel was more than we could have ever asked for- he is very intelligent, charming, professional, informative, and has very good English. The tour was around the old city/Sultanahmet in Istanbul and we saw 7 sites all together; sites more difficult to get to than the Aya Sofia and the Blue Mosque. I would recommend this tour highly to anyone. All of the places we visited were very worth it and showed you a lot about the city and history. The transportation was very good as well- I commend the very good driving in such difficult streets in the old city! They even brought us peach juice and a sweet bread for breakfast! Very good value for the price of 15 euro (about $20) for hotel pick-up in Sultanahmet at 9:00 am until 1:00 pm. Drop off at the Spice bazaar or back at hotel.

Amazing Mosaics and Frescoes - a must see!. The Chora Church/Kariye Muzesi is located along the Theodosian Walls, separated from the remainder of the tourist destinations in Istanbul. We took a bus (90 I believe) from Eminonu towards Edirnekapi. The stop for the Chora Church is right after the soccer stadium on the right hand side of the bus, about 10 blocks or so past the Fatih Camii.Entry was about 15 TRY, but it is worth it!. The church itself dates to 1077 (give or take) and the mosiacs inside date to 1315-21. Enter into the Paracclesion, and turn to the right. Look up, and you are underneath a rib dome depicting the Virgin and Child and Attendant Angels. Continue in the Paracclesion and two outstanding frescoes are visible: The Last Judgement and Anastasis or The Resurrection.The Interior Narthex is adorned with the Geneology of Christ inside one rib dome and the Ancestors of the Virgin Mary in the northern rib dome. Large mosaics of St. Peter and St. Paul flank the entrance into the Inner Nave and Apse. The Inner Nave and Apse are marble, and a mihrab is almost hidden with the Apse. Any frescoes in the dome have been whitewashed over - in comparison to the remainder of teh church, the Inner Nave and Apse seem barren. Only three mosaics are here, including the Dormition of the Virgin Mary over the exit to the Inner Narthex.The Exterior Narthex contains more mosaics, including The Journey to Bethlehem, Enrollment for Taxation, Nativity, and the Temptation of Christ.Simply put, the works within the Chora Church are remarkable and one of the highlights of our trip to Istanbul. I could easily have spent half a day inside the museum staring at the mosaics and remembering stories from the Bible. If/when we go back to Istanbul, this will be visited again.If you have a DSLR here are some recommendations: Wide angle (12-24mm), Medium fast telephoto (50-150mm F2.8), Shake reduction/image stabilization, monopod. No flash photography!Here is my flickr site: http://www.flickr.com/photos/dhoopercu/sets/72157617165541075/

A Must See--stunning mosaics, some from apocryphal gospel. The mosaics are gorgeous and previous reviews have written a bit about the history. I would like to second that this is a must visit for anybody visiting Istanbul. It is a bit off the beaten track, but it's really not too far. If you're up for walking, I wandered over here from the Blue Mosque, stopping at several mosques along the way, and it was quite lovely (took less than 3 hours at a leisurely, stopping-often pace).The inner narthex mosaics are of Mary's life from an apocryphal gospel, which I found to be quite interesting. While it's smaller, I found this church to be as interesting as the Haghia Sophia in many ways--you won't regret taking the time to see it.

Awesome Mosaics and Murals!. The Chora Church is also known as the Kariye Museum. Originally built in the 4th Century it has gone through many changes. The current building was built in the 11th Century. It has been used as a Church, a Mosque and a museum. The Byzantine mosaics and murals are awesome! The murals date from around 1320 that should not be missed. Although there is not much near the museum it was worth the trip for us.

A Must See!!. I am surprised that this is not ranked higher than 12th in the Places to See in Istanbul. I can only guess that this is because not enought people know about it. We took my Turkish friend who was showing us around Istanbul during our stay to this place, and she ahd not even heard about it before!This church is absolutely amazing! We took a bus to get here, sorry I do not remember exactly which one. Upon exiting the bus, we asked directions from a nice man who led us almost the enitre way there. It is about a 20 minute ride from the Beyazit area, and it is interesting to see life farther out in the city.It is a beautiful Byzantine church. I love the Byzantine architecture! The mosiacs inside are well-preserved and beautiful. Because of the smaller size of the church, you are also much closer to the mosiacs and can appreciate them more than in Hagia Sophia. The way some of the mosiacs have come off, with the sketches and drawings underneath also offers an intersting perspective into how the mosacis were made.The entire museum is a gem and should be on anyone's must see list in Istanbul!

If you do 1 thing in Istanbul this SHOULD BE IT. This museum seems to have different names in different guidebooks, and my friend accidently referred to it as the Charo Museum (which it is not), but it is an absolute must. We took a taxi from the Sultanahmet to the museum and then grabbed another taxi which was just hovering around the museum to get back. The mosaics in this church are incrediblly detailed, moving, dramatic and poetic. Bring a zoom lens for your camera to be able to see into the rafters. You will crane your neck for a while looking up but really worth it. There is nothing else surrounding this museum really. You can wander a little ways away to see some of the ancient wall which circled the city. Unfortunately when we were there it was under restoration and you couldn't get close. Lunch at the Asitane restaurant at the hotel next door to the museum is a must. They have a very unusual menu and you will enjoy the outdoor garden and unusl offerings.

A beautiful experience. I love this place! I found the mosaics better and more beautiful than Hagia Sophia.The mosaics follow depict several gospel stories and it was great fun trying to identify these stories and interpret the pictures.This website provides a list of the different mosaics. http://www.enjoyturkey.com/info/sights/chora.htmThe church should be open from 9 a.m to 4:30 p.m except Wed.
